webTitle: Kapil bows out with a blast

fields.headline: Kapil bows out with a blast
fields.trailText: Kapil Dev, one of the giants of Indian cricket, says he has walked away from a game that has been "murdered".
fields.body:
Kapil Dev, one of the giants of Indian cricket, says he has walked away from a game that has been "murdered". The man who led his country to their triumph in the 1983 World Cup, and was national coach until he resigned on Tuesday after being questioned over alleged match-fixing, has poured scorn on the Board of Control for Cricket in India.

In his resignation letter Kapil, the former world record holder for Test wickets and the man who has sent down more deliveries in Tests than any other, said he was "being put down on every occasion" by his employers.

"I have taken what came to me," he said in an emotional letter to the BCCI president A C Muttiah, "but I would request the board to be kinder to the next coach and give him his due respect if they have the welfare of the game at heart.

"This is not a battle of flexing our muscles. The game which has been murdered has to be slowly brought back to life."

Kapil has been under investigation by the Indian Central Bureau of Investigation in connection with the match-fixing scandal that has blighted world cricket.

Last May he was reduced to uncontrollable weeping during a television interview when answering allegations of impropriety made by another former India all-rounder, Manoj Prabhakar.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Cardiff cricket fans can rarely have seen anything quite like it. A ding-dong day in which 325 runs were scored, 10 wickets fell and two teams with plenty to gain tussled for ascendancy. Where are the critics of the two-divisional championship, with apologies to Brian Close, now?
fields.body:
Cardiff cricket fans can rarely have seen anything quite like it. A ding-dong day in which 325 runs were scored, 10 wickets fell and two teams with plenty to gain tussled for ascendancy. Where are the critics of the two-divisional championship, with apologies to Brian Close, now?

Glamorgan, fighting for promotion, ended the first day with a slight edge over Middlesex, battling to avoid their first wooden spoon. The difference between the sides was Mike Powell - yet another precocious young English (OK, British) opener - whose 114 rescued the hosts from 65 for three.

Worcestershire's promotion hopes took a dive in the final session against a second-string Northamptonshire. Darren Cousins and Paul Taylor had the hosts tottering at 50 for five at stumps, after an unbeaten 96 by the keeper Toby Bailey - playing only his fourth first-class match and showing few fears of Glenn McGrath's huffing and puffing - had earlier lifted Northants from 96 for seven to 260 all out.

Shane Warne, meanwhile, gave Hampshire fans something to remember him by, taking five for 92 and smashing an unbeaten 48 against Yorkshire . But it was all too late for the south coast big spenders as Kent sealed their relegation fate by picking up a single batting point against Leicestershire .

Alistair Campbell hit his first fifty in 28 innings, a snail-like 88, as Zimbabwe crawled to 350 against New Zealand at Bulawayo.

webTitle: Cricket: Unstoppable Surrey secure place in history

fields.headline: Unstoppable Surrey secure place in history
fields.standfirst:
Hollioake's men start the new era as they ended the old one
Lancashire 324
Surrey 28-2
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText:
Lancashire 324
Surrey 28-2
fields.body:
Surrey last night celebrated their second consecutive championship, and the championship's inaugural First Division title, by watching Manchester United play Anderlecht. That seemed appropriate, because comparisons between the brown hats and the Red Devils are increasingly hard to resist.

After a long, barren spell of underachievement - 28 years without a title, as opposed to United's 26 - they are now dominating the county game.

"We're a quality squad, no two ways about it," said Surrey's manager Keith Medlycott, after they had won the single point needed at the start of play by picking up a third Lancashire wicket shortly after lunch. "We can pick from 18 or 20 players who can all come into first-class cricket and produce match-winning performances. Over the last few years sides haven't wanted to play us. People are probably fearful."

Swap first-class cricket for first-team football, and Medders might have been Fergie.

But that is where the comparison ends. Medlycott has kept a remarkably low profile despite presiding over a team who, with the Second Division of the National League already wrapped up, have won three trophies in as many years. A knighthood, at this stage, remains some way off.

In cricketing tradition Adam Hollioake, the captain, is the public face and voice of this Surrey team. But he had other things on his mind while Medlycott was holding court in the Old Trafford library, typically leading from the front as the opposing skipper, Warren Hegg, rallied Lancashire.

They had slipped to 154 for seven - with Neil Fairbrother, Chris Schofield and Glen Chapple all deceived by Saqlain Mushtaq - before Hegg and Gary Keedy put on 107 for the eighth wicket. Surrey were starting to look decidedly ragged, spurning four catches and a stumping, before Hollioake grabbed the ball himself and had Keedy caught at gully in the last over before tea.

"It's not been one of our best performances today," admitted Medlycott, putting it down to the inevitable let-down once the title was sealed. "You could see how much it meant to them by how drained they are."

Surrey had made the perfect start, with Martin Bicknell trapping Mike Atherton leg-before in his second over. They then received a substantial helping hand from Sourav Ganguly for their second wicket, as India's captain left Mark Chilton stranded by refusing to respond to his call.

If poor running is one reason why Ganguly will not be missed at Old Trafford next year, another is his failure to score a championship century. His penultimate attempt ended on 54 when he was brilliantly caught by Hollioake at third slip off Alex Tudor, and that was the wicket which gave Surrey what they came for. It prompted a team huddle which included the 12th man Ben Hollioake - whom Medlycott hopes to keep at the Oval despite suggestions he should move on.

Tudor, bowling an excellent spell, had Fairbrother missed twice in the slips from consecutive balls and then sent Graham Lloyd's middle stump cartwheeling. But Hegg kept Lancashire on course to finish second for the third year in a row, helped by Keedy and then Mike Smethurst in a ninth-wicket stand of 54.

Hegg was left seven short of his second ton in five days when Peter Martin holed out, but Martin made amends by trapping Mark Butcher lbw in the first over of Surrey's reply. Chapple then pinned Nadeem Shahid and struck the elder Hollioake square in the box. The Surrey captain may have been the first man to accept the championship trophy with a voice an octave higher than it had been at the start of the day.

fields.headline: Glorsters hit rich seam
fields.standfirst:
Nottinghamshire 216
Gloucestershire 13-0
County Championship Second Division points table
fields.trailText:
Nottinghamshire 216
Gloucestershire 13-0
fields.body:
Talk about profits in search of honour. Should victory here secure promotion for the Glorious Glorsters, the triple one-day champions will have fulfilled every fantasy promised by their wildest daydreams.

Nevertheless, yesterday morning's Bristol Evening Post, in its infinite wisdom, devoted as much space to this match as the Catholic Herald would to the chief rabbi's grandson's barmitzvah.

Not that the hosts were alone in their ambition. Nottinghamshire arrived four points ahead in the thick of a pack of six clubs vying for two promotion places, the sort of climax envisaged when a two-tiered championship was first mooted. Backs should be patted and glasses raised.

By stumps, courtesy of fine seamwork from Mark Alleyne, Mike Smith and Jon Lewis, whose first-class bag of 69 trails only Glenn McGrath, that advantage had withered to one point. Even so, given that the ball swung like Benny Goodman on ecstasy, the visitors' total may not prove as modest as it appears.

After Jason Gallian had opted to bat, Ian Harvey started the rot by yorking Darren Bicknell and four men fell before lunch. Requiring 25 runs for his 1,000, Usman Afzaal seemed too cautious and soon edged Ben Gannon to slip and Guy Welton eked out 23 in 34 overs before Alleyne bowled him through a hitherto imperceptible gate.

Gallian himself was livid, less with a loose shot off Lewis than the constant bustle of traffic behind the bowler's arm. Gesticulating angrily as he strode off, he fumed at length; Lewis merely conveyed his grateful thanks to the unwitting aide de camp.

Chris Read was bowled off his pads by Smith and, when Paul Johnson groped at Lewis's outswinger, six were down with three figures barely in the bank. Stability of sorts now arrived in the form of Paul Franks and Mark Bowen, the latter making his farewell before taking up a full-time job at Sellafield, arguably the oddest career switch since Peter Green quit Fleetwood Mac to become a gravedigger.

Resisting the primeval urge to thrash anything round and red, Franks directed a stand of 70 before Alleyne had both partners snared in the gully in successive overs. Johnson, as he looked on from the boundary edge, insisted there should be more points available for a win, while noting that, since they have won two to Gloucestershire's five, this would have scuppered his side's chances. Bias 0 Common sense 1.

webTitle: Cricket: Essex lose their way in Wagh zone

fields.headline: Essex lose their way in Wagh zone
fields.standfirst:
Warwickshire 348-5 v Essex
County Championship Second Division points table
fields.trailText: Warwickshire 348-5 v Essex
fields.body:
Raman Subba Row, the former England batsman, has had a good summer. His first county, Surrey, are county champions and his second, Northamptonshire, have walked away with the second division.

He enjoyed more good fortune yesterday. He came to New Writtle Street in his role as one of the England and Wales Cricket Board's dozen pitch inspectors and had a doddle of a day. There was nothing here to concern him.

Essex, who stand third in the Second Division and need 17 points from this final game to be sure of promotion, were perverse in their actions, rolling a flat pitch before deciding to put Warwickshire in.

They were beguiled by the possibility of early movement and their judgment was not entirely misplaced. There was both swing and a little deviation off the seam early on but so badly did Essex bowl that they allowed the Warwickshire openers Mark Wagh and Michael Powell to put on 230 in no time at all.

Warwickshire, who are also one of the six teams who could join Northants in the First Division next season, had 112 on the board at lunch and were 259 for one at tea.

It is difficult to recover from such situations but Peter Such, foolishly overlooked early in the season, was once again their best bowler, examining each batsman with forensic care before taking three wickets.

At the close, three overs early because of bad light, Warwickshire were 348 for five. They will almost certainly take a maximum five batting points today.

Both Powell (106) and Wagh (137) made centuries but the day belonged to the latter. He has come into the side in place of the injured Nick Knight and scored 130 against Worcestershire a fortnight ago.

After yesterday's hundred, his best in the championship, he was awarded his county cap, which should be enough to placate him after asking for a move earlier in the week.

The 23-year-old Wagh, who had a disappointing summer last year and has had little opportunity this season, over came not only the Essex bowlers but an attack of cramp. He reached his century when he pulled Ricky Anderson for four. He had been twice missed at second slip, on 18 and 48.

There were 21 other fours, many driven with some style. There were also two sixes, both hit off Such in the space of three deliveries, and both driven over wide mid-on in the direction of the Tom Pearce Stand. He faced 233 balls.

Powell, who struck 17 fours, was the first to go when he was run out by Ronnie Irani's fine throw from mid-on. Then, at 306, Dominic Ostler was beaten by Such's turn and Essex took their first bowling point at 5.10, when Wagh was caught off the glove by Paul Prichard at first slip.

Shortly before the close David Hemp was caught behind off Anderson and Anurag Singh was caught and bowled by Such.

fields.headline: Britten Sinfonia/James MacMillan
fields.standfirst:
Cambridge Corn Exchange
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Cambridge Corn Exchange
Rating: **
fields.body:
James MacMillan's Parthenogenesis, a piece for actors, singers and instrumentalists, is based on the story of a young woman in Germany in the second world war who apparently gave birth to her own twin. It was supposed that the shock of a bombing raid made her cells spontaneously reproduce, resulting in a fatherless birth: parthenogenesis.

Collaborating with librettist/poet Michael Symmons Roberts, and Rowan Williams, Archbishop of Wales (Cambridge's Theology Through the Arts project sponsored it), MacMillan uses the story to investigate the ethical questions surrounding human cloning.

Presented as a dark annunciation, Parthenogenesis has Christopher Purves as Bruno, a "falling angel", whose intense relationship with Lisa Milne's Kristel culminates in his curse: "A girl will come to you / She will have no father." The progeny of this non-union, Anna, played by actress Anastasia Hille, comments on the complexities of her existence in spoken interludes between each scene, to an electro-acoustic accompaniment of earth-shaking rumbles.

The problems begin with the libretto. Just as in his words for MacMillan's song cycle Raising Sparks - performed by the Britten Sinfonia in the first half of their concert - Roberts's text is redolently symbolic. But in the context of a dramatic work, the poetry is leaden and unwieldy. His libretto has only one register - thinly veiled spiritual imagery - so the characters are reduced to a single, static dimension.

These difficulties are compounded by MacMillan's music. As in Raising Sparks, he is scrupulously faithful to Roberts's text in finding musical analogies for the libretto's fecund symbolism. In Raising Sparks, the result is an overblown idiom that affects the gestures of high drama - operatic melismas and melodic lines - in response to the imagery, but does not support them with an integrated musical language. Similarly, in Parthenogenesis, MacMillan finds effective depictions of musical darkness and light: screeching dissonance and hyperbolic, high-register vocal writing, as opposed to limpid, chorale-like consonance and ingratiating vocal lines. But, having set up these dramatic extremes, he uses them whenever the text seems to demand it, instead of creating a musical structure that can sustain dramatic development. All this makes Parthenogenesis a heavy-handed treatment of the issues surrounding human cloning. Despite committed performances, it lacks a coherent musical, dramatic or intellectual purpose.

Parthenogenesis will be broadcast on Radio 3 on September 20.

webTitle: Business: Fear of dot.coms swept away

fields.headline: Fear of dot.coms swept away
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Fears of a dot.com revolution sweeping away "bricks and mortar" businesses have all but disappeared and old economy multinational businesses are taking a more cautious approach to e-business, according to a firm of management consultants that rebranded yesterday as an e-consultancy.
fields.body:
Fears of a dot.com revolution sweeping away "bricks and mortar" businesses have all but disappeared and old economy multinational businesses are taking a more cautious approach to e-business, according to a firm of management consultants that rebranded yesterday as an e-consultancy.

A string of high-profile failures among internet-only businesses has convinced the chief executives of old economy companies that the web will remain just one of many routes to customers, said the management and technology consultants Headstrong, formerly known as James Martin & Co.

James Martin, the author of several bestselling management books, came to prominence in the 1970s and founded his eponymous company in 1981. Chief executive Patrick Litre said yesterday that the company had been rebranded following a decision to supply consultancy services exclusively to companies that want to develop a digital strategy, which he said went further than simply adding a web presence to their business.

"Large companies are being more deliberate when it comes to their spending and business strategies," he said. "They are not rushing any more to build websites in a haphazard manner. They are not driven by the fear of dot.coms wiping them out."

Mr Litre said Headstrong would continue to grow strongly and could float at some time in the next three years.

A string of high-profile failures among internet-only businesses has convinced the chief executives of old economy companies that the web will remain just one of many routes to customers, said the management and technology consultants Headstrong, formerly known as James Martin & Co. James Martin, the author of several bestselling management books, came to prominence in the 1970s and founded his eponymous company in 1981. Chief executive Patrick Litre said yesterday that the company had been rebranded following a decision to supply consultancy services exclusively to companies that want to develop a digital strategy, which he said went further than simply adding a web presence to their business. "Large companies are being more deliberate when it comes to their spending and business strategies," he said. "They are not rushing any more to build websites in a haphazard manner. webTitle: M&S in bid fever as Debenhams' chief quits

fields.headline: M&S in bid fever as Debenhams' chief quits
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's City advisers moved to a heightened state of bid alert yesterday as a fresh wave of takeover speculation swept across the London market, pushing shares in the ailing high street retailer almost 10% higher.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's City advisers moved to a heightened state of bid alert yesterday as a fresh wave of takeover speculation swept across the London market, pushing shares in the ailing high street retailer almost 10% higher.

The new rumours were prompted by the surprise departure from Debenhams of Terry Green, the highly respected chief executive who has been widely tipped as a potential new boss for M&S. Marks, which admits it intends to strengthen its management team, insisted it had not approached Mr Green, but this failed to dampen speculation about its future.

Last February entrepreneur Philip Green tried to mount a bid for M&S amid rumours that he had backing from Mr Green and Allan Leighton, the chief executive of Asda, who resigned from its parent Wal-Mart last week.

Mr Leighton's unexpected decision to leave Asda reawakened speculation about his potential interest in M&S although he tried to quash talk that he been approached directly about a role.

The resignation of Mr Green from Debenhams was such a surprise to the market that shares in Debenhams fell sharply, by more than 8%, to 182.5p. His replacement was named as Debenhams insider Belinda Earl, who previously held the role of trading director.

The departure had the opposite effect on M&S shares which ended the day 17p higher at 228p in trading five times larger than normal.

This latest wave of takeover speculation comes as M&S continues to reinvent itself. It recently announced that it would open new discount "outlet" stores in out-of-town shopping centres and launched a multi-million advertising campaign featuring a nude woman. The group is also reformatting its stores and in troducing a new designer range of clothes. None of these moves, implemented by new chairman Luc Vandevelde, has quashed suggestions that it could yet receive a hostile takeover bid.

Debenhams would only say last night that its former chief executive was to "pursue a new business opportunity". Some industry sources suggested that this could be outside retailing altogether. Ms Earl, meanwhile, plans a charm offensive in the City.

webTitle: Jobs threat as Chase devours JP Morgan

fields.headline: Jobs threat as Chase devours JP Morgan
fields.standfirst: $38.5bn merger Banks coy about casualties
fields.trailText: Fears of thousands of financial job losses were raised yesterday after two of the biggest firms on Wall Street confirmed their $38.5bn (£23bn) merger.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in New York and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
Fears of thousands of financial job losses were raised yesterday after two of the biggest firms on Wall Street confirmed their $38.5bn (£23bn) merger.

Chase Manhattan, fresh from its takeover of Britain's Robert Fleming, is buying JP Morgan to create one of Wall Street's biggest firms. The newly combined bank, to be called JP Morgan Chase, expects to save $1.5bn (£1bn) from cost-cutting measures as a result of the deal.

Both banks were coy about expected job cuts from the combination of Chase, which employs almost 75,000 people around the world, and JP Morgan's staff of about 16,000.

In London JP Morgan employs 3,500 people while Chase has 8,500 staff.

"There will be some cost savings but this is a revenue growth story," said Bill Harrison, the chairman and chief executive of Chase. He added that Chase's experience of mergers suggested that about a third would come from job cuts, a third from merging head offices and a third from technology improvements.

Sources close to JP Morgan in London said management would move quickly to calm nerves over job fears. They said most of the cuts were likely to be in the US, but that the City of London would not go unscathed.

But unlike other newly merged firms Chase does not plan to set aside hundreds of millions of pounds to hold onto key staff.

Shares in Chase fell 11% on the news to less than $50 - valuing the deal at $34.4bn. Shares in JP Morgan also eased, after rising more than 50% since April on the back of takeover speculation.

The move surprised analysts and recruiters yesterday. One Wall Street headhunter said: "It sounds to me like an open door policy to people who want to go."

Brian Sullivan, head of the financial services unit for Heidrick and Struggles, the Wall Street headhunting firm, said that about 20% of the combined firm's fixed income traders could be cut because of overlap.

The all-share takeover brings together two operations that trace their roots to America's greatest financiers, John Pierpont Morgan and David Rockefeller.

The deal unites JP Morgan's global investment banking and asset management businesses with the commercial banking operations of Chase.

It is also expected to exacer bate the turmoil in an industry already shaken by a wave of cross-border mergers.

Analysts criticised Chase for paying too much for one of the last remaining independent investment banks.

One analyst said: "Strategically, there are a lot of merits to the transaction but at the end of the day the financial implications are negative."

Another said: "They paid too much. It's going to mean that they have got to cut a lot of heads."

Chase executives will dominate the 13-strong executive management committee. Sandy Warner, JP Morgan's chief executive, will become chairman of the business and co-chairman of the committee. Mr Harrison, who will continue as chief executive of the merged company, said that the top 40-50 jobs had all been decided.

Neal Garonzik, the head of Chase's asset management business, is the most senior casualty of the deal. His counterpart at JP Morgan, Ramon de Oliveira, will oversee the bank's asset management operations, which will manage more than $720bn.

Of the few remaining independent banks on Wall Street, Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns are felt to be the most likely to be taken over. Bankers said yesterday that a European bank was the most likely to pounce on Lehman because of its attractive US fixed-income business.

fields.headline: Moribund rehash
fields.standfirst:
Tosca
Royal Opera House, London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
Tosca
Royal Opera House, London
Rating: *
fields.body:
Another season, another Tosca, and there cannot have been many revivals of the Royal Opera's production, now 36 years old, that have been so lacking in a sense of occasion as this. Since it was first staged by Franco Zeffirelli, with a cast including Maria Callas and Tito Gobbi, this studiously realistic show has passed through many directorial hands. The latest incarnation is based on John Cox's makeover, now a decade old itself. Jeremy Sutcliffe is credited with the moribund rehash this time. However the rehearsal period was spent, it was certainly not devoted to making the piece into a credible piece of theatre.

On Monday the problems began in the first seconds of the work. The three massive chords with which Puccini launches this highly coloured tragedy were flaccid, and Carlo Rizzi went on to conduct the rest of the score as if this were no more than a run-through, consistently failing to rise to the precisely plotted climactic moments. As we know from his conducting at Welsh National Opera, he can do far better than this, but then theoretically so could almost everyone involved here.

Roberto Alagna was singing his first Cavaradossi, but his effortful, often coarse-grained tone suggested that it is not a role for which nature intended him. Catherine Malfitano was Tosca. She is usually an involving actor, but here her gestures were just histrionic, her singing uncertain. Anthony Michaels-Moore's Scarpia looked more like a Regency fop than the tyrant who terrorised Rome. A good singer, he simply lacks the dark tone and the vocal authority to make anything of the character. But then there were no flesh-and-blood characters here.

A weekday seat in the stalls for this complacently prepared show will set you back at least £115. If a company that aspires to being regarded as an international opera house cannot launch a new season - its first full one, let's not forget, in the refurbished theatre - with more commitment and thoroughness it does not deserve to be taken seriously.

The Royal Opera is managing to put on only four new productions between now and next June. That is feeble enough, but if it can't prepare its revivals better than this, perhaps it should regard itself as just a facility for corporate hospitality and let anyone actually interested in opera go elsewhere.

In reperatory. Box office: 020 7304 4000.

fields.headline: 20-year unemployment low
fields.trailText: New figures showing unemployment at a 20-year low and an easing in wage inflation were seized upon by ministers last night desperate to switch attention from the mounting crisis over fuel and the debacle of the millennium dome.
fields.body:
New figures showing unemployment at a 20-year low and an easing in wage inflation were seized upon by ministers last night desperate to switch attention from the mounting crisis over fuel and the debacle of the millennium dome.

In a double piece of good economic news, the office for national statistics announced that unemployment had fallen to a 20-year low while tight pay deals are keeping wage inflation firmly under control.

The number of people out of work and claiming benefit last month fell by 18,000 to stand at 1,051,300, while the proportion of the workforce claiming benefit has fallen to 3.6%, its lowest since October 1975.

Employment minister Tessa Jowell hailed the figures as adding to the government's "sustained record of achievement" while the TUC general secretary John Monks said the figures were "excellent news" and showed that full employment was now attainable.

The claimant count has fallen by an average of nearly 20,000 a month since June, according to the ONS, raising hopes among Labour strate gists that it will fall below the key 1m level by Christmas.

On the government's preferred measure on unemployment, based on the labour force survey, the number of people looking for work has also declined. The internationally comparable rate of unemployment fell to 5.3% in the three months to July, from the 5.7% of the previous three months.

The tightening labour market does not appear to be sparking wage inflation. The ONS said average earnings increased by 3.9% in the year to July, a fall from the 4.1% rate recorded the previous month. The last time earnings were rising this slowly was August 1996 when the annual rate was 3.7%.

Economists said the subdued earnings figures strengthened the chances that interest rates would be kept on hold.

fields.headline: Gallic to a turn
fields.standfirst:
Conversations After a Burial
Almeida, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Conversations After a Burial
Almeida, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
John Osborne once described a play as "impossibly French". I'd call Yasmina Reza's piece, first seen in Paris in 1987, as exquisitely Gallic. It is exactly like one of those delicate Eric Rohmer movies in which little happens on the surface but where by the end a whole set of relationships has been exposed and subtly changed.

The title is exactly right: six people gather in the Loire countryside for a family funeral. Three of them are siblings and it becomes clear that there is a dark rivalry between Alex, an agitated literary critic, and the older Nathan who is a Nanterre lawyer. In part it stems from the enigmatic Elisa who was Alex's mistress and now loves Nathan: much of the tension stems from whether Elisa, whose car has broken down, will stay the night and in which bed. Watching helplessly are Edith, sister to the fractious brothers, their ageing uncle and his nervously new wife.

Death, said Hazlitt, cancels everything but truth; and part of Reza's point is that it forces antique grudges, failures and longings into the open. Above all, you sense the heavy hand of the dead father on his three unmarried, middle-aged children. The neurasthenic Alex was expected to be a writer but settled for the quieter pastures of criticism. Nathan was the precociously brilliant older brother who lapsed into the law. Even Edith, who has a transient lover, sees herself as "a dried-up old apple." While parents are alive, suggests Reza, we nurse our disappointments: once they are dead our alibis are gone.

It may not display Reza's cutting edge. But it is poignant, graceful, wise: one notices the quiet skill with which Reza implies the marriage of the uncle, Pierre, is built on shifting sands. And Christopher Hampton's translation highlights the play's self-consciously literary quality: at one point the marooned Elisa remarks that her enforced return is like something out of a novel and when Pierre refers to Alex's "rattlesnake compliments" one is clearly meant to relish the choice phrase.

Howard Davies's production, with an autumnal set by Rob Howell, is acted with finesse. The delicious Amanda Root is not my idea of a fading spinster, but Paul Higgins as the Hamletesque Alex and Matthew Marsh as the assured Nathan spar convincingly, Clare Holman is suitably mysterious as Elisa, and it is luxury casting to have David Calder as the Baudelaire-quoting uncle and Claire Bloom radiating stylish insecurity as his wife. All lend Reza's elegant text an elegiac Chekhovian sadness.

Until October 21. Box office: 020-7359 4404.

webTitle: Bogus caller demands: Show Me The Money

fields.headline: Bogus caller demands: Show Me The Money
fields.standfirst: A group of internet bulletin board tipsters have boasted they knew which stock would be recommended by Channel 4's Show Me The Money
fields.trailText: A group of internet bulletin board tipsters are believed to be at the centre of a stock exchange investigation after boasting online that they knew which stock would be recommended by Channel 4's Show Me The Money the next day.
fields.body:
A group of internet bulletin board tipsters are believed to be at the centre of a stock exchange investigation after boasting online that they knew which stock would be recommended by Channel 4's Show Me The Money the next day.

One poster, who appears under the cyberspace name of Wideeye, posted the message: "I fancy them to tip Screen and for it to rise by about 20% by 12.55pm. Just one of my hunches of course!!!!???"

The hunch, though, could prove a little too well informed. Suspicions were aroused after it emerged that Sun business editor Ian King, who had been planning to tip shares when he appeared as a guest on the show yesterday lunchtime, was duped into revealing what he intended to pick by a phone caller pretending to be from the show.

Around 2pm on Tuesday a man claiming to be a researcher for Princess Productions, the company behind the show, called Mr King asking him to pass on the company details.

"Somebody did ring Ian, claiming to work on the show and asked him to name his tip for the day," said Richard Hastings, series producer of Show Me The Money.

"He did give the tip, which of course was changed."

Shortly after Mr King was tricked into naming the stock, the news leaked out to the internet and shares in Screen, which makes security products, shot up 25%. "It was amazing. The phones on the dealing desk just lit up. They all wanted to buy Screen," said one market-marker.

Screen shares eventually came off the boil to close 1.5p higher at 15.5p, leaving dealers moaning that a false market had been created in the shares.

Mr Hastings, however, was unrepentant: "We are quite glad it happened. It shows the lengths people will go to."

fields.headline: American weirdos
fields.standfirst:
The Handsome Family
Maguires, Leeds
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
The Handsome Family
Maguires, Leeds
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Never mind the roads and the supermarkets, the fuel crisis is biting deepest in American gothic alt country. "If anyone has a really big dog that they're not using for the next week that we could use to get down to Bristol," deadpans the Handsome Family's female weirdo, Rennie Sparks. As people start to chuckle, her husband Brett launches into song: "There once was a poodle, who thought he was a cowboy..."

So begins an hour in the weird world of the Handsome Family. They could have stepped out of David Byrne's film of American kookiness, True Stories. Morbidly funny, the Family teeter on the edge of normality, but the closer they get, the odder they seem.

With their PA stuck on a lorry in Newcastle, they are using some speakers they just "found" in a room upstairs. "We can't turn our voices up," says Brett, concerned, "only the instruments down." He then proceeds to sing even louder. His voice is a truly amazing thing, somewhere between Ring of Fire-era Johnny Cash and a crooning preacher, but has an edge that takes it beyond the familiar. Equally, their grim humour has a long history in murder ballads, but few have played it this off-kilter.

Crucially, they have at least one crooked eye on reality. Many of Brett's songs derive from the period when he was pilled up and "strapped to that fuckin' bed". However, you start to worry when he narrates Arlene, a peculiarly detailed song about a kidnap and murder. Shortly afterwards, the married couple introduce the new guitarist as "their" brother Don. Jaws silently drop.

Far from sterilising the songs, the computerised rhythms add to the surrealism while rooting them in the now. These songs are living, modern American tragedies whose dark taste is sweetened by the couple's delicious humour. It's a tragedy of sorts when Rennie's microphone collapses, rendering her serene vocals and wry pronouncements almost inaudible, but true to the occasion she seizes the moment. Cradling a zither like a small child, she announces: "You don't want to hear me. I've got cholera."

Many of Brett's songs derive from the period when he was pilled up and "strapped to that fuckin' bed". However, you start to worry when he narrates Arlene, a peculiarly detailed song about a kidnap and murder. Shortly afterwards, the married couple introduce the new guitarist as "their" brother Don. Jaws silently drop. Far from sterilising the songs, the computerised rhythms add to the surrealism while rooting them in the now. These songs are living, modern American tragedies whose dark taste is sweetened by the couple's delicious humour. It's a tragedy of sorts when Rennie's microphone collapses, rendering her serene vocals and wry pronouncements almost inaudible, but true to the occasion she seizes the moment. Cradling a zither like a small child, she announces: "You don't want to hear me. I've got cholera."

fields.headline: The Story of an African Farm
fields.standfirst:
Young Vic Studio, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Young Vic Studio, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Olive Schreiner's novel about the coming of age on a South African farm of cousins Em and Lyndall and their friend, the fiercely thoughtful Waldo, was published in 1883 under the pseudonym Ralph Iron.

The unconventional Lyndall, who doesn't believe in God but does believe in education, free love and independence, was undoubtedly a self-portrait of Schreiner herself, and the character was seized upon by feminists of the time. But, like Lyndall, Schreiner never succeeded in reconciling her intellectual ideas with society's expectations and her own emotional needs. Personal happiness eluded her.

This adaptation teems with good ideas but both the narrative line and the style of the production lack coherence. Fatally, although Lyndall is played with gusto and charm by Charlotte Purdon, the lack of depth in the characterisation and the nerviness of the staging never allow you to engage fully with her; she feels like a series of poses.

Aided by Jens Cole's simple design, the production succeeds in conjuring the landscape and the claustrophobia of the farm. But it employs so many performance styles that it very quickly becomes irritating. Neither is there any differentiation between the visual or physical effect that adds to the drama and the one that merely slows it down.

The young cast work very hard, but the overall effect is, alas, botched.

Till September 30. Box office: 020-7928 6363.

fields.headline: Under-fire Kapil quits
fields.trailText: Former India captain Kapil Dev has resigned as coach of the national side, sparking talk that he is about to be officially linked with the match-fixing scandal.
fields.body:
Kapil Dev, the former India captain questioned last week by the Indian Central Bureau of Investigation, has resigned as coach of the national side, sparking talk that he is about to be officially linked with the match-fixing scandal. He was halfway through a two-year contract.

Anshuman Gaekwad, India's coach in the 1999 World Cup, has been appointed acting coach as India prepare for the ICC Knockout Trophy in Nairobi early next month.

Kapil held the world record for Test wickets with 434 from 131 appearances until this year, when Courtney Walsh overtook him.

He had been interrogated by federal Indian police over allegations made against him by Manoj Prabhakar, another former India player. Prabhakar has repeatedly alleged that Kapil offered him cash totalling £40,000 to underperform during a limited-overs match against Pakistan six years ago.

Kapil has denied involvement and in May he sobbed during a television interview when pressed on the issue, saying that he would commit suicide rather than take a bribe.

Two months ago, though, as part of a co-ordinated operation, tax officials raided his house and those of other cricketers and administrators, including the former president of the International Cricket Council, Jagmohan Dalmiya, and another former captain, Mohammad Azharuddin.

Kapil's resignation comes less than two weeks after the selectors omitted Azharuddin, Ajay Jadeja and an off-spinner, Nikhil Chopra, from their shortlist for the ICC Trophy.

 Andy Flower provided the only fireworks as Zimbabwe crawled to 185 for four on the first day of the opening Test against New Zealand after their new captain Heath Streak elected to bat in Bulawayo. Coming in after tea was taken at 105 for two off 69 overs, Flower raised the tempo with successive sixes off Paul Wiseman and once the new ball was taken took 10 off an over from Chris Cairns - who promptly had him caught at slip for 29.

fields.headline: Hollioake hails his heroes
fields.trailText: There is no fuel shortage in Surrey. All over the county there is the muffled sound of champagne bottles being covertly popped as another championship is toasted.
fields.body:
There is no fuel shortage in Surrey. All over the county there is the muffled sound of champagne bottles being covertly popped as another championship is toasted.

No one wants to admit it, of course, but the party has already started, even though the players themselves will be the last to taste the bubbly.

Today at Old Trafford they start their final match against Lancashire, the only side that can beat them to the title. But in truth Lancashire's task is hopeless unless you happen to be an Old Trafford fantasist.

Surrey lead them by 19 points. So Lancashire can only take the title with a maximum 20 points while denying Surrey a single bonus point.

"It's just not on," concedes the Lancashire coach Bobby Simpson. "Even if we score, say, 400 for two, and then declare before they can get a bowling point, they can stop us taking the title by declaring their own innings early to deny us bowling points.

"Realistically we just can't win. But we're going out there to win the match and end the season on a high."

Many see Surrey's championship last year as the better performance. Then, they won 12 out of 17 - they have won nine out of 15 this year - winning the title, unbeaten, with two matches to spare.

Surrey's captain Adam Hollioake, however, is unconvinced. "We got off to a dodgy start this year. But I think some of the cricket we have played in the past three and a bit months has been fantastic. Last year there was this great elation at winning the title after such a long time. This year the feeling will be more of relief."

The ingredients have been largely the same: positive leadership and the variety of their penetrative attack, in which Martin Bicknell, Alex Tudor, Saqlain Mushtaq and Ian Salisbury have all starred at times.

Once again their success is fully deserved, and their 272-run win over Lancashire at the Oval last month was clearly the pivotal performance.

Their coach Keith Medlycott said yesterday: "We are celebrating nothing until we have won it but obviously we would have to go some to lose it. This season we have played all the top sides twice. Coming up against players twice, we have had to work them out.

"It's been a very relaxed and democratic dressing room. Everyone is full of opinions and the captain listens. Players have also responded to being given responsibility."

Surrey have not been everyone's favourite side in recent years but there has been a lot of envy in the unpopularity. Of all the counties they have come closest to responding to the Australian model, playing ruthless, attacking and sometimes brilliant cricket.

The last word can safely be left to Hollioake. "In captaincy you learn and learn. But this season I've been able to sit back and enjoy the ride more. A lot of the hard work had been done and only some fine-tuning was required.

"And I always remembered something my dad told me. Whenever in doubt, he said, go for the attacking option."

webTitle: Platt in danger of the sack at Forest

fields.headline: Platt in danger of the sack at Forest
fields.trailText: David Platt has said he thinks he is on the brink of the sack as his troubled Nottingham Forest side visit Sheffield Wednesday tonight.
fields.body:
David Platt has said he thinks he is on the brink of the sack as his troubled Nottingham Forest side visit Sheffield Wednesday tonight.

The former England captain, once tipped to manage the national team, has had a discouraging 14 months in charge at the City Ground.

Platt refuses to resign but he admitted, after defeats by Blackburn Rovers and lowly Darlington (in the Worthington Cup), that the sack was a possibility. "Of course that enters my mind but it will not harm how I carry out my job," he said. "At the end of the day the only control I have over that factor is in the results of the team on the pitch. I won't quit; it's for other people to decide whether I stay or not."

He added: "At the end of the day this whole situation has come about because people are already starting to think that after five games into the season we're not going to get promoted.

"When you're talking about promotion there are three teams in this league - Fulham, Blackburn and Watford - who will be up there with the resources they have."

Platt was Forest's fourth choice - after Martin O'Neill, Glenn Hoddle and Joe Kinnear - when he was appointed in July 1999. Despite an outlay of more than £10m last summer Forest struggled against relegation and only a late run saw them finish 14th.

After a month of the new season they stand six points off the automatic promotion places.

webTitle: Elegant, romantic and not good enough - just like Chelsea

fields.headline: Elegant, romantic and not good enough - just like Chelsea
fields.trailText: <David Lacey This essentially decent man will put it all down to experience. And so will his successor once he has spent two seasons or so proving that Chelsea still do not speak the language of champions.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli's departure from Chelsea is sudden but hardly surprising. Two-and-a-half seasons is about par for the course for a manager at Stamford Bridge, long enough to show that no matter how talented the players may be Chelsea remain a club on the fringe of football's elite.

Since Dave Sexton's seven-year reign ended in 1974 only John Neal has lasted there more than three years. Of the others, John Hollins and Glenn Hoddle made some headway without suggesting they were about to manage championship-winning teams.

Vialli, like Ruud Gullit before him, led Chelsea to success in the FA Cup but the failure to re-enter the Champions League this season was not merely a shock to the finances but a blow to the self-esteem of a club pining to be ranked with Manchester United and Arsenal.

Instead Chelsea have never quite shaken off their image of elegant dilettantism. Vialli, intelligent, courteous and discerning, a lover of London and its lifestyle, was perfect for Chelsea as they are but maybe not for Chelsea as they wanted to be.

What Ken Bates, Colin Hutchinson and everybody else associated with Chelsea want is clear enough: a team with the consistency to make a serious challenge for the Premiership title plus a regular Champions League place.

Under Vialli, for a time, this appeared possible. At their best no team, not even Manchester United, passed the ball so well so often. But having been overrun 5-1 by Barcelona in the Champions League quarter-final second leg last season, a misery compounded by finishing fifth in the Premiership, winning the FA Cup was a brief consolation.

Vialli's position was always going to be vulnerable if Chelsea made an indifferent start this season and so it has proved. One win and a defeat at Bradford, followed by three draws, has hastened his downfall.

Like Gullit, Vialli was unable at times to get his players going for the bread-and-butter fixtures. No side with serious championship or top-three pretensions loses to Watford and Sheffield Wednesday, who were both relegated, the way Chelsea did last season.

In January Bates described the 1-1 draw at home to Leicester City as "the worst display I've seen from a Chelsea team for many a year" but until now the Chelsea chairman has always been solid in his backing of Vialli, preferring to blame the team for sub-standard performances.

The next Chelsea manager will face the same problem of producing a winning side from an assortment of foreign talents plus Dennis Wise, a rare but essential Englishman who remains the team's rotor arm. There are some outstanding youngsters at Stamford Bridge - Jon Harley and Robert Wolleaston among them - but Chelsea need success today, not tomorrow or the day after.

The name of Gullit helped persuade the likes of Vialli, Gianfranco Zola and Roberto di Matteo to come to England but Chelsea were never quite the same once Gullit had stopped playing regularly at the back and to a lesser degree this was the same with Vialli in the attack.

Chris Sutton, last season's expensive mistake at £10m, was never going to be the answer up front and it is too early to judge whether the £15m Chelsea have paid for Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has been spent more wisely.

Vialli will not be around to find out and presumably this essentially decent man will put it all down to experience. And so will his successor once he has spent two seasons or so proving that Chelsea, with one league title in their 95-year history, still do not speak the language of champions.

webTitle: Leicester relief as Belgrade trip is called off

fields.headline: Leicester relief as Belgrade trip is called off
fields.trailText: Leicester City breathed a sigh of relief yesterday on hearing that the second leg of their Uefa Cup first-round tie against Red Star Belgrade will be played tomorrow fortnight at a neutral venue.
fields.body:
Leicester City breathed a sigh of relief yesterday on hearing that the second leg of their Uefa Cup first-round tie against Red Star Belgrade will be played tomorrow fortnight at a neutral venue.

European football's governing body originally decided that it must take place in Belgrade on September 21, three days before elections in Yugoslavia, but only on condition that Red Star guaranteed player safety.

That assurance failed to materialise by yesterday's deadline so the tie will revert to September 28. Red Star, who visit Filbert Street for the first leg tomorrow, have been given until 3pm on Monday to offer an alternative venue, which must meet Uefa approval. The Bulgarian capital of Sofia has been mentioned.

The foreign office has warned British nationals against non-essential travel to Yugoslavia and it is believed the Football Association would have advised Leicester against travelling if Uefa had insisted that the tie go ahead in Belgrade. Last season Leeds were allowed to play a Uefa Cup tie against Partizan Belgrade in the Netherlands.

The FA's chief executive David Davies said: "This is the right decision for Leicester City and for European football. It had become perfectly clear that in no way could a match go ahead in Belgrade over the next fortnight in anything like normal conditions."

Halifax's Mark Lillis became the second manager to be sacked this season - beating Gianluca Vialli by a matter of hours - after 15 months at the Shay. Lillis, 40, left after Saturday's 5-1 defeat at Mansfield which left Halifax bottom of the Third Division.

Newcastle have finally made a bid for Colchester's Lomano Tresor Lua-Lua, the teenage forward watched by several Premiership clubs. Colchester insist they do not want to sell the 19-year-old, who was born in Zaire but raised in London, but will be hard pushed to resist any bid of more than £1m. West Ham claim to have first refusal.

Ipswich have agreed terms with Maribor for the Slovenia defender Amir Karic, who played in Euro 2000. The 26-year-old has had a medical and is expected to complete his move next week once a work permit has been granted.

However, Everton's hopes of signing the Israel midfielder Idan Tal, 24, have been dashed after he was refused a permit because he failed to meet the criterion of playing 75% of his country's internationals. Everton plan to appeal.

fields.headline: Taylor cuts no dash for toothless Wolves
fields.trailText: Wolves 0 - 0 Sheff Utd
fields.body:
Sheffield United left the West Midlands for the second time in four days singing a familiar refrain: we came, we bored and failed to conquer. But whereas the Blades succumbed to a penalty at Birmingham on Saturday, they managed to keep a clean sheet here against an impotent Wolves attack.

For the second season in succession Wolves are resembling an old banger on a frosty morning, painfully slow to start, with plenty of coughs and splutters thereafter.

At least at this juncture last year they had the arrival of Ade Akinbiyi to look forward to. This season, following his departure to Leicester, the striker in chief Robert Taylor, is in situ. But despite his £1.6m arrival Wolves have not scored more than once in a game yet.

That continues to be the case, with Taylor particularly culpable. Put through by Darren Bazeley in the 17th minute he dallied, allowing Simon Tracey to leave his line, and the goalkeeper smothered his shot.

Taylor, who was substituted at half-time, had an even better chance towards the end of the first period but this time headed Kevin Muscat's right-wing cross straight at Tracey.

While Taylor laboured it was left to Neil Emblen to come closest to scoring for the hosts. Deployed as a centre back because of injury problems, Emblen rattled the top of Tracey's bar with a fierce free-kick hit from distance.

As the half progressed the Blades, who set out as if to contain, became more adventurous with Marcus Bent a particular source of menace.

The Wolves goalkeeper Michael Oakes did well to keep out a close-range shot from Bobby Ford 10 minutes before the interval. And he produced an even better save to prevent Bent from giving the visitors the lead. Diving to his left he managed to palm away a fierce shot after it had taken a deflection off a Wolves defender.

Had the rest of the United players matched the fire of Neil Warnock they would have been in with a better chance of securing their first away win of the season. The manager became so animated on the touch-line following a foul by Muscat that the referee ordered him to leave the dug-out and take a seat in the stand.

But despite the new vantage point Warnock and the crowd of only 14,000 were treated to more huffing and puffing with no end product.

Wolverhampton Wanderers (4-4-2): Oakes; Muscat, Emblen, Lescott, Naylor; Bazeley, Osborn, Sedgley, Robinson; Taylor, Proudlock.

Sheffield United (4-4-2): Tracey; Uhlenbeek, Murphy, Santos, Quinn; Brown, Ford, Woodhouse, Newby; Kelly, Bent.

Referee : G Cain (Seaforth).

But despite the new vantage point Warnock and the crowd of only 14,000 were treated to more huffing and puffing with no end product. fields.headline: Saha leads Fulham fightback
fields.trailText: Fulham 3 - 1 Burnley
fields.body:
The Nationwide League's only 100% record was rescued by the banks of the Thames last night with a three-goal barrage by Fulham sinking Burnley after the break. Their sixth successive win, in front of a meagre crowd, equals Fulham's best start to a season.

Until last night there had been two predictable things in this season's First Division, Fulham winning and Burnley's starting line-up.

Ten players had started all of their previous league games, but two of those, Phil Gray and Steve Davis, were missing with hamstring and back injuries respectively.

At half-time Fulham's winning run looked distinctly threatened a slow paced and the incident-free opening 10 minutes came to a sudden halt when Paul Cook's free-kick from 25 yards took a wicked deflection off Fulham's defensive wall and bounced limply off a wrong-footed goalkeeper Maik Taylor.

It was the last comfortable moment that Burnley were allowed, and Fulham should have been at least level by the break.

Lee Clark, playing magnificently in the continued absence of John Collins, came close with an angled drive after Barry Hayles had dispossessed Gordon Armstrong, and Hayles would have scored had Louis Saha, his own team-mate, not blocked the ball on the line.

Burnley's luck could not hold. Ten minutes after half-time Bjoarne Goldbaek's storming run was illegally halted by Andy Cooke.

The referee, Thomas Parkes, immediately showed him the red card but, as the home fans celebrated, he realised his mistake and bashfully raised the yellow. The home fans were not to be silenced for long, as Goldbaek picked himself up to send the free-kick arrowing into the far corner from 40 yards.

A Fulham win at this stage seemed inevitable, and sure enough Saha put them ahead just before the hour with a fine, firm left-foot finish after Burnley's defence had allowed Fabrice Fernandez to advance from halfway and play him in.

In the 85th minute the red card was out again, shown to Lee Riscoe, and again it heralded a Fulham goal. This time Goldbaek's free-kick was headed in by Saha for his seventh league goal of an already successful season.

Fulham (4-4-2): Taylor; Finnan, Brevett, Melville, Coleman; Golbeak, Clark, Davis, Fernandez; Saha, Hayles.

Burnley (3-5-2): Crighton; Thomas, Armstrong, Cox; Weller, Little, Bull, Briscoe, Cook; Cooke, Mullin.

Referee: T Parkes (Birmingham).

fields.headline: Mooney leaves Rovers in ruins
fields.trailText: Blackburn 3 - 4 Watford
fields.body:
Blackburn lost their unbeaten record in the most humiliating fashion in front of their own fans last night when they capitulated to their promotion rivals Watford after going two up inside 16 minutes.

Tommy Mooney's spanking header on 65 minutes rubbed salt in Ewood Park's wounds for all Nathan Blake's 87th minute consolation. It was the loss of the home striker Matt Jansen, carried off in the 20th minute after a sickening collision with Espen Baardsen, that attended their woes, three Watford goals coming in the space of 17 minutes.

Graham Taylor's title hopefuls had already pulled one back via Micah Hyde's magnificently struck shot from the edge of the area after an Allan Nielsen corner. Then, with Blackburn clearly unsettled by their enforced changes, Heidar Helguson took advantage of some shoddy defending to stoop and head in Paul Robinson's 35th-minute cross.

The comeback was completed two minutes later, as Hyde was granted space in midfield to line up a 25-yard shot which he placed into the bottom right-hand corner of Alan Kelly's goal.

Yet Rovers had started so well. By the sixth minute, when David Dunn headed them in front, they had already threatened three times, Garry Flitcroft striking the outside of a post with the best effort inside 60 seconds

Jansen was involved in the first goal, his accurate cross from the right touchline finding Dunn pulling away from his marker to place a perfectly judged header into the corner.

More was to follow from the scorer, a shot at speed that just missed and a cross for Henning Berg to head narrowly over, before Nathan Blake extended the lead in the 16th minute. He rose impressively to meet John Curtis's cross, headed against the bar and reacted quickly to beat Darran Ward to the loose ball, forcing it over.

A Blake header was cleared off the line before the interval and after it Blake, again, and Kaba Diawara came close with headers. But Watford stood firm and Mooney met a Paul Robinson cross with a venomous header to score the killer goal.

Blackburn Rovers (4-4-2): Kelly; Curtis, Berg, Short, Bjornebye; McAteer (Carsley, 65min), Flitcroft, Dunn, Duff; Jansen (Diawara, 20min), Blake.

Watford (4-3-1-2): Baardsen; Cox, Ward, Palmer, Robinson; Helguson, Hyde, Nielsen; Mooney; Smith, Noel-Williams.

Referee : J Jones.

webTitle: Champions League: Mols makes merry as Rangers storm Graz

fields.headline: Mols makes merry as Rangers storm Graz with tornado
fields.standfirst: Mols 9, De Boer 19, Albertz 28, Van Bronckhorst 71, Dodds 85
fields.trailText: With European ambition that almost constitutes an anxiety, Rangers could not have asked for a more comfortable opener in the Champions League. The men in gleaming white representing Sturm Graz proved surprisingly incompetent, especially defensively.
fields.body:
With European ambition that almost constitutes an anxiety, Rangers could not have asked for a more comfortable opener in the Champions League. The men in gleaming white representing Sturm Graz proved surprisingly incompetent, especially defensively.

This, though, is not to denigrate Rangers' own craft. Evenings like these have been fraught in the past at Ibrox but last night the Scottish champions exhibited spikiness in front of goal.

Deceit is the most dreadful business in football. These Austrians had led Rangers and their permanently indignant manager Dick Advocaat to believe that Ivica Vastic, Markus Schopp and Sergei Yuran would all be missing from their line-up. Vastic, who scored 32 goals last season, was indeed out but the other two were soon bounding around the pitch.

Advocaat could afford to be unperturbed as Rangers inflicted on their visitors a tornado of early goals, going three up inside 28 minutes.

Strangely, once the business of goals seemingly pouring for Rangers had put their fans at ease, something much more important to their Champions League aspirations could be considered.

The return of Michael Mols to the line-up, after a year of nursing a wrecked knee, could not be viewed dispassionately. Following the debacle of John Hartson's attempt to join the club, Mols's squirming, menacing presence is going to be essential in the months ahead.

He had returned gingerly to duty against Dundee on Saturday but there was still a communal apprehension about his physical powers here. One exquisite turn and burst of pace which left Markus Schupp floundering in the first half eased that anxiety. It did no harm to Mols's own self-belief when he prodded Rangers ahead in the ninth minute.

As the Austrians made a hash of trying to shepherd the ball over their own by-line, Ronald de Boer crept through a side-door past the defenders and poked the ball back to Mols. The Dutchman lashed out a foot to score past a startled Josef Schicklgruber. In an arena in which the usual Ibrox racket seemed to bowl the players along Rangers found it hard not keep pounding at the visitors.

Allan Johnston, used sparingly so far by Advocaat this season, had already struck a post before De Boer made it 2-0 after 19 minutes, stealthily advancing to the near post to reach Johnston's cross and flick it past Schicklgruber. Rangers also welcomed back Jorg Albertz, the big German of lumbering gait and thunderous shot, who seems to have the presence of a panzer division on the field. Last night Albertz could afford to be slovenly, missing a penalty after whacking in Rangers' third from 16 yards.

Giovanni van Bronckhorst drilled a fourth for Rangers in the 71st minute before Billy Dodds's delightful chip completed the rout five minutes from time

Rangers (4-4-2): Klos; Reyna, Konterman, Amoruso, Numan; Johnston, Ferguson, Van Bronckhorst, Albertz; De Boer, Mols. Sturm Graz (3-5-2): Schicklgruber; Mamedov, Foda, Strafner; Schopp, Schupp, Fleurquin, Koros, Prilasnig; Yuran, Reinmayr.

Referee: L Cortez (Portugal).

fields.headline: Ferguson primed for major impact
fields.trailText: Forty-four years ago Anderlecht were Manchester United's first opponents in the European Cup and proved not so much a hurdle as a vaulting horse for Matt Busby's emerging young team. With Old Trafford still awaiting floodlights the teams met at Maine Road and United, having won 2-0 in Brussels, routed Anderlecht 10-0.
fields.body:
Forty-four years ago Anderlecht were Manchester United's first opponents in the European Cup and proved not so much a hurdle as a vaulting horse for Matt Busby's emerging young team. With Old Trafford still awaiting floodlights the teams met at Maine Road and United, having won 2-0 in Brussels, routed Anderlecht 10-0.

The Manchester Guardian reported: "Prettily as [Anderlecht] passed and repassed at times, they panted vainly at the heels of a team playing superlative football at an incredible pace." Sir Alex Ferguson's side are unlikely to reach double figures tonight but the present Anderlecht side may still be breathing heavily by the end of the match.

For once United have begun the season showing little sign of the summer torpor which in the past has raised the hopes of rivals. They have scored 14 goals in five Premiership games and though Ipswich and West Ham held them to draws the form of Paul Scholes, David Beckham, Andy Cole and Teddy Sheringham has at times been awesome.

United should, therefore, embark on their latest quest in the Champions League with a solid victory in Group G. This is one of the less intimidating groups and if they can win and then take, say, four points from their next matches, away to Dynamo Kiev and PSV, they will be well placed to go through.

Going out last season to Real Madrid in the quarter-finals was a bitter anticlimax for Ferguson, who would like to make another major impact before he retires in two years' time. Anything less than the last four will be considered a failure.

Anderlecht completed the Belgian double last season and, though no longer the force they were in the 70s and early 80s, still have the means to punish opponents who take them lightly. As Beckham said yesterday: "We have to play every game as if we're playing the best side in the world."

Anderlecht too have begun brightly, with four wins in five league games. "We're not going to Old Trafford for a beauty contest or just to get a pat on the back," said their coach, Aimé Anthuenis. "We want to win."

Nevertheless he may switch to a five-man defence, with Davy Oyen detailed to mark Beckham. In attack he will put much faith in the lofty Jan Koller to disturb a defence lacking Jaap Stam; the Dutchman has not recovered from the achilles injury that forced him off on Saturday. "The firm grounds are a bit of a problem for the lad," Ferguson said. "If we get enough rain I may just risk him as a substitute."

Ronnie Wallwork, Mickael Silvestre and Gary Neville are the alternatives for partnering Ronnie Johnsen at centre-back. Ferguson also has Dwight Yorke and Denis Irwin fit again.

 Manchester United may bank as much as £40m if they repeat their 1999 Champions League victory, £13.6m of it in prize money.

fields.headline: Media stories from today's papers
fields.trailText: What with the rolling petrol wars and the collapse of Nomura's dome deal, there's not a lot of room in the papers for media stories, which might explain the bizarre placing of the Telegraph's "BBC1 controller steps down today" story. For more details through the morning, visit www.mediaguardian.co.uk.
fields.body:
What with the rolling petrol wars and the collapse of Nomura's dome deal, there's not a lot of room in the papers for media stories, which might explain the bizarre placing of the Telegraph's "BBC1 controller steps down today" story. For more details through the morning, visit www.mediatheguardian.com.

The Daily Telegraph
An unbylined, three-paragraph bulletin on page 6 claims that Peter Salmon, the controller of BBC 1, is stepping down today to take over control of BBC sport. The bookmaker William Hill has stopped taking bets on who will win Big Brother on Friday, with Craig 1-3 favourite, followed by Anna and Darren. The Republican campaign team of US presidential candidate George W Bush have been accused of hitting below the belt with adverts which flash the subliminal message "rats" next to the Democrat slogan.

The Sun
Still no sign in the Sun of Marina Hyde's UK Confidential column, which disappeared without trace or mention this week (for more details see MediaGuardian.co.uk's Media Monkey). But happily "Sexy TV Vet" Emma Inglis (from Vets in Practice) has dressed down to tell of her stalking nightmare on pages 12 and 13. Stalkers continue to be the new kiss and tell. All bets are off on Big Brother after a fun of bets on Craig at the terrible odds of 1-3. William Hill has closed the book for fear that someone has insider knowledge. Nasty Nick still backs Craig. (The Bizarre column is on to a winner with its "Lig Brother" guide to which cast member has been enjoying hospitality where)

The Guardian
Broadcaster and omnipotent brain Melvyn Bragg says critics who claim the arts in Britain are being dumbed down are "foolish citizens of culture." A study at Keele University argues that the media's idolising of female sports stars such as Anna Kournikova is part of a culture that discourages women from keeping fit for their health. The British branch of internet seller Amazon.com says the number of customers using the site has broken the 2m mark.

Daily Express
Lee Boardman, who plays Coronation Street baddie Jez Quigley, says he is glad his character is being killed off, as he is afraid of being typecast. Dutchman John Jadnanansing, a former Big Issue seller, could become a millionaire after a court ruled that he owns the Teletubbies brand name in Holland, Belgium and Luxembourg.

Daily Mail
Football fan Paul Stevenson is suing the police after the trauma of being arrested left him too stressed to watch his favourite TV programme, the Bill. Channel 4 bosses have axed Denise Van Outen's desperate Something for the Weekend show because it has lost its shock value. A hut bought in Margate by controversial artist Tracey Emin, with two pictures of the shy and retiring genius inside, has been bought by advertising tycoon Charles Saatchi for £75,000.

Financial Times
The Advertising Standards Authority has ruled that companies offering to connect people to the internet cannot use the word "free" in their advertisements unless the whole of the service, including the call charge or cable connection, is completely free of charge. A report published by recruitment consultancy Kelly Services UK predicts that telecoms and internet technology will allow 25% of the labour force to work from home by 2020. A report by accountancy giants PwC states that the technological revolution will make the global media and entertainment industry more competitive, thanks to an "unquenchable" consumer appetite for media in physical and digital forms. Chime Communications, the advertising and public relations group that owns Bell Pottinger Communications, is looking to buy high-technology online PR companies in the US and Germany. Jean-Marie Messier, chairman of freench media giant Vivendi, says the company's shareholder base and ownership will have to shift to the US if it is to become a market leader.

The Times
Mercury Music prize winner Damon Gough, AKA Badly Drawn Boy, said of his surprise victory last night: "I assumed I was never going to win it, 'cos good things don't usually happen to good people." American TV giant NBC has blown Big Brother out of the water by revealing plans for a show which will send a group of ordinary Americans on a Russian cosmonaut training mission, to compete for the chance to go into space.

The Independent
A psychologist at Leicester University, with too much time on his hands, has found that words used in best-selling pop songs can predict an economic recession. New York advertising agency J Walter Thompson is in trouble after a shoot in Peru for a beer commercial damaged an Inca temple. Sportswear titans Nike are hoping that the Sydney Olympics will revive flagging fortunes, after a two-year period in which sales growth has tumbled.

Tabloid Story of the Day
The Daily Star runs a subtle double-page spread of photos showing Big Brother favourite Craig stark naked on a beach. The front page headline screams "TV Craig shows there's no shortage at his pump."

fields.headline: Budweiser to air Whassup? ad in UK
fields.standfirst: See the ad here
fields.trailText: Budweiser is launching cult US ad campaign Whassup? in the UK, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Budweiser is bringing cult US advertising campaign Whassup? to the UK after it was voted the best in the world at this year's Cannes International Advertising Festival.

The ads, in which friends greet each other with the phrase "Whassup?", have become a cultural phenomenon in the US. The campaign has captured the public imagination with its emphasis on male bonding, and the phrase has entered the vernacular and become the latest way for trendy, young Americans to greet each other.

The campaign will debut on Channel 4 during Friday's final broadcast of Big Brother, and will run until Christmas.

Budweiser is screening four ads, all of which feature friends sitting around watching American football and screaming "Whassup?", to which comes the laid-back reply, "Watchin' the game, havin' a Bud."

Budweiser has also created a website so that consumers can download screen savers and send emails from the characters to their friends.

Lucy Cooke, UK brand manager for Budweiser, said: "The humour of Whassup? is universal and the research we've conducted shows it translates very well over here. It really reflects the lifestyle of 18 to 34-year-old lads, who love sitting around watching sport, and who have their own secret language."

webTitle: Israeli telecoms darling takes a tumble in Nasdaq's wake

fields.headline: Israeli telecoms darling takes a tumble in Nasdaq's wake
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: BATM, the Israel-based technology group which has been one of the stock market darlings of the past 12 months, suffered a 7.8% drop in its stock price yesterday despite turning in a 252% increase in half-year profits.
fields.body:
BATM, the Israel-based technology group which has been one of the stock market darlings of the past 12 months, suffered a 7.8% drop in its stock price yesterday despite turning in a 252% increase in half-year profits.

The shares were dragged lower by weakness on the technology-laden Nasdaq market in the US - with sentiment also being damaged by the previous day's slump in GEO Interactive, the Tel Aviv-based technology business which has been a favorite among investors in London.

At its peak, BATM reached 765p earlier this month - a near-300% increase over the past year.

Yesterday the price dropped 60p to 655p, with part of the fall also attributed by analysts to profit-taking.

BATM, which makes equipment for telecommunications networks, said pretax profits for the half-year had risen from $2.7m (£1.9m) to $9.4m, partly on the back of its $330m acquisition of Telco Systems of America. Revenues were 237% higher at $36.8m.

Dr Zvi Marom, BATM's chief executive, said the Telco deal meant the company's new focus was on developing its business in the US. America was the "make it or break it" market for the business.

Dr Marom said the company would continue to pursue bolt-on acquisitions in the "tens of millions of dollars" price range to drive profitability.

The company's share price has benefited from the drip-feed into the market of a series of partnerships with well known businesses. In the past six months it has received orders from Sprint in the US, welcomed Sun Microsystems as an investor and entered into research and development agreements with Sun Microsystems, mobile phone maker Nokia and Samsung.

The company is seeking to increase its presence in South Korea, where it has an alliance with Samsung and from where it plans to expand in China.

Dr Marom said: "The amalgamation of Telco Systems with BATM is proceeding even better than we had anticipated, and the relationships we have entered into with our new business partners have been particularly gratifying. They give us confidence that we can look forward to accelerated growth in 2001 and beyond."

The company said there continued to be a surplus of demand from companies building telecoms networks which enables it to compete alongside larger competitors, including Cisco Systems, Nortel Networks and Lucent Technologies. The market is also being fuelled by the constant drive for ever faster technology, it added.

Dr Marom said the deal with the American long distance carrier, Sprint, although only worth $5m, would be likely to result in repeat business. Relationships with the larger networks were difficult to establish but become easier thereafter, he added.
