webTitle: Chelsea,  More Chelsea, and  A bit of Olympics

fields.headline: Chelsea,  More Chelsea, and  A bit of Olympics
fields.trailText: I'M BLUE DADADEEDADADA
fields.body:
I'M BLUE DADADEEDADADA

As the Fiver strutted along the Kings Road today, we were looking mighty good. And so, we thought, was fashionable West London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea. Now that Vialli was gone, all the friction and disharmony and disillusioned rants from M Leboeuf would go with him. And with everyone happy, Chelsea would surely storm up the league like a recently refuelled truck, and hand Cuddly Ken Bates his first Premiership trophy. Made sense to us.

But just as Gianluca Vialli is unlikely to be signing Paolo Di Canio in the near future, we appeared to have misjudged the mood at Stamford Bridge. In fact it was more like a morgue than a mash-up. Just listen to Dennis Wise, who was so depressed he was wearing turned-up jeans and a curious Morrissey-style quiff. "Everyone was disappointed - Luca was a good friend of mine," he wailed. "We have not started very well. Maybe that is one of the reasons and that is down to us."

Chief executive Colin Hutchinson joined in the mournathon as he revealed that "The mood when I arrived was subdued. It showed the affection Luca was held in. None of the players knew about it until the announcement. It came as a shock to them."

It was getting like an episode of Thirtysomething. But then Ray 'Butch' Wilkins stepped in to set everyone straight. "That side of Chelsea Football Club is closed and we have to crack on and crack on in big style", he said manfully. Which means, we presume, getting rid of Wilkins and Graham Rix and bringing in a new man. Not turning Stamford Bridge into a freebase factory. But you never know

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

JOB APPOINTMENTS MADE EASY

So who will be the new Luca? Certainly not the Fiver, who will resist any attempts to shoehorn us into one of the most demanding jobs in professional football. It won't be Gianfranco Zola either, the overnight favourite for the job having been ruled out after Colin Hutchinson, managing director at Chelsea's of Chelsea said: "we do not believe that we will take anybody from the current staff despite what some people have been suggesting." So who is up for the job? The Fiver profiles the candidates.

1/ Terry Venables. The former England coach has been out of management since leaving Crystal Palace. Now the bookies' favourite, but close friends are said to be unsure whether Venables would be interested in a highly-paid position coaching cultured footballers at a glamorous London-based football club. Would not have been available for work if the Fiver's Tel for England campaign hadn't failed so miserably.

2/ Arsenal's George Graham. Currently manager of Tottenham Hotspur, this shouldn't stop Graham from spreading the Gooner gospel to another of their deadly local rivals. A stern disciplinarian, his frill-less coaching style should go down well with Frank Leboeuf, Marcel Desailly, Gianfranco Zola, Jes Hog[list curtailed due to reasons of space], and John Harley. Would be able to hook up with old pal Jimbo Hasselbaink though.

3/ Aime Jacquet. Basically just dossing around at the French FA, the former national coach could be tempted back into management if the package is right. Obviously close to the French contingent, Jacquet also has the continental approach that appeals to Ken Bates. Reports today have named Jacquet and Didier Deschamps as the new team. A partnership that would please the fans no end.

4/ Marcello Lippi. Ideally qualified for the post as he is already coaching Internazionale, the Italian Chelsea (only with less Italians). Like Vialli he's also failed to get into the Champions League, so another duff result or five could see him looking to exchange the hothouse of Milan for the, er hang on, hothouse of London.

5/ Craig from out of Big Brother. Soon to be released from his contract in East London, the charmless scouser would be the people's choice. Great at hiding things and talking about gang bangs, "Eeerrrm" could be the man to bring the glory days back to West London.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HONK IF YOU'VE THOUGHT OF A GREAT PUBLICITY STUNT!

Premiership sponsors Carling have promised free coach transport for fans facing long trips on Saturday, because of the fuel crisis. Supporters of Newcastle, Ipswich and Derby - who go to Southampton, Leeds and Sunderland respectively - have been guaranteed help, and Carling are hoping to extend the offer to fans of all Premiership teams.

Carling - the brewer that backs our truckers

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I could hardly see any of the goal. When you've got players like Niall Quinn in the way, you can't see anything!"

David Beckham explains why the new ten-yard rule for dissent isn't good news for him.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WHY THE OLYMPICS ARE INTERESTING

The opening ceremony may not be until Friday, but the Olympics got underway in earnest today with the start of the "soccer" tournament. Normally in situations like this, the Fiver would turn to its Australian cousin Bruce Fiver for coverage. But sadly Bruce has relocated to London where he is carving out a high-flying career as a bar operative. So then we asked the Chinese Olympic team to file a report, but they were too busy being sent home, and Toadfish from out of Neighbours was unavailable. Which meant we had to use the official report instead. So here it is.

"The smell of the Deep Heat, the roar of the crowd! This was truly international sports at its finest, as Olympic hosts Australia locked horns with the mediterranean maestros of Italy at the MCG. A crowd of 93,000 - beat that Phil Collins! - thrilled to the delights of a match decided by a miscued toe-poke by Italy's Andrea Pirlo, the star of Internazionale reserves. Try as they might, and boy did they try, the Olyroos just couldn't get back into the game. Mainly because Pirlo scored near the end of it.

"Another game pitted little Nigeria against the might of Honduras. The Hondures duly took the lead in the game three times, to lead 3 to 0. But the plucky Nigerios never know when they're beat and equalised three times in the final fifth of the game to get a draw which was well deserved, or not. Elsewhere the Czechs drew 2-2 with soccer powerhouse UsofA, and London club player Lauren scored in Cameroon's 3-2 victory over Kuwait, a repeat of the final score in the Gulf War. I love this game."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester City are mulling over a move for Taribo West, according to reports.

Colchester United will decide over whether to accept Newcastle's £2m bid for striker Lomano Lua Lua by the end of this week.

Giant Czech striker Jan Koller would love to join Liverpool. The Anderlect striker, speaking ahead of tonight's Champions League match against Man Utd, said: "I want to do well against Manchester United to show Liverpool what I can do against English clubs. It's been my dream to come to England and to play for Liverpool."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Laurent Blanc has revealed that Manchester United made another attempt to sign him just two weeks ago. "I have been contacted by Manchester United, two weeks ago, just before the friendly between France and England," he admitted. "However, the book is now closed. I could have made an excellent financial deal and I could also have asked Inter to upgrade my wages, but I am very happy here - on a human and sport level."

Bryan Robson has held talks with striker Andy Campbell in a bid to persuade him to stay at Middlesbrough. "I've spoken to Andy and he's fine. He knows he's got a challenge to try to get into the team," he said. "But I've told him he's got every chance because at the moment I'm looking to play with three forwards."

St Etienne have turned down Blackburn's renewed £7m bid for striker Lucien Mettomo. Graeme Souness upped his bid from £5m and offered to triple Mettomo's salary. But St Etienne coach Robert Nouzaret said: "We've decided we would hold to our position, and Mettomo won't leave. The English First Division is not what I call ambition."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live! (7pm) Is there really any need for the exclamation mark? After all, the excitement of Manchester United v Anderlecht surely sells itself.

The Big Match (11.30pm) Highlights of the evening's Big Cup action, presented by Barry Venison! and Gabby Yorath.

Football extra (3.05am) As late as a woman who has started being mysteriously sick in the morning.

ITV 2: The Big Match - Live! (7pm) Barcelona v Leeds. You can understand why they've added the exclamation here. After all, how else would anybody else realise there's a really big game being shown on a channel only two people can watch?

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mondial (7pm) The programme that shows bureaucracy at its best.

Soccer Special (7.30pm) Jeff Stelling - better than Jesus.

You're on Sky Sports! (10pm) Better than a poke in the eye with a burning stick. And I think you know which eye I'm talking about ladies'n'gennlemen.

British Eurosport: Olympic football (started at 4.45pm) Catch up with the latest from Sidney. Although why this programme should be presented by a long-dead star of the Carry On films is anyone's guess.

webTitle: Deprivation study pinpoints ethnic divide among elderly

fields.headline: Deprivation study pinpoints ethnic divide among elderly
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Elderly people from the Pakistani and Bangladeshi communities in Britain are far more likely to suffer from multiple deprivation than their Indian or white contemporaries, according to a survey of the over-60s published yesterday by the office for national statistics.
fields.body:
Elderly people from the Pakistani and Bangladeshi communities in Britain are far more likely to suffer from multiple deprivation than their Indian or white contemporaries, according to a survey of the over-60s published yesterday by the office for national statistics.

It found 28% of older Pakistani and Bangladeshis were in households with no central heating that were more likely to suffer from dampness and condensation. And 38% lived in overcrowded homes with more than one person per room.

They were almost three times as likely to live in a household without a phone than white, Indian or black Caribbean older people.

The report said the ethnic dimension of social inequality among older people could no longer be overlooked. There were nearly 250,000 over-60s from ethnic minority groups, and this number was set to swell as these groups aged.

The high point of immigration from the Caribbean was in the early 1960s. Immigration from India and Pakistan peaked in the early 1970s, and from Bangladesh and Hong Kong in the early 1980s.

"The proportion of older people within ethnic minority groups is expected to increase over the next couple of decades, as the first generation migrants from the different minority groups begin to retire," said the author of the report, Maria Evandrou of Kings College, London.

On an index of multiple deprivation, the survey found 47% of Pakistani and Bangladeshi pensioners experience three or more types of disadvantage, compared to 42% of black Caribbeans, 26% Irish, 19% white and 13% Indian.

Two-thirds of white elderly people live in owner-occupied accommodation, usually without mortgage commitments. Indian elders have the highest rates of owner-occupation (88%), but often with an outstanding mortgage.

Black Caribbean, Irish and Pakistani and Bangladeshi older people were more likely to live in local authority or housing association accommodation.

Black Caribbeans were least likely to live in a household with a car. Nearly two-thirds relied entirely on public transport, affecting ease of shopping and attending hospital.

Just over a fifth of white and a quarter of Irish elderly people are in the bottom fifth of the income scale, compared to a third of the older black Caribbeans, half the Indians, and three-fifths of older Pakistani and Bangladeshis.

 Shelter, the housing charity, warned yesterday that homelessness has reached record levels in England. Figures from the Department of the Environment showed the number of households living in temporary accommodation was 66,030 in the secondquarter, a rise of 11% on a year before.

"Households on low incomes are the innocent victims of the housing boom. As rents continue to soar thousands of households are becoming homeless. Our experience shows that temporary accommodation such as bed and breakfast hostels are totally unsuitable for nurturing stable family life," said Chris Holmes, the charity's director.

Other official figures showed the number of homeless households living in bed and breakfast hostels was 8,380.

Shelter said that while house prices were beginning to level out, soaring rents showed no signs of falling, leading to a shortage of affordable housing and homelessness for thousands of low-incomes families.

The situation was particularly acute in London where rents have risen 62% since 1993 to an average of £285 per week for a two-bedroom flat. House prices in the capital now average £193,000.

Shelter called for "massive investment in decent affordable housing". About 100,000 affordable homes per year had to be built between 2000 and 2011 to tackle the crisis, it said.

On an index of multiple deprivation, the survey found 47% of Pakistani and Bangladeshi pensioners experience three or more types of disadvantage, compared to 42% of black Caribbeans, 26% Irish, 19% white and 13% Indian. Two-thirds of white elderly people live in owner-occupied accommodation, usually without mortgage commitments. Indian elders have the highest rates of owner-occupation (88%), but often with an outstanding mortgage. Black Caribbean, Irish and Pakistani and Bangladeshi older people were more likely to live in local authority or housing association accommodation. Black Caribbeans were least likely to live in a household with a car. Nearly two-thirds relied entirely on public transport, affecting ease of shopping and attending hospital. Just over a fifth of white and a quarter of Irish elderly people are in the bottom fifth of the income scale, compared to a third of the older black Caribbeans, half the Indians, and three-fifths of older Pakistani and Bangladeshis.  Shelter, the housing charity, warned yesterday that homelessness has reached record levels in England. Figures from the Department of the Environment showed the number of households living in temporary accommodation was 66,030 in the secondquarter, a rise of 11% on a year before. "Households on low incomes are the innocent victims of the housing boom. As rents continue to soar thousands of households are becoming homeless. Our experience shows that temporary accommodation such as bed and breakfast hostels are totally unsuitable for nurturing stable family life," said Chris Holmes, the charity's director. Other official figures showed the number of homeless households living in bed and breakfast hostels was 8,380. Shelter said that while house prices were beginning to level out, soaring rents showed no signs of falling, leading to a shortage of affordable housing and homelessness for thousands of low-incomes families. The situation was particularly acute in London where rents have risen 62% since 1993 to an average of £285 per week for a two-bedroom flat. House prices in the capital now average £193,000. Shelter called for "massive investment in decent affordable housing". About 100,000 affordable homes per year had to be built between 2000 and 2011 to tackle the crisis, it said.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk.
fields.trailText: Before he became a doctor (and a famous footballer) Brazilian footballer Socrates apparently spent some of his student years in Dublin. My memory is hazy but I think I was told that while there he played for University College Dublin (UCD) in the FAI Cup, or it could have been that he only managed to make the UCD reserve team. Is there any truth to these unlikely stories? if so, maybe that's where he picked up his smoking habit", writes Colman Walsh
fields.body:
Before he became a doctor (and a famous footballer) Brazilian footballer Socrates apparently spent some of his student years in Dublin. My memory is hazy but I think I was told that while there he played for University College Dublin (UCD) in the FAI Cup, or it could have been that he only managed to make the UCD reserve team. Is there any truth to these unlikely stories? if so, maybe that's where he picked up his smoking habit", writes Colman Walsh

Amazingly enough Colman, you're right. "Socrates did play for UCD, but it was way, way back, sometime in the 70s." says Brendan McKenna of the Football Association of Ireland. "He was an attraction at the time, but it was before he played for the Brazilian team. He wouldn't have played much more than a season." That's confirmed by Gerry Callan of the Irish Star, who says he thinks Socrates did play for UCD, but only for the reserves on Saturday's as the first team played on Sunday, and he didn't want to play then. Did anyone see the great man in action for UCD? If so then let us know at the usual address.

"How are the Fifa rankings worked out? Germany have been pants for the last two years but are still ninth, above the Euro 2000 semi-finalists Holland. Is there some complicated Duckworth-Lewis style co-efficient or are the ratings decided on the whim of a Blatter?" asks an exasperated David Maton.

Well David, there is a method to Fifa's madness, which is explained in excruciating detail on their website. For those of you who can't be bothered reading through it all, you can rest assured that that the ranking list comes from a powerful computer program that gives a country points for each match they have played based on six criteria.

These are: a) whether a team wins, draws or loses; b) by how many goals; c) whether it's a home or away match; d) the importance of the match; e) the strength of the opponent; f) the regional strength of the team. All of which still doesn't explain why Wales are below Oman in the latest rankings.

Get the full, painful, facts here

"Does anyone know of any footballers that went to public school? I know Frank Lampard Jnr was one (he went to Brentwood). But are there any others?" wonders Joel Davison.

"Simon Morgan, once club captain and now the longest serving player at Fulham, attended King Edward VI Five Ways School in Birmingham," says Ben Homer. "I know this because he was my brother's best friend and then best man at his wedding."

"Is it true that a winner of a Cup Final medal was hung for sheep stealing in Australia in the early 1900s? I was told that it was an ex-Everton player," asked James Carlin.

"Well, if this is true, it can only be one of four members of the 1906 Everton team which won the FA Cup for the first time in the club's history - because the other seven are all documented as having departed this world a long time after the early 1900s," says Anthony Williams. The four possible names he mentions are John Crelley, Hugh Bolton, Alex Young and James Settle. Can anyone else narrow it down further?

Last week Kevin Rainey asked: If a free kick is advanced 10 yards by the referee into the penalty area does it become a penalty? The answer is of course no, it remains a free kick, but I would like to know what kind of free kick. I think any free-kick should become indirect on entering the area - am I right? And we fobbed him off with Fifa spokesman Andreas Herren, who insisted that the referee - no matter how much a team hassles him, or even if the original free kick was awarded a millimetre outside the box - can only move the ball to the edge of the area, and not into the penalty box.

Clearly, as Chris Harker points out, Andreas was wrong. "At the Leeds v Man City on Tuesday referee Graham Poll awarded Leeds a free kick on the edge of the City area. Alan Smith attempted to take it quickly but it was blocked by a City player only a few feet away, and the free kick was then advanced ten yards, well into the City area to be taken again," he says. The correct answer, says Kevin Rainey, is that the ball can move into the penalty area as far as the six-yard line, where it becomes indirect.

Can you help?

"Which is the oldest English League club (current or defunct); and if they can truly claim to be the first football club, who on earth did they play agains?" asks Matthew Szabo.

"In This is Spinal Tap, the bassist Derek Smalls can be seen to be wearing an early 80s Shrewsbury Town shirt. Have there been other incidences of silver screen glory for the lower league clubs?" asks James McKie, who says he's not interested in the thousands of times "Man U-bloody-United have managed to foist their brand onto celluloid.

"The Nationwide Conference is a national league, but the leagues that feed into it are regional (north, south and midlands). Presumably the winners of these leagues (Unibond, Dr Martens and Ryman) are promoted to the Conference, with the bottom three in the Conference going down. But what happens if, for example, the bottom three are all northern clubs. Do they all go back into the Unibond league (or whatever) or would some of them have to play in the 'wrong' league, geographically speaking. How is it all sorted out?" asks Andrew Tracey.

Any questions?

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

webTitle: ISPs told: free must mean free

fields.headline: ISPs told: free must mean free
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Internet service providers were today warned they should not advertise services as "free" if they charge for any part of their online package.
fields.body:
Internet service providers were today warned they should not advertise services as "free" if they charge for any part of their online package.

The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) took action after upholding a complaint from 167 consumers about ntl's failure to provide the free internet access promised in its advertising.

An ASA spokesman said: "The advertisers said they experienced such a significant demand for the service that it resulted in an overload of their capacity to provide telephone and internet services.

"They explained that improvements to their service capacity were made immediately, but to maintain services at optimal quality levels they had opted to phase the distribution of the CD-rom that was required to access the free internet service."

But the ASA said it was concerned that ntl had continued to advertise the free service, knowing it could not satisfy demands.

The spokesman added: "We have asked the advertisers not to advertise free internet access through ntlworld until they could supply the service to all applicants within a reasonable time."

webTitle: New dot.com stakes first claim to global business service provision

fields.headline: New dot.com stakes first claim to global business service provision
fields.trailText: At the end of 1998, two FT.com executives were having a drink at the bar of the Pudong Shangri-La hotel in Shanghai, lamenting the difficulties of doing business far from home.
fields.body:
At the end of 1998, two FT.com executives were having a drink at the bar of the Pudong Shangri-La hotel in Shanghai, lamenting the difficulties of doing business far from home.

Almost two years later, Donal Smith and Jonathan Schmidt are about to launch eCountries (due September 28), an internet business designed to address those complaints. As media executives wrack their brains at trying to turn their content-rich sites into money-makers, eCountries may have outfoxed the opposition with its admirably direct premise.

Sometimes described as an online version of the Economist Intelligence Unit, which also churns out country analyses, eCountries is a site that provides news and analysis for 150 countries. As with most publishers, the information comes free of charge. The site consists of profiles on countries from Austria to Venezuela and up-to-date news feeds.

eCountries is hoping to attract traffic by being listed on various news sites such as ABC.com and would eventually like to license its content to news outlets that have trimmed their foreign coverage. But the ace up the company's sleeve is its Marketplace matchmaking service for companies wishing to do business on foreign turf.

Marketplace seeks to take the hassle out of international transactions, sparing companies the trials and tribulations that afflicted Smith, 38, and Schmidt, 36, during their dealmaking for FT.com years ago. Matchmaking has proved to be a successful formula for technology and internet networking group First Tuesday and eCountries has taken the concept further by adding a global twist.

"There is a large volume of international professional services that gets traded," Mr Smith said from eCountries's headquarters in Clerkenwell, the area of London where internet companies are proliferate as fast as the trendy cafes and restaurants in the neighbourhood. "But the market is very disaggregated. The internet is a fantastic way of introducing buyers and sellers to each other."

Say a British company needs a translation of Bulgarian telecommunications legislation in a hurry - an actual request that came to eCountries recently. The company then fills in a form at the eCountries site and eCountries will try and come up with matches for appropriate services; at least two or three.

If the transaction is completed, eCountries takes a cut of up to 10% of the fees. Transactions are expected to range from £5,000 to £100,000, with eCountries counting on commissions to make up at least half of revenues.

Other companies have spotted the potential for business matchmaking via the net. Business.com and Work.com are doing something similar for firms in the US. The two American companies have constructed big directories organised around business topics and plan to place partners' services and news feeds around these databases. But shrewdly, eCountries has its eye on the global market.

With cross-border trade growing, eCountries believes there is plenty of scope for its venture as companies seek out reliable lawyers, accountants and other professionals in the countries in which they are doing business.

Building up a database of service providers from accountancy firms to law firms was tough at first. It took six months to sign up the first supplier, but then momentum built up and eCountries now has about 400 service providers in its database, which covers four areas: legal translation and market research; recruitment; property services and insurance; and financial services. When a client posts a request on the site, it will get, at the very least, a global and a regional player in the specified sector.

Great care is taken to vet the companies for marketplace. Of the 400 Russian companies suggested for eCountries's marketplace, only 50 survived the cull. In the most important part of the vetting process, a candidate who wishes to be included has to provide references from three companies with which it has done business.

Clients "are entering a walled garden for vetted suppliers," said Smith, who sold a broadcast monitoring business to Pearson in 1995 for £4m and then went on to run the company's FT.com subsidiary. Schmidt, meanwhile, founded Asia Intelligence Wire and ran the Asian division of the Financial Times.

eCountries expects to break even by 2002. Investors like the look of the top team, which includes Michael Elliott, the editor-in-chief, who jumped ship as international editor of Newsweek to get involved. He had no qualms about joining the new venture.

"I'd become more and more thrilled by the possibilities of the net," he said, "Especially by its ability to be a global distribution mechanism for international news and information and I thought, 'If I don't make the leap into something new now, I never will.' I'm having a blast."

eCountries has undoubtedly hit upon a good idea. The dual keys to success will be the thoroughness of its vetting process to keep out less-than-reputable companies and of course, whether people use the service.

It could be cheaper and easier to conduct searches on the net and call up a few local companies, though there is no guaranteed safety net like with eCountries. If companies want their hand held as they strike out into new markets, eCountries could be their guide.

Useful links
eCountries

fields.headline: The second-division promotion race
fields.trailText: It's the sort of scenario apologists for two divisions must have dreamt about. With one round of matches to go, six sides are in with more than just a mathematical chance of promotion from the lower echelon of the County Championship. Northamptonshire are already there, but Glamorgan in second are just seven points clear of Gloucestershire in seventh - almost the entire division is still in with a sniff.
fields.body:
It's the sort of scenario apologists for two divisions must have dreamt about. With one round of matches to go, six sides are in with more than just a mathematical chance of promotion from the lower echelon of the County Championship. Northamptonshire are already there, but Glamorgan in second are just seven points clear of Gloucestershire in seventh - almost the entire division is still in with a sniff.

The concept of dead matches, which under the old one-divisional system used to begin around late-July, has gone the way of the aluminium bat, the eight-ball over and blackwashes by West Indies.

No matter that the first division is virtually done and dusted (Surrey need one point to clinch the title, and Kent need one to condemn Hampshire to the drop - along with Derbyshire and Durham). The new system has been utterly vindicated by the second-division dog-fight that makes every game matter.

So who's going to join Northants? Here's a guide to the final four matches of a county season that has peaked later than any other can ever have done.

Essex (3rd, 150 pts) v Warwickshire (6th, 144 pts)

Essex need 17 points to be certain of promotion - that's a win plus five bonus points. A draw plus a full quota of bonus points (eight) might be enough too, but Essex won't want to take that risk. And on a pitch where their last two first-innings scores have been 136 and 131 it's unlikely they'll be able to. Particularly as Warwickshire will be going all out for the win they need to give them an outside chance of going up. Can Allan Donald stand any more disappointment after the NatWest Final washout?

Glamorgan (2nd, 150 pts) v Middlesex (9th, 127 pts)

Of the six teams in the chasing pack, Glamorgan appear to have the easiest path to first-division status: Middlesex are the only side in action who can't be promoted (Sussex, who have already completed their fixture-list, will be in Division Two next season too). Like Essex, Glamorgan need 17 points to make sure, while a draw would leave them dependent on other results. But they've won just one match at Cardiff all season, and any side led by Justin Langer won't want to take the wooden spoon back to Lord's. Even so, pride should be no match for the Dragons' burning desire.

Gloucestershire (7th, 143 pts) v Nottinghamshire (4th, 147 pts)

Gloucester have probably left it too late to show they can play games that last longer than 100 overs: promotion would require them to score 400 in their first innings (something they haven't done all season), then win, then hope that two of Glamorgan, Essex and Worcestershire don't. Notts' hope of emerging from the doldrums depend on winning well and either Essex or Glamorgan slipping up.

Worcestershire (5th, 144 pts) v Northamptonshire (1st, 180 pts)

Worcestershire are playing the runaway leaders, but this is no bad thing. Northants' season in effect ended when they lifted the trophy after their draw with Essex, and if they're not hungover, they could be demob-happy. The seaming wickets at New Road aren't the best place for them to execute their usual game-plan of batting first, racking up 450 and unleashing Jason Brown's offspin. Worcestershire on the other hand will have Glenn McGrath - who rarely fails on the big occasion - but even a big win for Worcester would still leave them waiting on the other results.

Predictions Glamorgan to finish second after beating Middlesex, and Nottinghamshire to finish third after they beat Gloucestershire and Essex lose to Warwickshire.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read last week's column, on the return of Northants, click here

webTitle: Parents: Trying:  Leah Wild's IVF diary

fields.headline: Tales of the unexpected
fields.standfirst: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
The Long Wait between two embryos being placed in my womb and finding out if either of them had implanted, meaning I was pregnant, wasn't as long as I expected. On the 10th day, I started bleeding.

First I swore a lot. Then took revenge on the medical procedure I had been subjected to for months. I stopped inserting a progesterone pessary every night, "to make the uterus lining as receptive as possible to the embryos". I threw out my folic acid. I staggered up to the attic to make a pile of those things I would have to give away - the high chair, the box of baby clothes, the unbleached eco-friendly re-usable nappies, as if I were any more likely to use this ridiculous fop to world environmental destruction the second time around.

I was clearing out my life, moving on, and in that way in felt good. But maudlin and awash with self-pity, I wrote in my diary: "Today seems unbearably long. I cannot wait for the time when this sadness is gone."

On the 12th day after my embryo transfer, I did a pregnancy test. The clinic requires it.

The blue line was so strong I thought it must be faulty. I sent my boyfriend out to buy another. The blue line was just as strong. The bleeding, said the doctors, was one of those inexplicable things; despite what the textbooks say, there's no such thing as normal. I am pregnant.

Now, a week or so later, I see the confusion surrounding my pregnancy test as a reminder, a warning even. Everything in this world is down to chance - especially childbirth.

We like to think that we can control almost everything. Infertility treatment both bolsters and confounds this hope. It promises to overcome the chance of barrenness. Yet, infertility itself unsettles all our plans. It wasn't supposed to be that way. Aged 41, I wasn't supposed to be attending the Assisted Conception Unit. It is as if my life plan had been hijacked.

Here is the fairytale, how it is supposed to be: we grow up, we fall in love, we have children. This is still the narrative young people read. It is what my seven-year-old daughter is reading now. Even today, there is no alternative tale. Infertility is not an option any of us imagine for our futures.

Yet, once you know that everything doesn't necessarily turn out as predicted, you can never unlearn that knowledge. I have entered a world of agonies, other women's as well as my own, and it is as if my innocence has been lost. When someone tells me they're planning to have a child next year, after they have moved to a bigger flat, I can't feel unfiltered joy. When someone says they're pregnant, my congratulations are feeble.

I know life doesn't always turn out as you may want it to. One of the most painful paragraphs I have ever read was in the classified small ads section at the back of Issue, the magazine of the National Fertility Association. "Issue was extremely saddened to hear that baby Emily Isabel Jones died suddenly and unexpectedly earlier this year, from Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. Our profoundest sympathies go to her parents, Heather Roberts and Neil Jones. Emily Isabel Jones: born November 18 1999, died January 1 2000". The parents must have thought the plan was back on track.

I expect everything to turn out fine; it usually does. But I do not regard a positive test as the end of the road. Pregnancy is a long and winding road.

I am, just, beginning to view happenstance as an essential part of being human. Even though we would not wish agonies on ourselves or others, a regimented, predictable, utterly expected 77 untroubled years in this world would hardly be worth living. The vagaries of pregnancy and childbirth, above all, teaches us that. We cannot control it; we will never be able to. That's life.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: A National Childbirth Trust study out this week says fathers feel left out of the pregnancy and birth of their children. We asked six new dads: is that how you felt?
fields.trailText: The Question: A National Childbirth Trust study out this week says fathers feel left out of the pregnancy and birth of their children. We asked six new dads: is that how you felt?
fields.body:
John Williams Father of George, two weeks

We didn't attend antenatal classes as we'd heard that it wasn't great preparation. We just read up on childbirth together. I didn't feel left out or rejected - I expected to be on the sidelines, as all I could really do was be supportive and help with breathing. The midwife encouraged me to help, but I wouldn't have wanted her to concentrate on me. I did feel like a spare part, but there's nothing anyone could do about that. Dawn stayed in hospital for two nights afterwards; there were strict visiting times, but these allowed us both to rest properly so it wasn't really a problem.

 Verdict: No

Toby Rye Father of Silva, three-and-a-half, and Marlow, one.

I made sure that I was fully included, but I was lucky because I work part-time and was around more. Employers don't acknowledge the need for fathers to take time off to participate in pregnancy. Most fathers can't even make it to the antenatal classes because of work. This ethos filters down through society so that fathers think that the only way in which they can give love to their children is through earning as much as possible. I didn't feel excluded as people respond positively to obvious interest and commitment. The root of this problem is with employers.

 Verdict: Yes

Mark Shepherd Father of Esmé, three-and-a-half, and Eli, 11 months

You have to be a very forward person like me to feel involved with your partner's pregnancies and births. It is an area designed to accommodate women in which men can easily feel out of place; I can see how many men end up thinking that holding their partner's hand is all they can do. When I first went to the hospital with my partner, people only talked to her, so I had to ask questions to be noticed. Letters from health visitors were addressed only to my partner, so I didn't feel part of the process. When I pushed through the barrier, I found that it was not just for women.

 Verdict: No

Jeremy Meeson Father of Charlotte, 15 months

My wife briefed me so that I could take part in decisions and help her when the time came. Some of the NCT classes were during business hours but I got time off to attend. I felt that going to them was 50% to support my wife and 50% preparing myself for the birth. The classes were aimed at both parents and fathers asked questions freely. The midwives were fantastic and I felt comfortable being there. I made useful suggestions to help my wife through labour. I'd have felt pretty pathetic in the delivery room if I didn't know what I was talking about.

 Verdict: No

Graeme Jackson Father of Isabel, 10 weeks

I made sure I got involved from the start. This was the most important event in my entire life and I didn't want to miss anything. I went to some antenatal classes which weren't really for my benefit, but I learned some good relaxation techniques for Clare. Only once did I feel like a spectator - mostly the fathers were treated with as much importance as the mothers. When I arrived at the hospital for the birth, I was stressed out but I understood that all attention had to be on Clare. These days we have to work harder to make relationships last and being there for the birth is a key factor.

 Verdict: No

Tom Beardshaw Father of Cole, three months

There is no real provision for dealing with fathers. Some midwives were fantastic and very accommodating to me and others ignored me. My wife spent four exhausted nights on a ward after a caesarean birth and couldn't even lift our baby. I was with her during the days, but between 8pm and 10am I was kicked out. Every morning my wife and child were very distressed. It was so frustrating because they wouldn't accept my help, so I had to sit around at home. Because fathers have only recently become involved in pregnancy and birth, no one has been trained to deal with them.

 Verdict: Yes

webTitle: Parents: Peter Stanford  wonders at the sacrifices parents make

fields.headline: Home truth
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair says he would consider giving up his job for his children. Peter Stanford wonders at the sacrifices parents make

Special report: Blair's babe
fields.trailText: Tony Blair says he would consider giving up his job for his children. Peter Stanford wonders at the sacrifices parents make
fields.body:
'After all I gave up for you..." It's the rebuke that every parent hopes they won't utter in anger to their offspring: but here's betting most of them will think it. Traditionally it has been women who have made the sacrifices to be there for their children. The most fathers have endured is trading in their prized sports car for a people carrier.

But now Tony Blair has revealed that he would consider giving up being prime minister rather than see his children's lives disrupted.

There is, of course, something of a running joke in British politics about second-rate ministers avoiding impending dismissal with talk of giving up their job in order to concentrate on their family. Yet Blair seems to be talking about something altogether more honourable and intriguing.

Before Gordon Brown gets too excited, it should be stressed that it was only a hint in the prime minister's interview with Reader's Digest that family should come first. Imagine, though, where it could lead: can you see Madonna relinquishing her slot in OK! to look after Lourdes and Rocco?

What you give up for your kids is all about where you draw the line: one friend tells me the point of no return for her would be having to drive her children to school. However good the establishment was, she would not be prepared to sacrifice hours of her time in a traffic jam.

Like many parents, we have moved across London to be in an area where the state schools are (allegedly) better and the gardens larger. Once, in our childless days, we would agonise over our own carefully crafted version of inner-city-interiors chic and wrinkle our noses in distaste at anything flat-packed. Now we have no time to think about such fripperies.

It is not so much that we have consciously given up our erstwhile concerns; rather, that they have given us up through lack of time. And, to be honest, it's fine. I certainly don't resent my children for what seem like small sacrifices.

Indeed, I have learned now to reject most job-related invitations if they impinge on my evenings or weekends. It took time to get there, but at least I've avoided joining those millions who, according to figures released this week by the TUC, do £23bn of unpaid overtime each year, at huge cost to their families, in the hope of gaining advancement.

But then no one is asking me to run the country. How, I wonder, would Blair feel if he chucked it all in for Euan, Nicky, Kathryn and little Leo only to see his dour next-door neighbour do so well that history will see Blair's prime ministership as a brief prelude to 20 years of record-breaking achievements with Brown at the helm?

It will be a difficult choice for Blair, if choice it comes to. Should he leave his mark on history, or should he be prepared to sacrifice that to steer his family's future in the way he would wish it to go? He would know, if he did so, that the only people who might value him for that would be his children.

And, of course, we cannot count on them. We all know couples whose offspring have fled with scarcely a backward glance, or - even worse - with a backward insult. You can't rely on your kids to appreciate what you have done for them.

There again, having children is not an altruistic act. It's essentially a selfish thing, and as parents we occasionally find ourselves calculating our stake in it. My children are four and one, but already I think about becoming a grand- parent. I look forward to it - all the enjoyment of kids without any of the responsibility. It's something I know I am expecting to get back from my children in the future.

As Tony Blair told Reader's Digest, family comes first. Quite where that thought takes him in the future we will all be watching with interest.

webTitle: Parents: having a baby 12 years after the last one

fields.headline: Changing more than nappies
fields.standfirst: Twelve years is a long time in childbearing, as  Louise Chunn  discovered when she had a third baby earlier this year
fields.trailText: Twelve years is a long time in childbearing, as Louise Chunn discovered when she had a third baby earlier this year
fields.body:
Things move quickly these days - but until I had a baby earlier this year I hadn't realised just how quickly. With two children aged 14 and 12, everyone assumed I'd simply be repeating my previous performance. Instead, I find myself feeling like I have become my own tut-tutting mother: "We didn't do it that way in my day."

Getting pregnant, being pregnant, having a baby, looking after a baby, and generally acting the parental part: sometimes subtly, sometimes quite fundamentally, there are times I feel that it's all changed. For the better? Not necessarily.

Some changes are well-publicised: the rise in assisted conception; the advances in genetic screening; the extension of immunisation programmes against childhood diseases - and the fears of what additional problems the vaccines might bring; the latest findings in cot death research; and what Madonna thinks of British maternity hospitals.

The fact that child-bearing and raising make front page news is in itself different from when I started out. Then, having children was a much more low-key, less self-conscious affair.

I had my first two children in the 80s - the so-called style decade. That was me in the John Galliano jacket, with the Conran shop armchairs and the Dualit toaster. But my babies were not privy to such excesses.

When I was expecting my first child I headed straight for the second-hand children's gear shops of west London where I was delighted to find a rather worn brown corduroy carrycot. It was wonderfully multifunctional: it sat on wonky wheels (as a pram), on a wooden stand (as a cot) and strapped in the back seat of the car (as a car seat). And it only set me back £10. Why would I spend more on something that would be needed for such a short time?

Since then the baby gear industry has gone into overdrive. The choice is vast and ever-changing. Just to take a newborn for a walk you are faced with a plethora of options: two-in-one or three-in-one "travel systems", front-facing or rear-facing, traditional pram, all-terrain pushchair. And you are still probably going to want a removable car seat, a Baby Bjorn carrier, and maybe a sling as well. And you'll probably stop using most of that within the first year - a period, according to Prima magazine, when the average parents spend £4,500 on their baby.

Everything costs a packet - a Land Rover all-terrain buggy for example is around £385 - and comes in a bewildering choice of "designer" patterns and colourways, as you might expect if you were purchasing a top-of-the-range BMW. As for second-hand, whether it's because of the scare over a connection between "used" mattresses and cot death, or simply that parents are gaining status from the fashionableness of their baby equipment, it does not seem nearly so common.

That doesn't mean I'm not happy to join in this time around. As a baby-proud new mother, I was delighted to discover Tim Waterstone's newest enterprise, Daisy and Tom, an easy-pram-access shop on King's Road in Chelsea selling great clothes, good books, educational toys, an edited selection of prams and strollers, and even a kiddie haircutting business. In my day, Mothercare was almost top of the range.

But the huge increase in things to buy - from sterilising units to magazines to the glories of Baby Gap - is only part of the change. There is a different mindset now. From the very point of conception, parents of the 21st century expect to be in control more than I ever did. A large number of women know the gender of the baby they are carrying. They write plans for the kind of birth they want and follow books that outline the rate at which their child should be developing. Yes, there were childcare manuals in 1986, but not many, and you felt rather foolish resorting to them. Now it is a market worth around £6m a year in this country.

The starkest current example of the quest for control is the runaway success of The Contented Little Baby Book by Gina Ford, a maternity nurse. If you follow its schedules - which start off with an hour-by-hour regime for a two-week-old baby - you will be able to set your watch by your newborn, and sleep through the night by at least four months. I suspect its popularity may be partially a result of modern parents witnessing the ghastliness of kids born to their libertarian predecessors, but it is spookily like the four-hourly feeds and leave 'em to cry disciplinarian tactics that my mother remembers guiltily from the 50s.

Information is key for the contemporary parent. Everything has a name and every problem has a solution; they daren't sit back or wait and see. Having absorbed the antenatal classes, books, TV programmes, magazines and newspapers, first-time mothers reach the labour ward knowing almost as much as their consultants about the most arcane bits of obstetrics.

The perfectly normal struggle to get a baby to sleep at night is now called "sleep training" for which there are a number of regimes to try. A London housewife called Annabel Karmel has become a baby food guru by writing books about what is basically mashing up fruit and vegetables. There's very little sense of doing what comes naturally - of having any kind of instinctive feeling for what might suit your particular child.

The plethora of research into child development has thrown up fascinating stuff - I never knew small babies were drawn to black and white images for example - but has also created new terrors that are treated with deadly seriousness. When, for example, a new mattress was delivered this week, the cot death warning boldly stated: "Do not let your baby get too hot (or too cold)."

Back in the 80s I blithely placed my babies on their tummies to sleep; routinely fed them delicious sloppy scrambled egg, and peanut butter sandwiches. While pregnant I drank coffee, wine, gin, whatever, and ate liver, unpasteurized cheese and seafood. I gave up breast feeding after a couple of months. I had never even heard of separation anxiety - and my older children seem fairly normal. Nowadays all of that is verboten , mostly because some report or other has shown them to be "bad for baby".

But, for all that feeling of proscription and orthodoxy, I have welcomed some changes in modern motherhood with open arms. Seeing celebs like Catherine Zeta-Jones, Madonna and Patsy Kensit with pregnant bellies stylishly bedecked did make me feel less drab when pregnant. Women are no longer routinely weighed at their antenatal class appointments. Antenatal yoga classes are a wonderful invention. Epidurals are readily available and much more acceptable among all types of women, even the staunch NCT-types. From the hospital to the local health centre, there is much more information and help on offer (even if half of it freaks you out). Fathers are generally more involved, and welcomed.

There is also one area in which progress has really changed the life of a new mother, and that is nappy technology. I am not talking about the change from cotton nappies to disposable - that did happen between my mother's childbearing years and my own - but the change from barely adequate disposable to miraculously absorbent, totally reliable disposal. And the best thing of all: some frighteningly efficient gel hidden within the depths of these lightweight new inventions means that there is simply no nappy rash anymore. Praise be to God and chuck out the Sudocreme.

As a baby-proud new mother, I was delighted to discover Tim Waterstone's newest enterprise, Daisy and Tom, an easy-pram-access shop on King's Road in Chelsea selling great clothes, good books, educational toys, an edited selection of prams and strollers, and even a kiddie haircutting business. In my day, Mothercare was almost top of the range. But the huge increase in things to buy - from sterilising units to magazines to the glories of Baby Gap - is only part of the change. There is a different mindset now. From the very point of conception, parents of the 21st century expect to be in control more than I ever did. A large number of women know the gender of the baby they are carrying. They write plans for the kind of birth they want and follow books that outline the rate at which their child should be developing. Yes, there were childcare manuals in 1986, but not many, and you felt rather foolish resorting to them. Now it is a market worth around £6m a year in this country. The starkest current example of the quest for control is the runaway success of The Contented Little Baby Book by Gina Ford, a maternity nurse. If you follow its schedules - which start off with an hour-by-hour regime for a two-week-old baby - you will be able to set your watch by your newborn, and sleep through the night by at least four months. I suspect its popularity may be partially a result of modern parents witnessing the ghastliness of kids born to their libertarian predecessors, but it is spookily like the four-hourly feeds and leave 'em to cry disciplinarian tactics that my mother remembers guiltily from the 50s. Information is key for the contemporary parent. Everything has a name and every problem has a solution; they daren't sit back or wait and see. Having absorbed the antenatal classes, books, TV programmes, magazines and newspapers, first-time mothers reach the labour ward knowing almost as much as their consultants about the most arcane bits of obstetrics. The perfectly normal struggle to get a baby to sleep at night is now called "sleep training" for which there are a number of regimes to try. A London housewife called Annabel Karmel has become a baby food guru by writing books about what is basically mashing up fruit and vegetables. There's very little sense of doing what comes naturally - of having any kind of instinctive feeling for what might suit your particular child. The plethora of research into child development has thrown up fascinating stuff - I never knew small babies were drawn to black and white images for example - but has also created new terrors that are treated with deadly seriousness. When, for example, a new mattress was delivered this week, the cot death warning boldly stated: "Do not let your baby get too hot (or too cold)." Back in the 80s I blithely placed my babies on their tummies to sleep; routinely fed them delicious sloppy scrambled egg, and peanut butter sandwiches. While pregnant I drank coffee, wine, gin, whatever, and ate liver, unpasteurized cheese and seafood. I gave up breast feeding after a couple of months. I had never even heard of separation anxiety - and my older children seem fairly normal. Nowadays all of that is verboten , mostly because some report or other has shown them to be "bad for baby". But, for all that feeling of proscription and orthodoxy, I have welcomed some changes in modern motherhood with open arms. Seeing celebs like Catherine Zeta-Jones, Madonna and Patsy Kensit with pregnant bellies stylishly bedecked did make me feel less drab when pregnant. Women are no longer routinely weighed at their antenatal class appointments. Antenatal yoga classes are a wonderful invention. Epidurals are readily available and much more acceptable among all types of women, even the staunch NCT-types. From the hospital to the local health centre, there is much more information and help on offer (even if half of it freaks you out). Fathers are generally more involved, and welcomed. There is also one area in which progress has really changed the life of a new mother, and that is nappy technology. I am not talking about the change from cotton nappies to disposable - that did happen between my mother's childbearing years and my own - but the change from barely adequate disposable to miraculously absorbent, totally reliable disposal. And the best thing of all: some frighteningly efficient gel hidden within the depths of these lightweight new inventions means that there is simply no nappy rash anymore. Praise be to God and chuck out the Sudocreme.

fields.headline: Divided loyalties
fields.standfirst: By the year 2010 there will be more step-families than birth families in the UK. So why are they still getting a raw deal, asks  Debbie Humphry
fields.trailText: By the year 2010 there will be more step-families than birth families in the UK. So why are they still getting a raw deal, asks Debbie Humphry
fields.body:
Mention step-families to anyone and they've got a story. A story like the one from my friend John, who was seven when he went to live with his mum and her new man. He hated the man, who told him to take all the toys out of the living room and keep them in his bedroom. His mum laughed with the man now, when she used to laugh with the child. Eventually the guy couldn't cope with the hostile child, so a year later John went to live with his auntie.

Or another story from a woman I barely know, who told me about her 16-year-old daughter's crush on a 17-year-old boy. He's her new stepbrother, sleeping every other weekend in the room next door to hers.

By the year 2010 there will be more step-families than birth families in the UK. Already 650 children see their parents go through a separation every day, and 40% of remarriages involve live-in stepchildren. Altogether, the number of children in step-families has more than tripled from three-quarters of a million in 1991 to 2.5m today.

Blending two families, with their own allegiances, habits, in-jokes, shared trust and history, is not easy and it takes time. You may think it easier when one of the parents is childless, but no. "Step-parents often compare themselves with immigrants who have been plunked down in a strange country to face an unfamiliar language and culture," says Genevieve Clapp, a family and divorce mediator. They frequently feel guilty because they don't instantly love their stepchildren, yet at the same time hurt when these children are unresponsive to their attempts at bonding.

Then along comes a baby of their own, and the equation is all changed again - with lots of potential for jealousy, guilt and resentment besides. Affection bonds, say Clapp, are "generally never as strong between a stepparent and stepchildren as they are between a biological parent and child".

Step-families have their work cut out: experts recommend them to move slowly, limiting or staggering change. The older the children are, the more resistant they usually are to a new family and the longer the adjustment period. Expectations often create difficulties: the last thing a step-family needs is pressure to reconstitute as a "proper family", adding more frustration, disappointment and guilt to an already emotionally fragile situation.

But expectations abound, and what the research shows is that step-families are getting a raw deal. Researchers from the Institute of Psychiatry in London and the University of Bristol followed the lives of 10,000 women aged between 16 and 40 who had a baby in 1991. They found that four in 10 of the couples who had their first child together, but also lived with children from previous relationships, were not together 21 months after the birth - compared with only 5% of families where everyone was related to each other. Other figures show that 40% of remarriages end in divorce within four years.

The support group Parentline Plus reports that four out of five calls concern step-families, and the majority of fathers lose touch with their children after the mother's remarriage. Children from step-families are likely to leave home earlier, at around 16 or 17, a recent Scottish survey revealed. With stepfathers outnumbering step mothers seven to one, the most common problem is discipline, with the men relying on an archetypal masculine role within the family.

And this does not work. As Maureen Freely says in her book The Parent Trap: "For a man who associates dominance with masculinity, the constraints of step-parenthood are likely to be problematic... Many have little or no experience of children, and nowhere to go for information or support." And then there are the most shocking figures of all, such as the fact that a step-parent is 100 times more likely than a birth parent to lethally batter their stepchild.

Stepmothers have their own problems. Bruno Bettelheim, a psychoanalyst, suggests the usefulness of the wicked stepmother myth in fairy tales is that it can help young children separate the good, kind mother from the scary, cross mother until a later stage when they are emotionally able to integrate these conflicting aspects and emotions.

But the world has changed and it is all too easy for children to become stunted in their development by imposing the good-bad mother model on to their birth and stepmother; scapegoating the stepmother in an attempt to protect their feelings about the birth mother. (Interestingly stepmother families are the most likely to fail.) For the children involved, the cost of a parent's remarriage may be high. They may have to move home and school; share their bedroom with a stranger; give up the status of older sibling. Children suffer anxiety and loss. The parent's time, attention and love must now be shared, so the step-parent is usually an unwelcome intruder. In the period since their parents' separation, children may have been confidants to their single parents or played other adult roles in the home. Many feel betrayed, replaced or insulted by the expectation that they become children again.

The fantasy that parents will get back together is irretrievably lost; for some it's like going through the divorce all over again. Data from a national US survey at Princeton University reveals that children develop more emotional problems after parental remarriage than they do after parental separation.

Children can be traumatised by split loyalties, especially when attempts are made to freeze out the other biological parent. "Children in blended families need more psychological space than do other children so they can move between families without feeling torn by loyalty conflicts," Clapp says. "Many mental-health professionals feel that loose family relationships are more conducive to smooth step-family functioning than close-knit relationships - with the exception of the couple relationship, which should always be very strong."

With a strong couple partnership the children are unable to exploit rifts in an attempt to drive the impostor out. And it makes it safer for the kids to make a commitment to the family, secure it won't end in divorce.

So is it time to rethink the whole framework of what we persist in calling "family life"? In many ways we are returning to the extended family and it is time to embrace something more chaotic, complex and unstable. Nothing is average any more: forget all about 2.2 kids. Children from step-families have step-siblings and half-siblings, some whom they live with, some who they see at weekends and some they may never have met. There can be up to eight grandparents. The boundaries of where the family stops and starts in unclear.

But step-family life is not all trauma and gloom. The very act of remarriage in itself is a positive one, full of optimism and love. The new family form can provide an extended base of support. Studies on step-parents that stay together report a high level of satisfaction with their marriages. Those that are successful are creating something positive out of a broken home and the pain of the past. They're great role models.

As Joanna Trollope found when researching her novel Other People's Children, now adapted as a TV series on BBC1: "What became hearteningly plain was that a step-family can be positive and enriching for all its members because it has mended something important that got broken - it mended a broken home."

What we need to do is start talking. Pilot schemes in schools have run step-family workshops and the children are talking. They're dying to talk, they need to talk. And so do we, as a society: in the legal arena, the media, in therapy, at work, at home.

Step-families themselves must talk. Clapp says that "many well-functioning step-families report that weekly family meetings are an indispensable part of their lives while trying to blend their two contingents". She suggests two containers for comments - one for problems and one for appreciations.

My friend, who had five different homes as a child - with his mum and dad, then his mum and that man, then his auntie, then his grandma and then his dad - came out of it all OK. His parents sat him down and explained what was going on with every change - as best they could. We need to listen to the experiences of people such as John and others who have or are in step-families: we need to listen, and we need to learn.

fields.headline: The iX merger
fields.standfirst: As the iX merger between the London Stock Exchange (LSE) and Frankfurt's Deutsche Boerse collapses, Mark Tran explains the ructions in the world's money markets
fields.trailText: As the iX merger between the London Stock Exchange (LSE) and Frankfurt's Deutsche Boerse collapses, Mark Tranexplains the ructions in the world's money markets.
fields.body:
What was the idea behind iX?
The idea behind iX is that share trading would be most efficient if it were concentrated in several large traditional exchanges - perhaps eventually one - that could deliver economies of scale and flexible markets.

Why did the deal collapse?
There were reservations from the start. The most important questions were how London and Frankfurt would reconcile their different regulatory regimes and how the two clearing and settlement systems operate together in the short term. Moreover, many LSE shareholders thought they were getting the raw end of the deal as the 50/50 merger does not take account LSE assets, such as surplus cash and property worth an estimated £267m.

Did someone threaten to scupper the deal?
OM Gruppen, the group, which owns and operates the Stockholm exchange made an offer for the LSE. A global leader in developing the software programmes for electronic exchanges, it built the platform for the International Securities Exchange, the first electronic options exchange in the US, which started in May. The system can handle about 5,000 transactions per second, according to OM. The Swedish company argues that stock markets will cease to be national institutions and become just an icon on a trader's screen - accessible anywhere, any time.

Why did OM want to take over the London Stock Exchange?
It thought it could run the exchange more efficiently and produce greater returns using the latest technology. It says it made its £800m bid for the LSE - the first hostile takeover attempt of a bourse - not simply to stop the merger between London and Frankfurt, but to provide an alternative. The LSE and Frankfurt, Europe's two largest exchanges, had decided to merge in May.

Why are exchanges so keen to merge?
Stock markets are looking for combinations around the world as investors demand lower costs and easier access to other markets. In response to such pressures, the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels exchanges are combining to create Euronext. The Swiss Exchange and Tradepoint Financial Networks of the UK are setting up an electronic market. And Madrid and Milan were considering joining LSE-DB. Nasdaq, the exchange focusing on technology companies, was planning to join iX as a joint venture partner, with a view to a full merger. The overriding goal of these combinations is to attract investors by making it cheaper to buy and sell shares.

Would investors have seen a fall in transaction fees under iX?
Supposedly, the merger would have made it cheaper to buy and sell shares. The biggest cost in trading shares across borders comes in the form of transaction fees charged by companies that settle trades after they have been agreed.

How expensive is it currently for British investors to buy foreign shares?
According to Don Cruickshank, the LSE's chairman, a British investor buying shares in a German telecommunications company currently pays an average of £100 in transaction charges, compared with £1-15 for trading a UK stock. The quickest way to lower costs is merging settlement companies. But there were no plans to bring together the settlement firms in the iX deal - Crest in London and Clearstream in Frankfurt (which is 50% owned by the Deutsche Boerse). Both were reluctant to give up their independence.

Deutsche Boerse
OM Group
London Stock Exchange

webTitle: Chinese party officials in landmark sleaze trial

fields.headline: Chinese party officials in landmark sleaze trial
fields.trailText: Leading Communist party officials went on trial today accused of smuggling and taking bribes in China's biggest corruption case in 51 years of communist rule.
fields.body:
Leading Communist party officials went on trial today accused of smuggling and taking bribes in China's biggest corruption case in 51 years of communist rule.

Court officials said hearings began in five cities in the south-eastern province of Fujian. But they were unable to supply more information, as most court staff were banned from the courtrooms, while judges and prosecutors kept tight control on the proceedings.

The secrecy illustrates the potental damage the scandal could cause to China's leaders. President Jiang Zemin, who heads the 61m-member Communist party, has declared clean government a goal of his rule.

Among the unspecified number of defendants were the general manager of the Fujian-based Orient Group, Cao Xinghai, who went on trial in Putian. Court officials refused to specify the charges against Mr Cao.

The Fujian scandal has tainted members of the elite ruling circle, among them one of Mr Jiang's proteges. The government has used occasional prosecutions of high-level officials to show the party's determination to end rampant corruption that has eroded support for communist rule.

State-run newspapers today reported that the deputy head of transport for Sichuan province had received a death sentence for taking bribes and amassing wealth beyond his means. The court sentenced Zheng Daofang's wife and son to 15 and 12 years in prison and seized property worth £140,000.

By contrast, no mention was made of the Fujian trials. At the centre of the trial is the bustling port of Xiamen and the Yuanhua Group. The company allegedly smuggled oil, cars and cigarettes through Xiamen and other ports and spent lavishly to buy official protection or silence.

Cao Xinghai of the Xiamen-based Orient group and the 11 other defendants provided Yuanhua with certificates, seals and other "conveniences" allowing it to engage illegally in import-export trade, the Hong Kong Commercial Daily reported. In return, Mr Cao and the others were said to have received £1.6m a year in rents and payoffs.

Officials have called Yuanhua's web of smuggling and payoffs China's biggest corruption scandal. Homg Kong media have claimed that about £6.2bn worth of goods and money changed hands illegally.

Among those arrested in the investigation were the national police force's immigration chief, the provincial deputy police chief, two deputy Xiamen party secretaries, a vice mayor, the city's customs head and the official in charge of Xiamen's undercover police. Because of the number of defendants, the cases are being heard in courts in Xiamen, Fuzhou, Quanzhou, Putian and Zhangzhou.

fields.headline: Out of balance
fields.standfirst: Unpaid care work is a bar to full employment, argues  Jane Lewis
fields.trailText: Unpaid care work is a bar to full employment, argues Jane Lewis.
fields.body:
It is widely accepted that the welfare settlement after the second world war was based on the assumption that there would be stable families and full-time work for men. Given the increased insecurity and flexibility of the labour market, the growth in women's employment and the rapid pace of family change in the late 20th century - divorce up threefold and the proportion of children born outside marriage up fourfold in one generation - it is no wonder that the principles underpinning the welfare state are in question.

The old welfare model assumed that men would be breadwinners and women would take responsibility for the care of young and old in the family. While the model never wholly accorded with reality, it acted as a powerful prescriptive model reflected in public and private law.

At the beginning of the 21st century, government's assumptions have changed dramatically. The drive of "welfare-to-work", begun by the Conservatives and developed by Labour, assumes an "adult worker model family". All adults who are capable will be in the labour market. But how far does the model fit social reality? And what about unpaid care work?

The old male breadwinner model has certainly eroded. According to the general household survey, 81% of men and 62% of women aged 16-64 were economically active in 1975. By 1996, this figure was 70% for both sexes. Married women are just as likely to be employed as non-married women. In contrast, men's labour market participation has fallen; indeed the contribution by men to family income fell more than 10 percentage points between 1979-81 and 1989-91.

However, the vast majority of the post-1945 increase in married women's employment is accounted for by part-time employment in the service of the welfare state (much of it low paid); 44% of women workers were part-time in 1998 and almost a quarter work "short part-time" - under 20 hours a week. So while families supported by a single male breadwinner are now undoubtedly in a minority, the division of paid work in dual earner households takes a variety of forms. Dual career couples are in fact relatively rare. The norm in Britain, as in many European countries, has become the more or less one-and-a-half-earner household.

Government has been stressing the obligation to engage in paid work. But there is also an obligation to care and these two things must be balanced. The Labour government has not neglected the issue of care work. The national child care strategy is a first for a country that has consistently occupied a place near the bottom of the European child care league. The child care tax credit embodied in the working families tax credit scheme is also an important initiative in a country where the issue of reconciling work and family responsibilities has been historically ignored. Further, there is the new strategy for carers and proposals for second pension credits for those caring for young children or adults.

However, all these positive initiatives are relatively small alongside the major programmes to get people into employment: the New Deal and the working families tax credit. There is no coherent policy on the care of dependants, young and old, to match the policy on paid work.

The problems of moving towards a full adult worker model are fourfold. Unpaid care work is unequally shared between men and women, which has substantial implications for women's position in the labour market. Given the lack of good quality affordable care in the formal sector (public and private), many women have little option but to continue to provide it. A significant number of female carers want to feel that it is "right" to prioritise care over paid work. Women's low pay, especially in care-related jobs, means that full individualisation is hard to achieve, on the basis of long part-time or even full-time work.

Just as policy assumptions based on a male breadwinner model disadvantaged women in particular, so assumptions based on an adult worker model are likely to do so. This does not mean that policy should swing back to a more traditional family model. Given the likelihood that all adults will have to rely more on self-provision in future, not least in respect of pensions, it is important that as many adults as possible are able to earn. However, it is important that government pays attention to the context for the promotion of a new adult worker model. Without access to affordable, good quality support for care, women in particular may resist the injunction to enter the labour market on more than a short part-time basis. Or they will enter and risk adverse effects on dependants.

There are two examples of a long-standing adult worker model. In the US, the obligation to enter the labour market is embedded in a residual welfare system that often borders on the punitive. The US has extremely high rates of child poverty and high rates of juvenile imprisonment. Sweden and Denmark also operate an adult worker model, supported by an extensive range of care entitlements in respect of children and older people. Child poverty rates are the lowest in OECD countries and juvenile crime rates low.

These contrasting experiences show there are policy choices. Taking care work seriously should be a priority and we need to share unpaid work between men and women more fairly. Policies that would promote the sharing of care include: paid parental leave, with a portion set aside for use by men (the so-called "daddy month" in the Scandinavian countries; a right to a shorter working day (as in Scandinavia) or a shorter working week (as in the Netherlands) for parents with small children; and greater provision of good quality child care and elder care.

On the care side, jobs need to attract a living wage and certainly pay no less than working the checkout at Tesco; and the social security system needs to take account of people's lifetime labour market experience, particularly in respect of pension guarantees, so that carers do not suffer further consequences of low-paid work and periods with no pay.

It is difficult to work full time and care for dependants. Something has to give. Policy-makers are concerned about the family and about parenting. They are concerned about work. It is strange that they are so little preoccupied with policies on care.

 Jane Lewis is Barnett professor of social policy at Oxford University. This is based on a paper she presented on Monday as part of the Social Policy Association's contribution to the British Association for the Advancement of Science's festival of science in London
