fields.headline: Grow with the flow
fields.standfirst: The Thames festival is a symbol of the river's regeneration for those who live in it and those who live by it.  John Vidal reports
fields.trailText: The Thames festival is a symbol of the river's regeneration for those who live in it and those who live by it. John Vidal reports.
fields.body:
A short stroll down one stretch of the tidal reach of the Thames last Wednesday was illuminating. On the north foreshore, below the Royal Hospital in Chelsea, an eclectic group of people were gathered. Here, feet in the rising waters, keenly debating the need for land reform and the problems of the global and local environment, were the Queen's Asian chaplain, the bishop of Southwark, a Buddhist monk, a businessman, a journalist (myself), an artist, a Brazilian human rights worker, a baroness, a general and landowner, an MEP, a refugee, and the head of Amnesty International.

With ducks looking on and the tide rushing in, the gathering of these 12 "archetypal" characters - under the auspices of the String of Pearls festival - was billed as the "people's" riposte to the UN social summit in New York. It was, most participants agreed, bizarre, symbolic and uplifting.

The same day, a few miles downstream at Westminster, the Dome and its Thames-side were the centre of another furious political row, the doomed attraction having asked for - and been given- another £47m to keep going. The government claimed the project was now about regenerating the local riverside community.

At least one member of the Thames Waterside Regeneration project said the Dome had brought no discernible benefits for local employment or disadvantaged people, although Jenny Bates, of Friends of the Earth in Greenwich, disagreed, having seen marginal local returns of more than £750m.

But the most optimistic view of the Thames that day came a mile downstream from Westminster, at Coin Street, the great and only central London community success story of the past 30 years. There, preparations were being made for this Sunday's Thames festival, the annual burgeoning celebration of the river and the communities who depend on it, love it or just happen to live by it. Christophe, the undisputed king pyro-artiste, following his millennium firework display on the Eiffel Tower, was in deep discussion with festival organiser Adrian Evans about how to light up the river and the city from 30 barges.

Evans, in turn, was explaining that thousands of people, helped by artists and people from more than 78 community projects, would be walking in procession by lantern light in wild, river-related fancy costumes over Blackfriars bridge and down the embankment.

Evans was upbeat. "Most Londoners have a place for the Thames in their heart," he said. "The river is becoming common ground. It now links London, rather than divides it. There is more respect for it by developers. It's as if we are revaluing the Thames for its 'riverness'. You can walk virtually the length." The Tate Modern, the London Eye, the millennium village at the Dome, the pagoda, the wibbly-wobbly bridge, and a bunch of new riverside developments allow access and have attracted people back.

Much of this new awareness of the river as a resource for the metropolis and a source of pride, Evans and others believe, has been inspired by the great clean-up of the river. Human diversity has been found to improve when the ecology prospers. When the Thames was dead, Londoners turned away from it. Now that it is biologically alive people are flocking back like the birds. You can spot anglers, sailors, eel fishers, school parties and bishops nowadays on the river almost as easily as waders and ducks.

It is a major reversal. Only 40 years ago a report to the Natural History Museum stated that there were no resident fish populations between Kew and Gravesend. Investment in sewage treatment cleaned up the water. Fish and wildlife began to reappear in the 1960s and the invertebrates in the 1970s. The small mammals still haven't made it, but there are 114 species of fish.

But the river, like the Thames festival and the new cultural awareness of the river, is desperately fragile, say both the Environment Agency and Evans. The history of the Thames is for developments to extend further into the river foreshore, so further destroying its ecology. There are still few habitats along the tidal Thames. Only 1% of the tidal river now has a natural river bank and less than a third of its length has sloping, artificial banks. The rest is wall, limiting access, and increasing the river flow.

Equally, the history of the Thames shows that human creativity has been snuffed out. Witness the depressing new housing developments along the river beyond Tower Bridge, uniformly elitist, mostly inaccessible, unwelcoming enclaves for people with several cars and huge mortgages.

Yet improving the river, socially and ecologically, is a priority for many. The Thames has more interested par ties, watchdogs and "owners" than almost any other stretch of Britain. But, as river lovers point out, many institutions, councils, companies and others who want to promote access and sensitive development, are relatively powerless.

An anonymous, undated article on the web sums up the situation. It is clearly written by someone who loves the river and knows its politics. The river, it says, is for sale. The Environment Agency, it accurately surmises, is under-staffed and under-funded, and only has power to advise. However much it may seek the agreement of developers to respect the the ecology of the river, it has weak legal status and only marginal influence on decision-makers. Many developers and councils are impervious to local opinion, have no environmental concerns, and "pay lip-service to envi ronmental assessment, if at all". Land owners such as Thames Water, British Gas and Railtrack, it accurately points out, still bear no statutory responsibility for ecological or social good practice. The Port of London Authority is not a statutory consultee in the planning process and as such does not see all river plans and cannot legally influence them.

Equally, English Heritage has no remit to protect the Thames, and English Nature has very limited powers that relate only to statutory protected species. They have no overall powers regarding the cumulative impact of piecemeal development.

Meanwhile, says Jenny Bates, of Friends of the Earth, the powerful London business community is trying to build three river crossings which would increase the traffic and intensify development in down stream riverside boroughs. "Business argues that the river is a barrier and that London must work in a 360-degree circle," she says. "They should, surely, be trying to meet local needs."

So what would improve the situation? The anonymous author wants statutory protection of the Thames as a green corridor and a wildlife super-highway, and a change of planning emphasis away from the presumption to build. Educating planning officers, MPs and decision-makers is vital and there should be better cycle routes and more shore access.

It will do for now. In the meantime, the Thames festival may have to wait a while before it can fully celebrate the return of the river to Londoners.

 The Thames festival at the Oxo tower starts at midday on Sunday. Admission free

fields.headline: Action station
fields.standfirst: The new, digital Community Channel launches next week, dedicated to promoting the work of charities.  Celia Locks reports
fields.trailText: The new, digital Community Channel launches next week, dedicated to promoting the work of charities. Celia Locks reports.
fields.body:
The two representatives of WaterAid look a little nervous as they wait in film studios off London's Carnaby Street to brave the cameras for the Community Channel, which will arrive on Britain's digital airways next Monday. Unsurprisingly, the two are full of goodwill. "It's a good idea and a great opportunity for the voluntary sector," says Andrew Cook, WaterAid's head of fundraising, thus winning appreciative grins all round.

Filming is in full swing to make ready the channel for its launch date when, at 1pm, viewers with Sky Digital will be able to tap 655 into their remote controls and see films, information and appeals for help from charities and voluntary organisations. They will be watching, according to its own slogan, "the channel that turns viewing into doing".

It is the brainchild (and non profit-making wholly owned subsidiary) of the charity, the Media Trust, and its founder and chief executive, Caroline Diehl. She says: "It seemed crazy that there wasn't a place that people could come to in the digital mix to get dedicated information about the work of charities and NGOs. I knew there were a lot of fascinating films around about the work of charities that normally never see the light of day. I thought let's see if we can find a place to show the work of these organisations, and also to start to experiment a bit with format and content, that sort of thing".

It has taken two and a half years to get it from the drawing board to its launch. En route it has netted £900,000 of lottery funding, £250,000 from the Home Office's active community unit, and £130,000 from the Department for International Development. Sky Digital is providing free air-time of up to 12 hours a day for three years - a commitment worth £1.8m - but lean finances mean that the channel is taking up only three hours a day.

Gerry Melling, its managing director and a former editor of GMTV, the breakfast station, says: "No sane person would try to put a channel up and on the air for under about £5m really. What's being attempted here is at the edges of what is possible."

As the channel will be promoting charities, it will have a tele-shopping licence. "The ITC quite rightly says 'hang on, there's a difference between editorial and promotional [programmes]. You are not setting out as independent film-makers to make a film about the Cancer Research Campaign, you are actively promoting the campaign'," says Melling. "Yes, we are, unashamedly because no one else is, and you cannot do that on a normal channel."

Viewers will see information about charities displayed on a yellow strip down the left of the screen, and might be asked to volunteer, or buy charity crafts or training videos, or goods or services for third parties (such as a water pump for a village in Africa). "You can transact with the channel if you want but that's not really the point," says Melling. "The point is to explain what the charities do, and to actively seek your involvement, if you are interested... It's got to survive by having interesting filming." No one would watch a channel that kept actively asking for something, he acknowledges.

"It's early days - the initiative is very good and the concept is fascinating but I think my worry is how many years before we are really going to get it off the ground in terms of viewers being there to know about it and also to use it from time to time."

"I think they need to monitor the concept of the channel as it stands, to see if it's really taking off and working, and I hope it will," says Gray.

Joe Korner, communications manager of the Royal National Institute for the Blind (RNIB), says that his key issue is whom the audience will be. "I think at the moment their thinking is that it's the voluntary sector," he says. "The challenge for charities such as the RNIB is to get out beyond the people who already know about us to the general public."

How the channel will be funded in future has yet to be resolved. "We will ensure that commercial interests don't take over the channel and we will fight to the end to make this a charity-only channel that is run on a not for profit basis," says Melling. The channel is applying for more government funding and consultancy KPMG is doing models for future financing. One possibility, says Diehl, is to charge bigger charities for airtime (which is now free) or bring in corporate sponsors. Another is to take a cut of the price of goods bought. "We've gone down the tele-shopping route, partly as a wheeze to show the charities' own films, but also because we know that charity trading is the one area of charities that's growing at the moment," she says. "We think that the concept of a charity shop, an electronic charity shop - television and web - is an exciting one. The shopping channels are doing pretty well in the digital world."

Diehl rates the channel's survival chances after three years as pretty high. "We are the first in there and that's always useful. There's an enormous amount of backing for it from across government, across the corporate sector, from the charities. I think that because it has such a USP - unique selling point - that in itself will keep the momentum going and attract a range of support, both cash and in kind.

fields.headline: Seven up for it
fields.standfirst: While London flourishes, England's other big cities feel they are losing out on investment.  Peter Hetherington  reports
fields.trailText: While London flourishes, England's other big cities feel they are losing out on investment. Peter Hetherington reports.
fields.body:
Britain's big provincial cities are on the march. Tired of being overshadowed by a booming London, pushed towards the bottom of the EU wealth league by continental giants and lectured about an urban renaissance in parts of the US, they have told government ministers to give them a break.

They want a level playing field to help them compete with the capital, and a fair share of national resources to encourage the new knowledge industries. Most of all, they want the kind of low tax, or "no tax", incentives which have kick-started regeneration across the Atlantic.

On one level, England's seven big cities, which begin their second annual conference in Sheffield tomorrow under the core cities umbrella, can claim great success in revitalising centres which seemed to have passed the point of no return. They are becoming fasionable again. People are trickling back to once-seedy, depopulated areas, where converted warehouses - the ubiquitous lofts - and new flats provide attractive homes. Restaurants, bars and cafe societies have sprouted everywhere. High streets are reviving as city retailers slowly win the battle against out-of-town shopping centres.

But on another level, these great cities - Birmingham, Bristol, Leeds, Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle upon Tyne and Sheffield - remain polarised between rich and poor. Expensive houses - flats selling for up to £1m in Manchester and Leeds - lie cheek by jowl with empty, modernised council estates and older terraces. Boarded up and vandalised, they have become the ultimate symbol of urban decay.

Inevitably, the flight from the city followed the collapse of manufacturing and the redirection of new companies to greenfield sites. Since 1981, according to a report by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, the 20 biggest cities have lost over 500,000 jobs, while the rest of Britain gained 1.7m.

No amount of new building fuelled by the public purse in the 80s and 90s, from concert halls to convention centres, huge arenas to flashy hotels, can hide the fact that England's cities are a pale shadow of European rivals, let alone London. In terms of wealth, the city region of Antwerp has a GDP above the EU average at 37%. Greater London is 40 points above while the old West Midlands county, around Birmingham, is 7% below - slightly better than Greater Manchester.

Research for the core cities group shows that "knowledge based" businesses, which largely determine Britain's international competitiveness, choose to locate in London and the south-east. In mainland Europe, they are more widely scattered, helping to drive city economies up the wealth league.

Part of the problem is government- directed, and influenced, research funding. Central London universities alone attract 26% of all research contract income, compared with 24% going to the universities in and around the seven core cities.

But there are more deep-seated problems which an urban taskforce attempted to address last year as a prelude to a much-delayed urban white paper, due next month. The taskforce suggested a network of urban areas in which business taxes would be cut to encourage new investment. Although the Treasury was not keen, overtures have been made to Gordon Brown, the chancellor, about giving cities more "fiscal flexibility", perhaps in the form of special zones free of council tax. Significantly, Brown's chief economic adviser, Ed Balls, is a speaker at the conference.

But Brown and Balls, inspired by the "can do" culture in some US cities, may find that a conference contribution from a leading American urbanist and writer, Roberta Gratz, will jar with their perception of the US revival. Gratz believes that big government, pushing through big city redevelopment programmes, is a recipe for disaster. She argues that the success "stadium cities", from Baltimore to Cleveland, is illusory. "The idea that new stadiums and convention centres can revive cities is totally erroneous," she says. "All they do is bring tourists. They don't bring life back to the city."

Her views are underlined by America's Congress for New Urbanism, a burgeoning movement for "smart growth" embracing architects, planners, developers and a few politicians. Shelley Poticha, its executive director, says numerous programmes designed to revive cities have failed because they have sought a "magic bullet" in the form of massive public investment. While this attracted some private investment, it failed to "employ the jobless, house middle-class families, or revive schools".

Gratz says that the best neighbourhood have not been torn down and rebuilt. Rather, they incorporate new flats and businesses, in old factories and warehouses, instead of big, publicly-funded projects.

To be successful, she argues, regeneration schemes must be community-led and not imposed from the top by government. "The role of the government must be as nurturer not initiator and funder," she warns.

But city government certainly does have a role. Town halls in the US attract private developers with long, tax-free periods and a range of other incentives. In turn, businesses join cities in funding street improvements, light rail systems - in the case of Portland, Oregon - and new river walks and reborn city centres, such as Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

It couldn't happen in England - yet. But Gratz is optimistic. She says: "The thing that strikes me most about your cities is that you have not totally bulldozed your downtown areas the way we did. There is a lot going for you."

 Peter Hetherington is the Guardian's regional affairs correspondent

fields.headline: Keys to the kingdom
fields.standfirst: Joyce Headley has one of the toughest jobs in Brixton prison - helping inmates get work on the outside
fields.trailText: Joyce Headley has one of the toughest jobs in Brixton prison - helping inmates get work on the outside.
fields.body:
When Joyce Headley came to Birmingham from Jamaica with her parents and sisters in the early 60s, she dreamed of the snow and of becoming a nurse. She never imagined she'd end up in prison.

But here she is working in one of Britain's most troubled prisons, the notorious HMP Brixton in south London, which has witnessed nine suicides and gone through three governors in the last four years.

Headley's job, part of a scheme set up by the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders four years ago, is to help inmates find an alternative means to a life of crime after their release - the key ingredients to which are employment and housing.

She became interested in community work via a playscheme for disadvantaged children where she worked as a volunteer in her 20s. "I lived in a very deprived part of north London, in Stoke Newington, and so I saw what happened to people who had nothing - they turned to wrong-doing," says Brixton's lone rehabilitator. (Her planned nursing career ended after three years, and she confesses: "I couldn't bear being around sickness and laying people out. It was an environment where I had no control or influence.")

After becoming a teacher's helper, Headley went to teacher training college (deferred after she decided her children needed her at home more) and then joined another ex-offender charity before landing a post in a "jobclub" at Pentonville prison, north London.

Now aged "50-ish", she spends five days a week in Brixton, talking to men about their futures. "I can help because I'm not judgmental," says Headley, whose own family struggled to make ends meet on arrival in Britain. "You can't just write people off as bad because they've broken the law, especially if you are in a position to make a difference. Anyway, it's in everyone's interest to try to reduce repeat offending. I always tell the employers I invite into Brixton for seminars: 'It could be your mum or a member of your family who is burgled or attacked next.' Everyone deserves a chance at a job."

Around 40 to 50 inmates visit Headley each week. "I emphasise to the men they must always try to be rational and positive, and not behave like a victim," says Headley. This comes from her own experience bringing up a family in a white-dominated society. When she found her children bleaching their faces to be whiter, she told them they could be whatever they wanted to be if they wanted it enough. Still, she knows it's hard for inmates to retain a positive attitude to life on the outside when there is so much discrimination against them. Without a job to go to, she knows some 65% are likely to re-offend.

Ken Hawley, a governor at Brixton with responsibility for inmate activities, says of Headley's work: "It's about making the prison accessible to those who can help and advise inmates. Joyce is a great organiser, persuasive, and approachable. That, combined with her in-depth knowledge and understanding of inmates' problems, means she is really superb for this role."

Most of the inmates Headley sees are from disadvantaged backgrounds - many with inevitable literacy and drug problems. "They're at the bottom of the pile, with no way out," she says. "And with no job, they revert to underhand dealings.

"I want to break down the barrier of employer prejudice, which is largely fear. By getting employers such as Iceland and Kwik-Fit into the custodial setting, I try to break down the myths about ex-offenders. When they see a prisoner in an education class, they often see someone who really is trying to do the best with what they've got instead of someone who is just bad."

Headley has found jobs locally for several inmates with Iceland, which has pledged to expand the practice to employing ex-offenders nationally, and Kwik-Fit has also expressed interest. She says: "There's nothing more satisfying than bumping into an inmate on the outside, which I often do, and finding they are working, or have set up a small business."

She helps inmates to find accommodation, sorts out welfare benefits and gets those in financial difficulty on to debt management pro grammes. She listens to their emotional and domestic problems, and is the only civilian ever to win the prison's "employee of the month" award of its 500 staff, 200 of whom are officers.

One inmate who acts informally as a "buddy" to other prisoners says: "Men can have a confrontational attitude to other men, whereas they are kinder and gentler to a woman. Joyce is gold. Having her comforting presence and care is so important in a hostile environment like this, it's like water in a desert."

"When I walk around, there's such a high black population here I think: 'God, why are you all here? Wouldn't you rather be somewhere else?' None of them did it, of course - they were all fitted up - but quite a few of them do want to change their lives, and with the right help and support they could actually do it. Sadly, there isn't usually a budget for this work in prisons."

The government has just announced funding for careers and housing advice for seven prisons, including Pentonville, to be run along similar lines to Brixton's Nacro project.

Jobs can't get much tougher than persuading employers to take on men who've been in prison. Headley attributes her success to her parents, but not in a totally positive way. She says: "They were terribly Victorian and strict, but they were in a strange country and were unquestioning of those in authority, such as doctors and teachers, in a way that only immigrants are. I was determined not to be the same. I don't have tunnel vision. I'm more challenging and exploratory, and I'm grateful to them for that."

fields.headline: The creation principle
fields.standfirst: Is it possible to remake natural habitats destroyed by man?
fields.trailText: Is it possible to remake natural habitats destroyed by man?
fields.body:
Seen from the train: a skein of wild geese in ragged arrowhead formation flying over urban Merseyside. It is a fitting symbol for a gathering of environmentalists from around the world who met in Liverpool last week. What matters for both the geese and the environmentalists is the subject of the gathering - ecological restoration: the return of indigenous, historical eco-systems.

Ecological restoration is still relatively new. It began with the development of techniques to recreate prairies in America and has developed to encompass all kinds of damaged habitats around the world. The Society for Ecological Restoration (SER) was formed in the 80s to bring together environmental scientists, activists, philosophers, campaigners and artists and this was its first international conference in Europe.

Under discussion were projects like restoring rainforest, coal-mining spoil in New Zealand, wetland habitats and dry woodland edges caused by forestry in Florida. Restoration is not just about wild lands either. Marc Matsil works for the city of New York parks department. He manages 30,000 acres in the city which never sleeps.

"We raised $70m from companies which polluted the rivers and used the money for restoration," he said. "We now plant 50,000 trees a year and have restored 500 acres of saltmarsh in two years. We're using wild saltmarsh plants to break down petroleum hydrocarbons to reduce water pollution," says Matsil. "The bottom line is: everyone must be accountable and everyone must pay."

But how does ecological restoration differ from traditional conservation? According to Mike Oxford, principal ecologist for north Somerset and chair of SER UK, "Conservation has traditionally been defensive, trying to protect habitats and species from damaging human action, but ecological restoration is offensive and aims to create more habitats in 10 years' time than we have now."

The difference between restoration in the UK and the US is that here environmentalists are largely dealing with a cultural landscape, shaped by people over millennia, whereas in the US and Australia there is still a desire to restore "wilderness" or at least some semblance of what the landscape was like before the arrival of Europeans.

But this search for what is called ecological integrity, is highly problematic. There are mutterings from some environmentalists about producing fake landscapes. Although the renowned Australian environmental scientist Richard Hobbs recognises the desire to turn back the ecological clock to a less complicated time, he believes the past is no guide to the future and that nature is dynamic.

Some environmentalists, such as US philosopher Andrew Light, see the potential of ecological restoration to encourage and empower local democratic participation towards an "environmental citizenship".

Eric Higgs, associate professor of anthropology at Alberta University, Canada, who is the incoming chair of SER international, says: "Ecological restoration is about ecological and cultural rejuvenation and can rebuild social relationships".

Higgs cites a restoration project in British Columbia where the Songhees first nation people had an island from which they harvested wild bulbs, a practice which had been abandoned for 50 years. The restoration project returned the bulbs to the island and the Songhees resumed the harvest. "This is where ecological restoration also restores the cultural ecosystem," says Higgs.

Dennis Martinez, of the Indigenous People Restoration Network, is a campaigner for cultural restoration issues in North America. He is concerned that many ecological restoration projects have very western frames of reference and are more concerned with products than with process. "We need to develop the more cyclical processes, understood by traditional local knowledge, which create conditions of a renewability between people and nature," says Martinez.

It is a fitting symbol for a gathering of environmentalists from around the world who met in Liverpool last week. fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: With one voice | A serious omission | Spin a protest
fields.body:
With one voice
Sir John Krebs, chairman of the government's Food Standards Agency, made few new friends recently when his organisation's report claimed there was little nutritional difference between organic and conventionally-grown food. Dr Patrick Wall, chief executive of his Irish counterpart agency, the Food Safety Authority of Ireland, has now reminded people to buy organic food because it is "more environmentally friendly, more wholesome, and better produced". He then dismissed Sir John's views as "extreme".

A serious omission
When the Environment Agency held its annual meeting last week in east London, it bravely chose the theme of environmental equality and social exclusion. Problem: there was not one black, and only one Asian face in the invited audience of more than 100 people. Still, the chairman Sir John Harman did recognise the racy lives of those there: he advised the audience at the start of his opening address to "turn off your vibrators - they interfere with the video camera". Which reminds Eco Soundings' correspondent of a similar comment once made to MPs by the Commons' retiring speaker Betty Boothroyd. Another nice touch was that at the junction of heavily polluted Commercial Road and Whitechapel Road near the conference centre was a road sign directing motorists to a car park for all committed environmentalists attending the meeting.

Spin a protest
In the countdown to November's crucial climate summit in The Hague, a coalition of leading global environmental groups has launched the first international web-based initiative to give people a voice in demanding a halt to global warming. It intends to collect 10m names in just three months. So far, three weeks in and with 10 to go, almost 800,000 people have signed up. The address is www.climatevoice.org.

It's a blast
Considering the good people of Las Vegas used to go into the hills above the gambling capital in the 50s and hold atomic BBQs whilst watching the atmospheric atomic tests 60 miles away, it comes as a surprise to find the council of the gambling town passing a resolution declaring Las Vegas a nuclear free zone. Yucca Mountain, on the other hand, the only site the US government has studied for a huge high-level nuclear waste repository is just down the road.

fields.headline: Muzzling the watchdog
fields.standfirst: Donna  Covey, director of the Association of Community Health Councils for England and Wales
fields.trailText: Donna Covey: The self-congratulatory fanfare announcing the launch of the national plan for the NHS has overshadowed real concerns about accountability.
fields.body:
The self-congratulatory fanfare announcing the launch of the national plan for the NHS has overshadowed real concerns about accountability, raised by the plan's proposed abolition of community health councils (CHCs).

Established in 1974, CHCs have provided a national network of independent health watchdogs. The plan fragments part of their work across a number of new bodies and gives no indication as to who will perform which of their functions. There are also significant worries about how effective and independent the proposed replacement structures will be.

Patient advocates will be based in trusts. They will perform a role combining meeting and greeting in hospital reception areas and troubleshooting to deliver on the spot solutions to patients' problems. They will "steer" patients towards the complaints system "where necessary", rather than play the proactive role that CHCs have in supporting patients and families when things go wrong.

Advocates based in trusts will struggle to be truly independent and, more damaging, will not be seen as independent by patients. Hospital-based advocates have a role, and effective schemes already exist. But they are a complement to the independent support and advice provided by CHCs - not an alternative.

The plan also introduces trust-based patient forums and advisory committees to act as sounding boards at health authority level. The right of CHCs to refer contested, substantial variations in local health services to the secretary of state will be given to local authority scrutiny committees.

Our CHCs are independent. They have statutory rights. They draw on individual complaints work, regular visits and public involvement to inform their scrutiny role. Without a co-ordinating body, there is a real danger that separating the scrutinising function from the monitoring and complaints work will mean that broader patterns that emerge from individual complaints, or from problems in service provision, will never come to light.

To be an effective public voice in the NHS, the new system will need to be independent and integrated. It will need specialist support staff, clear statutory rights to act on behalf of local communities and mechanisms for exchanging best practice across the country. This sounds very familar. Renamed, reconstituted and given a higher public profile, CHCs could be transformed into new bodies that could rise from the ashes of the national plan's ill thought out proposals to deliver real patient power.

webTitle: Prisons fail to get to grips with inside jobs

fields.headline: Prisons fail to get to grips with inside jobs
fields.standfirst: Penal reform group accuses jails of not helping inmates get the skills needed to find work and break the cycle of crime
fields.trailText: Penal reform group accuses jails of not helping inmates get the skills needed to find work and break the cycle of crime.
fields.body:
Disgraced former Conservative minister Jonathan Aitken last week spoke with pride of his jobs in prison. Keeping "the cleanest bogs in the gaff" was one achievement. Putting washers on roofing screws, at a rate of 1p per 100, was another. If you were good at it, Aitken said, you could make 10p a session.

A report today, however, says jails are failing to meet prisoners' employment needs. Far from helping them to develop skills that could keep them out of crime after release, prison workshops are providing limited, unskilled jobs in poor conditions and are sending the message that crime pays.

Fewer than 9,000 of the 65,000 prison population are employed in workshops, according to latest figures. They mainly produce items such as tables, chairs and clothing for other prisons, although more than £10m a year is made from external contracts. The average wage is £7 a week, compared to £2.50 for "unemployed" prisoners.

Such pocket money wages - used to buy tobacco, toiletries, sweets, stamps and phone cards at high street prices - risks making prisoners feel exploited and provides little incentive to work, says the report by the Howard League for Penal Reform. Although it stops short of recommending more appropriate rates, it quotes one prisoner as saying: "If prisoners were paid £30, £40 or £50 a week, they could save and help support their families while in prison and on their release."

The report comes three years after the chief inspector of prisons criticised lack of employment for prisoners, since when numbers in work have fallen from a peak of almost 10,000 in 1998-99. The days of sewing mailbags may be over, but little of the work that does exist is said to offer much in the way of challenge or variety.

The report, Rehabilitating Work, says there needs to be a greater emphasis on developing aptitudes for the modern jobs market. There should be training in skills such as computing and communications, new standards for recruitment of workshops staff, a record of achievement for every prisoner and help with preparing a CV, job-hunting and handling interviews.

Above all, the report concludes, the government should match its commitment to full employment in the community with a similar promise for prisoners. And there should be a presumption of employment for a full working day: at present, workshops commonly close for lunch from 11.30am to 2pm.

Frances Crook, director of the Howard League, says: "Time after time, research has demonstrated a strong link between crime and unemployment. Improving prisoners' job prospects is crucial to breaking the cycle of offending. We have found too many prisoners doing dull, pointless work for a miserly wage - work which does nothing to boost that person's chances of getting back on their feet after release."

 Rehabilitating Work is available at £5 from the Howard League, 1 Ardleigh Road, London N1 4HS

fields.headline: Making the best of value judgments
fields.standfirst: Councils escape censure as the local government inspectorate publishes its first reports
fields.trailText: Councils escape censure as the local government inspectorate publishes its first reports
fields.body:
Councils in England and Wales this week enter the brave new world of rigorous monitoring with publication of the first reports from the new local government inspectorate. They face the ultimate sanction of Whitehall intervention if performance in particular sectors - from refuse collection to housing management and libraries - is considered consistently below par. But fears that under-performing authorities face Ofsted-style "naming and shaming" have been allayed by the woman who will lead the new regime.

Unlike the abrasive Chris Woodhead, who leads Ofsted, Wendy Thomson is a friend - albeit a critical one - of town and county hall. "Some authorities are excellent, doing an excellent job," says the head of the new inspectorate in the audit commission, whose 300-strong army has begun fanning out across England and Wales. "Others are complacent, keeping their head down. Then there are a few bad ones that everybody hears about."

Thomson, credited with turning around the east London borough of Newham during her three years as its chief executive, this week produced her first seven reports on council services, ranging from housing management in Sutton, south London, to waste management in Dudley and building control in Sefton on Merseyside.

Not the most earth-shattering services, she agrees - but vitally important to people in local communities. "Local government may not always be sexy, but it spends £70bn annually of public money . . . so there is an important question to be asked about how you get the best value without jeopardising local democracy and the need for local areas to have their own way of doing things."

In the end, the seven councils acquitted themselves well with "two star" ratings in a four-tier system, ranging from three stars for excel lence to one (could do better) and none (bad).

Thomson, a Canadian who came to Britain 18 years ago for a PhD in social administration, is young enough to have wider ambition - as a future head, perhaps, of a super-inspectorate embracing Ofsted and the Department of Health's social services inspectorate (SSI)? The two services, after all, account for the bulk of council spending. Naturally, as a good diplomat, that's something she declines to discuss, although her inspectorate has to work closely with both Ofsted and the SSI.

But as someone with experience of Ofsted during her time at Newham ("I know how focusing it can become - we were one of the ones that came off well," she laughs dryly) the chief inspector is clearly determined to offer more of a carrot than a stick. Her inspectors, while mainly "the best [local government] service managers we can find" also come from the private sector. Significantly, she is also recruiting from charities - "because we want that community perspective".

She says: "I know if you want to change organisations you've got to have some pretty strong ambition and vision to do that and you've got to both support people and also challenge the existing ways and try to get that balance." It's about "how to work with people to drive up improvement".

That should please the Local Government Association which - with a critical eye on Ofsted - warned last week that inspection must deliver long-term improvement "not just short-term headlines".

As part of the new regime, councils will have to produce a best value performance plan for a particular service every year, while looking at all services in detail every five years. Best value, underpinned by a bewildering array of performance indicators, is all about continuous improvement through community involvement.

Thomson, while firmly committed to strong local government, is keen to make it clear she can be tough as well as tender.

As a final sanction, she will issue authorities running failing services with a tight time-frame to improve them. And if that fails to work, she can make a recommendation to the government which can order another authority, or service provider, to take over.

But for now, that powder is being kept very dry.

webTitle: Losing the ability to sign your name

fields.headline: Stripped of power
fields.standfirst: When illness prevents you from signing your name, life can become very difficult.  Conrad Hodgkinson on his partner's battle against enforced dependency
fields.trailText: When illness prevents you from signing your name, life can become very difficult. Conrad Hodgkinson on his partner's battle against enforced dependency.
fields.body:
Christine Barton can't write. She has a PhD, is an equal opportunities consultant, a trustee of various charities, and received an MBE in the recent birthday honours list, but she can't write.

Christine is my partner. It's not that she doesn't know how to write. She knows how to write rather well; words are part of what she does. But she has multiple sclerosis and there are a lot of physical things she can't do. Not being able to hold a pen might seem trivial in comparison with not being able to stand, walk or feed yourself, but the consequences are far-reaching.

Strictly, it's not writing that's the problem; with a personal computer and the latest voice recognition software, Christine can put words on screen almost as fast as she can think. The problem - and it's a big one - centres on that untidy, personal and often illegible squiggle which we all take for granted: our signature. Without the means to identify ourselves, we don't exist. And Christine can't sign her name.

Because multiple sclerosis is a progressive condition, what begins as a minor inconvenience can rapidly become a major problem. As writing became more difficult, I started signing her cheques. Holding a pen at the very top produced a good approximation of her shaky signature, and no one ever queried it. Yes, I know it's illegal, but it's the best we could think of at the time.

At first, I think we both accepted that further limitation of Christine's independence was inevitable. By now, she couldn't sign cheques, use her credit or Switch card, sign a passport or an insurance application, and I didn't even want to think about what might happen if we ever wanted to sell the house.

Early solutions tended to accept the limitations. Christine arranged for a credit card to be issued in the name of her personal assistant. This solved the immediate problem of shopping, but wasn't a lot of use when she was out with friends or her daughter. A joint bank account was suggested, but Christine has always steadfastly resisted this - something to do with my belief that, if God had wanted us to keep our accounts in credit, he wouldn't have created overdrafts. However, I did become an authorised signatory on her account.

People made helpful suggestions. Could Christine hold a pen in her mouth? Could a pen be put between her fingers and someone else move her hand?

All were well intentioned, but the reality was that Christine's capacity to make her own decisions, to control her own life, was being progressively eroded. She was being penalised for not being able to write her name. But who is at fault - Christine, or a system which insists that she must?

Attempting to open a new building society account was the catalyst: "Certainly, madam, but we need a signature - someone will need to take power of attorney."

Power of attorney involves handing over responsibility to someone else. Christine was not prepared to allow this. It would reduce her independence still further and reinforces the tacit link in the public mind between physical impairment and mental incapacity. It's the "does she take sugar?" syndrome, and it's unacceptable. Physical impairment need not and should not equal dependency. But it frequently does and that's why the system needs challenging. Christine started with the building society. It took a number of phone calls and some intensive consultation between the local branch and head office, but she now has her Nationwide Isa. The forms were filled in by the branch manager without signature and she can withdraw money from the local branch at any time, again without signature. The Inland Revenue was quite sniffy about the arrangement, claiming that there had to be a signature for the account to qualify for tax exemption, but Nationwide managed to overcome these objections.

Next, the bank. Christine had been in protracted negotiations with Barclays because, being unable to sign, she could not use either her Barclaycard or Switch card in shops. Initially, they were unable to come up with any solution, so it was time to try a different tack.

Christine is a trustee of Voluntary Action Sheffield. Its legal adviser suggested she try a number of routes, one of which eventually led to the British Bankers' Association in London - and this turned out to be the key. Joanna Elson, a director of the association, wrote to Christine enclosing a leaflet advising banks and customers what can be done when customers find it difficult to sign. This leaflet contained the crucial statement: "English law recognises as a valid signature not only one written manually by the signatory, but also one appropriately embossed using a facsimile signature stamp."

Christine now has a facsimile stamp. This was easily obtained by taking a copy of an old signature to a legal stationer who produced the stamp. Barclays supplied new Switch and Barclaycards which were embossed with the stamp (slight prob lem: on the cards, the ink from the stamp took three days to dry). A copy of the signature has also been scanned into her computer so that she can use this on letters.

Now, when Christine goes shopping, she pays. Whoever accompanies her will use the stamp on her behalf, but she is in control. No retailer has ever questioned this method of payment. In fact, the reaction of most has been: "What a good idea!"

There has been one challenge, almost inevitably from the legal profession. Christine was until recently a trustee of Age Concern Sheffield and, in this capacity, agreed to sign a lease for office accommodation. The solicitors handling the transaction initially refused to accept the facsimile, suggesting that the advice from the British Bankers' Association counted only as custom and practice and was not in fact law. Back to the association and Elson was able to supply the necessary references and precedents. Lease stamped!

Christine is angered and frustrated by the barriers which society creates. "You stop being a real person with the same rights as everyone else," she says. "The more impaired you become the less rights you seem to have and this is not how it should be."

But there's always another battle. Christine's passport needs renewing. The Passport Agency will accept a facsimile stamp on passport applications, but only with a covering statement from the applicant's GP. Do the rest of us need a statement from our GPs? No? Oh dear, here we go again.

Right impression

Nobody knows how many people cannot sign their name, or have problems doing so, but it is likely to number many thousands. As well as people with degenerative illnesses, there are those with severe physical and learning disabilities who may never have had a signature.

The British Bankers' Association leaflet, which prompted Christine Barton to find a solution in the form of her own "rubber stamp" (pictured left), says some banks will provide templates to help position a signature on a cheque book or credit card, or will issue cards with a photograph of the user.

fields.bodyText: Christine Barton can't write. She has a PhD, is an equal opportunities consultant, a trustee of various charities, and received an MBE in the recent birthday honours list, but she can't write. Christine is my partner. It's not that she doesn't know how to write. She knows how to write rather well; words are part of what she does. But she has multiple sclerosis and there are a lot of physical things she can't do. Not being able to hold a pen might seem trivial in comparison with not being able to stand, walk or feed yourself, but the consequences are far-reaching. Strictly, it's not writing that's the problem; with a personal computer and the latest voice recognition software, Christine can put words on screen almost as fast as she can think. The problem - and it's a big one - centres on that untidy, personal and often illegible squiggle which we all take for granted: our signature. Without the means to identify ourselves, we don't exist. And Christine can't sign her name. Because multiple sclerosis is a progressive condition, what begins as a minor inconvenience can rapidly become a major problem. As writing became more difficult, I started signing her cheques. Holding a pen at the very top produced a good approximation of her shaky signature, and no one ever queried it. Yes, I know it's illegal, but it's the best we could think of at the time. At first, I think we both accepted that further limitation of Christine's independence was inevitable. By now, she couldn't sign cheques, use her credit or Switch card, sign a passport or an insurance application, and I didn't even want to think about what might happen if we ever wanted to sell the house. Early solutions tended to accept the limitations. Christine arranged for a credit card to be issued in the name of her personal assistant. This solved the immediate problem of shopping, but wasn't a lot of use when she was out with friends or her daughter. A joint bank account was suggested, but Christine has always steadfastly resisted this - something to do with my belief that, if God had wanted us to keep our accounts in credit, he wouldn't have created overdrafts. However, I did become an authorised signatory on her account. People made helpful suggestions. Could Christine hold a pen in her mouth? Could a pen be put between her fingers and someone else move her hand? All were well intentioned, but the reality was that Christine's capacity to make her own decisions, to control her own life, was being progressively eroded. She was being penalised for not being able to write her name. But who is at fault - Christine, or a system which insists that she must? Attempting to open a new building society account was the catalyst: "Certainly, madam, but we need a signature - someone will need to take power of attorney." Power of attorney involves handing over responsibility to someone else. Christine was not prepared to allow this. It would reduce her independence still further and reinforces the tacit link in the public mind between physical impairment and mental incapacity. It's the "does she take sugar?" syndrome, and it's unacceptable. Physical impairment need not and should not equal dependency. But it frequently does and that's why the system needs challenging. Christine started with the building society. It took a number of phone calls and some intensive consultation between the local branch and head office, but she now has her Nationwide Isa. The forms were filled in by the branch manager without signature and she can withdraw money from the local branch at any time, again without signature. The Inland Revenue was quite sniffy about the arrangement, claiming that there had to be a signature for the account to qualify for tax exemption, but Nationwide managed to overcome these objections. Next, the bank. Christine had been in protracted negotiations with Barclays because, being unable to sign, she could not use either her Barclaycard or Switch card in shops. Initially, they were unable to come up with any solution, so it was time to try a different tack. Christine is a trustee of Voluntary Action Sheffield. Its legal adviser suggested she try a number of routes, one of which eventually led to the British Bankers' Association in London - and this turned out to be the key. Joanna Elson, a director of the association, wrote to Christine enclosing a leaflet advising banks and customers what can be done when customers find it difficult to sign. This leaflet contained the crucial statement: "English law recognises as a valid signature not only one written manually by the signatory, but also one appropriately embossed using a facsimile signature stamp." Christine now has a facsimile stamp. This was easily obtained by taking a copy of an old signature to a legal stationer who produced the stamp. Barclays supplied new Switch and Barclaycards which were embossed with the stamp (slight prob lem: on the cards, the ink from the stamp took three days to dry). A copy of the signature has also been scanned into her computer so that she can use this on letters. Now, when Christine goes shopping, she pays. Whoever accompanies her will use the stamp on her behalf, but she is in control. No retailer has ever questioned this method of payment. In fact, the reaction of most has been: "What a good idea!" There has been one challenge, almost inevitably from the legal profession. Christine was until recently a trustee of Age Concern Sheffield and, in this capacity, agreed to sign a lease for office accommodation. The solicitors handling the transaction initially refused to accept the facsimile, suggesting that the advice from the British Bankers' Association counted only as custom and practice and was not in fact law. Back to the association and Elson was able to supply the necessary references and precedents. Lease stamped! Christine is angered and frustrated by the barriers which society creates. "You stop being a real person with the same rights as everyone else," she says. "The more impaired you become the less rights you seem to have and this is not how it should be." But there's always another battle. Christine's passport needs renewing. The Passport Agency will accept a facsimile stamp on passport applications, but only with a covering statement from the applicant's GP. Do the rest of us need a statement from our GPs? No? Oh dear, here we go again. Right impression Nobody knows how many people cannot sign their name, or have problems doing so, but it is likely to number many thousands. fields.headline: Patients claim priority
fields.standfirst: People are ever more ready to challenge medical decisions
fields.trailText: People are ever more ready to challenge medical decisions.
fields.body:
It is a given that people are becoming increasingly consumerist in their attitude towards public services. But a report today shows just how fast that change is happening.

Two years ago, health management expert Chris Ham was co- author of a study of the "Child B" affair which had brought into sharp focus the issue of healthcare rationing. The study suggested that confrontations between health authorities and patients and their families could be avoided if there was direct communication between the two sides when decisions about treatment were being made.

In today's report, however, Ham and a co-author admit communication is no panacea. They say people are so ready to challenge what "experts" tell them, and to go to the courts or the media, that authorities must act on several fronts to defend a decision to restrict treatment.

There "may be limits to which face-to-face discussions and the opportunity to receive a direct explanation of the basis of decisions will succeed in compensating for outcomes other than those sought unless there is scope for those decisions to be changed", say Ham, director of the health services man agement centre at Birmingham University, and Shirley McIver, senior fellow at the centre.

Their conclusion comes after assessing five anonymised cases. Ham and McIver interviewed the chief executives or directors of public health of each authority, using a checklist of questions arising from the Child B case in which 11-year-old Jaymee Bowen was denied further treatment for terminal leukaemia.

The patients and/or their families in the five cases were not interviewed lest the experience distress them or further damage relations with the authorities.

One case involved a four-year-old with a brain tumour refused further treatment; the second concerned a woman with advanced ovarian cancer whose doctor wanted to prescribe Taxol, then an unproven drug; the third involved a patient wanting a sex change operation; the fourth centred on a young man with multiple sclerosis whose clinician wanted to prescribe beta interferon; and the fifth concerned an eight-year-old with haemophilia whose doctor wished to switch her to an expensive and less well proven treatment to reduce the side effects.

All but the last case attracted media attention, putting the authorities under more pressure, and two went to court. Few decision-makers were confident of their ground. The public health director in the first case told the authors: "Even in discussion with my own family there was disagreement."

The report, Contested Decisions, published by the King's Fund health policy institute, says the issues raised by the cases should be of particular interest to primary care groups. "With GPs increasingly involved in commissioning services, there is the potential for conflict between their role as agents and advocates for individual patients on the one hand, and as commissioners of services to improve the health of the community on the other."

Ham, who is seconded to the Department of Health, says: "There will be times when [the NHS] has to refuse a medical treatment because its potential benefits do not match its costs to the NHS or the risk to the patient. Making those decisions is fraught with difficulty, but there are ways of improving the ways in which they are made."

 Contested Decisions is available at £10.99 from the King's Fund bookshop on 020-7307 2591

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: The drain strain
fields.body:
The drain strain

The brain drain of voluntary sector executives to the civil service (Headhunted, September 6) does indeed reflect Whitehall's acknowledgement of the wealth of talent and experience that resides in the sector.

But it does more.It also reflects the impact of the skills and knowledge gaps created by civil service restructuring and "delayering" of recent years and by the current constant turnover in membership of departmental teams.

Paul Convery rightly points to the need for government to underpin organisations from which it has recruited top talent. What better way to do this than by revisiting the issue of dwindling core funding for the voluntary sector? Its gradual disappearance is responsible for a quiet crisis which may soon render the sector unable to nurture the talent from which the government now benefits. Civil society will be all the poorer for it.
Eva Lloyd
Chief executive
National Early Years Network

Funding fiasco

Timothy Hornsby says that the National Lottery Charities Board (NLCB) does not have the money to "fund forever the ongoing costs of organisations" (letters, August 30). Of course it does, if it chooses to use its funds in that way. Instead, it chooses to fund mostly for very limited periods of time.

It would be really interesting to know what possible good will come of allowing projects to start, or to expand, and then taking the funds away three years later, especially when the funds being applied by the NLCB are so large that there is no hope of the projects being picked up by other funders. Not only is it difficult to see what good is being done, for many of us in the sector these stop/go policies appear to be positively harmful.

I would like to see an organisation like the NLCB looking at its policies in terms of their actual effect on the beneficiaries, and on the structure of the voluntary sector, rather than sticking with the nonsensical idea that the most useful way to spend money is to spread it around liberally.

It might also be useful if the NLCB looked at the government code of good practice on funding.

Carole Howells
Director
Newcastle Council for Voluntary Service

Housing realities

It would be a great shame if the debate over the future ownership of Glasgow council housing (Out of stock, September 6) were to rest on the assumption that only housing associations can borrow against rental income.

It is quite clear that with minimal changes to central government accounting rules - within EU and international criteria - Glasgow council could, by means of a local housing corporation (not company), borrow in the same way as any housing association and therefore retain control.

There may be democratic arguments for transfer of housing stock, but these need to be differentiated from false economic ones.
Martin Earl
London

There is no question that the battle over whether council housing in Glasgow should, in effect, be privatised is one which will have an impact throughout Britain. Soothing talk of mutuality and social ownership, together with the poor state of much council housing, have been used to push through privatisations in other areas.

Before Labour councillors anywhere go down the road of privatisation, however, they need to ask themselves: if councils cannot provide cheap, well-run and maintained housing for those who can't afford to buy their own homes, then what exactly are they and local councils for?

Keith Flett
Haringey Against Privatisation
London

Give and take

Diana Grimes (letters, September 6) is wrong to punish cancer researchers just because their fundraisers have to be paid.

Fundraisers do a dirty job but bring millions to the coffers of their employing charities. Without them, the charity would die - if for no other reason than someone else's fund-raiser would soon seduce its donors into switching loyalties.

If £70,000 is what is needed to buy a top-grade head of fundraising, then it is money well spent.

This is the same reasoning that keeps capitalists paying their running-dog/fat-cat directors huge salaries. And it reflects the fact that "charity" is an industry almost like the manufacture of, say, automotive parts. The difference is that parts' quality can be measured objectively whereas that of charity has to be taken largely on trust.

My advice to Ms Grimes is to keep giving. She might consider not sending her donations in the form of responses to mailshots, as such donations may be "skimmed" of fundraising commissions before reaching the target charity. (This is not the case with Oxfam and charities of similar good standing.)

Lionel Shapiro
 London

A land not fit for heroes

I happened to read Bob Holman's moving account of his wartime childhood (A world set on fire, August 23) the same day I visited the Spitfire summer exhibition at the Imperial War Museum.

I could not but reflect how badly we have let down some of those heroic "ordinary" people Holman describes, who more than rose to the occasion in 1940.

Many of them are now frail and alone, receiving indifferent care at best, in nursing homes that are privately run for profit.

It is ironic that they almost certainly were offered a better cup of tea in an air-raid shelter than they might be served today.

Sheila Millington
Weybridge
Surrey

fields.headline: Earthly delight
fields.standfirst: Woodland tribute to 'green' bishop
fields.trailText: Woodland tribute to 'green' bishop
fields.body:
Bishops may be accustomed to having community centres and schools named after them, but not woodland. In a first for a senior Church of England cleric, the Bishop Alan Chesters Wood has been opened on former grazing land in the village of Croston, Lancashire. It has been named after the current Bishop of Blackburn, who unveiled it last week.

The two-acre wood, surrounded by flat marshland, was planted last autumn and is designed to be a haven for wildlife next to St Michael and All Angels church. "I have been concerned about the environment for quite a lot of my life," says the Rt Rev Chesters, "particularly about trees and tree cover."

The bishop, who is closely involved with the Countryside Agency, hopes to set a trend. He would like to see the wood encourage other churches to create their own wildlife havens.

Canon Robert Brunswick, rector of St Michael and All Angels, says the church council wanted to create something of lasting value for the local community. "The land was grazed before, but the farmer retired last year so we felt it was the opportune moment to use the land in a different way."

webTitle: Hague aims to gag Tory activists

fields.headline: Hague aims to gag Tory activists
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague is planning to stifle dissent at the Conservative conference next month by excluding constituency motions from debate and confining party activists to a single vote during their week in Bournemouth.
fields.body:
William Hague is planning to stifle dissent at the Conservative conference next month by excluding constituency motions from debate and confining party activists to a single vote during their week in Bournemouth.

What party officials yesterday said would bring a "fresh and dynamic" approach to the conference, expected to be the last before the general election, will include what the Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, called a series of "fringe events organised centrally" - virtually a contradiction in terms.

The official fringe will include a "keep the pound" rally attended by Mr Hague, a "countryside fair" and a "save the union" rally - all at times that clash with the traditional conference fringe, where party dissidents of left and right usually challenge the leadership line.

Mr Ancram and his colleagues denied any intention to stiffle debate. Mr Hague's leadership had seen unprecedented levels of grassroots consultation, Mr Ancram said.

This consultation would culminate in a ballot this month on the new policy statement, Believing in Britain. There would be little point in a vote on policy shortly before a con ference in which votes could be taken on "old-fashioned motions submitted five months before" by party activists, he explained.

The one vote that will be allowed is on the "balloted motion", the emergency topic chosen for debate by delegates, usually on an issue embarrassing to the government.

Mr Hague will wind up the conference on Thursday afternoon as usual, but he will take part in a question and answer session on Tuesday morning - much as Tony Blair now does - albeit with questions notified to the conference organisers to help make it more TV-friendly, officials said.

fields.headline: Standard & Poor downgrades Interpublic
fields.trailText: Interpublic's expansion plans received a blow today when a major US credit agency downgraded the advertising group's rating.
fields.body:
Interpublic's expansion plans received a blow today when a major US credit agency downgraded the advertising group's rating.

Standard & Poor's revised its rating from positive to stable, citing the impact of payments for recent acquisitions.

Interpublic, which owns the McCann-Erickson and Lowe Lintas ad networks, has this year spent about $450m (£321m) in cash on the acquisition of several small companies. The group also took on a $180m (£129m) debt when it bought NFO Worldwide.

S&P said it expected Interpublic to continue to make strategic acquisitions in the short term, but it did not anticipate any major acquisitions financed with debt. It added that the company's new rating reflected the uncertain impact of the merger of the Lowe Group and Ammirati Puris Lintas.

fields.headline: ASA rules on free web access deals
fields.trailText: September 13: The ASA has warned ISPs they cannot claim to offer free access to the web if any part of their service carries a charge, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Advertising Standards Authority has warned internet service providers they cannot claim to offer free access to the web if any part of their service carries a charge.

The ASA has upheld complaints about a BT SurfTime national press and poster campaign, ruling that it was misleading.

The ASA said it received a complaint from AOL Bertelsmann that the tariffs shown in the BT ads implied misleadingly that both were available from all ISPs, and another complaint from a member of the public about the non-availability of SurfTime to existing BT internet customers.

A mail-shot for NTL's free ISP, ntlworld, attracted 167 complaints after applicants had to wait several months for the service.

fields.headline: IBM launches £107m e-business ad campaign
fields.trailText: IBM has launched its largest e-business advertising campaign to date, with plans to spend £107m globally.
fields.body:
IBM has launched its largest e-business advertising campaign to date, with plans to spend $150m (£107m) globally.

For the first time, IBM e-business ads will hit prime-time slots in the UK, appearing on ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5.

The campaign, which uses the strapline "It's a different kind of world. You need a different kind of software", targets business and technology decision-makers.

The ads feature actor Avery Brooks - best-known for his role as captain Benjamin Sisko in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine - and focus on his observations about how the world is changing dramatically.

The campaign is running simultaneously in the US, France, Italy and Germany.

You need a different kind of software", targets business and technology decision-makers. The ads feature actor Avery Brooks - best-known for his role as captain Benjamin Sisko in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine - and focus on his observations about how the world is changing dramatically. The campaign is running simultaneously in the US, France, Italy and Germany.

fields.headline: Enfield gives BSkyB biggest audience share for two years
fields.trailText: BSkyB has caused shock waves with the news that its new Harry Enfield series attracted a 4.7% share of the total TV audience on Monday night. Claire Cozens reports.
fields.body:
BSkyB has caused shock waves in the industry with the news that its new Harry Enfield series attracted a 4.7% share of the total TV audience on Monday night.

Unofficial ratings suggest the show attracted 891,000 viewers, giving Sky its biggest share of the market since it broadcast a double episode of Friends in June 1998. The figures prove for the first time that viewers will follow a favourite programme, even when it switches to another channel. Sky usually only attracts such high viewing figures for its high-profile US imports, Friends, ER and the Simpsons.

Sky's new Al Murray (aka the Pub Landlord) sitcom, broadcast immediately after Harry Enfield, also performed well. It attracted 439,000 viewers, giving it a 2.7% share of the total TV market.

Last night's figures show that the return of BBC 1's Castaway has failed to capture the public's imagination. The programme attracted just 6.1m viewers, a 28% share of the market, with viewers preferring to tune into ITV's The Bill - also broadcast at 8pm. The Bill attracted 8.5m viewers, giving it a 37% share of the TV market.

The BBC fared better with EastEnders, with 11.3m viewers tuning in to the 7.30pm broadcast, giving BBC1 a 52% share of the market.

Big Brother continues to dominate people's late-night viewing, attracting 5m viewers eager to capture the last days of Craig, Anna and Darren in the Big Brother house. The show, broadcast at 10pm, got a 24% share.

Channel 5's new Big Brother-style game show, Jailbreak, attracted 1m viewers giving it a 5% share. The programme, in which contestants are challenged to escape from a set that has been designed to look like a prison, will be broadcast every evening for the next three weeks.

But the real stars of yesterday's schedules were the news broadcasts. The Nine O'Clock News attracted 8.4m viewers, giving it a 35% share of the total and proving that people are far more likely to tune into news broadcasts at a time of national upheaval. The petrol crisis also spurred 2.6m viewers to tune into BBC2's Newsnight, giving it an 18% share. Proof, if any were needed, that we really do love a crisis.

fields.headline: Peter Salmon has 'no regrets' over leaving BBC1
fields.standfirst:
Salmon takes over BBC sport
Comment by Janine Gibson
fields.trailText: Speaking exclusively to Mediaguardian.co.uk, Peter Salmon reveals the highs and lows of his role as BBC controller and his hopes for the future. By Janine Gibson.
fields.body:
Peter Salmon says he has "no regrets" about his time as controller of BBC1. Speaking exclusively to Mediatheguardian.com this morning, Salmon acknowledged his three years in the job had been a "rollercoaster ride". But, he added, "I've loved it and I'm going to take up my next job with the same relish".

He spoke about his highs and lows in the job and his ambitions for BBC sport. Here are his thoughts on ITV, on the leaking of his departure and the future of the channel he leaves.

On leaving BBC1:
I've been plotting a change for some months. As my predecessors will tell you, it's always tricky to work out what you do next because BBC1's such a momentous challenge. Ultimately I thought, I'm passionate about sport, I'm sure I'm going to learn a lot and I hope they are going to benefit from my experience. I'm thrilled.

On leaving just as BBC1 receives the £100m cash injection he argued for:
I'm relieved for BBC1 that Greg Dyke so quickly took up the challenge and delivered [the extra cash]. That will change everything. The new foundations for BBC1 are all there and the next incumbent gets to design the new building. You don't do this job for life, you're a caretaker. You've then got to have the strategy and the instinct to move on.

On the speculation over his future:
[The announcement] was precipitated a bit, but this has been in the pipeline for a while. It was the Edinburgh TV Festival: all that booze and too many dinners and drinks, it was just full of speculation. His highs and lows: I'm very proud of the schedule week in week out. I'm so lucky to have had so many brilliant colleagues, I can't tell you. I've had a lot of support and I've earned it by backing creative people. I've had real creative highs [such as] watching Walking with Dinosaurs soar. It didn't get placed after the EastEnders trial that Monday by accident. And to see Warriors gobble up so much money when we didn't have much to spend then become one of the best dramas of the last five years, in my opinion. But you have to take the brickbats as well as the bouquets. I've loved it and I'm going to take up my next job with the same relish. You can't do the big jobs without sticking your neck out, without gambling.

Peter Salmon's highs and lows:
Highs: Dinosaurs, Warriors, Royle Family, Clocking Off.
Lows: Vanessa Feltz's contract rows, the effect of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? on the BBC1 schedule. It's a marathon running these channels. In the race we're in a pretty good position. It's cyclical. ITV is having a bad autumn but they'll bounce back. David Liddiment is a canny leader. I'm so pleased to be leaving this autumn because it's brilliant.

His ambitions for BBC Sport:
I want the BBC to be a major player, a major creative force in sport and put the emphasis on creativity. We've a lot to learn from the Dinosaurs in terms of looking at the emerging technology. Innovation is very important to us. Digital developments such as the BBC's interactive Open Golf and Wimbledon coverage are the beginning of an interesting creative journey. Clearly we've got to build some new relationships with rights holders. I can't reveal what our priorities are.

Any regrets?
No. None. I'm glad to be doing something this big and this meaty.

webTitle: Wise: players to blame for Vialli sacking

fields.headline: Wise: players to blame for Vialli sacking
fields.trailText: Chelsea captain Dennis Wise has expressed his disappointment at Gianluca Vialli's shock dismissal - and says the players must accept some responsibility for his downfall.
fields.body:
Chelsea captain Dennis Wise has expressed his disappointment at Gianluca Vialli's shock dismissal - and says the players must accept some responsibility for his downfall.

"Everyone was disappointed - Luca was a good friend of mine," Wise told a packed press conference at Stamford Bridge earlier today. "We have not started very well. Maybe that is one of the reasons and that is down to us."

But Wise insisted that the players had to put Vialli's dismissal behind them starting with tomorrow's Uefa Cup match against St Gallen. "We need to concentrate on the game and worry about the match tomorrow," he said. "The club have come to the decision; we have to go out and play and win."

Wise's words were supported by coach Ray Wilkins, who admitted: "It came as a big shock to me. Over the last 15 months I have become friendly with Luca so naturally it is a shock.

"Luca is in quite good spirits. That side of Chelsea Football Club is now closed and we have to crack on and crack on in big style. If the new man comes in and doesn't want Graham Rix or myself then that is how it has to be."

Meanwhile Chelsea chief executive Colin Hutchison gave the official view on yesterday's events, as he described the meeting which led to Vialli having his contract terminated..

"We parted on pretty good terms," he said. "There were no raised voices and in the circumstances it was conducted in a dignified manner. In fairness to Luca all the players bought were quality players.

"Luca left in a very dignified manner. None of the players knew about it until the announcement. It came as a shock to them. The mood when I arrived showed the affection Luca was held in. It was subdued."

"There is never a happy time for a parting but at the end of the day the club is more important than any individual. It was felt the time was right."

Hutchinson went on to deflect criticism of Chelsea chairman Ken Bates for the sacking.

"If you are suggesting that Luca was the wrong appointment blame me, not Batesy, because Luca was my choice," he said. "It will only set the club back if we don't go forward positively. We believe we can go forward. We are in no hurry to make an appointment."
