webTitle: Salmon appointed BBC director of sport

fields.headline: Salmon appointed BBC director of sport
fields.standfirst:
Exclusive interview
Comment by Janine Gibson
fields.trailText: After months of speculation, Peter Salmon today relinquished the most important programming role in the BBC as he stepped down from a tumultuous reign as BBC1 controller after three years.
fields.body:
After months of speculation, Peter Salmon today relinquished the most important programming role in the BBC as he stepped down from a tumultuous reign as BBC1 controller after three years.

Salmon, 44, who was confirmed as director of sport this morning, takes a role on the BBC's executive committee in his new job, which a BBC spokeswoman said was a promotion.

His departure opens the way for the first female controller of BBC1 - the BBC's core service. Lorraine Heggessey, currently the corporation's head of factual programmes, is said to be the only name in the frame, but no announcement is likely until later in the week.

Salmon acknowledged BBC1 was a "demanding roleÓ but said: "I am proud of what our programme-makers and I have achieved these past three years."

Greg Dyke, the BBC's director-general, stayed loyal to a controller who many in the industry feel suffered from weaknesses within the BBC's production department during his tenure, saying Salmon had done a good job in difficult circumstances at BBC1.

He added: "Peter told Mark Thompson, BBC director of television, and I some months ago that he didn't want to continue as controller of BBC1 beyond this autumn. It so happened that we were looking for a new director of sport and Peter seemed an obvious choice.

"Peter needed little persuading. He is passionate about sport, especially football, and he brings to the department great experience in programme-making, plus an acute awareness of the bigger picture in broadcasting - a picture in which BBC Sport needs to consolidate its position.

"Peter has done a good job in difficult circumstances at BBC1. This autumn's schedule, like last autumn's, is full of originality and quality and is testament to his commissioning skills. He will be a strong addition to our executive team."

Industry reaction and comment to follow...

webTitle: Why Salmon is stepping down from his role as BBC1 controller

fields.headline: Why Salmon is leaving behind the hardest job in TV
fields.standfirst:
With the announcement that Peter Salmon is to leave his role as BBC1 controller to become BBC director of sport, Janine Gibson looks at the motivation behind the move

Salmon takes over BBC Sport
Exclusive interview
fields.trailText: With the announcement that Peter Salmon is to leave his role as BBC1 controller to become BBC director of sport, Janine Gibson looks at the motivation behind the move
fields.body:
When covering the BBC, hacks learn to look carefully for major announcements timed to coincide with national emergencies. Today's is a classic. After months of speculation over his future, Peter Salmon's fate has finally been announced. Weeks after the national press unilaterally crowned Lorraine Heggessey his successor, Salmon goes but there is no replacement named.

In the rush now to express sympathy for the man who spawned a thousand fish-related headlines, no one, it seems, wishes Peter Salmon ill. It's a mark of how well he is liked that even as he quits BBC1, the BBC has gone to such efforts to pitch his move to director of sport as a promotion. And to be fair to him, he had to be something of a jack of all trades.

The fiasco created by Birt's broadcast/production split put tremendous pressure on the channel controllers which is only now beginning to be undone. Even now, it seems that one of the stumbling blocks to a new controller is the position of drama commissioning. The job, which is key to BBC1's success, remains vacant as those offered it are said not to want the mish-mash available.

Salmon's torrid time in what Media Guardian recently described as the hardest job in television, has been characterised by one of the worst periods in the BBC's history. It can't have been much fun running the channel as it plunged to record ratings lows, and though shows like Walking with Dinosaurs and the Royle Family are cited as his triumphs, there are numerous television figures who have better claims to having discovered those hits.

From the haemorrhaging of BBC Sport, to the masturbation gags on Christmas Day, from the Queen Mother's birthday pageant to the loss of Des Lynam and Vanessagate, Salmon has indeed had it hard. But none of these would be sufficient to dislodge a truly secure controller.

What really suggests Salmon's departure from BBC1 is involuntary is the memory of last year's Edinburgh TV Festival. In the midst of a revolution at the corporation just after Greg Dyke's appointment as director general designate, Salmon made a stirring plea for an extra £100m annually to be spent on his channel. We cannot produce the drama needed to anchor BBC1 on the money available, he said. Now, 12 months later, just as the money is on the table to be spent, Salmon is moved on.

He had to go, his position became untenable. But it's easy to see why the BBC might feel it owes him.

webTitle: Zola won't be Chelsea manager, but who will?

fields.headline: Zola won't be Chelsea manager, but who will?
fields.trailText: Gianfranco Zola will not become Chelsea manager it was announced this morning, as speculation increases over the identity of Gianluca Vialli's successor. Zola, installed as the bookmaker's favourite for the Stamford Bridge job, was ruled out of the race by the club's managing director Colin Hutchinson.
fields.body:
Gianfranco Zola will not become Chelsea manager it was announced this morning, as speculation increases over the identity of Gianluca Vialli's successor. Zola, installed as the bookmaker's favourite for the Stamford Bridge job, was ruled out of the race by the club's managing director Colin Hutchinson.

"Gianfranco Zola will not be promoted to the manager's job," Hutchinson said today. "We are a Continental side playing football in England and this will be reflected in the choice we make. But we do not believe that we will take anybody from the current staff despite what some people have been suggesting."

Hutchinson's comments seem to confirm the general feeling in this morning's newspapers that the Blues will turn to Serie A for their new coach. Marcello Lippi, currently in a shaky position at Internazionale, and Lazio's Sven Goran Eriksson, who is something of an Anglophile, are two of the names offered as potential successors.

Chelsea supporters appear to have a different idea as to whom they'd like to see at Stamford Bridge, with many backing former England manager, and Chelsea player, Terry Venables for the job. Malcolm Carle, secretary of the Chelsea Supporters' Club, claimed: "You need a manager to motivate and have an impact. Terry Venables would be my choice, with Ray Wilkins and Gianfranco Zola in the background."

Wilkins, along with Graham Rix, will take charge of the first team for Chelsea's Uefa Cup match with Swiss champioins St Gallen tomorrow.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip blockaded by a bunch of angry truckers
fields.trailText: It may surprise you to learn that the majority of speculation in this morning's papers centres on the likely successor to Gianluca Vialli at Stamford Bridge. The Sun sticks with the assertion it made yesterday that Gianfranco Zola will step into the breach. The Daily Express suggests a more experienced candidate like George Graham or Terry Venables will be appointed. However The Daily Mail and The Mirror believe Venables will not be approached, and that Ken Bates will look to Italy, and either Marcello Lippi or Sven Goran Eriksson, to replace Vialli. Teamtalk also puts the name of World Cup winning coach Aime Jacquet into the frame.

It's been my dream to come to England and to play for Liverpool." Teamtalk report that Fulham are very interested in Charlton's teenage defender Paul Konchesky. The 19-year-old, who is the youngers person ever to play for the Addicks, has not been featuring in Alan Curbishley's plans of late, and Jean Tigana is set to offer him a move across London.

webTitle: Axon predicts end to the e-distinction

fields.headline: Axon predicts end to the e-distinction
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The distinction between traditional and e-business will more or less disappear in about 18 months, the chief exexecutive officer of technology consultancy Axon Group predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
The distinction between traditional and e-business will more or less disappear in about 18 months, the chief exexecutive officer of technology consultancy Axon Group predicted yesterday.

Mark Hunter said most companies would integrate the internet into their businesses, providing opportunties for consultancies such as Axon.

Mr Hunter was speaking as he attributed rising turnover and profits to an increase in e-business projects.

Axon has won significant contracts to build internet portals for organisations including WH Smith, Miller Freeman and Electrocomponents.

Profit before tax was up 66% to £2.8m and net income rose to £1.91m from £1.13m for the same period last year. Turnover was up 47% and prospects looked good.

The main business of the Surrey-based company is still installing management software developed by SAP of Germany. This division had also performed strongly.

Mr Hunter said that although the market generally experienced a slow start because of the Y2K hangover, the group showed strong growth for the period.

Over the last 18 months Axon has become more involved in advising companies on their technological requirements for e-commerce.

"The business that relates to e-business has grown very quickly this year," a spokesman said.

Axon's new business wins are now primarily generated by e-business. The company said that 70% of the business it is winning is e-business and the sector counts for 40% of total business.

With business growing Axon wanted to acquire a British media company, but has struggled to find something suitable.

The company has recruited about 120 consultants this year.

Axon shares yesterday closed at £11.10, down 47.5p. They have almost doubled this year, valuing the company at £570m.

webTitle: Astronauts embark on space station home-improvement

fields.headline: Astronauts embark on space station home-improvement
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Atlantis' crew completed several projects aboard the international space station this morning, snapping new batteries into place and hauling gear into the growing outpost.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Atlantis' crew completed several projects aboard the international space station this morning, snapping new batteries into place and hauling gear into the growing outpost.

The focus was on bringing full power to the two Russian segments of the station.

Astronaut Edward Lu and cosmonaut Yuri Malenchenko finished sliding three new batteries into the station's newest addition, the Russian service module Zvezda.

Three of Zvezda's eight batteries were kept back on Earth to conserve weight aboard the hefty spacecraft, grounded for more than two years because of Russia's economic problems. Though Zvezda launched in July, it made its debut in orbit when Atlantis' crew cracked open its hatches Tuesday.

Down the hall from Zvezda, astronaut Daniel Burbank and cosmonaut Boris Morukov replaced one of six batteries aboard the Russian-built control module Zarya. They were to replace another one Wednesday night, to complete an upgrade of the craft's battery system.

In May, astronauts had to replace four of Zarya's batteries, which were damaged via careless overcharging by Russian flight controllers. The two up for replacement this time were near the end of their operational lifetimes, and may also have been improperly charged.

All of the batteries in both modules will have to be brought online, one by one, under the watch of Russian flight controllers. That usually takes about a day after installation, Nasa said.

The battery work wasn't without its difficulties. Four small nutplates, riveted to Zarya's floor, obstructed a pair of bolts that Burbank and Morukov needed to loosen to replace a voltage converter that goes with the new battery. Mission Control quickly consulted with engineers in Houston and Russia for a solution. Their high-tech answer? Knock the nutplates free with a hammer and chisel.

Mission Control sent Burbank to retrieve the space station's tool kit, with a motherly reminder to remember his safety goggles. He then chipped the end off the rivets holding the offending nutplates down, enabling him to remove a bracket that blocked part of the battery compartment.

Aside from that small challenge, the shuttle and station appeared to be running very well.

During their five days inside the station, the crew has to transfer 6,100 pounds of equipment from the shuttle and an unmanned Russian supply ship which docked with Zvezda in August.

The gear is for the station's first resident crew, who are due to spend four months on board beginning in November.

Atlantis is scheduled to undock from the space station Sunday and finish its 12-day mission with a September 20 return.

fields.headline: The new boys' network
fields.standfirst:
Silicon Valley seems like the idyllic place to work: high temperatures, high salaries and high-powered careers. There's just one thing missing - women. As Lucy Atkins reports from San Francisco, there's no business like e-business when it comes to gender discrimination

Special report: Net newsWork unlimited
fields.trailText: Silicon Valley seems like the idyllic place to work: high temperatures, high salaries and high-powered careers. There's just one thing missing - women. As Lucy Atkins reports from San Francisco, there's no business like e-business when it comes to gender discrimination
fields.body:
It's a typical slice of daily life at the palm-fringed hub of the new economy: a workplace, undoubtedly, but one where an unusual definition of "work" holds sway. Engineers are chasing each other down the hallways, firing soft-tipped darts from Nerf guns. Their programmer colleagues are busy playing table football, or hunched over video-games. And when real work begins, it is as likely to take the form of a "bug bash" - where programmers stay in the office long into the night until they have fixed a certain number of glitches in the system - as it is a conventional meeting.

Or, at least, this is what the male ones are doing. These are scenes from Valley of the Boys, a documentary by Monika Khushf, director of engineering at the software company Intuit, which alarmed many by demonstrating just how male-dominated Silicon Valley's working culture really is. Khushf, interviewing male and female engineers from major technology companies including Sun Microsystems, Apple Computers and Netscape, portrayed a workplace where men spend long hours - weekends included - constructing elaborate model cities in Lego while their female colleagues look on, depressed or simply resigned. "They're having a great old time," one woman told Khushf. "And I'm sitting there going, 'Oh, please!'"

These women would not be surprised by a new list of the most influential people in the valley compiled by the San Jose Mercury, its leading newspaper. Not one woman made the top 10. And in Britain, we're no better - our three biggest internet companies, Freeserve, the auction site QXL and the software firm Autonomy, have one woman director between them. In any sector this would be a cause for concern - but in the supposedly revolutionary crucible of e-business, where casually attired workers pride themselves on abandoning the hang-ups of the old economy, it is little short of a disaster.

It's not as if there aren't any women entrepreneurs to begin with: according to the National Foundation of Women Business Owners, the number of women-owned businesses in the US has more than doubled in the past decade. Indeed, American women seem positively fuel-injected when it comes to start-ups: they are launching businesses at twice the rate of their male counterparts.

But it is becoming increasingly clear that the old boys' network that has been consigned to history is being replaced by a new one, focused on the venture capitalists who provide the speculative backing for the valley's big ideas.

Insiders like to portray the new economy as running on little but caffeine and ideas, but of course, deep down, it runs on cash - and here, a new boys' network is vigorously asserting itself. According to Venture One, an organisation that provides information to venture capitalists, only 5% of the total venture capital funding in the States goes to companies with women chief executives. Of the 3,000 venture capitalists currently working in the US, only 90 are women, says Diana Reid, of the San Francisco-based Forum for Women Entrepreneurs. You do the math, as they say in San Jose.

Reid and others are starting to mobilise the valley's women, in a movement that includes Women in Technology International - which holds an annual Silicon Valley summit in Santa Clara - and a range of "incubators", such as the San Francisco-based Women's Technology Cluster, which aims specifically to nurture technology start-ups run by women. Not that you will ever get anyone in the politics-free valley to admit to being an activist. "We don't consider ourselves to be an affirmative-action group," says Reid. "We're just trying to jump-start excellent business plans."

In Britain, the situation is even worse when it comes to venture- capital funding. Lucy Marcus, who set up HighTech-Women.com to support women in technology-related fields by mentoring and networking, says there are a pitiful number of women venture capitalists working in London. "I can name them without running out of fingers," she says.

Launched in March this year, High Tech-Women already boasts 700 members. Recent months have also witnessed the launch of Busygirl.co.uk, the first business technology portal dedicated to women internet entrepreneurs, and Webgrrls.org.uk, another networking organisation.

"In the UK, getting VC finance is made more difficult because the VCs in town have always been traditional city boys of the old-school network," says May Chong of Webgrrls. "They are men who have very little experience of doing business with women - let alone women who are younger and more 'techy' than them."

The best-known American exception to all this is Carly Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard and the first woman to head one of America's 20 largest companies as measured by revenues. Recently named by Fortune magazine as the most powerful woman in business, she sees the gender divide as part of a wider problem of conformity - exactly the personality trait that most valley entrepreneurs expend energy trying to deny.

"Diversity needs to become a priority in the hi-tech industry," Fiorina says. "Right now there is a virtual wall between available talent and available jobs: diversity is not a hiring practice nor a hiring priority in many Silicon Valley companies." This, combined with the "less-than-open perspective of many hiring managers" means, says Fiorina, that "this industry has far too much conformity".

Strenuous attempts are being made to change things. The American Computer Experience, for example, offers free places to girls on its computer camps (predictably, computer summer camps are dominated by boys: only 10-15% of campers are girls). Other educational projects seek to educate the educators: surveys show that girls are put off computing by dull programming classes dominated by nerdy boys nursing violent videogames and an inability to communicate in anything other than computer programming languages.

Wendy Tan is one of the lucky British women to be shown the money. At 29, she is the founder and chief executive of Moonfruit, a service provider specialising in website-building tools. "In my career, it's so normal being the only woman that you don't notice it any more," she says. Of the 40 businesses in the investment portfolio of their major backer, the investment-fund firm Europ@web, Tan says she is the only female boss.

Ultimately, the valley's unstoppable appetite for talent may force change. Says Carolyn Leightton, founder and chair of Women in Technology International: "As the demand for talented technologists grows, and the supplies continue to shrink, those companies which are committed to removing the barriers for the advancement of women will certainly be the winners." Although it may be drowned out by the sound of the table-football games and the Nerf-gun shootouts, a quiet revolution may soon become an economic necessity.

webTitle: Papers to 'run out of newsprint' this week

fields.headline: Papers to 'run out of newsprint' this week
fields.trailText: Papers could run out of newsprint within days, warns the Newspaper Society.
fields.body:
Regional and local newspapers are facing a three-fold crisis if the petrol shortage continues, according to the Newspaper Society.

David Newell, director of the society, said the lack of fuel could affect newsprint deliveries, paper deliveries and staff levels at print works. He is negotiating with the government to ensure they is on the priority list for any petrol that becomes available.

"There is evidence that some newspapers will run out of print this week," said Mr Newell. "The newsprint suppliers cannot get petrol, and I hope that most newspapers will supply up to Thursday. The situation is deeply worrying."

fields.headline: Digital Radio Group reveals licence bid line-up
fields.trailText: The rival consortiums bidding for UK regional digital radio licences are beginning to take shape, says Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The rival consortiums bidding for UK regional digital radio licences are beginning to take shape.

The Digital Radio Group has finalised its line-up, with mobile phone retailer the Carphone Warehouse and radio and magazine company Emap joining the GWR Group, Wireless Group and Virgin Radio, which is owned by SMG.

The companies, which all have experience of running digital radio operations, will bid for the north-east, Severn Estuary, West Midlands, north-west and Yorkshire licences over the next two years.

The licences will be awarded on a "beauty contest" basis, rather than according to the size of the bid.

Ralph Bernard, chairman of the Digital Radio Group, said: "The addition of these new partners brings an unrivalled level of expertise and experience to the consortium."

DRG will run against the MXR consortium, which has added technology company Psion InfoMedia and the UBC Media Group to its shareholders. The core members are Chrysalis, Capital Radio, Jazz FM and the Guardian Media Group, which between them own the analogue versions of the regional licences that are up for sale.

Chrysalis Radio chief executive Phil Riley said: "Providing compelling and innovative data is something the MXR consortium members wanted to do. We're thrilled to have found the right partners to do it with."

The first licence up for grabs is for the north-east of England, with an October 17 closing date for all bids.

Digital radio provides bundles of audio services to portable radios, in-car radios and PCs, and offers a much clearer reception than normal analogue radio.

webTitle: Old war horses, young guns and a summer to remember

fields.headline: Old war horses, young guns and a summer to remember
fields.trailText: Ambi and Walsh
fields.body:
Ambi and Walsh

The next few months are going to be interesting ones for West Indies cricket. Will they lose one or both of their great fast bowlers? Ambrose's mind appears to be made up. As the cleaning staff at The Oval were clearing away the champagne bottles, and as the Windies and England players flitted in and out of each others' dressing-rooms clutching cans of Fosters Strong Lager, I finally cornered "Ambi", the man who talks to no-one.

Can anything make him change his mind? I asked. No, he was looking forward to going home to Antigua, seeing more of his family, and to doing some fishing - his favourite pastime. But if, as he himself has admitted, the support bowlers Rose, King and Co are not ready, then he should stay on, shouldn't he? He smiled at that one. "But I may stay for another five years and they still won't be ready".

The man apparently is not for turning, but who knows? He and Walsh are to talk with Patrick Rousseau, the President of the West Indies cricket board. Rousseau insisted to me at The Oval that he won't be asking them anything, just listening. But there's little point in holding a meeting with a man who's made it plain he's going to retire - unless of course you're going to try to persuade him to stay.

Jimmy Adams and the manager Ricky Skerritt stuck to the party line - our wish is what they wish themselves. I couldn't Walsh get to reveal his hand. "I owe it to them to listen to what they have to say before I make a decision". The cricketing world awaits.

Sarwan and Trescothick

Comparing a 20-year-old Ramnaresh Sarwan to Rohan Kanhai, another Indian Guyanese, seemed a sure way to make the young man big-headed. But no-one who saw or spoke with Sarwan thinks there's any danger of that. Sure there's a degree of self-belief that shows clearly at the crease. But there's also an easy amiability, and a down-to-earth attitude. He was one of the first West Indies players to go the Test Match Special box after the Oval defeat.

He speaks of his pride in playing for the maroon, and with guys who a few short years ago, he was watching on TV like the rest of us. He even seemed happy to carry the towels and water at Lord's. Once he stopped to talk to West Indies fans in the Edrich Stand, lifted both arms like an orchestra conductor and told them to make more noise for the team.

Is he the new Kanhai? It's an obvious comparison because of their ethnic similarities, but they have different techniques. What's clear is that Sarwan is already very good indeed. Upright stance, still head, high backlift, strong in the V, but with a hook and pull to match anyone.

I watched his two unbeaten innings at Headingley on TV from Guyana in the company of an old-timer who knows his cricket. "The boy sound, sound, sound", he said, his eyes never leaving the screen. "He may even be better than Lara technically". Another example of that famous Caribbean parochialism? We'll see. Before the Oval Test, Sarwan had to return home to attend the funeral of his girlfriend. He never let his grief show in his little cameo as he and Lara chased a hopeless cause. And he topped the tourists' batting averages.

The turning point of the series came in West Indies' second innings at Lord's. Two-nil and it could have been all over for England. But Marcus Trescothick helped sustain their momentum. Adams, Skerritt and Harper all said England got better as the series progressed, and Trescothick played a part in that. Sure he can hack it as a one-day player, but the question once the series resumed at Manchester was how he would cope with the more demanding environment of Test cricket. Very well as it turned out. It took a dropped catch by Wavell Hinds (desperately unlucky in the first half of the tour and desperately disappointing in the second) and Trescothick was on his way.

His 159-run opening partnership with Atherton made West Indies push for a drawn series much harder. The Windies have bowled to a few left-handed openers since the '80s, but Trescothick was probably the most difficult to dislodge since Chris Broad and Graeme Fowler. Duncan Fletcher was an easy winner of the battle of the coaches, because he ran a smarter campaign than Roger Harper. His judgement on Trescothick was another reason.

A summer to remember

So the Windies lost but it's been a summer to savour. Channel 4 is to be commended for simplifying the game for the non-anoraks, but someone should tell them that there's more to the Caribbean than the beach. Some of the symbols were too cliched. How about Derek Walcott or CLR James next time?

A plus for Caribbeans? Jimmy Adams bravely and honestly facing his press and his critics as England sprayed the champagne around. Relations between the sides were good, and the guard of honour for the two old warriors was an example of that.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. To read his previous column, in which he talks to disillusioned West Indies fans at the Notting Hill Carnival, click here

Jimmy Adams and the manager Ricky Skerritt stuck to the party line - our wish is what they wish themselves. I couldn't Walsh get to reveal his hand. "I owe it to them to listen to what they have to say before I make a decision". The cricketing world awaits. Sarwan and Trescothick Comparing a 20-year-old Ramnaresh Sarwan to Rohan Kanhai, another Indian Guyanese, seemed a sure way to make the young man big-headed. But no-one who saw or spoke with Sarwan thinks there's any danger of that. Sure there's a degree of self-belief that shows clearly at the crease. But there's also an easy amiability, and a down-to-earth attitude. He was one of the first West Indies players to go the Test Match Special box after the Oval defeat. He speaks of his pride in playing for the maroon, and with guys who a few short years ago, he was watching on TV like the rest of us. He even seemed happy to carry the towels and water at Lord's. Once he stopped to talk to West Indies fans in the Edrich Stand, lifted both arms like an orchestra conductor and told them to make more noise for the team. Is he the new Kanhai? It's an obvious comparison because of their ethnic similarities, but they have different techniques. What's clear is that Sarwan is already very good indeed. Upright stance, still head, high backlift, strong in the V, but with a hook and pull to match anyone. I watched his two unbeaten innings at Headingley on TV from Guyana in the company of an old-timer who knows his cricket. "The boy sound, sound, sound", he said, his eyes never leaving the screen. "He may even be better than Lara technically". Another example of that famous Caribbean parochialism? We'll see. Before the Oval Test, Sarwan had to return home to attend the funeral of his girlfriend. He never let his grief show in his little cameo as he and Lara chased a hopeless cause. And he topped the tourists' batting averages. The turning point of the series came in West Indies' second innings at Lord's. Two-nil and it could have been all over for England. But Marcus Trescothick helped sustain their momentum. Adams, Skerritt and Harper all said England got better as the series progressed, and Trescothick played a part in that. Sure he can hack it as a one-day player, but the question once the series resumed at Manchester was how he would cope with the more demanding environment of Test cricket. Very well as it turned out. It took a dropped catch by Wavell Hinds (desperately unlucky in the first half of the tour and desperately disappointing in the second) and Trescothick was on his way. His 159-run opening partnership with Atherton made West Indies push for a drawn series much harder. The Windies have bowled to a few left-handed openers since the '80s, but Trescothick was probably the most difficult to dislodge since Chris Broad and Graeme Fowler. Duncan Fletcher was an easy winner of the battle of the coaches, because he ran a smarter campaign than Roger Harper. His judgement on Trescothick was another reason. A summer to remember So the Windies lost but it's been a summer to savour. Channel 4 is to be commended for simplifying the game for the non-anoraks, but someone should tell them that there's more to the Caribbean than the beach. Some of the symbols were too cliched. How about Derek Walcott or CLR James next time? A plus for Caribbeans? Jimmy Adams bravely and honestly facing his press and his critics as England sprayed the champagne around. Relations between the sides were good, and the guard of honour for the two old warriors was an example of that. Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. To read his previous column, in which he talks to disillusioned West Indies fans at the Notting Hill Carnival, click here

fields.headline: Jack Simmons
fields.trailText: Emeritus professor of history at Leicester University and our finest railway historian.
fields.body:
Jack Simmons, who has died aged 85, was emeritus professor of history at Leicester University and our finest railway historian.

His authoratitive book, The Railways Of Britain: An Historical Introduction (1961), provided a clarion call for research, and a plea for an understanding of the role of railways in 19th and 20th century history. His original, dramatic and approachable work, St Pancras Station (1968), places the station, its railway and the men who built it - from magnates to navvies - at the centre of a spider's web that reached into every corner of Victorian life. "For me," he said, 'St Pancras station is a building that exercises the force of life itself."

By then, Simmons had established the transport history collection at Leicester University library, donating 200 objects of his own. The collection has since grown by tens of thousands of items, and become an immensely important research tool. He published Transport Museums In Britain And Western Europe (1970), and encouraged his fellow trustees on the Science Museum advisory committee to establish the National Railway Museum in York - in the teeth of opposition from those who thought all such national assets should be London.

Simmons was born in Isleworth, Middlesex, and, after his father was killed in the first world war, his mother brought him up as an only child; he lived with her until she died in 1971. He went to Westminster school in 1928, and to Christ Church, Oxford, in 1933, gaining a modern history degree in 1937. After a year in Paris, he returned to Oxford and, having been found unfit for wartime military service, became Beit lecturer in the history of the British Empire in 1943.

In 1947, aged 33, he was appointed as the first professor of history at what was then University College, Leicester, with just 200 students. Simmons's role in the growth of what became Leicester University can scarcely be exaggerated: he was, at various times, acting vice-chancellor, pro vice-chancellor, public orator and an energetic member of countless boards and committees. The year after university status was granted, he described it all in New University (1957), a rather dry account that betrays little of the strains of his own role. He should perhaps have become a vice-chancellor, but was held back by ill-health and a determination not to be deflected from his historical interests.

Simmons was responsible for starting Leicester's highly regarded course for training museum professionals, and was a longtime chairman of its university press. He lectured and published on the empire and commonwealth, on Victorian Britain, on travel, the countryside, and his beloved Devon.

His first book, African Discovery (1942), was edited with Margery Perham. His second, published in 1945, was an excellent life of Robert Southey, poet laureate to George III and IV. Sadly, his proposed study of Wordsworth never appeared.

It had been in 1947, at his inaugural professorial lecture, that Simmons first drew attention to the lack of study of Victorian railways. Twenty-eight years later, the National Railway Museum opened and, from 1981 to 1984, he chaired its advisory committee - the museum's reading room was renamed in his honour.

Simmons also served on the advisory committee of the National Museum of Photography, Film and Television, which was opened in Bradord in 1983, and both museums published short, but excellent, catalogues by him: Dandy Cart To Diesel (1981) and Image Of The Train (1985 and 1993). The last words of the latter express the hope that his readers, and visitors to the exhibition "may see here that there is more to the railway than they had supposed before, more to be noticed, and more to be enjoyed".

Jack Simmons helped many people to notice and enjoy not only railways but also landscape and architecture, language and literature, and food and wine. He took an interest in everything around him, and being interested meant making himself knowledgeable. Being knowledgeable meant sharing that knowledge.

His last publication was the magisterial, but accessible, Oxford Companion To British Transport History (1997), edited with Gordon Biddle. Its articles add up to a comprehensive story of the rise and fall of British railways. In 1999, Simmons was awarded an OBE. He deserved more.

 Jack Simmons, historian, born August 30 1915; died Septmber 3 2000

fields.headline: Donald Gallup
fields.trailText: The career of the bibliographer and curator Donald Gallup, who has died age 87, was entirely spent at Yale University, and closely parallels the rise of American literary archives to their present unchallenged supremacy.
fields.body:
The career of the bibliographer and curator Donald Gallup, who has died age 87, was entirely spent at Yale University, and closely parallels the rise of American literary archives to their present unchallenged supremacy. With sharp-eyed rivals at Harvard, Princeton and the University of Texas at Austin, Gallup was that bit sharper, and better connected. His skills as a courtier were no less fabled than his gifts as a bibliographer.

He was for three decades curator of the Yale collection of American literature, during which period he published the standard bibliographies of TS Eliot and Ezra Pound, and edited numerous manuscripts by Gertrude Stein, Thornton Wilder, Pound and Eugene O'Neill held in the Yale library. He curated exhibitions at Yale, addressed learned societies on bibliography, and seemed to have his thumb on virtually every modern literary discovery.

The son of a lumber worker in Sterling, Connecticut, Gallup attended Yale during the height of the depression. The Johnsonian scholar Chauncey B Tinker singled out his promise, and, after graduating in 1934, he wrote his doctoral dissertation on Giuseppi Baretti, a friend of Johnson's biographer, James Boswell.

The discovery of the Boswell papers at Malahide castle in Scotland, and their purchase by Yale in 1949, strengthened the identification of the university with 18th-century scholarship. After Gertrude Stein's death in 1946, Yale purchased her papers, and Gallup joined the team which published her unpublished writings. It was Stein, not Boswell, who represented the future direction of the Yale literary archive.

Gallup was crucial to the emerging reputation of Yale as a force in modern writing, having published a catalogue of Eliot's first editions, which were exhibited at Yale in 1937. That early catalogue formed the basis for a more detailed Eliot checklist in 1947, and for Gallup's full-scale bibliography of Eliot, published in 1952. It was not a commercial success, selling only 150 copies a year before being pulped in 1963. An expanded edition appeared in 1969.

When the manuscript of The Waste Land was discovered in the New York Public Library, Gallup was asked by the Times Literary Supplement to write an evaluation of the manuscript. In effect, he introduced the literary discovery of the century to a wider public.

Gallop's earliest literary passion was as a collector; while still a graduate student, he spent his spare money purchasing Eliot's early, and, on London trips, began collecting the sketches and paintings of Edward Lear. Back in wartime Britain with the US army, he continued to acquire first editions and rare titles by British writers, and, in 1945, spent a term at Magdalen College, Oxford, studying bibliography with David Nichol Smith.

In 1997, Gallup donated his $1m collection of Lear materials, which included seven oils and more than 300 drawings, to Yale's British art centre. Later, he donated a 13-shelf foot collection of the works of Lawrence Durrell.

Gallup's enthusiasm for Eliot was soon followed by an interest in Ezra Pound. Both writers had notoriously complicated private lives, and it took all of Gallup's charm and persistence to keep Pound's parents, wife, mistress, son and publishers sweet. He visited the Pound materials looked after by the poet's former mistress, Olga Rudge, at Sant'Ambrogio di Ripallo in 1957, and returned to Italy in 1961 on a Guggenheim fellowship, by which time the Pound papers were under the control of the poet's daughter, Princess Mary de Rachewiltz. Gallup's monumental Pound bibliography of 1963 was built upon materials he had purchased over the preceding two decades.

Yale University Library published two volumes of Gallup's reminiscences, Pigeons On The Granite (1988) and What Mad Pursuits (1998). Last spring, Jonathan Edward College, at Yale, staged an exhibition of paintings and drawing by Elie Lascaux from the Gallup collection. As a bibliographer, he was responsive to the needs of scholars, rare-book dealers and collectors. The purpose of a bibliography, he argued in a lecture in 1970, was "to establish the facts, clear away confusion, and create order."

He never married.

 Donald Clifford Gallup, bibliographer, editor and curator, born May 12 1913; died September 6 2000

fields.headline: Warning behind Derry blast
fields.standfirst: After last night's Derry bomb attack, Observer Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald looks at the symbolic nature of the target
fields.trailText: After last night's Derry bomb attack, Observer Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald looks at the symbolic nature of the target.
fields.body:
A FEW weeks after the Northern Ireland Assembly elections in 1998, a group of armed and masked men entered the home of former republican prisoner Michael Donnelly in Derry.

The gang beat Mr Donnelly so severely that both his legs were broken and an arm was shattered.

His "crime" had been to call for a boycott of the elections in the Creggan area of the city.

Mr Donnelly was a member of Republican Sinn Fein, which opposes the Good Friday Agreement.

His attackers were local members of the Provisional IRA, who blamed his boycott campaign for a Sinn Fein candidate failing to get elected to the Assembly.

The irony of the attack was not lost on hardline republicans. The victim had been tortured by the British Army in Long Kesh (now the Maze) during internment in 1971.

Almost three decades later his former comrades had turned on this victim of British injustice just because he stood against the Sinn Fein peace strategy.

The attack was meant to instil fear in radical republicans who did not agree with Sinn Fein's embrace of the partitionist agreement.

And for a while it worked. There was only muted protest in Derry over the Donnelly attack and few young republicans seemed attracted by RSF's hard-line rhetoric.

Last night's attack on Magillian Army camp just outside the city was important more for its symbolism than its destructive substance.

Republican and security sources indicated this morning that the Continuity IRA, the paramilitary allies of RSF, was behind the blast.

Magilligan became infamous during the early 1970s when civil rights demonstrators, including the SDLP leader John Hume, marched on the base and demanded freedom for internees held behind the barbed wire and the British Army watchtowers.

For dissident republicans in the Derry/North-West salient there cannot be a better symbol to attack than Magilligan camp.

The explosion also demonstrates that the CIRA and their political allies are confident to carry on their campaign of violence despite opposition, not only from traditional quarters of nationalism like the SDLP, but also Sinn Fein and, in particular, Martin McGuinness, who regards Derry as his home patch.

The bombing is not just a challenge to the security forces but also the authority of Mr McGuinness and his party in their stronghold.

Most people living in nationalist working-class estates like the Creggan and Galliagh support Sinn Fein's peace strategy and don't wish to see a return to the kind of devastation that wreaked chaos in Derry during the 1970s and 80s.

But last night's blast is a reminder that there is a determined and recalcitrant republican minority prepared to risk not only imprisonment at the hands of their traditional enemies but also the wrath of their former comrades.

And judging by the amount of pro-CIRA graffiti adorning the walls and bus shelters on the west bank of Derry, there are plenty of young recruits willing to pursue a campaign which men like Mr McGuinness have forsaken for good.

fields.headline: Jennifer Lopez
fields.trailText: 1. Ricky Martin and Ms Lopez seem to be the only survivors of last summer's Latin music "explosion" and, with Jennifer's movie career ever-burgeoning, odds on she's the one who'll go the distance.
fields.body:
1. Ricky Martin and Ms Lopez seem to be the only survivors of last summer's Latin music "explosion" and, with Jennifer's movie career ever-burgeoning, odds on she's the one who'll go the distance.

2. Her "disgusting" psychological thriller The Cell also opens this week in the UK. It gave the US box office the old one-two, grossing a perfectly shapely $17.2m (£12.2m) in its first weekend.

3. Latin, of course, equals feisty in the ever-so-subtle world of Hollywood and so Jennifer is seen showcasing her typical gutsy style, playing a psychotherapist forced to delve into the mind of serial killer Vincent D'Onofrio. Not exactly virtuoso stuff.

4. Still, it could be worse. Latinos in decades of previous Hollywood films have mostly just been of the unhinged "Eh! Senor! You want guns?" variety. Antonio Banderas was invariably typecast in such roles, occasionally broadening his scope to portray Latinos of the over-amorous variety.

5. Currently Ms Lopez is the only Latin film star to command heavyweight fees and displays humour and general believability in virtually every role she's been in. Blood and Wine, Selena, and Out of Sight - in which she can be seen smooching with the George Clooney - are stand-out roles.

6. Then there's her music career. Her background is as a dancer and singer and, though truthfully she's probably a better actress, her mission to get the globe writhing to tepid Latin-tinged pop has so far been successful. Her debut album On The 6 went double-gold in the UK and sold even better globally. The follow-up is due this autumn.

7. Surely it's only a matter of time before movie and music careers converge and we witness the sort of cross-promotional orgy flogged to death by the shameless (but still somehow charming) Will Smith.

8. Of course, Sean "Puffy" Coombs helped out producing on her debut and began stepping out with Jen shortly afterwards. Their relationship's since become the stuff of celebrity lore, with her inexplicably sticking by him throughout his numerous fracas, not to mention his gut-wrenching hip-hop karaoke.

9. Ms Lopez's bounteous curves, reportedly insured for $1bn (Puff Daddy has since gloated that they're worth at least $5bn), have rather inevitably captured the imagination of the sort of teenage males who populate the internet. Fansites are legion.

10. It's undeniable that, with her raucous beau and A1 career CV, Lopez is a bona-fide can't-touch-me star, shaping up to be an actress-singer diva of Streisand-like proportions.

fields.headline: Revolution round-up
fields.standfirst: The big new media business and marketing stories to break over the last week from trade title Revolution
fields.trailText: The big new media business and marketing stories to break over the last week from trade title Revolution. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Celebrity gossip site Peoplenews.com, which is being edited by former Tatler editor Jane Procter and has Andrew Neil on board as non-executive director, has secured funding of £4m and is set to launch on Monday September 18.

Agency Circle.com is weighing up its relationship with its client, Guinness, after being wooed by Budweiser to work on its award-winning 'Whassup?' ad campaign.

Thomson Travel Group has launched Skydeals.co.uk, a website selling both chartered and scheduled flights, unlike rival sites such as Expedia and ebookers, which offer only scheduled flights.

Interactive agency AKQA has snapped up the £1m online marketing task for Lloyds TSB's soon-to-launch Evolvebank.com, after a seven-way pitch.

And finally, great news - the wonderful Richard Lord is back from disease-infested Hong Kong. Revolution is back to normal now.

webTitle: Newspapers in crisis talks over fuel drought

fields.headline: Newspapers in crisis talks over fuel drought
fields.standfirst: Special report on the petrol crisis from Guardian Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's national newspapers will hold crisis talks on Thursday as the UK petrol drought threatens to bring their distribution system to its knees.
fields.body:
Britain's national newspapers will hold crisis talks on Thursday as the UK petrol drought threatens to bring their distribution system to its knees.

The Newspaper Publishers Association, the trade association for the eight national newspapers, is considering dropping magazines and supplements from the weekend editions. The national petrol shortage, caused by a blockade of refineries across the country, is set to bring distribution systems to a standstill if it continues.

The decision to remove supplements will reduce the load and number of deliveries by lorries and conserve fuel, but publishers face massive revenue losses as advertisers demand refunds.

Lucy Ukomunne, circulation and distribution manager of the NPA, said: "The decision will be made on Thursday. We will not distribute magazines and supplements if the crisis deepens."

Other options under consideration include narrowing the number of distribution runs from two to one, and reverting to the old, slower method of using rail transport.

"We have been talking to retailers and the government, who assure us that we are on the national priority list for this kind of situation," said Ms Ukomunne.

Circulation managers at all the national publications are drafting contingency plans that will get the papers out until the end of the week, but a complete standstill is likely if the pumps stay dry into next week.

webTitle: Ulster blast sparks fears of dissident campaign

fields.headline: Ulster blast sparks fears of dissident campaign
fields.trailText: A police station in Northern Ireland was rocked by an explosion today amid growing fears of a new bombing offensive by republican dissidents.
fields.body:
A police station in Northern Ireland was rocked by an explosion today amid growing fears of a new bombing offensive by republican dissidents.

The attack happened outside the Royal Ulster Constabulary station in Armagh, on the city's Newry Road.

There were no immediate reports of any casualties, according to a police spokesman, but a pregnant woman walking close by narrowly missed being hit by a piece of flying metal, which bounced off a wall. The area was packed at the time with scores of children on their way to school.

The mortar was fired from the back of a van parked on the building site of a new hotel and police said it was a "miracle" nobody was killed.

It was the second attack by republican dissidents in less than 24 hours, confirmed heightening security force fears that the Real IRA, which bombed Omagh, could be launching a new offensive.

Earlier a soldier escaped uninjured when an 80lb bomb partially exploded after he opened the door of a wooden hurt at a military training camp at Magilligan, County Londonderry. Another unexploded 80lb bomb was discovered nearby, police disclosed today.

Special Branch chiefs in Belfast fear members of the Real IRA - the dissident group responsible for the Omagh bombing - have been preparing to launch a series of attacks across the Province.

According to security sources, the group's numbers have been growing in Belfast, Londonderry and south Armagh.

The explosion came days after the discovery on Saturday of a firebomb in a soft furnishing shop in English Street in Armagh, but Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson said such action would not derail the peace process.

He added: "The people responsible for this will be tracked down and the police and security forces will bring a halt to this sort of activity.We are not going to tolerate any action, from any quarter, to disrupt and destablise the peace process which is so strong and so important to the people of Northern Ireland, and the future of Northern Ireland."

Chief Inspector Derek Williamson said: "It was launched without warning in an absolutely indiscriminate fashion and at a time when the place with busy with schoolchildren and people going to work. That showed utter contempt for the lives of everyone in the area.

"It was an attack of murderous intent, and it was all the more despicable because of the ongoing inquest into the Omagh bombing."

fields.headline: Blast at Jakarta stock exchange
fields.trailText: An explosion at Jakarta's stock exchange has wounded at least seven people.
fields.body:
An explosion at Jakarta's stock exchange has wounded at least seven people.

More than 1,000 workers were evacuated from the office block in downtown Jakarta and trading was suspended as thick black smoke billowed from a basement garage.

The cause of the blast, which originated in the generator room, was not known. Police at the scene said they suspected it was a bomb. But military personnel later suggested the building's diesel generator might have blown up accidentally.

The building had been hit by several power cuts earlier in the day.

Feri Indrianto, a broker among the stock exchange evacuees, said: "I was in my office on the 20th floor. I felt a big blast and heard a loud bang."

Indonesia has been hit by a series of unexplained bomb blasts in recent weeks in Jakarta and other major cities. On 1 August a bomb exploded outside the residence of Philippine Ambassador Leonides Caday, killing two people and injuring dozens, including the envoy.

A small bomb exploded last month inside an unoccupied bus less than 300 metres from the converted court building in Jakarta where former dictator Suharto is on trial on corruption charges. No one was injured and damage was minimal.

fields.headline: RTL Group to release extra shares
fields.trailText: The RTL Group is to increase its financial firepower by releasing more shares onto the market, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
RTL Group, the ambitious broadcasting giant which controls Channel 5, is to increase its financial firepower by releasing more shares onto the market.

RTL was formed this year through the merger of the TV interests of German media giant Bertelsmann, Spain's Audiofina and the UK's Pearson - owner of the Financial Times.

Following its July flotation on the London Stock Exchange, the company plans to break into the FTSE 100 index through increasing the amount of shares on the market from 10.3% to 15%.

The group today signalled its intent by acquiring an additional 6.23% holding in Spanish television channel Antena 3 for E155.7m (£95.2m). There are no regulatory barriers to RTL buying United News & Media's 34.5% stake in Channel 5, which would give it complete control of the channel.

The announcements came as RTL posted a 64% drop in half-year profits, following one-off gains for the same period last year. Net profits fell from E198m (£121m) to E71m (£43.5m), although sales rose from E1.7bn (£1.04bn) to E2bn (£1.22bn), up 21%.

Chief executive Didier Bellens said: "In record time, we have created a unique and powerful business with a clear and consistent strategy, a strong and united management team and a solid base for future growth."

The considerable expertise on the RTL board and its £16bn market value have seen the company linked to most takeover rumours in the European broadcast sector.

fields.headline: Amazon bolstered by 2m UK customers
fields.trailText: Analysts are resuming their love affair with Amazon again following the news that Amazon now has 2m customers in the UK, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Analysts are resuming their love affair with Amazon again following the news that Amazon now has 2m customers in the UK, the first such internet firm to hit this landmark.

Amazon says the site is adding about 125,000 new customers each month, and in the last eight months its user base has doubled across Europe.

Sales from outside the US now account for around 25% of the group's overall turnover, with more significant growth set to come from these operations.

As of July 2000, Amazon had 1.8m unique visitors in the UK, and 1.3m in Germany. Analysts have switched their recommendation to buy, less than a month after they began dumping the stock on the advice of leading internet analysts Henry Blodgett.

webTitle: Gossip site turns up a fortune cookie

fields.headline: Gossip site turns up a fortune cookie
fields.trailText: An irreverent US website set up to chart the demise of cash strapped internet start-ups has received a $10m takeover offer. Fuckedcompany.com - which was founded, owned and run by an industry pundit known as "Pud" - has become the must-visit website for gossip about dot.com failures.
fields.body:
An irreverent US website set up to chart the demise of cash strapped internet start-ups has received a $10m (£7m) takeover offer. Fuckedcompany.com - which was founded, owned and run by an industry pundit known as "Pud" - has become the must-visit website for gossip about dot.com failures.

Anyone working in the internet industry is encouraged to post rumours anonymously about what is going on in the industry and each week vote on the five web firms they think most likely to go bust.

Among the 27,950 subscribers to its daily email newsletter are journalists, venture capitalists, entrepreneurs, investment bankers and recruiters keen to keep abreast of the latest gossip. Fuckedcompany.com receives 2.6m page views a week, according to PC Data.

Yesterday Pud, whose real name is Philip Kaplan, put the site up for auction - online, of course. "I was bored this morning so I put FC on eBay," he said, explaining that he had always viewed the venture as a side issue to his other business interests and could not devote time to its development.

Last night the highest bid stood at $3.3m (£2.3m), although according to some reports Pud had been contacted by someone prepared to pay as much as $10m for the site.

Fuckedcompany.com has received glowing endorsements from industry experts. Ken Cassar, senior analyst at renowned internet research firm Jupiter Communications, says he checks the site before making positive comments about any company.

Michael Wolff, author of the seminal Silicon Valley novel Burn Rate, said recently: "I wish I'd though of it".

The site has attracted unspecified advertising and sponsorship revenues. User features include an archive that allows you to search for "all the bad news your little heart desires". Its main rival is dotcomfailures.com, whose motto is "kick 'em while they're down".

The auction ends on September 20.

fields.headline: ITN moots stock market listing
fields.trailText: The ITN board is to meet later this month to decide whether to proceed with plans to float on the stock market, Maggie Brown reports.
fields.body:
The ITN board is to meet later this month to decide whether to proceed with plans to float on the stock market.

If the move gets the green light, about 20 per cent of the news operator will be sold off, with each of its shareholders - Granada, Carlton, Reuters, United News & Media and the Daily Mail & General Trust - reducing their holding.

The aim would be to use some of the proceeds to further bolster ITN's push into new media, including the supply news online. The flotation would also allow top executives to be rewarded, while all 1,000 staff are likely to be included in a share option scheme.

The key business issue is whether ITN is seen as having a sufficient potential as new media player, rather than being wholly dependent on its three contracts to supply ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 with news programming. These contracts represent around two thirds of ITNÕs income - about £100m.

ITN has expanded recently with the launch of a 24-hour news channel and website, while Euronews has broken even after two yearsÕ of ITN management.

The key political issue is whether an impartial news organisation can operate as a stock market company.

In the longer term, ITNÕs board is likely to lobby for the 20 per cent restriction on any company holding more than 20 per cent of the company to be removed to allow a takeover by one group, or a significant shareholding to be built up.

fields.headline: Burger King rethinks $400m US account
fields.trailText: Burger King is reviewing its $400 million US advertising account out of Lowe Lintas, claiming the advertising has failed to increase sales.
fields.body:
Burger King is reviewing its $400 million US advertising account out of Lowe Lintas, claiming the advertising has failed to increase sales.

The move follows parent company Diageo's decision to sell the world's second-largest fast food chain. Burger King's US sales have suffered over the past year, making it more difficult for Diageo to attract a buyer.

Mikel Durham, Burger King's new North American president, said the decision was part of a drive to improve the chain's performance in North America, which accounts for about 80% of worldwide sales. She said a key factor was the failure of recent advertising to spark new sales.

The fast food chain said last night that its UK advertising account, also handled by Lowe Lintas, was not included in the review. But the news raises a question mark over the agency's hold on the business, particularly given that ads created by Lowe's US office frequently run in the UK.

fields.headline: Guardian Unlimited launches ad campaign
fields.trailText: Guardian Unlimited's first above-the-line brand campaign breaks today, attempting to establish the network of sites as one of the UK's most popular online properties.
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited's first above-the-line brand campaign breaks today, attempting to establish the network of sites as one of the UK's most popular online properties.

The two-week marketing push takes in 640 poster sites across the UK and coincides with the announcement that Guardian Unlimited is now pulling in more than 18m page impressions per month.

Created by Partners BDDH and bought by NewPHD, the campaign uses three statements - 24-hour surveillance, Permanently Switched On and Non-Stop Press - to emphasise the network's editorial strengths and its immediacy. The strapline is "News, Football, Film, Money, Education, Books, Talk and Jobs".

Marc Sands, marketing director at The Guardian, said: "We have invested in building a strong product that delivers on promise and we are now ready to take our product to a wider audience. This campaign perfectly encapsulates the core strengths of Guardian Unlimited and the benefits to users."

webTitle: September Films to launch online TV clips service

fields.headline: Indie unveils online TV clips service
fields.trailText: Independent TV production company September Films is preparing to launch an online trading platform for TV clips called Clipsalesnow.com.
fields.body:
Independent TV production company September Films is preparing to launch an online trading platform for TV clips called Clipsalesnow.com.

Sally Miles, managing director of September Films, is currently in talks with a number of independent TV production companies regarding third-party representation.

It is believed that United Productions is to be the first company to sign up, although Miles wouldn't confirm any deal. However she expects to have more than 100 minutes of material on offer at launch in eight weeks.

"I'm talking to a lot of big production companies at the moment and we should have a major ITV broadcaster to announce imminently," said Miles.

Clipsalesnow.com is a fully automated service, allowing broadcasters to search for relevant clips that can then be bought and downloaded directly from the website. A licence will follow in the post. The service has been set up by investment from September Films, although the company is looking for other investors to become strategic partners.

Miles has recruited Alessio di Capua from Pearson TV's archive department and will have library research staff on hand for users as well as the website search.

September Films is not alone in realising there is a market for this type of trading platform. The BBC is currently working on ways in which it can make money from its vast archive and has set up Project Irene to migrate the licensing of stock footage and programme clips into an e-commerce-based environment.

BBC Worldwide is currently seeking a financial partner to help with the costs of migrating its library sales business online. Given that the library sends out around 80,000 clips each year to businesses by courier, Project Irene is expected to be a big cost-cutting measure for the corporation. However, it is not expected to launch until summer next year.

fields.headline: Protesters - closet environmentalists?
fields.standfirst: Unwittingly, truckers and farmers have achieved what greens have been trying to do for years, says George Monbiot
fields.trailText: Unwittingly, truckers and farmers have achieved what greens have been trying to do for years, says George Monbiot.
fields.body:
Friday of next week is European Car Free Day, when the people of Europe's cities will be encouraged to leave their cars at home. I think the organisers will agree that it's building up rather nicely.

What have the truckers and farmers got which we greens have not? Whenever environmentalists have tried to stop petrol tankers from getting onto the roads, the police have pounced immediately.

Last year campaigners outside an oil refinery in Essex were charged with obstruction of the highway, even though they were standing on the verge. Today's protesters, far from being arrested on sight, seem to have been able to bring the whole system to a standstill merely by turning up and shouting.

The oil companies insist that their capitulation has nothing to do with the fact that they would also like to see fuel duties fall. They can't let their tankers go, they argue, because their drivers have been intimidated.

When pressed yesterday, a Shell spokesman explained that on Friday last week, someone threw a traffic cone at one of the company's trucks. Note to anti-capitalism protesters: next time you want to bring the entire economic system to a halt, threaten it with a traffic cone.

But in the meantime, congratulations, lads! Your position might defy all logic. The farmers among you are taxed at just three pence a litre, the fishermen not at all. Even the truckers and car drivers pay only a fraction of the costs they impose on the rest of us.

But you've managed to do what we environmentalists have sought to do for years: you've got cars off the roads, people onto public transport and fossil fuel consumption down to a record modern low. Our city centres are more peaceful and our cyclists and pedestrians are safer than they've been for years.

You have, in other words, reclaimed the streets for the people. Keep up the good work: as the government has made it clear that it will listen to no one else, we're depending on you and you alone to bring our crazy, unsustainable energy system to an end.

webTitle: Cashing in on the oil riches

fields.headline: Cashing in on the oil riches
fields.standfirst: High oil revenues can tempt governments into undisciplined spending sprees, as Brian Whitaker explains
fields.trailText: High oil revenues can tempt governments into undisciplined spending sprees, as Brian Whitaker explains.
fields.body:
Imagine that your salary could treble over the next 18 months, or that it could be slashed to a third of what you get now ... but you have no idea which.

Dare you move home or splash out on a new car? Should you save every penny you can in case the worst happens?

That, in a nutshell, is the problem that oil-producing countries face on a grand scale. Today, they are wallowing in money with oil at more than $30 a barrel. But early last year it fetched only $10 and everyone had to tighten their belts drastically.

The price rollercoaster can play havoc with national budgets and long-term economic planning. Even when times are good, nobody knows how long it will last.

During previous booms, oil-rich governments have tended to splash out on new toys for the military (thereby recycling the money back to western companies) and on welfare for their citizens.

Often this meant providing government jobs where employees were expected to do very little beyond collecting their salary.

But when prices fell, these economies came under enormous pressure. In 1998, for instance, the Saudis had an unprecedented budget deficit and even had to borrow money.

The shockwaves from the fall in oil prices were felt most strongly among the young school and college leavers who discovered - unlike their elder brothers and sisters - that there were few cushy government posts to be had.

Even for those who were prepared to do real work, there were too few jobs in the private sector to go round.

At one point, unemployment in Saudi Arabia reached 15 per cent. Iran faced even worse problems.

The impact of fluctuating oil prices depends on how much a country's economy relies on oil. Yemen, next door to Saudi Arabia and with a larger population, produces only about 400,000 barrels of oil a day but is almost totally dependent on it.

It is an impoverished country with no other exports worth mentioning, and oil is the government's main source of tax revenue. At $10 a barrel, Yemen was in dire straits; at $30 it's more comfortable, but with prices liable to change at any time there's no economic stability.

For the moment, most of the countries that have benefited from the current boom are being careful with their money. Some are using the extra cash to boost their reserves or to pay off old debts.

The question is how long they can maintain that discipline. If the boom continues, the pressure to resume government handouts will be hard to resist. And there's already talk in Saudi Arabia of buying $2.7bn worth of weapons from the United States.

Brian.Whitaker@theguardian.com

webTitle: NHS on 'red alert' over fuel crisis

fields.headline: NHS on 'red alert' over fuel crisis
fields.standfirst:
Special report: petrol crisis

 Supermarkets resort to rationing
 London off limits
 Emergency operations only
 Calls to reconvene Parliament
fields.trailText: The National Health Service has been put on red alert as a result of dipping fuel supplies.
fields.body:
The National Health Service has been put on red alert as a result of dipping fuel supplies.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn ordered all regions to have emergency plans in place for dealing with the fuel crisis.

Such planning procedures are normally reserved for coping with major incidents and winter pressures.

Mr Milburn has also instructed hospitals to deal with emergencies only. But the Department of Health was immediately accused of exaggerating the crisis as hospitals and the blood service denied they were experiencing the severe problems claimed in official press releases.

Mr Milburn said: "Those involved in this blockade need to know the very serious effect their actions are having on the NHS. Patients are unable to get to hospital. Operations are being cancelled. Drugs, food and medical supplies are now running short. The NHS is increasingly unable to do its job properly."

The Health Department claims, made in a press release, were immediately denied by the National Blood Service.

The department had claimed central blood stocks could only last for another four days and that there were problems with distributing supplies in some areas like Southampton, Yorkshire and the north of England.

But a spokeswoman for the blood service said: "We do have supplies for another four or five days but we are collecting new stocks all the time. There is no problem with distribution. This is scaremongering and it is causing unrest.

"People are saying that they are being told that blood donation centres have closed when they have not. It is outrageous."

The red alert announcement came as Conservative leader William Hague called for Parliament to be reconvened early, and it followed news that protesters in Scotland had voted to ignore the plea of the Road Hauliers' Association to end their action at 7pm tonight. Instead, the picket at Grangemouth refinery - and many others across the country - will continue.

Mark Williams, spokesman for the demonstrators, said they were "not very happy" with the decision. "We have come this far," he said "and to break up now is not going to get us anywhere. We are not stopping any tankers coming out - it is the drivers' decisions not to leave - we are just here to make a point and we will."

More and more tankers carrying precious supplies of petrol are making it through blockades and onto Britain's roads and distribution problems are easing, but oil companies say it will be "many, many days" before the situation returns to normal.

The widespread concern over fuel has also led to panic buying at supermarkets, particularly for bread and milk. Safeway has resorted to rationing in certain stores and Asda says it is unable to guarantee supplies further ahead than Saturday.

Earlier in the day, bubbling tensions saw two protesters arrested for obstruction at the refinery in Sunderland and a van believed to contain riot police was called in to escort a tanker through blockades in Essex as it delivered fuel to a filling station.

Central London became off-limits at lunchtime as more than 200 lorries converged on the area surrounding Trafalgar Square, in a bid to take their protest directly to the government at nearby Parliament Square.

Prime Minister Tony Blair had summoned oil company heads to Downing Street for more round-the-table talks aimed at getting Britain moving, after earlier promising the nation things would begin returning to normality by Wednesday evening.

And outside Number Ten, Shell chief executive Malcolm Brinder delivered a joint statement with John Manzoni his opposite number at BP, saying "every effort" would be made to comply with the emergency powers the government had implemented to ensure "the maintenance of services essential to the running of the country.

"We will be stepping this up as soon as possible to get back to normal," he added.

From Conservative Central Office, Tory leader William Hague called on Mr Blair to apologise for the situation and he accused the Government of failing to "get a grip" on a crisis which it had itself caused.

He said: "Their (the government's) sheer arrogance and refusal to take on board the public's grievances shows them to be an out-of-touch and tax-raising Government that has failed to get a grip on this crisis,"

However, Mr Hague urged protesters campaigning against high fuel duty to end their blockades of oil refineries and allow the country to get back to normal.

Across the country protests gathered pace. Demonstrators successfully turned back tankers leaving a fuel distribution centre in Poole while around 20 protesters outside the gates of the Manchester Fuels Terminal were joined by more than 100 taxi drivers who had earlier staged a go-slow demonstration with their vehicles in Manchester city centre.

In Aberdeen, tractors and heavy goods vehicles were continuing to cause disruption in Union Street and Market Street in the city centre. The protesters were believed to be heading for the city harbour to demonstrate outside a BP depot.

Meanwhile, in Inverness around six protesters were still gathered outside the BP fuel depot in Cromwell Road where only emergency service supplies were leaving.

At BP's Grangemouth terminal in Scotland eight vans carrying police dressed in riot gear arrived as a convoy of 10 tankers prepared to leave. Under police escort they departed for destinations across Scotland which police refused to reveal.

Up to 60 officers sent a cordon across the road to allow the lorries to leave without been hampered by protesters. The crowds chanted, clapped and cheered despite the heavy police presence. Haulier Davie Howie said: "We are more than happy to let emergency services have fuel. The amount of police involved last night was ridiculous, as the delivery had already been agreed by us and we were happy to let it through."

Panic buying spread from fuel to food today as consumers fearing the worst, stocked up on essentials and the Royal Mail warned it only had supplies for one more day of deliveries in some areas.

There was also a warning today that banks could start running out of cash because of the effects of the fuel crisis.

The banking union Unifi said it had reports from workers at a handful of branches in the Midlands that money was running out.
