webTitle: The government is standing firm. It must win this battle

fields.headline: The government is standing firm. It must win this battle
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: For the first time the government faces a real crisis. It is in the right, it is standing firm and it must win. But this tests its mettle as nothing has before. The unions don't scare it, but motorists do.
fields.body:
For the first time the government faces a real crisis. It is in the right, it is standing firm and it must win. But this tests its mettle as nothing has before. The unions don't scare it, but motorists do.

Suddenly the strength of government is in peril, as civilisation turns fragile with ambulances, schools, food supplies and refuse collection threatened. Haunted by the unburied bodies and rat-infested rubbish heaps of 1979, New Labour's mind-set switches to Thatcher-and-the-miners mode. But this isn't the unions, this is the world turned upside down. This is a fight against the forces of conservatism - a popular front of Poujadist small businessmen, farmers, cab drivers and truckers, all supported with weasel words by Mr Hague and the right-wing press. There is no ready-made language to describe this particular enemy of the people, the militant chambers of commerce. Meanwhile the unions parrot gleefully what the Rotarians used to say back in the 70s: Sir Ken Jackson of the AEEU, "They have to understand the damage being caused to the economy;" and John Edmonds of GMB, "Ministers must not allow themselves to bow to these demonstrations by small businessmen and Tory supporters." Quite right too.

These protesters are a small, tightly knit group of politically motivated men. Take the farmers. They have been blockading supermarkets over the falling price of milk - hardly a popular cause - but now they have found petrol hits the spot. But what cheek. Red diesel for tractors is taxed at just 3p a litre while ordinary diesel is taxed at 48p a litre, so it is time they got their state- subsidised tractors off our lawns. Their real grudge against Labour is ideological, angry at the right to roam and the banning of fox hunting. (Why were the protesters outside John Prescott's anniversary dinner in Hull yelling about banning hunting as well as petrol prices?) As ever, farmers seem oblivious of their special £3bn a year welfare state for producing 1% of GDP. Here's an interesting fact: in all Wales there are 2,000 civil servants to cover everything, but nearly a quarter of them are clerks engaged full-time in processing claims and paying out grants to farmers. (Poor rural dwellers hit by fuel prices could be far better targeted with council tax cuts.)

As for the truckers, they are highly selective when comparing petrol taxes with the rest of Europe. The Road Haulage Association (RHA) complains about unfair competition from French trucks, made worse now Jospin (so recently reviled by the right for caving in) has slashed their fuel tax rates. A French truck, says the RHA, can fill up in Calais, unload in Scotland, steal many small jobs from British firms on the way home all on one mighty tank. But do these British companies really want tax harmonisation with the French? If they had French petrol tax, would they accept French income tax, corporation tax and road tolls too?

The Greedy Gordon attack carries some weight. The price rise from $10 to $34 a barrel in just 18 months should bring him in a windfall in extra VAT on fuel and extra revenues from the North Sea. Most estimates suggest £1bn, the Mail came up with £4bn. But until the end of the year it's unknowable and even then hard to calculate. If people are spending more on petrol, they are spending less elsewhere, so other tax revenues drop as company profits fall. But if at the end of the year there is a clear Treasury bonus, then the chancellor should commit that sum unequivocally to green investment in desperately under-subsidised renewable energy projects or public transport. (Or how about free buses for under 21s?)

The government has sounded weak in this debate because Tony Blair never talks green. He is happy administering the thwack of firm government but green is for wimps. However this argument must be fought and won on its own merits. Friends of the Earth point out that road transport is the second fastest growing British source of carbon emissions and drivers still don't pay the true cost of their driving. Road transport costs the environment £42bn a year but tax raised from road transport is only £23bn. Government figures show how the cost of motoring has not changed in real terms in the past 25 years while train fares have risen by 53% and bus fares by 87%. We would be better off with fewer hauliers: 40 years ago more than half of all freight went by rail, now it is only 7%, although each ton transported by road gives out 80% more CO<->2 than by rail.

There was a sigh of relief at the weekend when Opec agreed to increase oil production by 800,000 barrels to try to ease prices. But those extra barrels will add 1/2% to the total global output of CO<->2 at a time when the world is committed to reducing emissions by 7%. What a small puff of protest it took to blow the world off course. Environmentalists watching the protest spread right across Europe wait in trepidation to see whether most EU leaders will take the Blair or the Jospin route. At the November climate change summit in the Hague they had hoped for a united European front to shame the Americans, whose CO<->2 emissions have risen by 20% instead of the cut they agreed at Kyoto. (Their cars use twice as much petrol, which is cheaper than Coca-cola). The fear is that the US will just laugh at a shamefaced Europe, where country after country has caved in at the first challenge.

By chance this is the government's Flood Action Week, warning that global warming means a 10-fold flood increase this century. It looks depressingly unlikely that politics can deliver enough - or any - belt-tightening to save the world from global warming. The only hope is that higher prices make the cost of alternatives (wind and solar power) commercially enticing. It is happening in countries where governments kick-started it with heavy subsidies but Britain is losing out. (BP moved its solar panel factory to Europe.) Denmark is now the world's manufacturer of windmills, not us, though we have half of all Europe's wind potential.

fields.headline: But what if Blair loses?
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: This is Blair's first out-of-our-control crisis. So what is he to do? It is clear what model the prime minister has in mind: Lady Thatcher at her most determined. Determined (like her) to expose the pusillanimous weakness of the French government in rapidly conceding £300m worth of tax breaks to militant truckers.
fields.body:
This is Blair's first out-of-our-control crisis. So what is he to do? It is clear what model the prime minister has in mind: Lady Thatcher at her most determined. Determined (like her) to expose the pusillanimous weakness of the French government in rapidly conceding £300m worth of tax breaks to militant truckers.

Mr Blair asserted - in a made-for-TV soundbite on Monday - "We cannot and we will not alter government policy on petrol through blockades and pickets. That is not the way to make policy in Britain and, as far as I am concerned, it never will be."

Fighting talk and Gordon Brown echoed it yesterday in his speech to the TUC in Glasgow, albeit with a few crafty caveats which may yet provide ministers with a necessary loophole. It is all very well to sound "Churchillian" as Michael Portillo mockingly put it (and he should know), but only if you can make it stick and do so at modest political cost.

Clearly caught off-guard, Mr Blair's remarks were a gut response to a campaign he instinctively dislikes. They were made without consulting his pollsters or his focus groups and - surprise, surprise - they rapidly turned out to be as out of touch with the mood of the moment as his WI speech in Wembley.

What he sounded like was less Margaret "Lady's Not for Turning" Thatcher than John Major in mid-1992 telling anyone who would listen that a devaluation of sterling inside the EU's exchange rate mechanism (ERM) was a "fool's gold" option which simply would not happen. The markets thought otherwise and, backed by public opinion, may do so this time. Lady Thatcher, a more pragmatic politician than it ever suited her to admit, would not have been so rash, though she might have let a colleague play mini-Churchill and carry the can for subsequent failure.

In 2000 it will be hard for Mr Blair to walk away from a climbdown. There are no quick fixes here. By invoking emergency powers the cabinet hopes to force the colluding petrol companies to try harder to get their fuel out and force the police to treat the truckers as if they were striking miners.

It may even work, in which case fickle public opinion - and the Mail - will applaud. But if it does not then the government's duty is to talk, even it that means "discussions, not negotiations", a distinction the hapless French transport minister tried to make last week. It may not mean immediate concessions, but a nod from Mr Brown that he has got the message - and will do something in his pre-election budget. Even Mr Jospin's package will be spun out over two years.

After all, this is a government which prides itself on listening to middle England and appeasing its newspapers. It is a government which does not want to alienate motorists, of whom there are a lot. Many need their cars and will still need them when John Prescott has miraculously transformed public transport.

There is no shame in admitting that factors outside its control (rising world petrol prices) have combined with some within its control (green taxes and budget balancing) to threaten real hardship to important producer groups and - politically more important - consumers on wheels.

So far the Blairites have usually managed to pick on easy targets for their tough stances. But Downing Street would do well to remember the fox hunting controversy, where a seemingly easy target turned into the formidable Countryside Alliance. The government backed off then. It may have to again. At last night's No 10 press conference Mr Blair already sounded more emollient.

webTitle: A tried and tested recipe for chaos

fields.headline: A tried and tested recipe for chaos
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: As fuel crisis hysteria spread yesterday, the Tories fought inexplicably shy of complaining that the public was being held to ransom by a motley collection of interest groups egged on by the Sun and the Daily Mail. Instead, William Hague pronounced this a crisis "made in Downing Street."
fields.body:
As fuel crisis hysteria spread yesterday, the Tories fought inexplicably shy of complaining that the public was being held to ransom by a motley collection of interest groups egged on by the Sun and the Daily Mail. Instead, William Hague pronounced this a crisis "made in Downing Street."

In one sense he is right. The roots of this crisis are in Downing Street, though at Number 11, not Number 10 and in 1993, not 2000. It was then, in one of the few environmentally responsible actions that the Tory government ever undertook, that the then chancellor of the exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, brought in the fuel duty escalator, which automatically raised fuel duty above the level of inflation each year. Its purpose, apart from being a nice little earner for the Treasury, was to increase the cost of fuel to reflect the true environmental cost of motoring.

So if Mr Hague is looking for someone to blame, he could start a little closer to home than Tony Blair.

Mr Blair is far from blameless, but not in the way Mr Hague means. Labour's promise of an integrated transport policy that would be about more than just building roads - in honour of its pledge to "reduce then reverse traffic growth" - has been progressively enfeebled until now we have arrived at Lord MacDonald's formula of more roads and by-passes.

And the government enjoyed the benefits of increased taxes on motoring. Mr Blair was hostile to investment in the alternatives that John Prescott initially advocated. High fuel taxes and good public transport would feel a lot better than high fuel taxes and public transport that is inadequate, dirty, unreliable and expensive as usual.

But the truckers, farmers and fishermen who have brought us to this pass are not lobbying for better public transport. They are, rather, the battering ram that an unwholesome coalition of the Tory party, the tabloid press and a group of disaffected interest groups has managed to direct at the government.

Riding on the back of an assorted collection of grievances there is a political agenda. The men on the picket line claim that their action is spontaneous: according to the Devon farmer Richard Haddock of Farmers for Action, it was the French example last week that set his own phone ringing. Like many of this week's protesters, he had not been active in protests before. Now he spends most of his waking hours on the picket line in the company, he says, of an unstructured assortment of OAPs, fishermen and truckers.

It's an effective combination: the lack of formal involvement of big interest groups such as the NFU (who are sympathetic, according to Mr Haddock) means that there are no easy targets for injunctions and the passivity of the oil companies suggests they have, in any case, little to lose in this dispute. The combination of mobile phones and the internet makes networking easy and cheap.

The protesting farmers, like the fishermen and the truckers, are fuelled by a raging sense of grievance and a powerful feeling that nobody cares. Now they have found a way of getting our attention. But try to get hold of their case and it's not easy to see how lowering excise duty on fuel would solve their problems. Mr Haddock's grievances, shared by thousands of small farmers, encompass everything from the havoc wrought by the BSE crisis to the low prices he receives for his crops.

Nobody argues that farmers are having a good time, but the fact is that they pay almost no excise tax on the fuel they use on their farms, which makes them one of the few groups in the country who cannot reasonably blame the Treasury for the rise in fuel costs. The fishermen, too, have their troubles. But they pay no excise duty on their fuel at all, so for them to castigate fuel tax is doubly irrational. And as for the truckers, interesting though it is to see such a conservative body arguing for tax harmonisation with the EU, we should take it seriously only if it includes harmonisation - upwards - of business and income tax and of the wider cost of motoring, including motorway tolls. Level the playing field, by all means, but level all of it, and join the single currency while we are at it.

So why target fuel taxes? Partly because paralysing transport is a devastatingly effective weapon that has been used to great effect in the past by interest groups who want to make political chaos: when the CIA wanted to destabilise Salvador Allende's Chile in the early 1970s, they organised a truckers' strike because they knew that if they paralysed the roads and interrupted food supplies, they could create unrest and make the government look weak and incompetent. Add to that the hectoring of the newspaper El Mercurio, heavily subsidised by the CIA at the time, which mobilised its middle-class readers in Santiago to bang their saucepans for all the world as though they were hungry. Within days they had the desired disorder, all created under the cloak of what was made to appear like popular protest.

In Northern Ireland the Ulster Workers' Council strike of 1974, called by Loyalists unhappy with the Sunningdale power-sharing agreement, also targeted transport and succeeded in breaking the power-sharing executive. That was not a popular protest in the pure sense of the word either, but an example of effective popular mobilisation for political ends.

Nor, so far, is the petrol war a popular protest against the government, though as it escalates and with the inflammatory urging of the tabloids it could become so.

As far as the grievances on the picket lines are concerned, several palliatives suggest themselves. Britain could join the implausibly named Euroflutter scheme, which would impose a tax on foreign trucks using British roads. The farmers' prices could be made to reflect the cost of production. Or farm subsidies could be directed away from the big farmers to the small producers.

But the one option that does not appeal is that the government lower the duty on fuel. In a stand-off like this, nobody interested in democratic government has an interest in seeing the government give way.

webTitle: Police opt for softly, softly approach

fields.headline: Police opt for softly, softly approach
fields.standfirst:
Scotland Yard unit tries to devise peaceful end to crisis
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard unit tries to devise peaceful end to crisis
fields.body:
The police launched a nationwide strategic response to the fuel crisis yesterday as the home secretary Jack Straw and Sir John Evans, head of the Association of Chief Police Officers, held emergency talks over possible ways of ending the protests.

The Acpo-run national information centre, which collects intelligence from all forces in England and Wales so that officers can be deployed effectively, was reopened at Scotland Yard for the first time since Millennium eve.

Mr Straw and Sir John also convened the civil contingencies committee in the cabinet offices to discuss ways of breaking the deadlock.

Although yesterday's meetings were amicable, Sir John reminded the Home Secretary that chief constables are "operationally independent" and will not bow to pressure to use force against demonstrators.

Before yesterday the police had done very little to stop protesters setting up camp outside refineries and depots, preferring to "manage" the demonstrations as best they could once they were in place.

Many senior officers believe the government has drifted unwittingly into a full scale crisis and cannot look to the police to sort it out. Scarred by the experiences of the miners' strike when they were accused of being Margaret Thatcher's stormtroopers, forces re very reluctant to be drawn into protracted conflict again.

"Policing by consent is what it is all about in Britain," said Kevin Morris, president-elect of the Police Superintendents Association and a veteran of policing protests against live animal exports in Shoreham. "It would be appalling to go back to the way things were during the miners' strike. We don't want to get involved with that again."

Circumstances are different now. Before the miners' strike, the Conservatives introduced specific powers through the Employment Act of 1980 and 1982 to restrict picketing and secondary picketing.

"The government introduced laws to deliberately take on the miners in an industrial dispute and even then it took nine months to defeat them," Mr Morris added. "This is not an industrial dispute in the same way. It is a dispute involving an industry but there are different parties involved so those powers cannot be used."

The police can turn to the 1980 Road Traffic Act and the 1986 Public Order Act. They give officers the right to intervene when protesters are obstructing the highway or if they are turning violent. There are also common law powers relating to unlawful assembly and breaches of peace.

So far, there has been little appetite to use them. Other factors have also steered the police towards a policy of non-intervention. People are allowed to protest lawfully and human rights legislation demands that the police response be "proportional".

Many of the demonstrators have allowed emergency supplies to leave the refineries after talks with the police, so is it "proportional" to break up a peaceful protest forcibly, probably with an inevitable escalation to violence?

There are practical problems too. Very few police officers have heavy goods vehicle licences. If hauliers are arrested, the police will not be able to drive their lorries away. Officers would rather take the details of protesters and deal with them later rather than be confrontational.

"The government and the police have to respect the fact that these protests seem to have widespread public support," Mr Morris said.

Privately, senior officers say they would prefer the government to sanction army intervention rather than applying pressure on them to act.

Although the police have made it clear this is not a mess of their making, the forces were undoubtedly caught on the hop by the escalation of the dispute.

There was very little, if any intelligence on the likelihood of demonstrations, which has forced the police to adopt a defensive position.

The national information centre, at Scotland Yard, is used to coordinate police resourcing of critical situations, such as Millennium eve, and is linked to the Metropolitan police's "golf tango" special operations unit, which oversees London's uniformed response to emergency situations.

"There is no frustration between the police and Mr Straw," said a Home Office spokesman. "He respects the position the police are in. A strategy is being formulated but it is being kept under wraps unless and until it is needed."

A strategy is being formulated but it is being kept under wraps unless and until it is needed."

webTitle: Health service and buses hit hardest

fields.headline: Health service and buses hit hardest
fields.standfirst:
Worse could be yet to come, warn business leaders, public transport operators and tourism chiefs

Special report: Transport in Britain

Special report: The petrol war

Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Worse could be yet to come, warn business leaders, public transport operators and tourism chiefs
fields.body:
Public transport

Leaving the car at home and using public transport looked futile last night as bus companies stopped night services, diesel trains were cancelled, London Underground drivers struggled to get to work and taxis in the north began to charge double rates.

Stagecoach spokesman Barry Gardner said 75% of buses nationwide had enough fuel to run normal services until Friday. After that, less popular routes outside 8am to 6pm would have to be cancelled.

The worst hit were buses in the north-west and Wales. The Stagecoach bus depot in Chadderton, greater Manchester, yesterday ran out of fuel as did three other bus depots in Bolton, Wigan, and Glossop, Derbyshire. Bullocks bus company suspended all services in Cheshire and south Manchester between 10am and 3pm, while callers to BBC Greater Manchester Radio complained that taxis in the area were charging double rates.

In Gwent, Wales, around 50% of Stagecoach buses were cancelled and 30% of services stopped in Cheltenham and Gloucester.

From tomorrow, rural areas in Cumbria and Suffolk could become cut off outside rush hour.

Electric trams in Blackpool and Manchester were taking extra passengers and in Merseyside electric trains were preparing to run extra services.

But two-thirds of the national train network runs on diesel fuel and the Association of Train Operating Companies said yesterday that companies only had enough to last until Friday.

South West Trains began cancelling services yesterday, terminating its London Waterloo to Paignton, south Devon, service around 30 miles short at Exeter. This was likely to be repeated today.

The Brighton to Reading service was being terminated at Basingstoke.

Railtrack had to call in extra staff to control crowds at peak hour times, and some train companies reported a 50% increase in passengers.

Railtrack has brought in extra beds at key locations so that staff can sleep between shifts. Diesel fuel supplies a considerable part of the rural network so train operating companies in these areas will be the first to suffer when supplies dry up.

Meanwhile, the British Airports Authority yesterday advised airlines to refuel at Heathrow or Gatwick airports, which have so far been unaffected because they have private pipelines for fuel. East Midlands, Luton and Liverpool airports asked airlines such as Easy Jet to refuel abroad and enter Britain with enough for a round trip.
Angelique Chrisafis and Keith Harper

Health service

The Department of Health warned last night that the fuel blockade was putting the NHS under "massive pressure" as people who could not get home visits by GPs and district nurses turned up at hospitals' accident and emergency departments. Many ambulance crews were answering emergency calls only.

A spokesman blamed the crisis for the cancellation of dozens of operations yesterday. "There is no doubt that the longer the blockades continue, the more chance there is of lives being put at risk," he said.

"GPs and district nurses are not able to visit elderly and vulnerable people in their own homes. Ambulances have cancelled non-emergency journeys and NHS staff are having great problems getting to work in many areas.

"This means that operations are now being cancelled and A&E departments are coming under more pressure as people cannot call out doctors easily."

The department said NHS blood stocks were reasonably high, but fuel shortages were hindering the collection of newly donated blood in some parts of the country. "Blood supplies are being moved around the country causing delays to deliveries. Vital hospital supplies - including medicines - are beginning to run low in some places," the spokesman said.

NHS managers were working to find emergency fuel supplies and pool meagre resources. Emergency planning teams, normally only used to ease pressures in the health service during the winter, were being set up to deal with the crisis.

Some local health authorities were issuing doctors, nurses and other health workers with special certificates to allow them to access emergency fuel supplies.

Protesters yesterday allowed fuel supplies earmarked for local ambulance services through the noose round refineries at Stanlow in Cheshire and Grangemouth, near Edinburgh, as well as distribution depots in Ipswich and Leeds.

Motorway garages also introduced a guaranteed supply system for emergency services, including all 42 sites run by Granada. London's big hospitals also held a joint meeting to draw up emergency plans to pool fuel for back-up generators if the crisis deepened, while routine operations were cancelled in mid-Wales and Staffordshire ambulances imposed a 55mph limit on non-urgent callouts.
John Carvel and Martin Wainwright

Supermarkets and shops

Some shops and supermarkets have seen customers clearing the shelves of bread, milk, flour and sugar as panic buying has shifted from petrol to groceries.

Although supermarkets assured customers they had enough fuel for food deliveries for the foreseeable future, this actually meant up to the weekend, according to the British Retail Consortium.

Drivers at the frozen food company Iceland claimed they would not be able to make food deliveries after tomorrow.

Tim Mason, marketing director at Tesco, said yesterday that ultimately fresh food supplies would be affected by the fuel crisis. However, a company spokeswoman said there had been no evidence of panic buying.

Staff at shops and supermarkets in the West Country have witnessed panic buying of fresh and dried milk, bread and flour. Pat Bint, acting manageress of Londis in South Cerney, near Cirencester, sold out of bread and milk within 90 minutes of the shop opening yesterday.

Sales at Somerfield's supermarket at Malmesbury, Wiltshire, had increased by 7% over the last four days. Shelves were being cleared of bread, milk, eggs and sugar, according to store manager Stuart Yeandel.

Roy Litchfield, treasurer of the National Association of Shopkeepers, warned that commerce could grind to a halt because of the shortage of fuel. He said the impact could be felt by shopkeepers within the next five to seven days. "It is really going to start to bite in the next few days. How are they supposed to get food to people if there is no petrol and there are no buses to transport people into towns and cities?"
Helen Carter

Business

The Confederation of British Industry yesterday warned that the country's hard-pressed manufacturing sector would start shutting down production lines today because of the fuel crisis.

The motor industry, food processing and steel manufacturing were running out of raw materials, had fuel shortages or had nowhere to store the goods which could not be delivered.

Service industries were finding difficulty getting out to see clients and workers in rural areas without public transport could not get to work.

A CBI spokesperson said: "It does look serious but some sectors are worse hit than others."

Transport companies saw their shares take a battering on the stock market as companies such as P&O, Hays and Excel were marked down by City pessimists.

A spokesman for P&O, which delivers containers and other goods from Tilbury and Southampton docks, said the crisis "is beginning to impede the flow of goods around the country."

Virgin said its megastores could run out of CDs and mobile phones within two weeks if they could not be restocked.

The Energy Intensive Users Group, which represents steelmakers and papermakers, said: "We have seen gas prices rise by 50% this year already and have been having a private fuel crisis which is only just registering with politicians now."
Terry Macalister

Local services

Local authorities have begun suspending non-essential public services amid mounting concern that the continued blockade of refineries and oil depots could soon start to force school closures in some parts of Britain.

Council leaders urged ministers to ensure that any emergency powers were used to direct fuel resources to priority areas such as fire services, refuse collection and care services for the elderly and other vulnerable people.

Emergency plans have already been drawn up by councils to eke out dwindling fuel stocks by dropping non-essential services such as mobile libraries, grass cutting and street cleaning.

In Devon, as in other rural areas, bus operators are being advised not to take children to school unless they know they have enough fuel for the return journey.

In Somerset, three rural primary schools will be closed today because staff are unable to get there. Free schoool meals for 10,000 children have been suspended and hundreds of pupils will miss school because some bus companies have run out of fuel.

In Leeds, 1,300 children at 11 special schools have been told their bus service may stop. In Essex, 44 pupils at De La Salle secondary school in Basildon woke up to be told their school bus would not be running. In Nottingham, two private bus companies providing school transport are running out of fuel.
Geoff Gibbs

Tourism

Tourist operators in rural areas said yesterday they were facing a disastrous collapse in bookings unless the fuel crisis was resolved in the next few days.

Chris Collier, chief executive of the Cumbria tourist board, said scores of small businesses were likely to fold as holidaymakers rushed to cancel bookings in the Lake District, amid fears that they would become stranded without petrol.

She said the tourist board had been inundated by calls from worried hoteliers, including the owner of a bed and breakfast who reported taking cancellations worth £2,500 in the space of a morning.

"The situation is extremely serious for Cumbria," she said. "September and October are traditionally our busiest months, and 95% of our visitors come by car."

One hotelier in Ambleside said he had lost £1,400 in cancelled bookings in 24 hours. Michael Fletcher, owner of the Nanny Brow country house hotel on Windermere, said he had only a week's supply of fuel oil left to heat the 18-bedroom hotel, and had asked guests to ration the number of baths they take. "We have quite a lot of staff here and we have to run the place whether we have 25 guests or 10 guests. If we're still in the same situation next week it will start to bite very hard indeed," he said.

Simon Bradley, the head of operations at South-west Tourism, said the situation was "very serious" for the economies of Devon and Cornwall. "We depend heavily on tourism in this region - in some areas it is the major employer," he said. "Undoubtedly, visitors are deciding not to come and that makes it absolutely crucial that this situation is resolved. September is a critical month." One major tourist operator in the south-west said it was laying on accomodation at rock bottom prices in case holidaymakers were stranded without enough fuel to travel home.

News of the fuel crisis is beginning to affect bookings from overseas, the British Tourist Authority said, with holidaymakers and business travellers thinking twice about coming to Britain while the shortages continue.

fields.headline: Oil giants accused of collusion
fields.standfirst:
Business may be in cahoots with pickets, says Straw aide
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Business may be in cahoots with pickets, says Straw aide
fields.body:
The oil companies were on a collision course with Tony Blair last night over their failure to dispatch tankers from storage depots immediately to replenish the country's empty petrol stations.

With a relatively small number of pickets managing to immobilise Britain, some ministers privately accused the companies of either colluding with the protesters or taking a line of no resistance.

Police around the country insist that there is free movement in most areas and only limited picketing. But outside some depots small groups of protesters are discussing with managers which deliveries should be allowed and giving "dispensations" only to fuel for the emergency services.

After crisis talks in Downing Street, John Prescott gave a hint of the government's frustration by telling the companies that it was their responsibility to ensure that supplies got to the forecourts.

Ray Holloway, director of the Petrol Retailers Association, said it was right to ask why tankers were being kept in the depots despite the fact that the police had cleared almost all the blockades.

"It is reasonable to postulate that the oil companies have made a collective decision not to send out their tankers. We have to establish whether there is a real picket line and there is danger to the drivers, or if it is just protesters. And if there is no picket line, then you would be perfectly right to ask why not."

The government's anger was underlined by Lord Mackenzie, a former senior policeman who now advises the home secretary, Jack Straw, on law and order, who said he was baffled that tankers were not leaving depots.

"It does not add up to me," he said. "The people who are demonstrating, in a sense, I suppose, are supporters of the Conservative party. There's something not right about it. It's not a normal demonstration and they should get their sleeves rolled up and start delivering the oil where it belongs, at the petrol stations."

Lord Mackenzie, a senior officer during the l984-5 miners' strike, said many protests seemed so minimal that they could not be regarded as picketing. "Roads are often not blocked - if they were, the police would not hesitate in arresting people," he said. "It seems to be the companies causing the difficulty, and there does seem some collusion with the protesters. Perhaps it's because if the fuel duty was reduced they would sell more petrol."

With conspiracy theories flying thick and fast, Dave Bryan, the TGWU transport union national officer representing truckers, said tankers were idle "because there has been a number of incidents in recent days where drivers have been physically abused by motorists and even followed home there is evidence of intimidation".

When the Guardian contacted several leading oil companies, they maintained a common line. Asked why their tankers were not leaving refineries and depots, a spokeswoman for Shell - more than half of whose 1,100 stations are running dry - said: "We are concerned for the safety of our drivers and do not want to take any risk."

Asked what threats drivers were facing, she mentioned an "incident" last Friday in which a traffic cone was thrown at a tanker.

BP, with close to three quarters of its 1,500 stations out of action, came close to hinting it that was the victim of a government-inspired smear campaign, and said tankers would only leave depots with a police escort.

The oil companies have been making bumper profits as the result of soaring crude prices, but not from the higher pump prices. Their profit margins on the forecourt are slim because of intense competition .

Their profit comes from the rise in wholesale price of the oil they sell on to other corporations. They would like to see the government reduce the cut it takes at the petrol pump to stop consumer anger.

In theory the companies can take out injunctions to remove the protesters from their depots and refineries.

Andrew Ward, the corporate communications manager of TotalElfFina, told the BBC: "We have investigated the legal implications of this. We are advised injunctions would be difficult because the protest is not by an official union presence, so therefore it would be difficult to serve injunctions, because we would have to serve many injunctions on individuals."

Told that the police were saying that the roads were free of illegal picketing, he replied: "We are at the moment liaising with police on a terminal basis to try and get our vehicles out of the terminals."

Later, a company spokesman said "The mood of the protesters is fairly amicable, and if we were to send drivers out it might change. Getting fuel to the pumps would only solve the short-term problem and not deal with the original concerns of protesters."

webTitle: The ordinary folk who decide who gets fuel

fields.headline: The ordinary folk who decide who gets fuel
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: The horn has sounded, a shout of "board meeting" goes up and 100 or so people gather together. Their leader stands on the back of a red pick-up truck and puts forward suggestions: would they let district nurses have fuel; are rural vets an emergency service?
fields.body:
The horn has sounded, a shout of "board meeting" goes up and 100 or so people gather together. Their leader stands on the back of a red pick-up truck and puts forward suggestions: would they let district nurses have fuel; are rural vets an emergency service?

These are some of the key protesters who decide whether to grant or deny special requests for fuel. The hospitals? "Yes". West coast trains? "Bollocks to it". Mersey docks? They laughed. The media? "OK, our story would be nowhere without them."

The decision-makers are not just farmers and hauliers but taxi drivers, small businessmen, postmen, the unemployed and even a magician - but together they are stopping fuel from getting out of Shell's Stanlow terminal in Ellesmere Port, Cheshire.

These people are remote from the world of revolt, they deny they are militant. But speak to them long enough and it becomes apparent that it is not just the price of fuel that bothers them. It is foreign truck drivers "making a killing here", weights are in kilograms rather than pounds, that the EU says "cucumbers must be straight", the "dictatorial style" of Tony Blair and how this country has "gone down the pan".

This new wave of protesters say they will stay on their picket lines until they get what they want: less tax on fuel and parity with other EU countries on petrol prices and road fund licences.

Alison Tate turned up at Stanlow at 6.30pm on Saturday with a caravan in tow. She and her husband, Tony, from Durham, are unemployed and have taken their six-year-old daughter Stephanie out of school to join the protest. They expected to stay only for the weekend but now they are running an ad-hoc snack bar for the protesters.

"They need the support of the ordinary people - not just the hauliers and not just the farmers - because we use petrol as well," Mrs Tate said. "I have never been involved in a protest before but this one is different, it's about everybody."

Alex Moore, who runs his own landscaping and fencing business, said:"It's not natural Labour supporters here. I have never done anything like this before. It's the first thing I have felt that I could do something about."

Clive Swan, a beef producer from Mold, one of the movement's spokesmen, said: "This protest started with farmers and hauliers. We have now got to the stage where we have got taxi drivers and people representing all types of business and members of the public as well. It proves that everybody is hurting for the same reason."

Alex Moore, who runs his own landscaping and fencing business, said:"It's not natural Labour supporters here. I have never done anything like this before. It's the first thing I have felt that I could do something about." Clive Swan, a beef producer from Mold, one of the movement's spokesmen, said: "This protest started with farmers and hauliers. fields.headline: High and dry
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: South Wales police issued a warning about fuel thieves and advised motorists to park cars in garages and use locking petrol caps.
fields.body:
Wales

South Wales police issued a warning about fuel thieves and advised motorists to park cars in garages and use locking petrol caps.

The All Wales Ambulance Service said it was taking emergency calls only. Hospitals cancelled outpatient appointments and elective surgery.

According to the AA, South Wales was yesterday almost out of unleaded fuel.

An undertaker in Llandudno, North Wales, is declining to carry out long distance funerals because of the risk of the hearse running out of petrol before it can get home.

Hospitals in Abergavenny, Caerphilly, Newport, Merthyr and Bangor have cancelled routine surgery because beds are blocked by patients awaiting ambulances home.

All 19 high schools in the Rhondda Cynon Taff area of the South Wales valleys are expected to close due to transport problems.

Rubbish collections are being suspended in the Vale of Glamorgan.

Midlands

Aircraft using East Midlands airport in Leicestershire were advised to refuel abroad.

In Moseley, motorists reported fights between drivers at petrol stations.

There were reports of a van going round Newtown, Birmingham, selling petrol for £5 a gallon.

Two slow-moving lorries brought the M6 between junction 8 and 10, the busiest stretch of motorway in Europe, to a standstill.

West Midlands fire service postponed non-emergency callouts and cut training in an attempt to save fuel.

A bride-to-be in Birmingham booked her brother's electric-powered milk float as her wedding carriage after her plan to hire a limousine fell victim to the fuel crisis.

South-west

Hospitals in Bristol were urging staff to conserve fuel amid fears they could be left stranded at home.

A fuel barge on the river Dart that usually caters for yachts and commercial trawlers was besieged by motorists in rubber dinghies and other boats trying to get hold of fuel.

Rail services between Paignton and Exeter were cancelled because of the crisis.

Devon county council postponed all meetings and halted non-essential services this week to save fuel.

Rural shops in Gloucestershire reported Christmas-like takings as customers began hoarding food. A shop in Cirencester ran out of milk, bread and flour in an hour and a half.

The North

Shell said its fleet of 60 tankers was idle at a refinery near Ellesmere Port because of threats of intimidation against their drivers.

Trains and buses in the north-west were packed as commuters took to public transport.

An AA spokeswoman in Yorkshire said it was estimated that about 50 petrol stations in the region had run dry.

The RSPCA said it was struggling to respond to calls about animal casualties in the north-west, Wales, Herefordshire and Gloucestershire because vehicles had run out of fuel.

A pump attendant in West Yorkshire was punched in the face by acustomer when he said there was no fuel left.

London

Hospital chiefs at St Thomas's have halted non-essential transport services, including community transport for the elderly, as a precautionary measure.

Protesters outside the Buncefield fuel distribution depot near Hemel Hempstead stopped fuel being delivered to Luton airport.

A coroner in Hornsey cancelled all inquests until further notice because officers and witnesses were having trouble getting to court.

The Radio 1 DJ Scott Mills missed half an hour of his breakfast show yesterday because of the fuel shortage after the cab firm due to pick him up ran out of petrol.

There were delays on the M25 after a convoy of lorries mounted a demonstration over fuel prices.

Scotland

Aberdeen, Europe's oil capital, ground to a halt as hundreds of truckers and farmers blocked all the main roads into the city during the morning rush hour.

An RAF rescue helicopter airlifted victims of a road crash involving a car and a school bus to Aberdeen Royal Infirmary because ambulances were delayed by the protest.

Dozens of lorries arrived at the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre in Glasgow where the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was addressing the TUC conference.

Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, cancelled a planned audience with the Queen at Balmoral to hold emergency talks on the crisis.

At Grangemouth, Scotland's main oil refinery, around 60 trucks set up a blockade. Only tankers carrying fuel for two hospitals were allowed to leave.

South-east and East Anglia

A lorry driver taking part in a fuel protest blockade on the A1 in Cambridgeshire was arrested after being warned by police about weaving in and out of the lanes of the southbound carriageway. He was taking part in a blockade of the road from Peterborough southbound, which caused jams of up to 20 miles.

Ferry operators and Eurotunnel have reported a surge of people booking trips across the channel to buy fuel in Europe.

All buses in Ipswich were due to halt at 7pm last night. Most other operators in the area said that off-peak services would be withdrawn until the situation improved.

fields.headline: Down to the last drop
fields.standfirst:
Blair tells oil firms to resume deliveries
Police promise to protect tanker drivers
90% of petrol stations out of fuel
Buses, trains and schools affected
NHS faces crisis, operations cancelled
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was at the centre of an extraordinary attempt to prevent the British economy collapsing into total paralysis last night when he made a series of personal pleas to oil bosses to instruct their tanker drivers to restore exhausted supplies to the country's petrol stations.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was at the centre of an extraordinary attempt to prevent the British economy collapsing into total paralysis last night when he made a series of personal pleas to oil bosses to instruct their tanker drivers to restore exhausted supplies to the country's petrol stations.

But with Britain's car- and road-based economy less than 48 hours from total shutdown, endangering hospital operations and food supplies, there was no immediate sign that the majority of tanker drivers would respond.

Mr Blair promised the oil companies that the police would provide complete protection to drivers, including escorts.

The tanker drivers, many of them sympathetic to the road hauliers' complaints, say they are too frightened to drive out of the refineries and oil depots.

But, giving the first indication that the police will get tough with the protesters, an order was served on 20 pickets last night to leave private property to stop blocking refineries in Colwick, Nottinghamshire.

The Police Superintendents' Association said officers would have no choice but to make sure that tankers were able to leave depots and deliver their fuel if oil companies decided to send them out.

A spokeswoman for BP said the company planned to move petrol once "assurances" had been given about drivers' safety.

It was "speculation" to say that drivers might refuse to cross the protest lines, and might take strike action if forced to do so.

Last night tankers taking petrol to empty filling stations left Purfleet refinery, in Essex: the first sign that the crisis might be easing.

A police officer sat beside the driver of each tanker and police cars drove alongside as an escort.

In Downing Street the government's civil contingencies committee was monitoring movements.

By the time Mr Blair spoke, the petrol companies were predicting that 90% of their stations would have run out of fuel by this morning.

The monumental scale of the crisis yesterday hit the transport system, the health service, food supplies, schools and businesses.

A dramatic day started with the Prime Minister abandoning a visit to Yorkshire and rushing back to Downing Street to take personal charge of a round of crisis meetings.

Despite further panic buying and continuing public support for the protests, Mr Blair gave an early evening press conference vowing that he would not buckle.

He insisted that the government could not change tax policy between budgets in response "to blockades, illegal pickets and direct action".

"Legitimate protest is one thing. Trying to bring the country to a halt is quite another," he said.

Raising already impossibly high stakes, Mr Blair said: "Were we to yield to that pressure it would run counter to every democratic principle this country believes in, and what is more, if the government was to decide its policy on taxes in response to such behaviour, the credibility of economic policy vital to any country would be severely damaged.

"I will simply not allow that to happen."

In a frantic attempt to prevent Britain descending into total chaos, Mr Blair spent the afternoon on the phone urging the chairmen and chief executives of the five big oil companies to force their tanker drivers to recommence supplies.

There has been suspicion in the government for some time that the oil companies have been sitting on their hands, either because they would like to see fuel duty cut or because their employees are sympathetic towards the road hauliers.

Ministers acknowledge that they have been urging greater coordination between the oil companies and the police for 48 hours, with little sign that the drivers are willing to break the blockades and restore the deliveries of non-essential supplies.

After his round of phone calls to the oil bosses, Mr Blair said: "We have made the necessary emergency order of council. The oil companies are agreed that they must move supplies."

The police had agreed to do "all that is necessary" to protect against intimidation.

"The main union concerned has issued a strong statement urging members to work normally.

"Everything is now in place to get the tankers moving. We hope in the next 24 hours to have the situation on the way back to normal. It will take longer than that to be fully back to normal."

If there is no significant breakthrough, Mr Blair will be forced to invoke emergency powers and send in the army to take over the distribution of petrol.

Exposing the deep fears in the cabinet about the political implications of this crisis, the Education Secretary, David Blunkett, became the first minister to draw open parallels with the Winter of Discontent of 1979-80, saying: "We are all bound by our history and remember the 'Crisis? What crisis'."

At a round of meetings of the civil contingency committee yesterday, plans were laid for designating 150 petrol stations around the country for the exclusive supply of petrol to the emergency services. Meetings were held at the Department of Trade and Industry with the petrol retailers to organise supplies.

The only sign of a political concession by Mr Blair were some hints that he would be willing to cut petrol duty in the Budget, or the pre-budget report in November.

He said: "The proper time to make proper budget judgments is at the time of the budget, when the year can be looked at as a whole."

Mr Blair was hoping that a strong plea to the tanker drivers from Bill Morris, general secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, would have some influence on the tanker drivers.

Mr Morris warned the drivers that they had to go back to work, saying: "The campaign has crossed the line from democracy and into anarchy."

Other union leaders called on the pickets to be hauled in front of the courts, just as striking miners were in the 80s.

However, many of the drivers are not members of the TGWU, and even more are unlikely to be moved by Mr Morris's instructions.

fields.headline: Industry facing volatile future
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Oil prices could more than double to nearly $70 per barrel in the next 12 months, an industry guru warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Oil prices could more than double to nearly $70 per barrel in the next 12 months, an industry guru warned yesterday.

He said that even if the price of crude remained at its current level, the effect could be "more dramatic" than the crisis of the 1970s.

Steven Strongin, an economist from US blue chip investment bank, Goldman Sachs, said much depended on whether there was a cold winter, which would send demand for heating oil soaring at a time of short supplies. This would cut into the core of western economic growth, he told a seminar in London.

Mr Strongin expected there to be much more volatility in oil prices over the coming year, with a 5% probability that they could hit $67 per barrel.

However, he believed the price of the benchmark West Intermediate (WTI) oil would average around its current level of $32 per barrel over the next year. This would compare with the single figure levels it reached 18 months ago.

Yesterday, the WTI price for October delivery was $35.25 per barrel, up from $35.04 the day before, while North Sea Brent Blend was virtually unchanged at $35.58.

He said that, overall, the current price spike should be shortlived but quickly followed by others because demand was strong and supply weak.

His overall view of the economic impact of the crisis was: "It may be more dramatic [than the 1970s] but it is going to be more transient."

Mr Strongin believed no-one could be blamed for the current problems. The oil companies were just "bystanders" who had inevitably cut drilling rates when times were tough.

He did not see the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) as anything more than a collection of individual countries pursuing their own narrow self-interest.

webTitle: How old tech oil put skids under new economy

fields.headline: How old tech oil put skids under new economy
fields.standfirst:
Recession rather than inflation the biggest threat
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Recession rather than inflation the biggest threat
fields.body:
As the queues formed outside the few remaining petrol stations open for business yesterday and panic buying for food began, economists who have pioneered the view that the world has become a virtual marketplace in which energy no longer matters were left scratching their heads.

Britain - after just two days of protest - had moved from a country in which the government talked about the benefits of a "new economy" to one in which emergency powers were being invoked to deal with a crisis caused by the oldest of old technologies - a shortage of fuel.

It is not just in Britain that governments are concerned about the possibility of the old economy biting back. President Bill Clinton has warned the oil producers' cartel, Opec, that it could plunge the global economy into recession unless it produces more oil, and the US government is considering whether to release oil from its strategic petroleum reserve to increase supplies and lower prices.

Professor Andrew Oswald, of Warwick University, is one of those who believe that the significance of the new economy has been overstated. He argues that the three previous sharp increases in the price of crude since 1973 have all led to recessions and that the fourth - the fourfold increase since the beginning of last year - will have the same impact. Prof Oswald rejects the idea that the computer chip and the mobile phone are the visible signs of a "weightless" world not vulnerable to energy shocks.

"Oil is an important input. Most especially, its price influences the prices of other energy sources, and so, in turn, determines lots of other infuential prices in the economy. [And] employment and output respond."

Economic historians now believe that the low level of oil prices in the three decades after the second world war helped to create the conditions for the long burst of economic growth from 1945 to 1973, and that the price collapse in the aftermath of the 1991 Gulf war has been equally important to the success of the US economy. Cheap energy has pushed down inflation, allowing the Federal Reserve, America's central bank, to foster growth by keeping interest rates low.

The key question now is what happens next? In theory, all three of the world's major economic blocs are vulnerable. Japan, which is only just emerging from recession, is highly exposed to higher oil prices, the combination of more expensive energy and the declining euro has already pushed inflation in the single-currency zone above 2% and triggered an increase in interest rates from the European Central Bank, while the boost to corporate profits from cheap oil, which has been a crucial factor in underpinning share prices on Wall Street, could quickly evaporate.

According to figures due to be released by the International Monetary Fund next week, 2000 will be the best year for the overall global economy in a decade.

But already there have been signs of a slowdown prompted by the rise in the cost of a barrel of crude oil from under $10 in early 1999 to around $35 last night.

Economists see recession - rather than a burst of 70s-style high inflation - as the big threat. Graham Turner, of consultancy firm, GFC Economics, said that the real problem with oil was not the increase in demand but supply-side factors specific to the oil market.

"Although the global economy has staged an impressive comeback since the economic crisis of 1997-98, the failure of non-energy prices to stage a more meaningful recovery suggests that high oil prices are not a reflection of a wider global imbalance between supply and demand.

"Supply restrictions certainly played a key role in lifting prices from the lows experienced at the end of 1998, but in recent months speculative forces appear to have taken on a greater significance."

Mr Turner added that the slowdown in the global economy caused by higher oil prices would eventually lead to the pricking of the speculative bubble, which in turn would bring prices down again.

Analysts believe that the impact of dearer fuel is being felt by both consumers and businesses. Consumers' living standards are affected directly by the extra expense involved in filling up their cars with fuel or by the higher cost of public transport, while the ultra-competitive global market has meant that businesses are finding it hard to pass on the full cost of the rise in the cost of energy to their customers.

Mike Lenhoff, of City firm Capel Cure Sharp, said that growth in real (inflation-adjusted) wages in the UK was lower now than it was at the start of 1999. "The bottom line is that higher oil prices have already done much to squeeze real income growth."

The scale of the slowdown depends on how policymakers react. In the short term, dearer oil will push up inflation but it is the medium and long-term effects that really count. If politicians and central bankers conclude that the result of higher energy prices will lead to knock-on effects, with workers able to secure higher pay to compensate for the reduction in their living standards, then the result will be higher interest rates and an increased chance of a hard landing.

However, if there are no so-called second round effects, policymakers will assume that the spike in inflation caused by the dearer crude oil will unwind as the economy slows and oil prices start to subside. The next few months will prove vital.

Consumers' living standards are affected directly by the extra expense involved in filling up their cars with fuel or by the higher cost of public transport, while the ultra-competitive global market has meant that businesses are finding it hard to pass on the full cost of the rise in the cost of energy to their customers. However, if there are no so-called second round effects, policymakers will assume that the spike in inflation caused by the dearer crude oil will unwind as the economy slows and oil prices start to subside. The next few months will prove vital.

fields.headline: Farmers already get subsidy
fields.standfirst:
Low duty on fuel that pulls the plough
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Low duty on fuel that pulls the plough
fields.body:
For more than 200,000 privileged people in Britain, cheap fuel is constantly on tap. Ironically farmers, the driving force behind many blockades and pickets, benefit from a huge diesel subsidy, which rarely attracts attention.

The £250m-a-year hand-out ensures that the fuel used to power tractors and other vehicles on the land - but not officially on the open road - comes at a third of the cost of the diesel on the filling station forecourt. Red diesel - so called because it is tinged red - is delivered straight to the farm and attracts excise duty of only 3.13p a litre. This means it currently sells at around 23.9p a litre.

The government slaps duty of 48.82p on conventional diesel, often pumping up its price to more than 80p a litre.

Customs and excise, which oversees red diesel distribution and use, accepts that the cost difference is, in effect, a subsidy.

Introduced after 1945 to bolster food production, red diesel is now seen by some agricultural economists as an anomaly difficult to justify.

"It is a mystery to me why farmers are protesting about the government's approach to fuel duty when agriculture gets such special treatment," said Neil Ward, senior lecturer in geography at Newcastle University, who helped produce a cabinet office report last year on rural economics.

Although the use of red diesel off the farm is prohibited, it has long been suspected that farmers pump it into four-wheel drive vehicles for the road and use it to take animals to market. Customs and excise says it sometimes makes "lightning raids" on vehicles to ensure that the system is not being abused.

Yet the militant farmers behind the current protests deny they are being given special treatment. David Handley, chairman of the pressure group Farmers For Action, said: "We're not subsidised on anything. I don't know where this bloody nonsense has come from. I have got agricultural equipment on this farm which allows me to carry out my duties on the farm. I am not allowed to take any of my vehicles on to the road."

Mr Handley, who has 140 cattle on 36 hectares (88 acres) in Monmouthshire, near the English border, added: "The price of our diesel over the last 11 months has jumped 50%. Right. My income has fallen 50%. Now someone wants to tell the public the figures don't quite stack up."

Sean Ricard, former chief economist at the National Farmers' Union and now a lecturer in management at Cranfield University, said that while lower-cost fuel was an accepted part of farming, hauliers had a "much stronger case" for a reduction because derv was much cheaper on the continent.

fields.headline: Leaders condemn protests
fields.standfirst:
TUC watches from sidelines as bosses picket

Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: TUC watches from sidelines as bosses picket
fields.body:
Trade union leaders yesterday queued up to condemn the petrol protesters and called for pickets breaking the law to be arrested.

General secretaries criticised the blockades after hearing reports that nurses, council staff and other employees had been told to stay at home.

Bill Morris, head of the Transport and General Workers Union, said: "This campaign has crossed the line from democracy to anarchy. If they are breaking the law, the protesters should be arrested."

The most effective industrial action for years is overshadowing the annual TUC congress in Glasgow and risks embarrassing a sidelined labour movement.

While union delegates discussed training and partnerships with business yesterday, the demonstrators they opposed were triggering Tony Blair's biggest industrial crisis.

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB, said the government would have faced even bigger problems if the unions were involved. But the unions' problem is that they are not involved. Instead they are watching helplessly as farmers, self employed drivers and hauliers make the running.

An embarrassed senior official in one of Britain's biggest unions joked that the TUC should launch a "let us work" campaign against employers in revenge for the 1926 General Strike or, in the spirit of true partnership, join their bosses on the picket lines.

Most union leaders have little sympathy with the non-union drivers and firms. They recall that lorry drivers have repeatedly driven through picket lines.

Danny Bryan, national secretary of the TGWU's road transport group, accused some pickets of bully-boy tactics. "We have evidence of the windscreen of a lorry being smashed over the weekend, our drivers being physically abused and there are rumours of drivers being followed to their houses," he said.

Rodney Bickerstaffe, general secretary of the Unison public service staff union, contrasted the support of Tory tabloids for the oil blockade with their opposition to union strikes.

The oil giants, added Mr Bickerstaffe, would almost certainly take legal action against unions if they took industrial action before winning a ballot.

"The vast majority of these pickets are self employed. I'm not saying that there is a conspiracy but I believe that there is an unwritten agreement with the petrol companies."

Steve Pickering, the GMB deputy general secretary, said: "It is an amazing situation when bosses are picketing the workers. It would be strange if small businesses and Tory spokespeople were to force concessions by the same tactics they so vehemently denounced during the 1980s."

fields.headline: Anger spreads across continent
fields.standfirst:
Lorry drivers paralyse EU capitals
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Lorry drivers paralyse EU capitals
fields.body:
Blocked roads, wildcat action and frayed nerves tested the patience of commuters and consumers across continental Europe again yesterday as anger over the price of petrol spread - hitting Germany for the first time.

In the centre of the Belgian capital Brussels lorries sealed off all exits to the Rond Point Schuman - considered the symbolic heart of Europe - as talks between the Belgian government and militant hauliers continued for a second day.

Further afield, Polish drivers and fishermen were reported to be considering blockades against the country's fuel depots, refineries and ports.

The European commission said it was powerless to act against blockades unless the movement of goods across EU frontiers was affected. But ambassadors of the 15 member states agreed to hold an emergency meeting of their transport ministers next week.

France's controversial deci sion to concede fuel tax cuts after six days of protests and blockades by truckers and farmers has, however, made it hard for other European governments to hold the line.

Also in Brussels, motoring organisations from five countries, including the British RAC, called on governments to negotiate with Opec - the cartel of oil-producing countries - whose announcement of increased production to lower pump prices last week has done nothing to end protests, or to convince governments to reduce fuel taxes.

"Governments should not give tax concessions to minority special interest groups taking direct action," the RAC said. "Rather they should defend the public interest and secure the right to mobility at an affordable price."

Protests continued in the Netherlands, with blockades slowing traffic on motorways surrounding Rotterdam, the capital Amsterdam and its airport at Schipol.

In Germany, truckers threatened to disrupt the country's transport network from tomorrow. Farmers in Hamburg said they would join the country's transport and taxi strike to press the government to cut diesel taxes and postpone plans to introduce an ecological tax on fuel.

Police said that about 100 trucks were joined by bus and taxi drivers for a protest at Saarbrücken. The German finance minister, Hans Eichel, repeated that scrapping the country's new energy tax would mean a rise in pension contributions.

Belgian truckers mounted their third day of blockades, vowing to stay put for weeks unless the government met their demands for lower diesel prices. Action spread to the southern cities of Charleroi and Nivelles.

"One week, 15 days, three weeks - no problem," said lorry driver Jean Bury.

Lorry drivers in Ireland have also vowed to take action from Friday unless their similar demands are met, though the Dublin government has said it will not act outside its budget framework.

Angry Spanish farmers were reportedly planning a series of protests after talks with the government in Madrid failed to reach a deal on how to compensate them for rising transport costs.

webTitle: Echoes of the Winter of Discontent

fields.headline: Echoes of the Winter of Discontent
fields.standfirst:
The 70s Widespread disruption broke pay limit

Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: The 70s Widespread disruption broke pay limit
fields.body:
David Blunkett's invocation yesterday of the Winter of Discontent - the industrial explosion that helped sink the last Labour government and the party's bitterest crisis of the past half century - is an unmistakable sign of ministers' determination not to let the hauliers' oil blockade run out of control.

"We are all bound by history," he warned. "We all remember the 'Crisis, what crisis?' of 30 years ago."

The words Crisis, what crisis? - which actually came 21 years ago - were the Sun's headline caricaturing prime minister Jim Callaghan's apparent nonchalance as he returned from a world summit in Guadeloupe: it epitomised the media onslaught which helped to create a lasting mythology about the strikes.

The wave of stoppages dur ing the winter of 1978-79 was targeted at a 5% government pay norm at a time when inflation was almost double that. It followed two years of pay restraint which had seen millions of workers' wages fall in real terms.

After the TUC and Labour conferences voted to reject a third year of real pay cuts, one group of workers after another walked out in protest. Ford and bakery workers were followed by railway workers, and petrol tanker and road haulage drivers. By January they had been joined by more than a million low-paid council workers.

The pay limit - seen in retrospect as a mistake by the Labour ministers who tried to impose it - was broken.

Disruption was widespread, compounded by intensive picketing, and was mercilessly exploited by the opposition leader, Margaret Thatcher. But much of the reporting - of bodies left unburied, for example - was wildly exaggerated.

Certainly the 1979 lorry drivers' strikes were a very different industrial phenomenon from the current protests by owner-drivers and farmers against fuel prices and taxes, and, despite dire predictions at the time, their impact on consumers was less dramatic.

This week's blockades of fuel depots and refineries are being organised largely by small groups of self-employed hauliers, with apparent toleration from some oil companies and the indulgence of Conservative politicians and newspapers, in support of lower taxes.

The pay revolt of 21 years ago was staged by millions of workers, many of them among the lowest-paid in Britain, to head off a further squeeze on their living standards.

In the short term at least, it was also successful.

The outcome of the current fuel tax protests remains to be seen.
