fields.headline: How Blair misread the momentum
fields.standfirst:
The protesters' victory in France persuaded the prime minister to take a different course

Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: The protesters' victory in France persuaded the prime minister to take a different course
fields.body:
Returning from the UN special assembly in New York last week, Tony Blair was relatively confident that his government would see off the just-gathering petrol blockades.

In a private conversation, President Jacques Chirac had told him that the French government would not make concessions to the farmers and hauliers paralysing his country. It seemed to Mr Blair that this might even be the moment when the Socialist French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, confronted the labour unions and irrevocably joined the Blairite Third Way.

By the weekend Mr Blair was rudely disappointed as Mr Jospin succumbed first to the fishermen and then to the hauliers.

Just as capital has globalised, so has protest. It gave fresh heart to the nascent demonstrations in Britain.

But at Chequers Mr Blair had other things on his mind. He had sent troops to fight in the Sierra Leone jungle, and he had to brace himself for the potentially damaging serialised books portraying a feuding cabinet and a jealous chancellor.

Over the weekend he held two conversations with Gordon Brown, and they agreed that the best solution was to put pressure on Opec members, particularly the Saudis, to bring the price of oil down to as low as $24 a barrel.

Caught out

Mr Brown, who had been repeatedly warned by Scottish Labour MPs of the danger of the high petrol prices, promised that he would ensure that EU finance ministers stood firm against fuel tax cuts. The pressure on Opec to increase output would remain.

In retrospect, Whitehall admits that it was slow to recognise the speed with which the crisis would escalate. Mentally, ministers remembered the miners' strike of 1984-5 and the unions' failure to halt energy supplies. No one foresaw the scale of the menace ahead. One reason for that, it seems, is that there is no coordinating machinery to report to ministers that garage forecourts could be pumped dry.

By Sunday, however, it was apparent that panic buying was starting to eat into supplies much faster than expected, especially in the north and Wales. It was agreed that Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, should convene an emergency meeting of the civil contingencies committee.

It was also agreed that Mr Blair should go ahead with a two-day visit to the midlands and Yorkshire, designed to highlight the burgeoning dot.com economy. Cancelling would be to betray signs of panic and increase the run on petrol.

The visit rapidly developed a surreal quality. The more Mr Blair enthused about the increasing pace of internet traffic in Britain, the slower vehicle traffic moved around the country. Privately, he knew that two of his industry ministers had rushed to Balmoral for the Queen's consent to invoke emergency powers.

He had decided that he faced a battle of wills. There would be no change in petrol duty outside the normal budgetary cycle. He would not meet the protesters, or even the Road Haulage Association. The price of petrol was not out of line with Europe, and in any case the farmers did not pay special levies.

The country would have to be patient as the oil price came down. In Thatcherite tones, he told colleagues that he would not be held to ransom. "We cannot allow what happened in France to happen here."

But there was also a mystery. His Whitehall planners had told him there were enough oil refineries, and enough of them unblocked, to ensure a proper flow of petrol. The picketing was good-natured and did not represent a genuine unlawful blockade, the police had reported. The oil companies said their drivers feared physical intimidation if they went through the picket lines.

Mr Blair concluded that there needed to be greater coordination between the oil companies and the police.The police said the depot exits could be cleared if the tanker drivers were willing to use them. The oil companies said otherwise: the safety of their drivers was paramount.

Why were the oil companies refusing to ask their drivers to go through the picket lines? One view in government circles is that oil company drivers have a lot of sympathy with the hauliers. They do the same job, share the same motorway cafes, and know that many hauliers are close to the financial edge. Some political sources pointed out that the oil companies had little economic stake in preserving the current level of petrol duty.

By mid-evening he knew his tour was becoming untenable. The last straw came when he had to pull out of a dinner to celebrate John Prescott's 30 years as a Hull MP: protesters had blocked the routes to the restaurant with their cars. He drove back to the Sheffield Hilton where, in further overnight conversations, it was agreed that he had to return to London.

The Education Secretary, David Blunkett, was left to spell out the eerie historical parallels with the Winter of Discontent. He said: "We are all bound in by our history and we all remember the 'Crisis? What crisis?' of 30 years ago. The Prime Minister needs to be able to sit down, take the necessary advice and to decide what measures need to be taken. We are on the edge of a very real problem. The problem we face is panic buying. We need to ask people to be very calm, not [to] believe we are going to run out of petrol."

By lunchtime Mr Blair was in Downing Street discussing the crisis with Mr Prescott; the Chief Secretary, Andrew Smith; the police; civil servants; the Industry Secretary, Mr Byers; and Mr Straw. Once again he focused on the companies' refusal to distribute petrol and decided to speak to their chief executives personally.

At lunchtime Mr Prescott finally made the government's anger clear. "We are quite convinced that the oil companies can face up to their responsibilities to see that oil is distributed properly."

The special powers:

 The Queen has given the government unprecedented powers to assume control of fuel distribution to keep the emergency services going: the cabinet's emergency contingency committee can instruct oil companies to deliver to ambulances, hospitals and schools

 Ministers on the committee are expected to list up to 200 filling stations solely for the emergency services. Police will be in attendance in case of protests

 If necessary the provision can be extended to buses and supermarkets to ensure that food supplies are maintained

 At the Balmoral Privy Council meeting the Queen approved an order in council to set in motion the powers "because there is imminent in the United Kingdom a threatened emergency affecting fuel supplies which make it necessary in Her Majesty's Opinion that the government should temporarily have at its disposal exceptional powers for controlling the sources and availability of energy"

 If protesters refuse to let oil tankers leave refineries, the government could fall back on a 1,500-mile network of pipes, normally used to to distribute fuel to military bases, to distribute civilian fuel

fields.headline: The crisis at the pumps
fields.standfirst:
Mr Blair needs to show results very soon

Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Six days ago there was nothing more to be seen than a cloud over Cheshire, the size of a band of farmers on a freelance expedition to try to shut down a single refinery. Now there is raging crisis: the prime minister back in London, having called off all other engagements to take charge of the government response; petrol supplies exhausted throughout the capital and forecasts that very soon none will be left anywhere in the country. How could this autumn of discontent have blown up so fast out of nowhere?
fields.body:
Six days ago there was nothing more to be seen than a cloud over Cheshire, the size of a band of farmers on a freelance expedition to try to shut down a single refinery. Now there is raging crisis: the prime minister back in London, having called off all other engagements to take charge of the government response; petrol supplies exhausted throughout the capital and forecasts that very soon none will be left anywhere in the country. How could this autumn of discontent have blown up so fast out of nowhere?

The government was all too clearly unprepared for the scale of it. On Monday evening, as the lights went out in service stations all over Britain, Mr Blair was still trying to keep a dinner date with John Prescott in Hull. Ministers had badly underestimated the forces ranged against them. What had begun as a rising of the Poujadist self-employed, a political constituency with which past Labour governments might have been only too happy to do battle, was now looking much more formidable. People whose roads were obstructed, who were forced to sit for hours in queues to fill up their tanks, seemed on the whole more upset by the chancellor's tax take than they were with those causing disruption. Whatever they thought of the tactics, they welcomed action which if successful would cut their own petrol bills.

So the government's message of "no surrender, wait for the budget" failed to find many takers. Nor did it play too well at the TUC yesterday, as Gordon Brown insisted that Labour must not amend its strategy to deal with an oil price increase which might prove only temporary. The trouble is that all experts see prices continuing to climb; none predicts a slipping back to acceptable levels. But by now, pertinent questions were surfacing as to how and why the protest movement has achieved such swift, overpowering success. Why have the pumps run dry when the picketing in many places was light, verging on vestigial? Why have oil companies made so little apparent effort to lift what in many places was hardly more than a token siege? Why, where the police had cleared the barricades out of the way, was nothing, even now, moving? One analyst even alleged that oil companies wanted to see the demonstrations succeed, in the hope that the chancellor would be forced to cut tax, thus boosting their takings.

The sun must have come out in Downing Street as the first signs appeared that the focus of public disquiet was switching from government unreadiness to oil company duplicity. But that could yet switch back again. Beyond Tony Blair's upbeat assessment and promised measures last night, he and Mr Brown need to move fast and purposefully to recapture control of the agenda. They need to be far more robust in defending taxes on petrol as essential to protect our threatened environment. They need to show that the Treasury's windfall from petrol price increases (a mere £400m in the past year, the chancellor says) will not simply disappear into the Treasury's maw, but be used for the public's long-term benefit through spending on enhanced public transport and investment in alternative sources of power. They must also resist the temptation to talk, as Jack Straw regrettably did yesterday, as if all street demonstrations, whatever their cause, constitute a form of disruption which society should not tolerate. Where disruption takes forms which are clearly illegal, there must be action to stop it. Where it is merely troublesome and discomforting for authority, no government with any liberal pretensions should try to deny its legitimacy.

fields.headline: My friends on the barricades
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: How could this be? How could terminally uncool people in shell suits and boiler suits, donkey jackets and tweed jackets, get to man the barricades? How is it that in the space of a few days farmers and hauliers (of all people) have managed to bring the country to what is approaching a standstill?
fields.body:
How could this be? How could terminally uncool people in shell suits and boiler suits, donkey jackets and tweed jackets, get to man the barricades? How is it that in the space of a few days farmers and hauliers (of all people) have managed to bring the country to what is approaching a standstill?

Well, my friends, think of the old Che Guevara poster you once had on your bedroom wall. This is a popular uprising, carried out by mobile phone and fuelled by a deep well of frustration and anger.

The first I heard of the campaigners was when a fax arrived at my Leicestershire home from a farmer friend, as long ago as last April. It was addressed "Dear Supporter", from the north-east branch of the Farmers and Hauliers Alliance. The group had been formed, they said, because of "the apparent aim of the UK government to destroy our industries" and the "indifference and ineptitude" of their own unions and trade organisations. This had been demonstrated by the fact that at a time when the haulage industry was "losing companies every week, jobs are going abroad and rates are being cut by foreign hauliers", the new chairman of the official Road Haulage Association was "against all forms of protestation".

Members were now taking matters into their own hands - and, the letter reminded me, they had allies in the farming community. Farmers were facing the worst agricultural depression since the 1930s, but the National Farmers Union's reliance on negotiation had failed to prevent government measures that actively worsened their situation (of which raising fuel taxes is but one small example).

A new grassroots organisation called Farmers for Action had allied with the disaffected hauliers. They intended to "pressure ministers into creating a level playing field of taxation and subsidies" across the EC - through "direct action". The alliance had already blocked roads into Newcastle that March. It planned to do more in June. I began to get a fax a week from Farmers for Action, giving the venue and time of a picket at a depot or a supermarket. In May I visited a FFA picket line at the Express Dairies depot in Ashby de la Zouch, Leicestershire. There were no other journalists. This was not a story to compare with the anarchist riots down in London, where Etonians might be found kicking in the windows of fast food restaurants. They were only 100 quiet dairy farmers. Some were council tenants, others owner-occupiers. All were desperate.

The supermarkets had pushed down the milk processors' prices and they had passed on the bill to the farmers, so that milk that cost the farmer 22.49 pence per litre ex-farm was selling for 16.2 pence - almost a third less than agricultural diesel.

But this surely wasn't a dispute to trouble the hauliers? A farmer told me that back in November they had targeted a Tesco's in Milton Keynes. A supermarket manager had ordered the drivers to come through the gates, but they just got out of their cabs. Nearly everything that comes into and goes out of a farm does so by haulier. They are individually aware of the farmer's situation as well as sympathetic to it.

"We are just unpaid labour for the supermarkets and the dairies," one farmer told me at a picket line this Sunday. "But their lorry drivers aren't much better off." Not only do hauliers suffer from taxes on fuel, they are also being squeezed by the supermarkets.

Picket lines at dairies and supermarkets spread the word of the Farmers and Hauliers Alliance up and down the motorways of Britain, and the organisation began to mount its own demonstrations last June. They started in Manchester and were followed at Chester in July and Bristol a month ago. You won't have read about them in the national press because it, like the government, is London-centric.

Out in the provinces, however, people read about the HFA's demonstrations in the local papers. Their gossip added to whispers at working men's clubs and farmers' markets. Thousands of people - some living in isolated houses and communities - have been waiting for an opportunity to fight back against a government that has, apparently, named them the enemy.

A government that has taken their jobs, attacked their businesses, destroyed their marriages and would even drive them to suicide. The unions have tried to reason with them. "Negotiate," they've said. The Countryside Alliance leadership has pleaded with them, "Don't do anything that might inconvenience the public".

But they've just been waiting for the call. It came at a cattle market in north Wales last week; hauliers and farmers took to the roads straight away. Then hunting people in Hull sent Blair running back to London. Now everyone is hearing it by phone and on the evening news.

webTitle: Italy's plea for prisoner on US death row

fields.headline: Italy's plea for prisoner on US death row
fields.standfirst: As one of its sons faces lethal injection in the US, Italy is united in opposition to the death penalty, reports Rory Carroll in Rome
fields.trailText: As one of its sons faces lethal injection in the US, Italy is united in opposition to the death penalty, reports Rory Carroll in Rome.
fields.body:
Italy is preparing to mourn an Italian-American due to be executed in a US jail tomorrow despite clemency pleas from the Pope, and the Italian parliament and public.

Derek Barnabei's final hours are being counted down in villages and cities convinced he is innocent of rape and murder. Viewing itself as a beacon against capital punishment, Italy has united in condemning the imminent lethal injection as further proof of American barbarism.

A lobbying blitz by legislators, newspapers and television stations failed to move the governor of Virginia, Jim Gilmore. DNA tests this week contradicted Barnabei's denial of the 1993 strangling and bludgeoning of Sarah Wisnosky, a 17-year-old college fresher he had been dating.

Led by Rome mayor Francesco Rutelli, hundreds of people today filed into a white tent outside the Colosseum to send emails begging mercy for the 33-year-old grandson of a Tuscan emigrant.

The Italian press pack assembled in Richmond, Virginia, have been praised by Barnabei's mother Jane for their support. "It's been like working with angels. They truly believe he's innocent. They're the only ones with an objective point of view."

Gerardo Greco, of the public television station RAI, said the anti-death penalty tradition was very deep. "Italy is an emotional country, and for Italians this is sort of a crusade."

District judge James Spencer this week rejected defence arguments that the three-day disappearance of evidence from a police laboratory represented deliberate and malicious tampering by the state.

"I have looked at this case from every angle. I have spent scores of hours studying this case. Barnabei is guilty," said the judge. Barnabei left Virginia the day his girlfriend's body was discovered nude and battered. He was arrested three months later living under an assumed name.

He was convicted without DNA tests but to allay concern governor Gilmore, noting "a generalized assault on capital punishment by many in this country and foreign countries", agreed to this week's analysis of skin beneath the victim's fingernails.

Tuscany had offered to pay £3,000 for the tests, which Italy's press hailed as a victory. When the samples matched Barnabei's DNA commentators said execution was immoral regardless of guilt or innocence.

Jane Barnabei said her son was convicted not just on circumstantial evidence: "It was evidence that was planted." Three Italian legislators met Virginia officials at the weekend and echoed two clemency appeals from Pope John Paul II.

Since abolishing the death penalty for civilians in 1948, and for the military in 1994, Italian towns and villages have taken to holding vigils and sponsoring legal action for death-row prisoners abroad.

Italy infuriated Turkey last year when it refused to extradite the Kurd rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan because Turkey retained capital punishment. In last Christmas's Urbit et Orbi ("to the city and the world") message the Pope called for a ban.

Since January the Colosseum, antiquity's temple of blood, has been turned into a worldwide symbol against executions. It is lit up in golden lights every time a death sentence is commuted or a country abolishes capital punishment.

In spontaneous comments which drew applause during his weekly public audience at St Peter's Square, the Pope today renewed his clemency plea. He said he was "again uniting my voice to that of all those who ask that Derek Rocco Barnabei's life not be taken away."

fields.headline: Acknowledging Germany's immigrant population
fields.standfirst: As Germany grapples with questions of ethnicity and nationality, John Hooper reports from Berlin on the country's hidden immigrants
fields.trailText: As Germany grapples with questions of ethnicity and nationality, John Hooper reports from Berlin on the country's hidden immigrants.
fields.body:
A German friend told me how she had once gone to see an English acquaintance at her workplace.

As she was taking off her coat she asked who the Africans were in the outer office. Her English acquaintance was nonplussed.

"Africans?" she asked. "Yes. You must know they're there - all those black people taking down files and writing out forms."

"Oh, them," said the Englishwoman. "No. They're not Africans. They're British."

My German friend says it was a moment that changed her whole outlook on a part of life.

"For the first time, I realised you could have a concept of citizenship that was completely separate from the idea of ethnic origin."

Her anecdote is particularly relevant in the week in which a new commission, headed by the respected Christian Democrat politician, Rita Süssmuth, starts work on a what promises to be a lengthy review of Germany's laws on nationality and immigration.

German, like Britain, has begun to suspect that it needs more, nor less, immigrants for its economic wellbeing.

But in Germany, to a far greater extent than in Britain, the issue is bedevilled by the concept of citizenship which my friend had unwittingly carried around with her till the day she went to that office in London.

But then it was only last year that a law was introduced by Gerhard Schröder's centre-left coalition to break the bond between blood and nationality.

It allowed foreigners to become citizens after living in Germany for eight years, provided they gave up their existing passport.

Those who had been born in Germany of foreign parents could keep dual citizenship, but were obliged to choose which to keep by the age of 23.

By the time it became law, the measure had been watered down in response to bitter resistance, including a petition got up by the opposition Christian Democrats.

The new nationality law cost the Social Democrats, the senior partners in the ruling coalition, a defeat in the first regional vote to be held after their general election victory - a result which, in turn, cost them their majority in the regionally appointed upper house.

Like my friend, Germans of all classes and persuasions had been conditioned by the fact that, for years, both main parties subscribed to the view that Germany - to use the stock phrase - was "not a country of immigration".

It was thus neither feasible nor desirable for people to be both black and German.

Or to be German and, say, Turkish or Serbian or Italian by origin. Even if you had been born in Germany and spoke accentless German, you could not be a German citizen unless your parents were.

Yet the country was, and is, teeming with people of foreign origin. More than seven million of Germany's 82m inhabitants are what, in other countries, would be called immigrants. But not here.

One group is made up of the workers from Mediterranean Europe who provided the cheap labour for the "economic miracle" and their families.

For decades, the politicians sustained the myth that they would one day go home. They were thus not immigrants, but "Gastarbeiter" (guest workers).

The other group was made up of those who had been accepted since. But they were let in as asylum seekers. The authorities knew full well that most were not genuine political refugees.

According to official estimates, only five per cent of those who entered in the early 1990s were fleeing political persecution. But, again, the important thing was to sustain the idea that Germany was "not a country of immigration".

One result is that Germans continue to refer to the seven million people of foreign origin in their midst, as "foreigners" or, at best, "Mitbürger".

At first, that sounds fine. Its dictionary definition is "co-citizen". But then, strictly speaking, "Mitarbeiter" means "co-worker", and in practice it is used as a euphemism for "employee".

The unspoken tenent is that Germany's foreigners are in the country on sufferance. It is one that infuses all areas of life, as the setting up of the Süssmuth commission on immigration demonstrated.

Until the fact was pointed out by irate leaders of the Turkish community, it had no one on it to represent the views of Germany's almost non-exisitent immigrants.

fields.headline: Negotiators offer Jerusalem peace suggestions
fields.standfirst: New ideas are being developed in a bid to solve the problems raised by holy sites, as Suzanne Goldenberg reports from Jerusalem
fields.trailText: New ideas are being developed in a bid to solve the problems raised by holy sites, as Suzanne Goldenberg reports from Jerusalem.
fields.body:
If all had gone according to plan, today, September 13, would have seen the birth of the state of Palestine, after a gestation period of more than 50 years.

But instead of a state - whose due date was delayed for the second time at the weekend - there is the birth of a strange new vocabulary, the creation of those trying to solve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Their offerings include: divided sovereignty, joint sovereignty, shared sovereignty, delayed sovereignty, suspended sovereignty, functional sovereignty, custodial sovereignty and extraterritorial sovereignty.

Because while the battle of sovereignty may seem archaic in an age of globalisation and free trade, this is the Holy Land, where religion, history and sacred sites complicate everything.

The newly minted terminology is intended to apply to the Haram al-Sharif, as Muslims call it, or Temple Mount as it is called by the Jews.

The site, within the walls of the old city of Jerusalem, is revered equally by Muslims and Jews, and claimed with equal passion by Israelis and Palestinians.

The Haram, which contains the shimmering gold Dome of the Rock and al-Aqsa mosques, is the third holiest shrine in Islam, after Mecca and Medina.

For Jews, it is the most sacred soil on the planet, the site of their temple, which was destroyed in 70 AD except for the Wailing Wall, and is visited by hundreds of worshippers every day.

The panoply of definitions, which have come into wide circulation in the last two months, represent attempts by those trying to solve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to strip the notion of sovereignty of its emotional charge.

The logic behind the lexicon is to finesse the present understandings of sovereignty so that both sides can claim victory in the most intractable of their disputes, thus overcoming the single most formidable obstacle to peace in the Middle East.

Today, Israeli radio talk shows invented yet another definition: vertical sovereignty. However, that may just be a fancy way of describing subterranean sovereignty.

That would see the Palestinians declared the masters of the Haram al-Sharif from the ground up, granting them control of the plateau where the mosques stand, but leaving Israel in control of the ground beneath, where the ruins of the temple are believed to lie.

Or humans could simply appeal to the almighty to take the whole dispute off their hands: divine sovereignty.

That would grant God title to the Haram, leaving mere mortals with the task of delegating responsibility for such human concerns as policing, rubbish collection, and the issuing of renovation permits for the holy site.

The inspiration for such creative solutions to the future dispensation of the Haram has come from some unexpected quarters - the frozen ice cap of Antarctica, a US naval base in the Caribbean, and the secessionist-minded Canadian province of Quebec.

At one point, Israeli academics were considering the International Law of the Sea as a possible model for land-locked Jerusalem.

The treaty assigns rights to oil, gas and fishing up to 12 miles beyond a country's shoreline - or "functional sovereignty".

Then there is "qualified sovereignty" or "relative sovereignty", which describes the extra autonomy enjoyed by the Canadian province of Quebec.

Although such ideas are engaging, many Israelis - including the former prime minister and Nobel peace prize laureate, Shimon Peres, has dismissed these efforts are word play.

They are seen as far less benign by Palestinians, who accuse Israel of presenting these ideas as fancy formulas to prevent Yasser Arafat from exercising full sovereignty over all areas of East Jerusalem occupied by Israel since 1967.

Some of the Israeli proposals would merely sanction the status quo, under which, Israel has exercised ultimate security control over the Haram, while the Palestinians, through the Muslim Waqf, or property trust, are in charge of daily administration.

"Which God should get sovereignty? The Lord of Hosts, Allah or the father of Jesus?" asked Zvi Barel, an Arab affairs columnist for Ha'aretz newspaper.

"Maybe the best idea of all would be to transfer sovereignty over the entire Temple Mount compound to the Disney company so it could build a Park of Holies there."

webTitle: Latin sound gets its own awards

fields.headline: Latin sound gets its own awards
fields.standfirst: From Ricky Martin to the Buena Vista Social Club, Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles as the US prepares to celebrate a musical genre
fields.trailText: From Ricky Martin to the Buena Vista Social Club, Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles as the US prepares to celebrate a musical genre.
fields.body:
For a split second it looked as though a classical education in America was finally being given the respect it deserved.

The red carpet at the Staples Centre, home of the LA Lakers basketball champs and venue for last month's Democratic party convention, is being rolled out.

CBS is going to broadcast the event live tonight and stars from around the world are flying in for the first Latin Grammar awards.

At last, all those who had toiled over their Cicero and their irregular verbs are going to be honoured.

On closer inspection, of course, this turns out to be the Latin Grammy awards.

Recognising the enormous part that music from Cuba to Brazil and Puerto Rico to East Los Angeles now plays, Latin music is to have its first very own awards ceremony, coming hard on the heels of the Emmy television and the MTV music awards.

The event is being organised by the three-year-old Latin Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences - it is always necessary to form an "academy" to bring due decorum to an awards ceremony even although no one ever studies at it.

Those tipped for awards "honouring musical excellence by artists performing in Spanish or Portuguese" include everyone from Ricky Martin and Santana to Ruben Blades and Marc Anthony.

But perhaps the choicest potential winner is in the Best New Artists Award: the Cuban star of the Buena Vista Social Club, Ibrahim Ferrer who made the recording for which he is nominated at the sprightly age of 72.

At least he's not going to peak too early.

Not that you need to be a Latino to win an award: the Latin refers to the genre of the music and not the ethnicity of the performer.

But the arrival of the Latin Grammys on the scene could not have come at a more appropriate moment.

This month for the first time since it became a state, California has a non-white majority.

This historic and much predicted demographic shift has been accomplished mainly as a result of the arrival of immigrants from Mexico, El Salvador, Guatemala and elsewhere in Central America.

They now account for 30 per cent of the population of California, 39 per cent in New Mexico and 29 per cent in Texas, which accounts for the fact that George W Bush now sprays his electoral rhetoric with so many "amigos" that he sounds like an American car salesman on his first holiday in Acapulco.

Ten years ago there were 22m Latinos in the US. Today, there are more than 32m, a 45 per cent increase in a population of 275m. By 2050 it is estimated that there will be nearly 100m, an increase of 197 per cent.

Since so many states - Florida, Colorado, Nevada, California, New Mexico, Texas - were originally Mexican, perhaps it is surprising that the shift has taken so long.

Anyway, by 2050 the Latin Grammy awards may well have become the mainstream music awards.

In the meantime, you can listen to audio clips of the top nominees.

webTitle: Unions say diluted rights and denied benefits harm entry to single currency

fields.headline: Unions say diluted rights and denied benefits harm entry to single currency
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: TUC leaders yesterday accused the government of undermining its campaign for entry to the euro by watering down improved employment rights and denying UK workers benefits enjoyed by the rest of Europe.
fields.body:
TUC leaders yesterday accused the government of undermining its campaign for entry to the euro by watering down improved employment rights and denying UK workers benefits enjoyed by the rest of Europe.

But efforts to unite British unions behind a compromise policy on the single currency, before the general election, fell apart when Bill Morris, leader of the TGWU, and Sir Ken Jackson of the AEEU, reignited their public row over how to handle the issue.

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB general union, said the best way for the government to fight its pro-Europe campaign was to set out a vision of a Europe that brought social progress and benefits.

"But, frankly, it does not help us to build a positive case for Europe if the TUC has to keep taking the British government to the European court of justice to win back employment rights which are clearly enshrined in European directives and which are freely accepted elsewhere in Europe," he said. "I would like to see [this] Labour government leading Europe on social improvements, not being the last in a very long convoy expressing arrogant disapproval."

The TUC is appalled that the government cut the three to four weeks annual holiday guaranteed under EU law to take account of public holidays, and won public backing from Anna Diamantopoulou, the Brussels employment and social affairs commissioner, for its stance.

Ms Diamantopoulou told the annual congress in Glasgow that the UK had a poor track record on social partnership, whereas the EU envisaged a much longer role for unions in collective bargaining on issues such as new forms of jobs, and favoured modern regulation rather than deregulation. The EU's social policy agenda, she said, was critical to the success of transforming Europe into a 10,000bn-euro economy, with living standards up 25%, within the next five years.

Tony Dubbins, leader of the GPMU print union, said: "To persuade people to vote for the euro, it has to be integrated with a government commitment to underwrite and extend the social dimension."

The united front shown by unions backing the euro collapsed when Mr Morris said the British people could not be "bullied or bounced" into adopting the single currency. He said: "There is no majority in the country for the single currency. No wonder, because we have a strong economy and a stable currency. Investors have confidence in our country despite some of us running Britain down. Foreign investment rose last year by 25%."

Sir Ken, the target of this jibe, insisted that foreign investors had warned him and Tony Blair they would pull out of Britain if the government did not clarify its position on the euro. He said of Mr Morris that he was "the only man who can support the chancellor and the shadow chancellor [Michael Portillo] on the same day".

Mr Morris's approach was echoed by a fervent anti-euro proponent, Fawzi Abrahim of the college lecturers' union, Natfhe, who said the motion was "tainted" because it did not represent the views of the trade union movement.

"It talks of ensuring members understand the benefits of joining as if they were stupid, but they do understand," he said, pointing out that two years of TUC campaigning had produced more people opposed to UK entry.

The only thing that united the TUC was the common view that Britain could not join at the exchange rate of DM3.20. That was "a suicide note for much of our economy", said Mr Edmonds, who saw it as a compelling reason against immediate entry. Unions now favour an entry rate of about DM2.80.

webTitle: Governor of Bank stirs euro debate

fields.headline: Governor of Bank stirs euro debate
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, yesterday moved centre-stage in the debate over Britain joining the euro when he rejected the government's argument that membership of monetary union was an economic rather than political question.
fields.body:
The governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, yesterday moved centre-stage in the debate over Britain joining the euro when he rejected the government's argument that membership of monetary union was an economic rather than political question.

In remarks that were immediately seized upon by the Conservatives as support for their line on the single currency, Sir Eddie said monetary union involved pooling of sovereignty in pursuit of both economic and political goals.

Speaking about monetary union, in a speech in Switzerland, Sir Eddie said: "It necessarily involves the deliberate pooling of national sovereignty over important aspects of public policy, in the interest not just of collective economic advantage, but of a perceived wider political harmony within Europe."

John Redwood, leader of the Tories' parliamentary campaigns unit, said: "The governor of the Bank of England is quite right that Emu is primarily a political project with huge implications for how we govern ourselves. His action has highlighted the complete failure of this government to lead a sensible national debate on whether we wish to join a United States of Europe."

The government has said that it sees no constitutional or political barriers to Britain joining the euro, but that the economy has to show real and lasting convergence with the rest of the single-currency zone before the issue can be put to voters in a referendum. It plans to assess early in the next parliament whether the five economic tests laid down by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, have been met.

Tory leader William Hague has ruled out British membership for the duration of the next parliament. He plans to make Europe a key issue at the next election.

Yesterday, opposition leaders were delighted, both by Sir Eddie's remarks about the political ramifications of the single currency and his warning that membership might make Britain less able to respond effectively to any economic crises.

The governor said that the UK would almost certainly have been pitched into an inflationary boom if it had joined the euro from the outset, because the outcome would have been a cut in interest rates to the level of those in euroland.

While accepting that membership of the single currency would have protected exporters from the effects of a rising pound, Sir Eddie said that the impact of higher inflation would have affected the entire economy rather than one part of it.

The "one-size-fits-all" interest rate applied across the euro-zone left governments without the macro-economic levers which are normally used to damp down inflation, he said.

"The fact is, there are no easy answers or ideal solutions to the one-size-fits-all problem at the eurozone level, without substantial - and sustainable - convergence between our economies," he said.

Sir Eddie added that there were "potentially powerful arguments in favour of UK membership" of the euro; particularly these advantages were the exchange rate certainty within Europe, the greater transparency of costs that it delivered, and the possibility of greater integration of financial markets.

But he also said: "The risks of divergent monetary policy needs within a monetary union are certainly real."

fields.headline: That lonely feeling
fields.standfirst:
Pro-euro campaigners need not despair; when the British referendum finally takes place fear of being left in the cold may swing the outcome
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The Danes vote on September 28 on whether to join the euro. Their campaign deserves to be closely watched. As our own euro referendum hovers interminably on the horizon, what is happening in Denmark is a guide to what will happen here whenever sterling finally has its date with destiny.
fields.body:
The Danes vote on September 28 on whether to join the euro. Their campaign deserves to be closely watched. As our own euro referendum hovers interminably on the horizon, what is happening in Denmark is a guide to what will happen here whenever sterling finally has its date with destiny.

Until recently it seemed Pia Kjaersgaard, the Danish People's Party and the no campaign would sweep all before them. Even the European Commission's own polling found (in May this year) a majority of Danes opposed to the single currency: 51%, compared with 40% in favour. This was itself a stiffening of the no vote compared with a similar poll six months earlier which showed the antis with an 8% lead - six months prior to that they were 4% in front. In fact, between January 1996 and January 1998, opposition to the euro in Denmark seldom fell below two-thirds. But since May margins have shifted. A Gallup poll last month suggested a photo finish with 44% of Danes saying they will vote yes to the euro and 43% intending to vote no. Even the 13% of respondents who told Gallup they were undecided seemed determined to take the outcome to the wire, as the proportions of them leaning towards yes or no were almost identical. Another poll put the pros in front. So could it be that what people learn during referendum campaigns is important in determining how they eventually vote - and in the case of the euro this tells in favour of the pros?

In September 1997 we experienced our own referendum cliffhanger when Wales voted on whether or not to create a national assembly. Half a dozen polls over the six months prior to the vote sent conflicting messages. In April 1997 one gave a 3% lead to the antis and another in the same month gave an 11% lead to the pros. The next two polls in June and August gave the pros leads of 12% and 22%. In the event, the pros won by a margin of 0.6%, a mere 6,721 votes out of the 1.1m cast. Was this further evidence of campaigns serving to focus minds?

On the surface, there seems little ambiguity in UK attitudes towards the euro, which is why prospects for the pro campaigners look bleak. ICM has been tracking attitudes for several years and in every one of their polls a clear majority have said they would vote no in a referendum. Last month they found 57% opposed, compared with 31% in favour.

Yet matters may not be so clear cut. Almost one year before the UK's June 1975 referendum on continued membership of the Common Market, Gallup registered a 17% lead for those who said they would vote to leave. By January 1975, those in favour of leaving still maintained a lead of 8%. Yet subsequent polls reflected a dramatic switch in proposed voting intention towards support for staying in. The switch was not so surprising if we look at the entrails. The same Gallup poll in 1974 that gave a 17% majority for leaving, gave a 30% majority in favour of staying in when people were asked how they would vote if the government negotiated new terms for UK membership and then advised that continued membership was in the UK's interests. By the end of February 1975, Gallup showed the pros with a lead of 8%: by the end of April this had risen to 24%; and by the end of May, Gallup registered a 34% lead among those favouring continued British membership of the Common Market.

An poll by NOP for Channel 4 in June suggested the headline figures produced by polls on a British referendum may not, as in 1975, tell the whole story. It put four propositions to respondents. Those who believed we should never join the euro amounted to 23%, compared with 9% who said we should join as soon as possible. But the real battleground in any future referendum campaign will be contested by those who supported the two remaining propositions offered in the survey. Fully 41% agreed that Britain should join the euro "at some point" but also that "the conditions are not yet right", while 22% signed up to what appears to be the current Tory position that joining "could cause problems" and therefore we "should rule it out for the next few years". These findings suggest that the result of a referendum could be closer than many expect.

In 1975, large numbers of voters were willing to be influenced by the government's assessment of the national interest. Also press, industry and commerce were solidly in favour of continued membership. Above all, the pro campaigners were on the side of the status quo. In a Blair-instigated referendum the electorate might be far less easily swayed by a government endorsement. The press, industry and the City are much more divided than in 1975. And pro campaigners are seeking to overturn the status quo. So can the (seemingly) relentless opposition of the majority to joining the euro be reversed?

The answer may turn on the real reason the UK voted as it did in 1975. That referendum was fought amid bitter arguments about the legitimacy of the UK's original membership. Neither then or now has it ever been difficult to find an audience within the UK willing to snarl at "Europe's" failings. But 1975 proved something much more important: that however reluctant and resentful we are at being Europeans, the one thing we fear most is being left out in the cold and on our own. Once the Blair government slides off the fence and campaigns for the euro, its success or failure will turn on whether that fear of losing out - of being stranded - is as powerful now as it was 25 years ago.

 David Cowling is a polling expert

The same Gallup poll in 1974 that gave a 17% majority for leaving, gave a 30% majority in favour of staying in when people were asked how they would vote if the government negotiated new terms for UK membership and then advised that continued membership was in the UK's interests. By the end of February 1975, Gallup showed the pros with a lead of 8%: by the end of April this had risen to 24%; and by the end of May, Gallup registered a 34% lead among those favouring continued British membership of the Common Market. An poll by NOP for Channel 4 in June suggested the headline figures produced by polls on a British referendum may not, as in 1975, tell the whole story. It put four propositions to respondents. Those who believed we should never join the euro amounted to 23%, compared with 9% who said we should join as soon as possible. But the real battleground in any future referendum campaign will be contested by those who supported the two remaining propositions offered in the survey. Fully 41% agreed that Britain should join the euro "at some point" but also that "the conditions are not yet right", while 22% signed up to what appears to be the current Tory position that joining "could cause problems" and therefore we "should rule it out for the next few years". These findings suggest that the result of a referendum could be closer than many expect. In 1975, large numbers of voters were willing to be influenced by the government's assessment of the national interest. Also press, industry and commerce were solidly in favour of continued membership. Above all, the pro campaigners were on the side of the status quo. In a Blair-instigated referendum the electorate might be far less easily swayed by a government endorsement. The press, industry and the City are much more divided than in 1975. And pro campaigners are seeking to overturn the status quo. So can the (seemingly) relentless opposition of the majority to joining the euro be reversed? The answer may turn on the real reason the UK voted as it did in 1975. That referendum was fought amid bitter arguments about the legitimacy of the UK's original membership. Neither then or now has it ever been difficult to find an audience within the UK willing to snarl at "Europe's" failings. But 1975 proved something much more important: that however reluctant and resentful we are at being Europeans, the one thing we fear most is being left out in the cold and on our own. Once the Blair government slides off the fence and campaigns for the euro, its success or failure will turn on whether that fear of losing out - of being stranded - is as powerful now as it was 25 years ago.  David Cowling is a polling expert comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The write stuff
fields.standfirst: Why bureaucratic jargon is just a pompous waste of words
fields.trailText: Why bureaucratic jargon is just a pompous waste of words.
fields.body:
Is your writing as transparent as a mixture of comminuted particles of rock with water of varying consistency, or is it just as clear as mud?

How do we judge the quality of, say, an iron? If it gets creases out of clothes, that would be one fair indicator. Design, colour, weight, and so on, will affect our choice, but these count for nothing if it doesn't do the job for which it's intended.

Social care writing should be judged likewise. If something can be read and understood at the first time of asking, then it's good writing. Simple as that. No matter that it's grammatically correct, well structured and displaying a wide vocabulary: if it's not understood, it's poor writing.

And, in this sense, social care is full of poor writing. It is often bloated, pompous and jargon-filled - sometimes so much so that even people who work in social care struggle with its meaning. And if they struggle, what chance do the rest of us have?

Why, for example, do inspectors (whose reports are all public documents) come up with "localised lighting to beds" for bedside lamps? Or "hot water outlets" for taps. Or "nutritional management" for food? And they must surely know that phrases such as continuity of care, inter-agency and multi-disciplinary, domiciliary care and self-advocacy are meaningless to the outside world. So why use them?

I believe that everybody has a fear of writing. For some, it's an in-your-face fear; for others, it's just a nagging doubt prowling around the back of their minds. I think this fear is there because of the permanency of writing. Say something, and it's gone. Write it down, and it's with us forever, just waiting to come back and haunt or embarrass us. And so we write words we would never say. We would never say, "Excuse me, may I look at your paper to ascertain what's on TV this evening?" We'd ask to find out what's on telly.

There is also the problem of professionalism - or, at least, a grasping perception of it. Social workers and others who see themselves as professionals also have a fear of not appearing sufficiently eminent or knowledgeable. And so, to prove they are, they click into pompous mode and produce bloated, jargon-filled writing. Recently, I heard a Wendy House referred to as a "domestic experience environment".

Jargon has its place. Provided everyone understands it, it's fine - a useful shorthand. Sadly, it is more abused than used. It excludes people and makes them feel inadequate. It also causes headaches for translators.

Many social care staff have a real concern that writing simply would undermine them, causing colleagues from other services to think less of them. One way around this is for their department to issue a policy statement saying that they are committed to writing in plain English. Some statement could also be put on letters, leaflets and posters, along the lines of: "We believe that all our public information should be in plain English. If you think we can improve this in any way, please let us know."

This would serve three functions: first, it would be an everyday reminder of the belief in plain English and an encouragement to staff to think about how they write; second, it spells out the policy for others, encouraging them not to think of everyone else as simpletons and may even inspire them to write clearly and concisely; and third, it encourages the public to comment on the readability of information they have received.

Talking the talk (and writing the write, I guess) is also why such overly bureaucratic language, with all its weasel words, breeds famously in the world of social care management. The higher up in the department you go, the further behind you leave ordinary, everyday talk. You start having strategies, while the rest of us are stuck with plans. You start lunching out on buzzwords - "robust" systems, "fluid" services and budgets - and, without batting an eyelid, start saying things such as "we'll road-test that" and "wait until the dust has settled on the budgets".

One director of social services felt the need to concentrate with staff on the "development of strategic plans". Now, I may be missing the point here, but this means "the development of planned plans". Or maybe that is precisely the point. It's thinking that way that makes them directors and sets them aside from mere mortals.

To write effectively, we need to know three things: why we are writing it; what we want to happen as a result of our writing; and who we are writing for. If the target audience includes the public then this means using shorter sentences (average about 15-20 words), shorter words and avoiding jargon. So don't write in plain English henceforth - write in plain English from now on.

 Graham Hopkins is author of Plain English for Social Services and The Write Stuff - A Guide to Effective Writing in Social Care, published by Russell House

fields.headline: Street drama
fields.standfirst: Newcastle communities claim they've been cold-shouldered by regeneration plans for the city.  Hilary and Martin Wainwright  report
fields.trailText: Newcastle communities claim they've been cold-shouldered by regeneration plans for the city. Hilary and Martin Wainwright report.
fields.body:
The chandeliered banqueting hall at Newcastle upon Tyne civic centre, commissioned by the city's one-time corrupt council boss T Dan Smith, has become the unlikely setting for protests over plans of the present-day local authority. The protests have been sparked by a regeneration masterplan, known as Going for Growth, which proposes large-scale housing demolition. And the row goes to the heart of the debate over whether Tony Blair's rhetoric of "community empowerment" means real power for local people or just talking shops.

It is not the idea of regeneration that provokes anger. The protesters talk proudly of the improvements carried out in Newcastle in the 1980s and recognise that more needs to be done. They even accept the need for some demolition. But they are proud, too, of the work they have done to rebuild their own communities after the factory and shipyard closures of the past 20 years.

Supported by a growing minority of the governing Labour councillors - including the lord mayor, Peter Thompson - and the Liberal Democrat opposition, the protesters say it is not enough to be consulted over plans they fear are a fait accompli. They are demanding to be involved in the decisions.

The neighbourhoods most affected by the plan are to the east and west of the city centre, overlooking the Tyne as it curves round the south of the city. The centre of the controversy in the west end is Scotswood, with its stunning view over the river valley. In the east end it is Walker, next to the trendy walkways and restaurants of the Quayside. In the Going for Growth pack, both Scotswood and Walker are coloured red, as "unviable", and the two riverside areas account for most of a total of 6,600 houses targeted for demolition. No other options are proposed.

You can feel the anger when you walk the slopes of Scotswood. Banners pour out of recently refurbished houses, declaring: "We shall not be moved." Local meetings have been 800-strong and community activists have presented their own counter proposals to Tony Flynn, leader of the council. But as Gwen Hinde, one of the activists, says: "He said it was not 'radical' enough in terms of demolition. Everything that is in Going for Growth is what we wanted: schools, transport, jobs. But they have left us, the community, out."

Radicalism, it appears, is a matter of offering enough of a "critical mass" of land to attract private developers. Kevan Jones, the council's cabinet member responsible for development, and a driving force behind the masterplan, admits: "In the past we've looked at small plots of land, rather than large areas which make it more attractive for developers." Private housebuilders have told the plan's consultants that they will not develop land smaller than eight hectares - the size of at least five football pitches - and their house prices are out of reach of most local residents.

The story of Newcastle's regeneration is more than community activists versus council bulldozers, however. Two other dramatis personnae need to be introduced: the government-initiated New Deal for communities (NDC) partnership in Cruddas Park and Elswick, also in the inner west end, which is one of 20 or so experiments across the country in "community-led regeneration"; and Lord (Richard) Rogers, chair of the commission on urban renaissance, who was brought in by the council to assist its work but now appears uneasy with the direction it is taking.

The prime minister explained the thinking behind the NDC when he said: "Too much has been imposed from above, when experience shows that success depends on the communities themselves having the power and taking responsibility to make things better."

In the Newcastle NDC, residents of an 8,500-strong neighbourhood, only a mile or so east of Scotswood, have developed their plans "from below". A mass meeting chose volunteers to serve, and lead, a partnership with the council, local businesses and public agencies. In November, the interim steering committee will subject itself to street-by-street elections. It has at times been a tense process. "There have been moments when it looked as if it would fall apart," admits Geoff O'Brien, a local Labour councillor. "But the final plans are very impressive, built around the principle of regeneration with people where they already live."

This approach is echoed in the way Rogers talks about communities. "When I walked along the beautiful streets of Scotswood and was told that this must be demolished, my heart filled with questions," he says. "We must build around anything with a flicker of life."

The council commissioned the Richard Rogers Partnership to work on the west end plan. "What we did was analyse the city as it is, and examine what is needed for communities to thrive," says Rogers. Stressing the independence of his work, he adds: "The problem is that the council has blurred our draft - very much a draft - plan, with theirs. We have offered no solutions yet. We made no specific proposals for demolition."

On the importance of involving people from the start in finding solutions to the planning of their neighbourhoods, Rogers says: "In this kind of situation, it's a matter of life and death. In the 50s and 60s, we took the wrong road. We were centralised. The best you had was consultation. There is a big difference between consultation and participation. With consultation the authority arrives at a plan and asks people: 'Do you like it?.' With participation, you get round the table with community leaders to work on solutions together. "

This approach goes down well with the city-wide Newcastle Community Alliance, founded last month at the meeting in Smith's banqueting hall, and now working with the sustainable cities unit of Northumbria University on alternative approaches. Kenny Bell, an alliance organiser, says: "Our aim is to get the council to withdraw its proposals for demolition and to make a positive commitment to the participation of the community, based on a genuine sharing of power and co-decision making."

The council has moved signifi cantly since the alliance was founded. Flynn has given a guarantee that those who wish to stay in their communities can, even if in a different house. The council has also committed itself to look at alternatives drawn up by local people. At the same time, though, Flynn has appeared dismissive of the alliance, saying: "We need to detach local people from other people with a wider agenda."

The council leadership now talks at length about consultation: one to one, in groups, any way you suggest. But will they let go of any power? Asked about the NDC way of doing things, Jones seems to suggest he will not.

"The NDC approach is to throw things into the air and see what comes down," he says. "I don't think that is the way forward. The council has got to have its own vision and then make sure that it pulls people in and brings people with it."

When the council has received all the feedback from its consultations, which close at the end of this month, it will analyse the responses, draw up its final plan and set up "support teams for areas of major change". Rogers and his team, meanwhile, are contracted to resume work this autumn and continue through until next March. Rogers is promising to work closely with local people.

The council's ruling Labour group is not unknown for faction fighting. A Lib-Dem opposition scenting blood adds to the piquancy. But what is about to happen in Newcastle is likely to have a far wider significance, one that impacts on inner city regeneration everywhere.

Northern lights

Some, but not all, northern cities have made a better fist of involving local people in regeneration. Among successful examples is the Royds regeneration of three big estates in Bradford. The key influence there was a real partnership with local people long before the funding bid.

Many eyes are now on east Manchester, location of another New Deal for communities project, where consultation awaits a delayed masterplan. A private developer has meanwhile applied to build within the NDC area.

Leeds has been successful with modest schemes like Ebor Gardens, reviving social housing near the city centre, but still smarts over the mess the former Urban Development Corporation made in Kirkstall Valley. Local energy - and wishes - were ignored and the resulting development is half-baked.

Trafford's tradition of community-led regeneration holds out better hopes for regeneration of the Partington estate, where local people have been involved from the start. And while Hull is using its telephone company millions more on double-glazing than democratic experiment, a council working party is considering creating the first "net city" with everyone online.

fields.headline: The best Morgan Freeman scene
fields.standfirst: Nurse Betty
fields.trailText: Nurse Betty
fields.body:
While Betty (Renée Zellweger) sits watching hit soap opera A Reason To Love, her nefarious husband Del (Aaron Eckhart) entertains two of his "clients", Charlie (Morgan Freeman) and Wesley (Chris Rock) at the dinner table. He brings over three beers; opening his, Del offers a toast.

"To a successful transaction."

Charlie and Wesley raise their bottles.

"Nice place you got here, Del," Charlie smiles. "Real comfortable."

"Nice town," agrees Wesley.

"You like it?" enquires Charlie.

"What, are you kidding me?" Del exclaims. He shakes his head contemptuously. "Small town, man."

Charlie peers at his host.

"What do you mean, Del?"

Del stares at his beer.

"Just a bunch of dumb fucks."

"Really?"

"You better believe it."

Charlie narrows his eyes.

"Can you give us an example?"

"Of what?"

"I'm asking for an example of one of these dumb fucks."

Del appears perplexed.

"I don't follow."

"Well, you're not a dumb fuck are you Del?"

"No."

"So, why don't you give me an example of one of these stupid people doing a stupid thing?"

By now Del is starting to look deeply put-upon. Charlie and Wesley stare at him impassively.

"Are we going to get down to business here, or what?"

See also: The Shawshank Redemption, Unforgiven, Seven, Amistad

Don't see also: Driving Miss Daisy, Deep Impact, Hard Rain

Pointless trivia: Morgan Freeman had a regular guest spot as "Easy Reader" on the 70s US children's show The Electric Company.

fields.headline: It's only rag'n'roll
fields.standfirst: This week yet another couple was devestated when a room in their 17th-century house was turned into a minimalist nightmare by the Changing Rooms team. This doesn't surprise Jonathan Glancey - the craze for instant make-over shows is ruining our homes and gardens
fields.trailText: This week yet another couple was devestated when a room in their 17th-century house was turned into a minimalist nightmare by the Changing Rooms team. This doesn't surprise Jonathan Glancey - the craze for instant make-over shows is ruining our homes and gardens
fields.body:
Are you the decidedly amateur, wait-till-next-weekend, let's-open-that-nice-bottle-of-wine-instead kind of DIY buff? The sort who would like your house in the country to have that knowing, quintessentially romantic, yet somehow casually thrown together Nicky Haslam look, or your town flat to be a sort of 60s James Bond number seen through the lens that filmed Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey... but can't quite get round to it? If so, it is all so simple. Call in the BBC's Changing Rooms team, and hey presto, your home will get a 48-hour makeover. Impress your World of Interiors and Wallpaper-reading friends. Be the envy of your chintzy neighbours. And make a complete fool of yourself.

I haven't seen an episode of Changing Rooms all the way through, but 11m viewers a week have. TV home and gardening make-over shows are as popular as they are potty.

Those fashionable long words rag-roll into the mind like so much luridly coloured gloss paint - hubris, schadenfreude - along with shorter, more powerful words, such as crap. Crap? Yes, this was the blunt, Anglo-Saxon verdict of Heather Cairns, whose guest bedroom in the family's 17th-century Northumberland home was transformed into a modern dog's breakfast by Changing Rooms "design expert" Laura McCree.

Cairns was not amused by a make-over described by her artist husband, John, as "just naff. It was so bad I burst out laughing... it was as if we had been visited by a playschool... the children had coloured, cut and stuck, and now it was time for mummy to come along and clean it up". McCree was reduced to tears.

Still, the Cairnses, McCree and the BBC can all bask in the sheer pleasure they have given those 11m viewers, all game for a laugh and a lorra, lorra fun. Just like any gameshow really. And this, surely, is what Changing Rooms and its clones are: old-fashioned entertainment. A bit of badinage between down-to- earth, seen-it-all Handy Andy and some la la decorator fop. A chance to laugh at other people's expense, a 30-minute send up of our curious national obsession with DIY.

Except, sadly, it could just be that more than a few of those 11m viewers who witnessed Cairns's outburst and McCree's tears take this stuff seriously. If they do, we really ought, as a nation, get out more. Walk the dog. Take up manly sports. Or gardening. Anything to get out of the home to free ourselves of this nonsense that encourages us to think that we can change a room, our homes, our lives in just 48-hours with the help of as-seen-on-TV designers.

I mentioned gardens. Sorry. Can't even escape there these days without telly presenters telling us that what we - a nation of really good gardeners, actually - really need is fewer lawns, prize roses and gnomes and more wooden decking, pebbles and a sort of zen-like, feng shui-approved oriental style meditation space. In Surbiton. I can't help thinking that what these programmes represent - the race for peak-time viewers aside - is our lack of confidence when it comes to matters design and decorating. Or, to paint the picture another way, our quiet concern that we don't do these things awfully well (too much beige, too much faux-antique, catalogue or weekend-warehouse furniture). And that when it comes to thinking about our rather naff, beige homes that smell so earnestly of Airwick, disinfectant and other industrial-strength cleaners, we half-dream of some fairy waving a magic wand and transforming Chez Angleterre-Midi into the sort of home we could invite Nigella Lawson over to, to share a bowl of "al dente" seafood linguini washed down with a bottle of Brunello di Montalcino brought back from last year's holiday in Tuscany?

What I find a little sad is so many people's willingness to let their homes and gardens be messed up by designers who would not be taken seriously away from the illusory world of TV make-over shows. No designer worth his or her salt (pure, natural crystals of sea salt) would tell any normal, decent, average Brit that a single room, let alone their home, could be changed in a way that will delight them in just 48 brief hours.

Better, really, if the Cairnses and other would-be gameshow fodder made their own decisions. After all, although we are not very good at home decor in Britain, we are a bit of whizz around the garden, even if we verge on the clinical (those poor lawns murdered by men in Viyella shirts and polyester-nylon slacks all summer long) or engagingly kitsch (gurning gnomes, pansies in macrame baskets etc).

Quite why so many people wish to be ridiculed and humiliated in front of the nation's TV cameras has to be a little puzzling. Is it the lure of being on telly? Maybe. What it certainly isn't is a way of making our homes more desirable. Perhaps we should stop changing rooms, pack a bag, shut the front door (a neo-Georgian number with built-in fanlight and gold-style "furniture" from B&Q) and change our lives.

fields.headline: At this price? EasyNet
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Investors looking for exposure to the telecoms and internet sectors could do well to take a look at EasyNet.
fields.body:
Investors looking for exposure to the telecoms and internet sectors could do well to take a look at EasyNet.

The pan-European telco and internet service provider has grown organically with limited investment to compete with bigger players including BT and Colt Telecom. It has previously used footballing terms to characterise itself as the Wimbledon of the sector, a plucky underdog snapping at the heels of the Manchester Uniteds.

But unlike the relegated south London club, EasyNet is on the up. Yesterday it reported a 53% jump in revenues to £19m for the six months to June 30. Net assets quadrupled and gross margins came in at 61%.

However, the company slipped into the red to record losses of £3.5m against a profit of £132,000 last time. Chief executive David Rowe, who has guided the share price from £2 to £11.50 in two years, says this is part of a deliberate investment programme.

He plans to spend the bulk of the £52m the company raised in April on new services that come with the unbundling of the local loop - like broadband internet lines - and building data centres across Europe.

Analysts at ABN Amro and Old Mutual had expected the losses to be greater and rate the shares highly. They say EasyNet is entering high-growth markets and forecast revenues of around £42m for the full year and losses of £9m-12m.

Much of EasyNet's success will depend on how BT unbundles its local loop and the rate at which competition is introduced.

Last night the shares slipped 1% to £11.30p. Old Mutual has a 12 month target on the stock of £15; house broker ABN Amro believes they could go as high as £22, having traded at £29 at the peak of the hi-tech frenzy.

Acquisition-hungry US telecommunications carriers may even see EasyNet as a useful way of gaining a European footprint.

Buy.

webTitle: Dome could be scrapped after buyer pulls out

fields.headline: Dome could be scrapped after buyer pulls out
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Emergency plans to tear down the Millennium Dome were being drawn up last night after the Japanese bank, Nomura, dramatically pulled out of its £105m deal to buy the beleaguered attraction.
fields.body:
Emergency plans to tear down the Millennium Dome were being drawn up last night after the Japanese bank, Nomura, dramatically pulled out of its £105m deal to buy the beleaguered attraction.

In a sign of the deepening crisis enveloping the dome, ministers have ordered English Partnerships, which owns the land the attraction is built on, to examine "all options" when it closes at the end of the year.

The plans include the possibility of dismantling the dome and selling off the land, a humiliating end to a project once hailed by Tony Blair as a symbol of "British flair and genius".

English Partnerships said it was issued with fresh instructions by the government yesterday after Nomura announced that it had "reluctantly withdrawn" from negotiations to take over the dome - whose cost has spiralled to £836m - because of worries about the "black hole" in the records of its assets.

Only last week David James, the troubleshooter brought to salvage something from the wreckage of the "greatest show on earth", described the £105m Nomura deal as a "killing... We are selling the place for a fraction of its value."

But yesterday, despite protests from Mr James that Nomura's qualms were a "list of excuses that don't stand up to scrutiny", Guy Hands, head of the Nomura bid, said he could not go ahead while denied access to the report by auditors PricewaterhouseCoopers which sparked the latest £47m bail-out last week.

"You don't buy a house without knowing whether you are getting the fittings," his spokesman said, denying accusations from the dome that Nomura was pulling out merely to drive a harder deal. "There is a gap between what is in the dome and what they have on their register of assets. We just didn't know what we were getting and what liabilities we would be left with."

Trevor Beattie, a spokesman for English Partnerships, said yesterday: "Now that Nomura have regrettably gone we have been asked to look at all the options for the site." Asked whether this could include dismantling the dome, Mr Beattie said: "Yes."

He stressed that the dome minister, Lord Falconer, still wanted the Greenwich site to remain open. Last night the consortium, Legacy plc, which lost out to Nomura to take over the dome, reopened talks with the government.

A spokesman for the group which wants to turn the dome into Knowledge City, based around IT businesses, said it had lowered its bid by £20m to match Nomura's £105m.

Lord Falconer, who spent three hours trying to persuade Nomura not to pull out, again faced calls last night to resign.

Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said: "Since Lord Falconer is obviously not going to resign, the prime minister must sack him. The time has come to open up the books. Every time the public is told nothing more can go wrong, it does. Nobody is going to buy a pig in a poke. Who would buy a used dome from this government?"
