fields.headline: How Nomura dropped dome bombshell
fields.standfirst:
Is the withdrawal of offer just a bargaining ploy?
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Even in the shark-eat-shark world of venture capital, Guy Hands, the man behind the withdrawn Nomura bid for the Millennium Dome, is acknowledged as a merciless predator.
fields.body:
Even in the shark-eat-shark world of venture capital, Guy Hands, the man behind the withdrawn Nomura bid for the Millennium Dome, is acknowledged as a merciless predator.

Last night, as shock set in at the collapse of the £105m deal which even David James, the troubleshooter brought in to salvage the Greenwich debacle, had conceded was a "killing" for the Japanese bank, many in the City were asking whether this was another of Hands's brutal bargaining ploys.

As if to call Nomura's bluff, it emerged last night that ministers were considering "all options", including demolishing the dome.

Mr Hands, the Tory leader William Hague's best man, could not have picked a better moment to drop the bombshell.

When his letter outlining Nomura's reasons for pulling out fell on desk of the beleaguered minister for the dome, Lord Falconer, on Monday, New Labour was in the throes of its deepest political crisis since entering government. With petrol supplies running out across the country, the government was never more vulnerable to another blow to the dome, its achilles heel.

A meeting was arranged for 6.30pm in Lord Falconer's suite in the Cabinet Office. Mr Hands - who ratcheted up the pressure last week by warning "we have signed nothing" when the dome was bailed out with another £47m of lottery money - began the tense meeting by setting out his case.

He went over how without a proper register of the assets he did not know what he was buying: "You don't buy a house without knowing whether you are getting the fittings."

He complained that no one seemed to know who owned what and that he had not been allowed to see the auditor's report by PricewaterhouseCoopers, which precipitated Mr James's appointment.

Mr James countered that Nomura had long known about the contractual chaos. They had been given a "full brief" by the PwC partner who wrote the report about its ramifications, and estimated the "knock-on implications" for Nomura would amount to only £2m a year.

The contractual mess was being sorted out, he maintained, and the remaining "problems were not as insuperable".

Nevertheless, Nomura said it had been frightened off by gap between what was in the dome and what was on the register of assets. "We just didn't know what we were getting and what liabilities we would be left with," a spokesman said. "When we walked into a zone the New Millennium Experience Company people couldn't tell us what they owned and what they didn't.

"We were first told there were 1,100 contracts with sup pliers relating to physical and intellectual property. It turned out there were 2,800 and almost every one was different. There was no such thing as a standard contract, which is a very, very unusual practice."

He said having spent "eight months and £10m" working on the deal, it was deeply frustrated but saw no option but withdrawal.

"We told NMEC we didn't want any discounting of tickets because that undermines the value of the dome. They agreed, then proceeded to do it."

A spokesman for Mr James dismissed Nomura's line as a "list of excuses that don't stand up to scrutiny.... This was not a new shock horror thing. We have been working very closely with them. They know why we can't show them the PricewaterhouseCoopers' report because it is chiefly concerned with the wind-down of the dome after January 1 and how final settlement is to be made with the suppliers. If we were to pass that to them and so make it public our strategy would be revealed. It would be commercial suicide." They keep saying, 'We were not told,' but they were. There has to be another underlying reason behind this."

Those suspicions grew when a Nomura spokesman told the Guardian it had not necessarily closed the door for good. "We still believe in our vision for the dome. Maybe if in a month or so if they can get us a proper register of assets and intellectual property, we may look at it again."

There is also a belief in the City that Nomura head office in Tokyo, frightened by the bad publicity, has gone cold on the project. It refused to comment last night, and directed callers to its London office.

The Guardian has also learned that the nub of Nomura's worries about ownership boiled down to two prefabricated structures which house McDonald's in the dome.

The only light at the end of the tunnel for the millennium commission, which will meet this morning to discuss the crisis, is that one of the failed bidders is still keen to take on the dome. Legacy plc which wanted to build a Knowledge City technology park inside the tent, said it was still interested.

Since the idea's most vocal supporter has been London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, embracing it now would be another humiliation for the government. It would also be a tacit admission the dome never worked as visitor attraction.

It is unlikely another white knight will emerge before the dome closes in January.

The commissioners, who have already forked out an extra £137m of lottery money this year, seem resigned to underwriting the dome for the £43m. Mr James intimated last night he had been as good as promised the money to complete the winding up.

"The facts remain as cold and unpalatable as they were," a commission spokeswoman said. "It would be more expensive to close the dome now than keep it open until the end of the year."

webTitle: UN to bolster peacekeeping force by 7,000

fields.headline: UN to bolster peacekeeping force by 7,000
fields.standfirst:
Decision to send extra troops could solve dilemma about leadership
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The United Nations security council is to agree a resolution on Friday to increase its peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone from 13,000 to 20,000, a move it is hoped will end the bitter dispute between the Indians and Nigerians over leadership.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
The United Nations security council is to agree a resolution on Friday to increase its peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone from 13,000 to 20,000, a move it is hoped will end the bitter dispute between the Indians and Nigerians over leadership.

Diplomats see the increase as an opportunity to remove the controversial Indian commander of the UN force in Sierra Leone, Major-General Vijay Jetley, who is due to finish his term in November.

A memo leaked to the Guardian last weekend revealed him to be at loggerheads with the Nigerian contingent. The Nigerians are now threatening not to serve under him.

Ambassadors representing the UN security council members met in New York on Monday to discuss the Sierra Leone crisis.

The draft resolution they agreed, which they described as close to the final version that will go before the security council on Friday, will not only increase the size of the peacekeeping force but widen its remit and change the command structure.

The strengthened force will increase the UN's annual bill for Sierra Leone from an estimated $400m (£285m) to $780m (£555m).

The Nigerians will be pleased to see Gen Jetley lose the command. But, in a move that will anger the Nigerians, some permanent members of the security council are pushing for another Indian to replace him. The final decision will be made by the UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan.

One diplomat, with inside information about the negotiations at the UN, said that although the Nigerians had the biggest contingent, there was resistance to giving them the command.

Mr Annan warned on Monday that the UN, the government of Sierra Leone and west African nations must "harmonise" their work if peace is to be restored to Sierra Leone.

The draft resolution notes "with concern serious shortfalls in capability encountered by Unamsil (the UN mission in Sierra Leone) in the recent past with regard to the command and control, equipment, training and preparation of military personnel and the implementation of rules of engagement".

It adds that success of the mission will depend on "an effective command and control structure and capacity, a single chain of command and the commitment to implement the mandate".

That mandate is to be made clearer: to respond robustly to any hostile action and "to extend state authority, restore law and order and further stabilise the situation progressively throughout the entire country".

Gen Jetley's memo complained that Nigerian politicians and soldiers had been sabotaging the peace effort in order to prolong the profits they were making from illegally trading in diamonds from Sierra Leone.

In response to the accusations, the Nigerian chief of army staff, Major-General Victor Malu, said his army could no longer serve under Gen Jetley and has demanded his immediate removal.

"We are not going to serve under that man in whatever circumstances. If he is not removed, he will not get our cooperation, and we are the largest contingent in the force," he said.

The two most senior Nigerian officials implicated in the report - Mr Annan's special representative in Freetown, under-secretary-general Oluyemi Adeniji, and Gen Jetley's immediate subordinate, Brigadier General Mohammed Garba - have both denounced the memo.

The increase in the number of troops to 20,000 means a higher-ranking soldier than Gen Jetley will be required. Western diplomats see that as a stroke of luck as it provides an excuse for his removal but they are equally adamant that he will not be replaced by any of the existing Nigerian commanders in Sierra Leone, whom they regard as being equally culpable for the row.

"You'd have to say that all of their positions are untenable," said one senior UN official. "Jetley clearly does not command the confidence of the largest contingent in his force. The Nigerians have stopped just short of saying they won't obey his orders. But there is also a strong feeling among the other contingents that whatever Jetley's shortcomings as a commander he is basically right about the Nigerians.

Diplomats see the increase as an opportunity to remove the controversial Indian commander of the UN force in Sierra Leone, Major-General Vijay Jetley, who is due to finish his term in November. A memo leaked to the Guardian last weekend revealed him to be at loggerheads with the Nigerian contingent. The Nigerians are now threatening not to serve under him. Ambassadors representing the UN security council members met in New York on Monday to discuss the Sierra Leone crisis. The draft resolution they agreed, which they described as close to the final version that will go before the security council on Friday, will not only increase the size of the peacekeeping force but widen its remit and change the command structure. The strengthened force will increase the UN's annual bill for Sierra Leone from an estimated $400m (£285m) to $780m (£555m). The Nigerians will be pleased to see Gen Jetley lose the command. But, in a move that will anger the Nigerians, some permanent members of the security council are pushing for another Indian to replace him. The final decision will be made by the UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan. One diplomat, with inside information about the negotiations at the UN, said that although the Nigerians had the biggest contingent, there was resistance to giving them the command. Mr Annan warned on Monday that the UN, the government of Sierra Leone and west African nations must "harmonise" their work if peace is to be restored to Sierra Leone. The draft resolution notes "with concern serious shortfalls in capability encountered by Unamsil (the UN mission in Sierra Leone) in the recent past with regard to the command and control, equipment, training and preparation of military personnel and the implementation of rules of engagement". It adds that success of the mission will depend on "an effective command and control structure and capacity, a single chain of command and the commitment to implement the mandate". That mandate is to be made clearer: to respond robustly to any hostile action and "to extend state authority, restore law and order and further stabilise the situation progressively throughout the entire country". Gen Jetley's memo complained that Nigerian politicians and soldiers had been sabotaging the peace effort in order to prolong the profits they were making from illegally trading in diamonds from Sierra Leone. In response to the accusations, the Nigerian chief of army staff, Major-General Victor Malu, said his army could no longer serve under Gen Jetley and has demanded his immediate removal. "We are not going to serve under that man in whatever circumstances. If he is not removed, he will not get our cooperation, and we are the largest contingent in the force," he said. The two most senior Nigerian officials implicated in the report - Mr Annan's special representative in Freetown, under-secretary-general Oluyemi Adeniji, and Gen Jetley's immediate subordinate, Brigadier General Mohammed Garba - have both denounced the memo. The increase in the number of troops to 20,000 means a higher-ranking soldier than Gen Jetley will be required. Western diplomats see that as a stroke of luck as it provides an excuse for his removal but they are equally adamant that he will not be replaced by any of the existing Nigerian commanders in Sierra Leone, whom they regard as being equally culpable for the row. "You'd have to say that all of their positions are untenable," said one senior UN official. "Jetley clearly does not command the confidence of the largest contingent in his force. fields.headline: World Bank dilutes report
fields.standfirst:
Agencies claim poverty document was censored
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: A World Bank report trailed as the most detailed ever investigation into global poverty was last night under heavy fire from development charities who accused the bank of censoring the radical conclusions of an earlier version.
fields.body:
A World Bank report trailed as the most detailed ever investigation into global poverty was last night under heavy fire from development charities who accused the bank of censoring the radical conclusions of an earlier version.

Aid agencies said that criticisms of orthodox economic policies from a draft published on the web in January had been removed from the final version of the bank's world development report, published last night.

"It is a comprehensive overhaul in which much of the draft's critique of conventional bank thinking has been replaced by an apologia for business as usual," said Duncan Green, policy analyst at Cafod, the Catholic aid agency.

The original author of the report, Professor Ravi Kanbur, resigned in June, after what friends described as a disagreement with the more orthodox economists at the bank over his insistence that redistributive taxation policies and social spending were vital in tackling global poverty.

The bank last night denied charges of censorship, and said that the key messages of Prof Kanbur's draft had survived the editing process. The final report argues that economic growth is crucial but often not sufficient to improve living standards in poor countries. It advocates a three-prong approach of expanding economic opportunities for the poor, while empowering them and providing security against social and economic shocks.

"There' s no censorship at all, what we've had is a process of consultation since we placed the January version on the web," said Professor Nick Stern, the bank's chief economist. "In that process, we have made revisions but the central messages [from the January draft] of opportunity, empowerment, and security are still driving the whole thing."

However aid agencies said the radical tone of Prof Kanbur's January draft had been watered down, and the standard Bank messages about the importance of economic reform, strengthened.

Prof Kanbur's draft criticised free market reforms advocated by the bank and the International Monetary Fund, which it says have harmed poor people in some countries. The final version of the report omits most of the sections describing the downside of market reforms and concentrates on their benefits for economic growth.

The January draft blamed rapid opening of financial markets for the crisis which swept through Asia three years ago and advocated countries using capital controls to stem speculative flows of capital. In the final version of the report, the section on capital flows has been cut down to a line recommending a "cautious approach" to the process of liberalising financial markets and using capital controls as a transition measure.

"On balance, I'd say this is a clear case of intellectual censorship," said Mr Green.

webTitle: Britain's hostage rescue team landed in swamp

fields.headline: Britain's hostage rescue team landed in swamp
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The British troops sent in to rescue comrades in Sierra Leone faced potential disaster themselves due to an apparent intelligence failure, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The British troops sent in to rescue comrades in Sierra Leone faced potential disaster themselves due to an apparent intelligence failure, it emerged yesterday.

When members of the Parachute Regiment disembarked from transport helicopters in Sunday's raid, they found they were waist-deep in swamp water and without cover, exposed to any fire from the rebels holding six British soldiers hostage.

Talking about the successful mission yesterday after returning to their base at Connaught Barracks in Dover, they admitted that the rescue unit had expected to be landed on solid ground near the West Side Boys' compound.

It was also revealed that at least one senior member of the mission was seriously injured, forcing a rapid reorganisation; and that some of those taking part were as young as 18 and had joined the regiment four days before being chosen for the 150-strong mission force.

The revelations illustrate the fine line between military success and failure - and the wider repercussions involved. One life was lost on the British side; if there had been more, political pressure would have grown on the British government to pull troops out of a country devastated by the struggle between rebels and government for power and the diamond mines.

The paratroopers landed in Britain early yesterday morning at RAF Brize Norton, near Oxford. The 12 injured in the rescue were taken to a military hospital; after checking in their weapons, the rest were given leave.

Before rejoining their families six of those who had taken part in the Sierra Leone attack volunteered to describe their experiences.

Forming the bulk of the rescue team was A company, as most of its members had recently completed jungle training in Jamaica. The company was augmented with some servicemen who spent time in Sierra Leone earlier in the summer and a handful of new recruits.

They were told that they were going on an exercise and ordered not to contact family or friends. Mobile phones were confiscated.

Not until they got to Africa did they learn what their job was and start a series of run-throughs for the operation, using full-scale models of the rebel encampment.

The night before the Sunday morning mission the paratroopers were up until 1am making final checks and preparations.

Sergeant "Fitz" Fitzwater, 34, who was to act as second in command of one of the three platoons, said he had been "apprehensive but excited". Julian Sheard, 19, one of the new recruits, said he was "more scared about letting anyone down than anything else". Senior officers later said they were proud at how the newcomers had performed.

The soldiers were woken at 4am and by 5.40am were on Chinook helicopters. Soon afterwards, as they hovered above the landing spots earmarked by reconnaissance, the rebels opened fire.

Sgt Fitzwater was first out of his helicopter. Leaping in the gloom he found himself in water when he had expected solid ground. He admitted that if the water had been more than waist deep, it could have been "disastrous" as the men were loaded with kit: "It was a brief but scary moment."

Exposed in the swamp, the paras had to wade for about 400 metres. There, "we reached the area of dry land we had expected to land on, which we quickly identified from aerial photographs we'd seen", Sgt Fitzwater said.

The paratroopers' mission was to secure the rebel camp on the south side of Rokel creek. It is believed that special services including the SAS had the job of pulling out the half-dozen hostages who were being held in a camp on the northern bank of the river.

The paras, backed by fire from two Lynx helicopters, drove the rebels out and when they got to the village found only blood trails from those who struggled away or were dragged off. Sporadic exchanges of gunfire with the West Side Boys continued, however.

As the troops entered the village the company's commanding officer was among those badly injured by either a landmine or an improvised mortar. Private Sheard said: "There was a loud explosion and we could hear these really agonising screams." The injured were flown out within 30 minutes.

Once the village had been secured the soldiers dug in, having been told that the rebels had a 120mm mortar to the south of the camp, but there was no firing from that quarter. Only when the paratroopers were airlifted out some six hours later did they learn that the hostages were safe but that one man had been killed.

He was later named as Bombardier Brad Tinnion, an army commando believed to have been attached to the SAS.

Sgt Fitzwater, the father of 11-month-old twins, said: "We thought there would be more casualties - it's the nature of the game."

Captain Danny Matthew said he had been worried that the operation was going too well, knowing the rebels had more forces nearby. A counter-attack had been expected.

The soldiers have been told to report back to Connaught Barracks for first parade on Monday. The battalion is due to tour Northern Ireland next year. One officer said: "Despite what they've been through life goes on."

webTitle: UK spacecraft 'will outdo Nasa on Mars'

fields.headline: UK spacecraft 'will outdo Nasa on Mars'
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The leader of the project to put a British spacecraft on Mars in 2004 said yesterday that a more expensive Nasa project due to land about the same time was "inferior", with less chance of finding any existing life elements there.
fields.body:
The leader of the project to put a British spacecraft on Mars in 2004 said yesterday that a more expensive Nasa project due to land about the same time was "inferior", with less chance of finding any existing life elements there.

Colin Pillinger, professor of planetary sciences at the Open University, leading the team building the Beagle 2 spacecraft, told the British Association festival of science that his machine was better equipped to "sniff out" compounds, such as water and methane, that would signify life.

Nasa's craft, two mobile labs called Athena which will roam about on wheels, are likely to cost about £400m, more than 10 times the cost of Beagle 2.

Beagle 2 will be launched as one of a European mission, aboard a rocket called Mars Express, set to blast off from Kazakhstan in 2003.

"Athena has what I believe to be an inferior package of scientific instruments to search for life," Professor Pillinger told the British Association science festival.

The race between Europe and the US to find evidence of life on Mars is focused on the search for evidence of water - some scientists now believe it may have been present on the planet much more recently than previously thought, and may even still exist in some locations on the planet.

"The spectrometers on board Athena are geared up to look for hydrogen rather than water," said Prof Pillinger. "The main instrument on Beagle 2 is a mass spectrometer which can look for organic matter, water, and the minerals deposited from water, and measure their abundance."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Spanish Prisoner | Very Bad Things | The Phantom Of Liberty | Two-Way Stretch
fields.body:
The Spanish Prisoner
(David Mamet, 1997)
10am, 4pm, Sky Premier

Mamet is back in House Of Games mode, and he's built a veritable tower-block of con-trickery this time. Campbell Scott's Joe Ross is the whiz behind The Process - a top secret wotsit with a hefty commercial value - and he is drawn into an odd relationship with wealthy, enigmatic Jimmy Dell (Steve Martin) after an altercation over a camera in the Caribbean. Scott, as the dupe of an intricate, infinitely complex scam, is too anodyne to be sympathetic, but it's a vastly entertaining intellectual exercise.

Very Bad Things
(Peter Berg, 1998)
10pm, Sky MovieMax

Five friends on a stag-party binge commit murder, then gradually crack apart as the burden of responsibility weighs on them. Berg - the smalltown dupe in The Last Seduction - in his debut directorial feature creates a black comedy that's a cross between I Know What You Did Last Summer and the Farrelly brothers' Kingpin, but the result is uncertain of tone and not really funny enough. Still, it is fun to see the obnoxious cast - Cameron Diaz, Christian Slater and all - squirm.

The Phantom Of Liberty
(Luis Buñuel, 1974)
3.40am, FilmFour

A surreal and subversive stroll through a series of apparently unconnected events, from the execution of Spanish insurgents (shouting "Long live our chains") by Bonapartist soldiers, to a revolution in a zoo. Mankind is once more under the amused Buñuelian lens, examining political, social and sexual freedom, and sharply focused on absurdity - such as the party guests who gather for communal defecation, and go into private cubicles to eat dinner.

Two-Way Stretch
(Robert Day, 1960)
5pm, Carlton Cinema

Convicts Peter Sellers, Bernard Cribbins and David Lodge, abetted by Wilfrid Hyde White's crooked clergyman, escape from prison, relieve a maharajah of his jewels and nip back into nick for the perfect alibi. Lionel Jeffries and Beryl Reid are among the familiar faces in a vintage comedy.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Psion joins radio bidding
fields.body:
Psion joins radio bidding

Psion, the technology group, and programme producer UBC Media yesterday joined the MXR consortium bidding for five regional digital radio licences. The presence of Psion among the consortium partners will enable the development of data services to be broadcast alongside the planned clutch of radio stations. MXR includes radio groups Chrysalis, Capital and Jazz FM as well as Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian newspaper.

Scottish Life closes doors

The Scottish Life mutual company, expected to be sold this week to GE Capital, yesterday closed the door on carpetbaggers taking out last-minute with-profits policies to try to make money from a sale. Creditor seeks savers US credit card issuer Capital One yesterday launched an assault on the British savings market, offering three products including a direct access account paying between 3% and 5.5% gross. Capital One, which entered the British credit card market in 1996 now has more than 1m UK cardholders.


Tin mine in new ownership

The first moves to reopen Britain's last working tin mine were announced yesterday, 29 months after it closed with the loss of 300 jobs. Contracts for the purchase of the 800m-deep South Crofty pit, near Camborne, west Cornwall, have been exchanged in a deal which would give Redruth-based Baseresult the relevant mineral rights, and the processing plant.

Belgo goes for posh pizza

Restaurant company Belgo believes there is scope to open 50 of its Strada upmarket pizzerias across Britain, to cater for a gap in the market between "Pizza Express and top-end Italian eateries".

Belgo's annual pre-tax profits increased 33% to £4.06m.

webTitle: Dirty rats leave Gore a subliminal message

fields.headline: Dirty rats leave Gore a subliminal message
fields.standfirst:
It was only visible for a thirtieth of a second but here's proof the gloves are really off
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The increasingly accident-prone Bush presidential campaign was accused of dirty tricks yesterday, after it was discovered that the word "rats" appeared subliminally in a Republican political broadcast targeting Democratic health care proposals.
fields.body:
The increasingly accident-prone Bush presidential campaign was accused of dirty tricks yesterday, after it was discovered that the word "rats" appeared subliminally in a Republican political broadcast targeting Democratic health care proposals.

The offending word, in large white capital letters, flashes against a black background for a thirtieth of a second as a woman narrator criticises Vice President Al Gore's plan for government funding of prescriptions for pensioners.

George W Bush ridiculed as "bizarre and weird" accusations that his campaign was trying to use such underhand techniques to discredit his opponent. Yesterday, however, he announced that the $2.5m (£1.3m) advertising campaign would be withdrawn.

Alex Castellanos, the Republican campaigner responsible for producing the advertisment denied trying to send subliminal messages.

"We don't play ball that way. I'm not that clever," he said.

However, Mr Castellanos has been involved in controversial political broadcasts before. In 1990 he produced an advertisement for the rightwing Republican senator for North Carolina, Jesse Helms, which used racial imagery in a contest with a black businessman, Harvey Gant. At one point a white pair of hands receives a job rejection letter and crumples it up, but for a fraction of a second the letter fades to a picture of Mr Gant and the hands appear to be crushing his head.

Kathleen Hall Jamieson, who analyses the advertisement in her book Dirty Politics: Deception, Distraction and Democracy, said Mr Castellanos insisted then that the imagery was accidental. Ms Jamieson believes the Helms advertisement was the first instance of subliminal imagery in US political advertising and Mr Castellanos's "rats advertisement" is the second.

Gore campaign workers were scarcely able to contain their glee yesterday as the Bush campaign was forced into emergency damage limitation for the second time in eight days, at a time when it is losing ground in the polls.

Last Monday - apparently unaware that he was speaking close to a live microphone - Mr Bush was overheard describing a New York Times reporter as "a major-league asshole". The reporter, Adam Clymer, had written a critical account of the Texas governor's record on health care, and the gaffe made Mr Bush appear peevish and unsettled.

Campaigning in Florida yesterday, the candidate seemed rattled by the new controversy yesterday, struggling to pronounce the word "subliminal", and raising doubts as to whether he understood its meaning when he argued: "The idea of one frame out of 900 hardly in my judgment makes a conspiracy."

After seeing a double-digit lead in the polls evaporate in less than a month, splits have emerged in the Bush camp over how to pursue the campaign, and when to "go negative". Last week the candidate's staff were trying to increase their control over the Republican National Committee's campaign office responsible for producing political broadcasts, because it was unhappy about the harshly negative tone of some of its output.

fields.trailText: Sir Julian Critchley's wit, humour and independence of spirit will be sadly missed (Obituary, September 12). fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Carlton television is of course most famous for its intellectual programming, having produced such highbrow TV classics as ... um. Oh yes, Inspector Morse. And who knows, there may be some others. Anyway, that dedication to quality can be seen in a memo sent round to staff at Carlton's HQ last week from Peter Mann, with "Page Three Stunner" in the subject line. "Does anyone know," asks Peter, "of a page three stunner who is a builder of some kind who we can turn into the next Charlie Dimmock on our new DIY show?" (Gosh, a DIY show. That must have taken minutes to think up.) Peter says he is not bothered if the aforementioned "stunner" is a plumber, electrician, bricklayer or jack-of-all-trades. "As long as she knows her stuff, looks good and can string a few sentences together we will consider her." Luckily, the building trade is full of former glamour models so Peter shouldn't have too much trouble finding some prospects. Any stunners out there can stop grouting the tiles and email: peter.mann@carltontv.co.uk

 How inspiring to see key attendees at the TUC conference shrugging off the gathering fuel crisis. Anna Diamantopoulou, the EU commissioner for social affairs and a speaker in Glasgow yesterday, set the tone by turning up in a lovely maroon Rolls-Royce, which might do, ooooh, 20 miles to the gallon tops.

 In Mandarin the word for crisis is the same as opportunity (crisitunity?), and in this case the fuel crisis is an opportunity for the Diary to hold another competition. Someone sent us one of those fold-up lightweight skate scooters that have become so fashionable - and it becomes the glittering prize in our new Running On Empty competition. The first reader to ring the Diary while actually stuck in a queue at a filling station, or waiting for the RAC on a hard shoulder after running out of petrol, will win a magnificent Viper 2, which retails at £85. This competition is not open to anyone in the south-east of England. But if this thing keeps going, how we are going to actually get the scooter to the winner is a tricky one.

 Matthew Norman's on holiday, and after one day in charge I've already made an appalling error. Yesterday's Diary ascribed Downing Street's comment on Andrew Rawnsley's new book - "A series of tittle tattle gossiping, flambéed up into some frothtastic cocktail" - to Alastair Campbell. But no, it turns out that it came from the brain of Godric Smith, Alastair's civil service stand-in. Godric was too busy dealing with the petrol crisis to come to the phone yesterday. But it is wonderful to see Godders transforming before our eyes, like a caterpillar changing into a beautiful butterfly, as he makes the job of being Mr Tony's mouthpiece his own.

 As the fuel crisis drags on, one can't help thinking that today was the wrong day for Peterborough city council to launch its new mobile library service. Anyone planning to gather by the post box on Silver Hill at 5.45pm and (as promised in the press release) borrowing "books of all kinds" may be very disappointed.

 I'm looking forward to catching Puppetry of the Penis when it opens at London's Whitehall Theatre next Wednesday. But a rival has appeared in the shape of a brochure for Sheffield's Site Gallery. If I had to recommend one thing from so many treats, it would be the live and visual art of Lisa Watts. "Running Machine Performance will be performed," says the blurb, "to a blindfolded audience who will listen to the performer working out on the stepping machine whilst reading a prepared text." It sounds tremendous. But there's more: "Crying Video is a competition of who can cry the most in a given hour performed by two actors." Frothtastic! (© Godric Smith 2000). Call the Site Gallery on 0114 28121077.

webTitle: An Exchange of squabbling and bluster

fields.headline: An Exchange of squabbling and bluster
fields.standfirst: Merger collapse was inevitable
fields.trailText: As battles for control of middling-sized British corporates go, the antics surrounding the future of our glorious 200 year-old London Stock Exchange take some beating.
fields.body:
As battles for control of middling-sized British corporates go, the antics surrounding the future of our glorious 200 year-old London Stock Exchange take some beating.

Yesterday's admission that the merger with Deutsche Börse is dead in its current un-thought-through form was inevitable. The whole idea was badly planned and terribly presented from the outset.

With hindsight, one of the great howlers of the aborted iX deal was the idea that trading in "growth" companies go to Frankfurt, while blue chip trading was to reside in London. Who, one senior market man asked recently, might decide what is a growth company and what is not - since anyone who has the ability to spot them should have retired by now to somewhere warm and light on taxes.

The deal was not thought through in advance. So it is little surprise to learn now that the exchange's management did not feel capable of fending off the hostile approach from Sweden's OM, while simultaneously selling (if that is the word) the London-Frankfurt merger to their shareholders, who also double up as their customers.

The exchange is now a commercial business and has to play by the corporate rule-book. In turn, corporate precedent says that when a management sees its plans for the business trashed by the owners and then lands itself with an opportunistic approach from a predatory rival, the owners tend to move in and sack the managers. An experienced pair of hands is then installed who can be trusted with extracting value and/or rebuilding the confidence required to remain independent.

In the case of the exchange, this is a bit tricky, since the new chairman, Don Cruickshank, was supposed to be the very man. (And anyway, David James is much too busy folding up that tent in south east London.)

On the other hand, the position of Michael Marks, a board member and a grandee of the London stock market in every sense, is much clearer. It is untenable.

Traditionally, the authorities (including the exchange itself and the financial services authority) have always frowned on City advisers who sit on the boards of corporate clients. Whatever the Chinese walls, there is perceived to be a potential conflict of interest. In the case of Mr Marks, his firm, Merrill Lynch, is the exchange's prime corporate finance adviser as well as its biggest customer.

More to the point, whether he likes it or not, Mr Marks is credited as the architect of the iX merger. He should resign now before the shareholders vote him off the podium at Thursday's annual general meeting.

But regardless of who sits around the exchange's boardroom table, mapping the future of this institution has not become any simpler after yesterday's events. The pressure for consolidation, in order to bring transaction costs down, is as great as ever. At the same time, there is no sign that the regulatory hurdles - where varying market rules, tax regimes, and supervisory structures in different jurisdictions make seamless cross-border equity trading impossible - are being dismantled.

This is an area where a confident London Stock Exchange, in partnership with the FSA, should be taking a European lead.

For all its flaws and technicalities and suspicious price movements, the London market remains rich in terms of integrity and practical experience - certainly when compared with any bourse on the continent. Sadly, rather than confidence, all any of us expect in the short term is more bureaucratic squabbling, with the occasional outburst of bluster.

Next lesson

Just 18 months ago, Next's finance director David Keens declared that people who wanted to choose clothes on the internet were "sad".

He dismissed the idea of putting the company's clothes catalogue online, because he thought Next's customers were too impatient to wait for pictures to download. Since Mr Keens' attack of foot-in-mouth disease, the group has put more than 1,200 pictures of shirts, skirts and jackets on the web. Next now expects more than £20m of online sales this year.

Mr Keens was guilty of underestimating the appeal of Next's unthreatening, classic clothes - even internet addicts want to get their hands on them.

Others have made a similar mistake - it has taken the City years to come round to the company.

Next has pulled off quite a feat by prospering while the rest of the middle-market has been suffering. Its secret is simple - each year it takes its unexciting range and just adds a few trendy twists. The company has stuck to one brand, avoiding the trap of diversifying into unknown areas. Others, such as Marks & Spencer, should watch and learn.

fields.headline: Sarah's law 'gets minister's backing'
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The government has agreed to give the public some form of access to details of sex offenders, the parents of the murdered eight-year-old schoolgirl Sarah Payne said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government has agreed to give the public some form of access to details of sex offenders, the parents of the murdered eight-year-old schoolgirl Sarah Payne said yesterday.

Emerging after an hour-long meeting with the Home Office minister Paul Boateng, Michael and Sara Payne said he had agreed to their request for a version of a "Sarah's law", giving parents access to the sex offenders register.

Outside the Home Office headquarters in central London, Mrs Payne said: "We have been assured there will be a Sarah's law. We are very happy indeed. It's what we were all working so hard for. Unfortunately we haven't got our daughter, but it might help somebody else's."

Mr and Mrs Payne refused to give further details of assurances made by Mr Boateng.

A Home Office spokeswoman said: "There were constructive discussions between Mr Boateng and the family of Sarah Payne. The proposed direction of government policy was part of those discussions. We expect to make an announcement shortly."

She refused to give further details of what had been agreed or to confirm claims that Mr Boateng had promised to introduce a Sarah's law.

Ministers have been looking at ways to strengthen police powers to deal with paedophiles, expected to be announced this month. These could allow police to photograph and question offenders on the register, and possibly authorise police to enter and search their homes.

But the plans had been expected to stop short of a Sarah's law - based on the US Megan's law, named for a schoolgirl killed by a paedophile in California in 1994 - making the names and addresses of sex offenders public.

Access to the information varies from state to state. In some states, names and pictures can be downloaded from a police website.

There has been scepticism over how effective Megan's law has been in stopping offenders repeating their crimes. The law has also been undermined by vigilante attacks.

In Britain only the police and certain other officials have access to the sex offenders' register. It has a higher compliance rate of offenders keeping it updated than US equivalents.

The former Tory home secretary, Michael Howard, said he had considered a British version of Megan's law in 1997 when the sex offences register was launched, but rejected the idea after advisers warned him of the dangers of paedophiles going to ground.

Lawyers have warned that the move could be challenged as a breach of the right to privacy guaranteed by the European convention on human rights.

The Paynes were whisked off in a Jaguar with the News of the World's editor, Rebekah Wade, and managing editor Stuart Kuttner, who also attended the meeting. The paper has been campaigning for the introduction of a Sarah's law.

This included "naming and shaming" people on the sex offenders register by publishing their details, a move thought to have led to vigilante attacks on innocent people.

Before the meeting, the Paynes handed the home secretary, Jack Straw, a 700,000-name petition calling for a Sarah's law, mainly from News of the World readers.

The couple, from Hersham, Surrey, said Mr Straw agreed to the need for tougher sentencing and more powers for families of victims.

Mr Payne said the massive public support for their campaign since their daughter was snatched on July 1 from a country lane near her grandparents' home in Kingston, West Sussex, had helped them cope with her death.

webTitle: DSS to relax pension fund rules

fields.headline: DSS to relax pension fund rules
fields.trailText: Strict rules introduced after the Maxwell crisis to protect pensioners seem likely to be relaxed later this week after intensive campaigning by the pensions industry.
fields.body:
Strict rules introduced after the Maxwell crisis to protect pensioners seem likely to be relaxed later this week after intensive campaigning by the pensions industry.

The DSS will tomorrow announce its review of the minimum funding requirement (MFR), which has effectively forced pension funds to buy large quantities of long-dated government stock to ensure liabilities are covered.

Strong demand for gilts, with low supply, has pushed yields down to the lowest level in Europe, also resulting in historically low annuity rates.

Yesterday there was heavy selling of gilts as dealers speculated that the DSS will permit pension funds to swap to double and triple-A rated corporate bonds instead. The yield on 15-year gilts rose to 5.18% from 5.12%, while 30-year gilts moved up from 4.68% to 4.74%.

Chairman of the National Association of Pension Funds Alan Pickering said: "Much of the thirst for gilts has been driven by the MFR, which has resulted in a distorted market which was unforseen when the rules were introduced. Our expectation is that the MFR review will result in asset class decisions which are less distorting and take away some of the pain in buying an annuity."

But detailed MFR changes are unlikely to be announced tomorrow. Instead the DSS is expected to set out options, with changes unlikely until the completion of the Myners review into fund management.

fields.headline: Going, going, gone: 200 years' independence
fields.trailText: Bonhams, the Knightsbridge auctioneer, has brought down the hammer on 207 years of independence by agreeing to merge with Brooks, a specialist in selling vintage cars.
fields.body:
Bonhams, the Knightsbridge auctioneer, has brought down the hammer on 207 years of independence by agreeing to merge with Brooks, a specialist in selling vintage cars.

The deal will create the world's fourth largest auction house, with 200 staff and sales of £75m. It has been partly prompted by the need for large investments in the internet.

Bonhams managing direc tor, Christopher Elwes, said: "The development of our business has been moving on apace. The bigger players like Sotheby's and Christie's have been investing heavily in the internet."

Founded by two antique book dealers in 1793, Bonhams holds sales in a large number of categories - including pictures, furniture, porcelain and jewellery.

It has offices throughout Britain, which it said would complement the Brooks network overseas. Mr Elwes said: "We have many plans. There are obvious synergies in the deal."

Bonhams is family-controlled - its deputy chairman is Nicholas Bonham, a sixth generation descendant of one of its founders. The auction house has been working with Brooks on the development of an internet auction site, Supergavel.

The combined entity will be called Bonhams & Brooks. The groups said the merger would be financed by Louwman Brooks - a holding company controlled by Brooks founders Evert Louwman and Robert Brooks.

Mr Elwes refused to reveal financial details of the transaction or whether the Bonham family was selling any of its shares.

Brooks was established in 1989 and had sales of £34m last year. Its most expensive lot has been a 1938 Alfa Romeo Berlinetta, sold for £2.08m.

The auction world has been going through a period of upheaval. The largest player, Sotheby's, is being investigated by the US department of justice for alleged price-fixing.

fields.headline: Roach stays with InterClub
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Dennis Roach, the leading football agent whose recent player transfer dealings are being investigated by the game's governing body, is to remain a consultant for InterClubNet, the newly floated web-based transfer company.
fields.body:
Dennis Roach, the leading football agent whose recent player transfer dealings are being investigated by the game's governing body, is to remain a consultant for InterClubNet, the newly floated web-based transfer company.

Finance director Gregory Puchert said last night that the position of Mr Roach, a 17.5% shareholder in the firm and father of InterclubNet's chief executive Nick Roach, was unchanged by the investigation.

"Dennis is a consultant to InterClubNet who introduces us to clubs and gives us knowledge about the football club market, but he is not a director or involved in the day to day running of the company," Mr Puchert said.

Following a complaint about his conduct, the Football Association is investigating two recent high-profile transfer deals conducted by Mr Roach that resulted in public slanging matches between the agent and Newcastle United and Manchester City. The FA confirmed the inquiry was going ahead but could not say what action might be taken as a result of it.

Mr Roach, 60, is one of the most powerful agents in world football and counts former England manager Glenn Hoddle among his clients.

He has a £100,000 per year consultancy contract with InterClubNet to introduce the firm's technology to top football clubs.

Manchester United and Real Madrid are among more than a dozen blue-chip clients now subscribing to the service.

In the offer document for its AIM flotation last month InterClubNet said it believed clubs would buy its service because characteristics of the player transfer market include susceptibility to abuse and a lack of transparency.

"The company's success to date, in terms of winning contracts with clubs, has been founded on its use of the reputation and ability of its consultants," it added.

fields.headline: Celltech moves into black
fields.standfirst: Medeva takeover makes a first contribution
fields.trailText: Celltech, Britain's biggest biotech company, yesterday moved into the black for the first time but saw its shares dive 5% as analysts branded its interim results "uninspiring".
fields.body:
Celltech, Britain's biggest biotech company, yesterday moved into the black for the first time but saw its shares dive 5% as analysts branded its interim results "uninspiring".

The Slough-based group, which recently entered the FTSE 100 index, made profits of £10.7m before exceptional items, largely owing to its acquisition of drugs firm Medeva in January.

Finance director Peter Allen said: "These profits are a first for us but we're rather cautious about life. We view them as just a start."

By buying Medeva, Celltech added a sales network and a portfolio of mature drugs to its portfolio of emerging products. However, Medeva operating profits fell slightly during the period to £25.7m, owing to declining sales of its top three drugs.

Mr Allen said the fall was due to Celltech's policy of encouraging customers to keep lower stocks of the key drugs - methylphenidate for attention deficit disorder, Tussionex for flu and heart drug Zaroxolyn.

The figures were accompanied by the unexpected departure of Garry Watts, the former finance director of Medeva who was retained after the takeover to continue running the business. Mr Allen said: "We wanted somebody with more of a pharmaceutical background than an accounting background."

Initial sales of Mylotarg, the recently launched drug for leukaemia, reached $3.8m. But analysts were disappointed by a modest contribution from Chirocaine, the group's new anaesthetic. Mr Allen admitted that it would take time to establish, saying: "Anaesthetists are a relatively conservative bunch."

There was also concern at the size of a £349m goodwill charge on the purchase of Medeva. Eva Haas of Old Mutual Securities said: "I'm mildly disappointed with the results. Some people might say that the size of this goodwill charge means they rather drastically overpaid for Medeva."

Celltech's shares closed down 77p at £44.20. Steve McGarry of Goldman Sachs said: "There's nothing really here to excite the market."

fields.headline: Dresdner looks at Wasserstein
fields.standfirst: German bank close to $1.5bn US deal
fields.trailText: Dresdner Bank of Germany is in talks to buy Wasserstein Perella, the American investment banking boutique founded by two of Wall Street's best known bankers, for up to $1.5bn (£1bn).
fields.body:
Dresdner Bank of Germany is in talks to buy Wasserstein Perella, the American investment banking boutique founded by two of Wall Street's best known bankers, for up to $1.5bn (£1bn).

Wasserstein, which featured prominently in the book Barbarians at the Gate - the account of KKR's then world record 1980s takeover of tobacco and food company RJR-Nabisco - advised Time-Warner on its takeover by America Online, the biggest deal so far this year.

The talks, which would combine London-based Dresdner Kleinwort Benson with the firm now known as Wasserella, underlines the fast pace of consolidation in the global investment banking industry.

A source close to the talks confirmed that a deal was very close. A report in the Wall Street Journal yesterday said financial terms were still to be finalised after both sides had largely agreed on the structure of the deal.

Bruce Wasserstein, who founded the firm with former colleague Joseph Perella in 1988, would be the largest beneficiary. He owns more than half of the business after Mr Perella's decision to leave in 1993 to head Morgan Stanley's investment banking department.

The takeover would improve Dresdner's position in the US market. Wasserstein was ranked fifth in all American mergers and acquisitions this year, compared with Dresdner's 14th slot, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data. As well as Time Warner, other blue chip clients include Phillip Morris, the tobacco group and Axa Financial, the US arm of the French insurer.

Mr Wasserstein has advised on some of the biggest financial services deals of the past decade. Two months ago, his firm advised UBS on its takeover of PaineWebber, a bid which set off the latest wave of consolidation.

Bernd Fahrholz, chairman of Dresdner, indicated that the German bank was prepared to spend about €1.5bn (£870m) on its investment banking business this summer after the bank's failure to agree merger terms with two German rivals, Deutsche and Commerzbank. The bank has a larger pool of money available for any purchase, however.

Sources close to the talks say there will be very little overlap. One said: "There is not much crossover between what we do and what they do."

A small number of Wasserstein's staff of more than 550 are based in London. Dresdner Kleinwort Benson employs 800 people in New York, but mainly in its equity operations rather than mergers and acquisitions.

Howard Covington, managing director of the US group's London operations, was flying back from New York yesterday morning. Although his team advised on Wal-Mart's acquisition of Asda last year, it ranked 21st in all European deals announced in 1999.

Mr Wasserstein, 52, is expected to have been offered a "very senior role" with Dresdner Kleinworth Benson and a seat on the board.

He shot to prominence in the 1980s alongside Mr Perella when they headed the mergers and acquisitions department at First Boston. Following their decision to leave the bank, they were deeply involved in the RJR Nabisco takeover.

webTitle: Next gets smart as profits surge

fields.headline: Next gets smart as profits surge
fields.trailText: Surging sales of "smart casual" clothes helped Next outshine its high-street rivals with an 18% increase in half-year profits to £80.7m.
fields.body:
Surging sales of "smart casual" clothes helped Next outshine its high-street rivals with an 18% increase in half-year profits to £80.7m.

The company's shares leapt 42p to 650p on the news, which was accompanied by a confident prediction on future trading from chief executive David Jones.

He said: "We've focused on one brand, providing good clothes at decent value for money. We've shown that if you provide the public with what they want, they'll buy it."

He said the chain had benefited from a renewed enthusiasm for dressing up: "There's been a move from real casualwear to smart casual, and formal clothes. We're seeing casual people dressing up."

Many retailers have reported a change in sales as a result of relaxed dress policies in many City offices. Mr Jones said the trend went wider, and that people were changing their habits in their free time.

Next's recent trading has been positive, with like-for-like sales up 7%. Mr Jones said there were signs of an end to damaging price deflation, which has been caused in recent months by fierce competition.

The group opened six new stores during the half-year, taking the total to 338. The company had taken leases on eight outlets previously occupied by C&A, the chain which is quitting Britain.

Sales from Next's mail-order directory increased 11% to £138m, with about 7% of revenue coming from orders placed on the internet.

Next said it had noticed a resurgence in the popularity of knitwear. Brightly coloured clothes were making a comeback, with red and pink replacing black and grey.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: MP's son died of insulin overdose
fields.body:
MP's son died of insulin overdose

Chris Beith, 25, son of Liberal Democrat deputy leader Alan Beith, died in Berwick-upon-Tweed after injecting himself with an overdose of insulin, an inquest heard yesterday. An open verdict was recorded.

Warning to internet firms

Watchdogs have told internet providers not to claim they offer "free access" to the web if any part of their service carries a charge. The Advertising Standards Authority ruled after it upheld complaints against Appleonline.net and PlusNet Technologies.

Victory for school head

A headteacher forced to work a five-day week on returning from maternity leave faced unlawful discrimination, an employment tribunal has ruled. Rebekah Marshall, of Torrington, Devon, went to the tribunal after school governors refused her a jobshare to help her return to work.

BBC stands firm on sketch

The BBC is insisting it will screen a controversial comedy sketch filmed to mark the 40th anniversary of BBC Television Centre. The comedian Ronnie Barker complained about the parody of a Morecambe and Wise sketch.

fields.headline: Kosovo 'mafia' strikes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: There are fears that organised crime is spiralling out of control in Kosovo after the murder of a senior Albanian official working for the UN mission in the province.
fields.body:
There are fears that organised crime is spiralling out of control in Kosovo after the murder of a senior Albanian official working for the UN mission in the province.

The UN has ordered a security review for local staff after the mission's director of planning, reconstruction and development, Rexhep Luci, was shot dead in what K-For officials say was a "mafia" killing.

Unidentified gunmen shot Luci, 58, in the back six times as he returned to his apartment in the regional capital, Pristina, on Monday evening.

Luci's tasks included signing demolition orders for illegal buildings. At the time of his murder, the department was in the process of demolishing a hotel complex.

Colleagues said Luci had been threatened twice in the last 10 days.

An initial K-For report on the killing says Luci may have been killed by "mafia" figures related to the hotel industry.

The hotel complex was partly financed by the Kosovo Hotels Association, which the department said was set up by former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army who seized control of property across the province when Nato troops entered Kosovo last June.

fields.headline: Lost in the mist
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

It is early morning and there is not so much of a chill in the air as almost the colour of one and it is fairly warm and dewy. But that autumnal colour is a mist - deeper in the hollows and around the river, thinner on top of the Edge - limiting visibility to about a mile or so.

The mist obscures the hills and blurs the lines of hedges and trees. A breeze gives the feeling of movement but the mist keeps still. Not being able to make out features of human life, except for the turned soil of the fields, the noise of distant traffic is weird.

Behind the mist the real world drives to work, low on petrol, worrying about blockades. Inside the mist, the real world seems hardly real at all and its anxious row moans from the bottom of a distant pit.

The mist endows its inhabitants with invisibility and instead of keeping to the field margins, as I would in broad daylight, I set off across a recently ploughed field.

Although the soil feels new, sweet smelling, grey brown and although much messed-with by modern agriculture, it is the ancient stuff of this landscape.

Suddenly I spot a white, alien-looking blob - a big field mushroom rising out of the bare earth. It emerges, a ghost from when this was pasture land. Its mycelium must stretch way back into the past but its fruiting body belongs to the disturbing tenuousness of the now. Then I see another field mushroom and walk towards it, 50 paces away.

Then another, and so on across the field, mapping a straight line. This makes me think of old Alfred Watkins, plotting his ley lines from one point of value and significance through a landscape steeped in mystery to make a mythological map.

In the next field, recently harvested for wheat, is a long straight line of round straw bales. I scramble up and walk along the top of them. The sun has not yet burned the mist off.

No one can see me. I'm invisible.

fields.headline: The crisis at the dome
fields.standfirst:
Nomura has gone. Falconer should go

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Still the skies darken for the Millennium Dome and its ministerial chief, Lord Falconer. On the back of last week's £47m bail-out by national lottery money and the verdict of David James, the corporate fixer brought in as chairman to resuscitate the project, that the dome was built in the wrong place, too quickly and should probably not have been built at all, comes the news that Nomura, the Japanese bank which had been planning to buy the site for £105m, has pulled out of the deal.
fields.body:
Still the skies darken for the Millennium Dome and its ministerial chief, Lord Falconer. On the back of last week's £47m bail-out by national lottery money and the verdict of David James, the corporate fixer brought in as chairman to resuscitate the project, that the dome was built in the wrong place, too quickly and should probably not have been built at all, comes the news that Nomura, the Japanese bank which had been planning to buy the site for £105m, has pulled out of the deal. This appears to bring down the curtain on what had been the project's one bright prospect and makes the question of whether Lord Falconer has a right to continue in office more urgent.

Not that Nomura should escape blame. At first glance one might think that a bank which had offered hard cash and a realistic future as a theme park for the corpse of a dying attraction would be the wounded party. Far from it. Though Nomura abandoned the deal only after getting a comprehensive briefing from the author of a crucial report on the dome's financial position, this report (which neither Nomura nor the public have been allowed to see) is not the only cause of the breakdown. Its details have been known for some time and for the bank to cite them now as its excuse for quitting is unconvincing, as is talk of blaming 12 small holes in the building's great plastic roof. Some may suspect a mere negotiating ploy; after all, Nomura announced its decision as ministers reeled under a still greater crisis.

This, though, may not help Lord Falconer, whose continual refusals to resign begin to look foolish. Not long ago he had a viable defence: that the errors which doomed the dome occurred before he took office and that he had done all he could to save the project, not least by selling it to Nomura. Now that has been blown apart. Under his watch things have gone badly wrong, even as he has insisted that they were going right. Nor does he seem to have acted on these problems. It is stretching credibility to believe that he was not aware of the background to the inconsistencies cited by Nomura as a reason for abandoning the deal, yet he seems to have ignored them. The dome may yet end up with Nomura, or may be picked up by the Legacy consortium, whose hopeful bid the government previously rejected. Or it may even be bulldozed. What is increasingly hard to accept is that its fate should remain in the hands of Lord Falconer.

fields.headline: Bragg brands arts establishment 'foolish senior citizens of culture'
fields.trailText: Melvyn Bragg yesterday attacked the self-appointed arts establishment, represented by VS Naipaul and John Tusa, branding its members as "the foolish senior citizens of culture" for their complaints about "dumbing down".
fields.body:
Melvyn Bragg yesterday attacked the self-appointed arts establishment, represented by VS Naipaul and John Tusa, branding its members as "the foolish senior citizens of culture" for their complaints about "dumbing down".

Launching the 24th series of the South Bank Show, Lord Bragg likened such commentators to Mary Whitehouse, the anti-smut campaigner who had been known for attacking almost anything remotely controversial. "I do not believe they know of what they speak, and in my book that's a crime," said Lord Bragg.

Recently Naipaul, Tusa and the former Radio 3 controller Sir John Drummond, have all attacked what they see as the trivial nature of modern British culture. Lord Bragg said they were misguided.

"Videos and film and CD have given popular culture the ticket to posterity and only a fool would rush in to say that today's, or rather yesterday's, hierarchies will live forever. Mind you, we are not short of foolish senior citizens of culture puff-puffing in."

Lord Bragg, 60, named Sir Vidia Naipaul, 68, the novelist, Sir John Drummond, 65, a former controller of Radio 3, and John Tusa, 64, a former head of the BBC World Service, as suffering from the "national disease" of "denigrating the present and pompously pumping up the past".

Naipaul was "on record" as saying he did not read contemporary novels, and, Lord Bragg said, he probably did not watch television or go to the theatre.

"And who knows, in 100 years' time, the voice of the young Presley might well be treasured above the voice of the young Pavarotti. I would even put a bet on it."

fields.headline: Blackmail letter over Enigma machine
fields.trailText: The case of Bletchley Park's missing Enigma machine took a new turn yesterday when police disclosed a letter offering to return the device for a five-figure sum.
fields.body:
The case of Bletchley Park's missing Enigma machine took a new turn yesterday when police disclosed a letter offering to return the device for a five-figure sum.

The writer claimed to be the "unwitting" new owner of the second world war German encoding machine, despite the worldwide publicity that the theft in April provoked, and he couched his demand in muddled and archaic phrases.

Describing the letter's bizarre language, Detective Chief Inspector Simon Chesterman said: "One explanation might be that the author is simply trying to disguise his identity.

"Or it could be that the author's first language is not English.

"On the other hand, it could be in code, bearing in mind the kind of people interested in the Enigma machine."

The letter writer demanded that he be reimbursed for what he claimed to have been paid, a sum said to be in excess of £10,000, and requested immunity from the risk of prosecution.

The letter ended with a code word which police withheld yesterday, but they said it was not in the English language. This word will be used to verify any contact with the letter writer, and coding experts are examining whether it was generated by the Enigma machine.

The demand was authenticated by a photocopy of the machine's serial number, G312.

The letter was addressed to Christine Large, director of the charitable Bletchley Park trust, which now runs the wartime code-breaking centre near Milton Keynes as a museum.

She received it last Wednesday.

It had been posted in the Midlands the day before and written on an old-fashioned typewriter, fuelling speculation the author was a professional collector. Police guaranteed yesterday that, if there was no wrongdoing, the Enigma's new owner would not face prosecution and would remain anonymous.

The machine was stolen on an open day at centre, despite the presence of hundreds of visitors. All visitors were fingerprinted but no matches were made.

The loss was discovered only when staff came to lock up at the end of the day.

Police initially feared that it had been taken as a prank, because it disappeared on Saturday April 1.

Mrs Large said she was prepared to do whatever was necessary to regain the machine for the public.

While there are a number of "three rotor" Enigma machines on the collectors' market, the one stolen, which was on loan from the intelligence-gathering centre GCHQ, is particularly rare: it has four rotors, producing a more advanced form of the Enigma code.

Mrs Large said the Abwehr Enigma machine had been used by German military intelligence. There was only one other like it on public display in the world.

"It is extremely valuable. A price of £100,000 has been put on it, but quite frankly how can you cost anything that is as rare as this."

She said the sum demanded by the letter writer was greatly in excess of the £5,000 "fighting fund" available, and the trust might have to make appeals to well-wishers.

The trust has accepted an offer from a private collector of intelligence memorabilia to place an original four-wheel Enigma machine similar to the one stolen on long-term display at Bletchley Park.

Military historians believe that without the code breaking activities of staff at there, codenamed Station X, the war would have lasted two years longer.

Part of the text of the letter, with some sentences blanked out by police

I have been asked by the current owner the above Enigma machine, who purchased it in good faith to say and tell you now today, the unwitting person has no ultimate desire of depraving (sic) your august self or anyone the pleasure to see it again. It is though also not his position to freely give the possession for nothing either as the large sum is not to be lost that has been paid (here the police have blanked out the sum) but only on your full acceptance which are to be published nationally, with no conditions of escape on your part or any other person or official body involved in this matter.

[Here police have blanked out a paragraph]

A guarantee as said before in this letter that no pursuit of the unwitting now owner shall be made, this to get had by published notice in television and newspaper. This condition is of utmost desire to him and must be done for any further word can be exchanged to you on this matter. It is also of utmost importance also in this matter the person who will be as the negotiating medium will be afforded the same freedom of entanglement in this matter as they are not involved only on my insistence that they contact you to make this offer and for no other reason.

If no notice is to be seen by the day of Monday as the 18th day in September then nothing else is to be said again.

webTitle: How women sport stars lose out

fields.headline: How women sport stars lose out
fields.trailText: The media idolisation of female sports stars like tennis player Anna Kournikova at the expense of their less feminine but more successful counterparts is part of a culture that discourages women from keeping fit for their health, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The media idolisation of female sports stars like tennis player Anna Kournikova at the expense of their less feminine but more successful counterparts is part of a culture that discourages women from keeping fit for their health, it was claimed yesterday.

Precilla Choi, a health psychologist at Keele University, told the festival that one of the key reasons why eight out of 10 women failed to take enough exercise was that sport and working out were presented to women as ways to be thin and beautiful rather than as ways to be healthy.

"Women who don't conform to the stereotype - for example tennis players like Mary Pierce or the Williams sisters - who are quite muscular, get a much harder time than Anna Kournikova," she said.

"Kournikova is held up as one of the best role models in women's tennis, even though she isn't as good as the Williams sisters. Women in sport are still being valued more for what they look like than how good they are."

Dr Choi has carried out a study of representations of sportswomen in the media to back up her argument. "Far more often any discussion of women's sports performance is secondary to what they look like, whether they are married and have children."

She said the stereotyping extends from the home, where parents spend more time and money on sons' sporting ambitions than daughters', through schools, where sometimes there are no girls' changing rooms, through to adult life, where the link between keeping fit and slimming is reinforced by the media.

"Recreational exercise is presented as being about looking beautiful. The idea is they're not doing it to improve heart rates or bone thickness but to look good."

fields.headline: £9bn hired hands are cleaning up
fields.trailText: The upstairs, downstairs domestic lifestyle may be long gone, but Britons still spend more than £9bn a year on help in the home, a report revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The upstairs, downstairs domestic lifestyle may be long gone, but Britons still spend more than £9bn a year on help in the home, a report revealed yesterday.

Full-time servants are a thing of the past for most families, but more than 2.7m households now regularly employ some sort of domestic help.

The report, 21st Century Housekeeping, shows that each household employing domestic help spends an average of £3,493 a year on it, equivalent to £73 a week, on everything from gardeners to nannies.

The rate of pay for employing a cleaner is about £4.85 an hour, while a gardener earns a typical hourly rate of £6.46.

Yet nannies and child carers who have a bigger responsibility are earning much less - being paid just £3.64 an hour.

The research shows that nine in 10 people who work as hired helps are paid cash in hand, while two in three "domestic bosses" have never discussed a pay review with their employees.

Surprisingly, almost half of homeowners say they rarely see their hired help, while a similar amount of home helps failed to set out terms and conditions before they started the job.

Nine in 10 employers say they have not considered the insurance ramifications of hiring extra help in the home.

The report said: "Times have changed since the days when live-in servants were only for the aristocracy and leisured classes.

"Taking on hired help in the home is commonplace for ordinary working families up and down the country and, in many cases, is becoming essential rather than a luxury."

The report, by the insurance company Norwich Union, said the number of working women and mothers, today's long hours culture and the desire for more leisure time have all led to an increasing number of families taking on domestic help.

It said that 2.75m British households employ domestic help for, on average, 13.14 hours a week at an average wage of £5.54 an hour. "Based on a 48-week working year, that means as a nation we are spending £9bn on hired help," the report claimed.

Norwich Union commissioned research among 1,000 households across Britain, as well as 500 employers and 500 employees.

fields.headline: Statement that killed deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The statement issued yesterday by Nomura said:
fields.body:
The statement issued yesterday by Nomura said:

"Dome Europe announces that it has reluctantly decided to withdraw from the Millennium Dome legacy competition.

"This follows information that has come to light recently regarding the situation at NMEC and the Millennium Dome.

"Critically, the information provided to Nomura recently has revealed substantial uncertainty with regard to the ability of NMEC to transfer the dome assets on a timely basis.

"Dome Europe has learnt the following: a report by PriceWaterhouseCoopers, which Dome Europe has not been given, apparently reveals critical new information about the costs and future liabilities of the dome; NMEC has not established what assets it owns; NMEC's lack of understanding of who owns the intellectual property relating to the dome and its assets is likely to adversely impact on Dome Europe's ability to operate the zones; there are various disputes with sponsors where certain sponsors could have claims against various assets of the dome, including items core to the project; NMEC's undertakings to Dome Europe on ticket price discounting have been broken; a number of suppliers to the dome are claiming ownership of assets and demanding payment for their future use by Dome Europe; rights under the construction contracts relating to the structure of the building may be unenforcable due to lack of compliance by NMEC with repair and maintenance procedures.

"Therefore it is not possible at this time to progress with a purchase of the dome. Accordingly, Dome Europe has withdrawn.

"Dome Europe remains convinced that a successful leisure attraction can be operated at the dome.

"However, it is clear that it will be some time before there will be sufficient information available about the state of NMEC and its assets to permit any transaction to proceed."

Guy Hands, managing director of Nomura International's principal finance group, said: "This was a very difficult decision to make, but in the circumstances we had no alternative.

"I feel very sorry for the people of Greenwich and particularly the dome's employees, who face an uncertain future through no fault of their own."

fields.trailText: In our profile of David James, page 15, September 9, we quoted him saying about the diving support vessel British Argyll: "That ship was the last built at Smith's yard on Teesside.
