webTitle: Australia let Indonesia invade East Timor in 1975

fields.headline: Australia let Indonesia invade East Timor in 1975
fields.standfirst:
Records show Canberra had 3 days warning but did nothing
Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Australia knew in advance of the 1975 Indonesian invasion of East Timor and stood by for three days while Jakarta's troops prepared for the attack, secret documents released yesterday by the government revealed.
fields.body:
Australia knew in advance of the 1975 Indonesian invasion of East Timor and stood by for three days while Jakarta's troops prepared for the attack, secret documents released yesterday by the government revealed.

Memos, cables and letters sent and received by Australia's foreign department between 1974 and 1976 confirmed that Australia gave tacit approval to Jakarta to annex the former Portuguese colony.

East Timor voted overwhelmingly for independence last year and is under temporary United Nations control after the referendum triggered a wave of violence by pro-Jakarta militias.

Australia's foreign affairs minister, Alexander Downer, said the release of the documents ahead of the usual 30-year wait would help to clear the air over what is considered one of the most controversial events in Australian history.

Five Australian journalists were killed in the assault.

Mr Downer said that although the Labour government of Gough Whitlam had advance warning of the attack, there was no evidence that Australia could have prevented the journalists' deaths.

"The Department of Foreign Affairs had no information beforehand of any intentions to kill the journalists, although it did have prior knowledge of the planned invasion," he said.

"I'm not today, with 25 years of hindsight, going to pass judgment on the actions of Australian ministers and officials during this critical exercise, nor will I offer opinions about the conduct of other governments at the time."

Australia's two main political parties have come under fire for their actions at the time. Mr Whitlam's Labour party was in office when Indonesia's then president Suharto ordered the invasion, and Malcolm Fraser's Liberal/National coalition was in power by the time Indonesia annexed East Timor in 1976.

Cabinet minutes from the time will not be released until the 30-year waiting period is up, and Mr Downer said intelligence reports might never be released for reasons of national security.

Australia was the only western nation to recognise Indonesia's rule over East Timor.

Human rights groups said up to 200,000 people died during the invasion and subsequent fighting and famine in East Timor, sparked by Portugal's withdrawal in 1975.

Indonesia and its western allies reacted to the withdrawal with alarm, fearing that pro-communist East Timorese were taking over and that another communist stronghold would emerge in the region, months after the fall of Saigon to the communists.

President Suharto also had tacit US support for the invasion, which took place just after a visit by the then president, Gerald Ford.

With Vietnam fresh in mind, Australia told Jakarta it did not want to get involved in East Timor - a territory it had once called "an essay in the hopeless". Critics said this gave President Suharto a green light to invade.

"While preferring the integration of Portuguese Timor with Indonesia, the Whitlam government wished there to be a genuine act of self-determination in the territory," Mr Downer said.

"Fears that Indonesia might seek to obtain the territory otherwise than by these means led the Whitlam government to adopt a policy of studied detachment."

fields.headline: Drug firms' rebalancing act
fields.trailText: An attack of the technicals was about the best explanation for the strong performance of London's three blue chip pharmaceutical stocks yesterday.
fields.body:
An attack of the technicals was about the best explanation for the strong performance of London's three blue chip pharmaceutical stocks yesterday.

AstraZeneca advanced 115p to £33.00 - a new closing high - while Glaxo Wellcome added 65p to £19.75 and SmithKline Beecham rose 29.5p to 893p.

Certainly, there was some positive background music for the sector. There was some defensive buying as the fuel crisis deepened and AstraZeneca announced higher than expected British wholesale orders for Nexium, its successor to Losec, the world's biggest selling drug. There were even some wild rumours that Franco-German group Aventis was in merger talks.

All of this, however, was a sideshow, the real explanation for the moves was much more mundane.

On the one hand there was the level of the dollar against the pound, which fell below $1.40 for the first time in 14 years. SmithKline and Glaxo make the bulk of their profits in the US and bring them back to Britain. A strong dollar tends, therefore, to flatter profits.

On the other hand, there was news of some important index changes. From next Monday, the companies which make up the widely followed Dow Jones STOXX family of blue chip indices will be selected on the size of their free float (the number of share freely tradable) rather than on market capitalisation.

The implications of the move could be significant. According to one estimate there is €50bn (£29bn) of institutional cash tracking the Euro STOXX 50 index and €10bn following the STOXX 50 index.

One consequence of the index rebalancing is that AstraZeneca will be joining the STOXX 50. This means funds which track the index will need to buy more than 4m AstraZeneca shares by the close of play on Friday. Another is that Glaxo and SmithKline will see their weightings increased in the STOXX 50 index and trackers will be forced to buy 1m and 1.6m shares respectively by Friday.

Although these changes have been flagged well in advance, dealers said, it was buying by the trackers that really pushed the trio higher.

Other leading shares, meanwhile, ended lower as investors decided to ignore an early rebound for tech stocks on Wall Street and concentrate on events closer to home.

The FTSE 100 closed down 26.5 points at 6,555.5 as investors started to worry about the impact the fuel crisis. The FTSE 250 fell 46.4 to 6,907.7 and the Techmark dipped 26.07 to 3,964.57.

As the fuel crisis worsened, with some City wags labelling it the "Autumn of Discontent", transport stocks came under pressure. Logistics group Exel was one of the worst affected, falling 70p to £10.10, while P&O eased 25p to 580p. The misery was not just confined to the blue chips. FTSE 250 logistics group Tibbet & Britten slipped 27.5p to 715p, while Securicor shed 9p to 124p and National Express closed down 30p at 765p.

Oil groups BP and Shell were also weaker, falling 6p to 665p and 8.5p to 618.5p respectively.

In sharp contrast to the rest of the media sector, which had a thoroughly miserable day with big declines for WPP, down 57p to 910p and EMI, 30p lower at 550p, news and information group Reuters moved higher. Its shares rose 12p to £13.56 lifted by a report from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, which claimed that trading remains strong.

Lower down the corporate scale, Recognition Systems, the credit card fraud group, moved 18.5p higher to 410p. The buying came ahead of a dinner organised by broker Investec Henderson Crosthwaite at Claridge's last night. Apparently 12 heavyweight institutions were invited to the hear background on the company's investment propositions .

Brunel Holdings gave back some of its recent gains, losing 1.25p, or 27.78%, to 3.25p.

webTitle: Brown runs into a barrage of criticism from unions

fields.headline: Brown runs into a barrage of criticism from unions
fields.trailText: Union leaders yesterday lashed out at Gordon Brown for failing to act over "the disaster" overtaking British manufacturing and what one called "idiotic ideas" about working harder and "half-baked lectures about effort."
fields.body:
Union leaders yesterday lashed out at Gordon Brown for failing to act over "the disaster" overtaking British manufacturing and what one called "idiotic ideas" about working harder and "half-baked lectures about effort."

As the Chancellor sat on the TUC conference podium GMB general union leader John Edmonds hit back at yesterday's report of Mr Browns call for a national productivity drive and told him: "Gordon, you just have to do something about the monetary policy committee" of the Bank of England.

The committees decision about interest rates lay behind the high pound's impact on manufacturing jobs, he declared: "It should spend less time fretting about inflation and more time responding to the needs of producers and ex porters".

"Why cannot we have at least one member who works in manufacturing industry, or knows about manufacturing industry, or at least lives in a town that understands the importance of manufacturing industry." He asked, demanding treasury action to reduce the value of sterling.

Before Mr Brown rose to address the congress, Mr Edmonds said he had read in the papers - a clear reference to the chancellor's trailed productivity appeal - that one solution to the manufacturing crisis was that British workers should work harder.

The union leader said that whoever thought up "these idiotic ideas" should go and see women workers operating sewing machines on piece rate, who were desperate to increase their productivity but instead face the sack.

He was echoed by Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary Amalgamated Engineering & Electrical Union, who told Mr Brown that the over-valued pound was "pricing British manufacturing out of the market, wiping out productivity gains overnight and prevent the investment needed to compete in the Global Economy."

The Chancellor, who used his speech to insist that there would be no "short-term lurches" in tax policy in response to current protests, was at pain to defuse union criticism by emphasising that he understood their concerns about the exchange rate and manufacturing and by down playing his trailed demands for wage restraint.

"We will continue to do more to support manufacturing." He pledged, wooing his audience with the prize of "full employment sustained for a generation," built on growth and pro ductivity.

He appealed to unions and employers to work together with government to close the productivity gap with Britain's competitors, arguing that this was the foundation on which the country could "achieve full employment, abolish child and pensioner poverty, build world class public services in education and health."

But there could be "no short -term lurches in spending policy or tax policy, no irresponsible spending increases or inflationary pay rises that put youth jobs at risk, no quick fixes or soft options, that would put long-term stability, public services and our policy for full employment at risk."

Mr Brown used his first speech as chancellor to the TUC to praise the traditions and achievements of the labour movement, hailing the trade union pioneers as "idealists not dreamers" who "knew it is easier to take your own share that fight for everyone to have a fair share".

But his reiteration of plans for an increase in the minimum wage and promise the ensure that pensioners gained more from Britain's rising prosperity left TUC delegates demanding more details.

Union leaders were far less critical after they had heard the chancellor, but never the less wanted to know more. Rodney Bickerstaffe, leader of the public service union Unison, said he would have like to have heard more about what the chancellor planned to do about public sector pay and union concerns about the creeping privatisation of public services and need to restore the pension-earning link.

Mr Edmunds said he hoped Mr Brown remarks about training opened the way for legally binding obligations on employers to invest in skills, but ruled out the chancellors suggestion that unions might move away from annual pay bargaining to promote economic stability.

fields.headline: 45 minutes to avoid
fields.trailText: After Monday's bout of volatile trading, when a botched "sell" program sent the FTSE 100 reeling and resulted in 23 blue chip stocks being temporarily suspended, dealers are warning of further turbulence ahead.
fields.body:
After Monday's bout of volatile trading, when a botched "sell" program sent the FTSE 100 reeling and resulted in 23 blue chip stocks being temporarily suspended, dealers are warning of further turbulence ahead.

Friday sees a "Double Witching," the quarterly occurrence that marks the settlement prices for the latest FTSE 100 index future and FTSE 100 index option series.

Typically the Double Witching period, which runs from 10am to 10.45am, is characterised by high levels of trading activity and unpredictable price movements as the City's largest players try to realign their futures and options positions with those in the underlying cash market.

"Our advice to clients is that if your order is not time critical then hold off until the market has stabilised," said Richard Hunter, head of dealing services at NatWest Stockbrokers.

webTitle: Roman grave believed to be female gladiator's

fields.headline: Roman grave believed to be female gladiator's
fields.trailText: Archaeologists believe they have found a burial unique in Roman Europe - a woman gladiator who fought in the Roman amphitheatre in London.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Archaeologists believe they have found a burial unique in Roman Europe - a woman gladiator who fought in the Roman amphitheatre in London.

Since the excavation four years ago in Southwark, archaeologists and scientists have been studying and arguing over the cremated bones and the extraordinary grave goods, including a funeral feast of luxurious imports and tiny pottery oil lamps showing a fallen gladiator and the Egyptian god Anubis, who is associated with the cult of the dead.

"We now believe that this is something quite remarkable, the only known grave of a woman gladiator," Simon Thurley, director of the Museum of London, said yesterday. "You can argue with our interpretation. You cannot argue with the fact that this was an extraordinary burial, of an individual - a woman, as we know from the bones - who was regarded as quite exceptional."

It was impossible to tell how she died, but the life of a gladiator tended to be brutally short. At the big games there were heaps of corpses, as shown on a Samian bowl found in the foundations of the London amphitheatre, though an exceptionally skilful, brave or graceful fighter might be spared, by a thumbs up symbol from the crowd, and freed.

The woman's grave held scraps of the funeral feast: fragments of dates, figs, the bones of four chickens and a dove. Pine cones, then an exotic import from the Mediterranean, were burned as incense.

There were eight ceramic incense burners, made in St Albans, and eight lamps imported from Gaul. One shows a fallen gladiator, and three show Anubis, associated with the Roman god Mercury. The bodies of gladiators slaughtered in the ring were dragged away by slaves dressed as Mercury.

The grave was found outside the walled Roman cemetery in Southwark, suggesting that the dead person, though highly honoured, was in some way an outsider.

"Gladiators had a special place in Roman society; it was not just about blood lust," Dr Thurley said. "The blood of a gladiator was believed to have healing or aphrodisiac powers, and the spear with which a gladiator was killed, if a man parted his wife's hair with it on the night before their marriage, would bring a marriage of extraordinary luck and fecundity."

The body was burned on a wooden platform with the grave goods heaped around it, and then collapsed into the pit. Such Roman burials are unusual and associated with eastern Europe, which also provided many of the gladiators, who often fought in travelling troupes.

Women gladiators are known to have fought, usually costumed as Amazons. An inscription from Pompeii boasts that a games organiser was the the first to bring women into the arena of the town destroyed by the eruption of Vesuvius in AD79.

The practice was condemned by some Roman writers and was regarded as inflaming audiences even beyond the usual ferocity of the games. It was outlawed by the emperor Septimius Severus in AD200 but probably continued illicitly.

 On Saturday a re-creation of a gladiatorial combat, including women fighting with swords but without the spilled blood, will be held in Guildhall Yard, on the site of the amphitheatre.

fields.headline: No: 1719
fields.standfirst: Nemir Kirdar
fields.trailText: Nemir Kirdar
fields.body:
Age:
63.

Appearance:
Stratospherically wealthy Middle Eastern investment banker.

Status:
Stratospherically wealthy Middle Eastern investment banker. So, no surprises there.

How he spends the cash:
The usual stuff - luxury homes, an office in Mayfair, art collecting, children's charities, the provision of free housing to cash-strapped royalty, that sort of thing.

Run that last one by me again.
Last weekend, the generous Mr Kirdar gave the run of his idyllic Cap d'Antibes villa, Serenada, to a certain Mr Windsor and Ms Parker-Bowles.

But I thought the shipping tycoon John Latsis held the ancient sinecure of Purveyor of Holidays to his Freeloading Highness.
Not any more he doesn't. The Greek multimillionaire fell from favour after certain accusations were made about his background.

What kind of allegations?
You'll have to ask his lawyers. Anyway, Mr Kirdar's background is far less problematic.

Where's he from?
Iraq, where his radical student politics fell foul of Saddam Hussein's Ba'ath party. Threatened with the firing squad, he was forced to flee - which he did by means of a carpet.

They really do have flying carpets in the mysterious east?
It was your standard household carpet, actually, loaded on to the back of a truck. Kirdar was rolled up inside as it drove across the border.

So where does all the money come from?
Kirdar went to university in California and New York, landed a job at Chase Manhattan, then raised $50m to start his own bank, Investcorp, in 1982. It went on to buy large chunks of top-flight businesses such as Gucci, Tiffany the jewellers' and, erm, Welcome Break service stations.

A friend says:
"Nemir would pay all the money in the world to be surrounded by the right persons."

Least likely to say:
"If you want a couple of free nights in a Travelodge at one of my service stations, your highness, I'd be happy to see what I can do."

webTitle: 'Use child sleuths' to trap shops selling cigarettes to under-16s

fields.headline: 'Use child sleuths' to trap shops selling cigarettes to under-16s
fields.trailText: Local authorities are to be urged by the government to use children, working under cover, to trap newsagents and shopkeepers who sell cigarettes to those under 16, and provide evidence which can be used in court.
fields.body:
Local authorities are to be urged by the government to use children, working under cover, to trap newsagents and shopkeepers who sell cigarettes to those under 16, and provide evidence which can be used in court.

The strategy is part of a government crackdown on under-age smoking. Ministers want trading standards officers to come down hard on retailers selling cigarettes to children. Today, the Department of Health, and the Department of Trade and Industry, launched a code - the tobacco enforcement protocol - outlining approaches proven to work.

Child sleuths are already used in some areas. In Kingston, Surrey, a girl aged 13 helped trading standards officers establish the extent of the problem in 1990 when 45% of local shopkeepers were found to be willing to sell her cigarettes. A series of high-profile prosecutions since then has reduced the number selling to children; by 1995, only 10% were agreeing to sell tobacco to the child volunteers.

Although the use of children for entrapment purposes is controversial, ministers have accepted that it may be the only way to gather proof that will stand up in court. Yvette Cooper, minister for public health, said: "Any action that can be taken to stop harmful tobacco products falling in to the hands of children will reduce the chances of [their] becoming smokers."

Kim Howells, DTI minister for consumer protection, said: "Local trading standards officers will now be able to use these guidelines to come down hard on retailers who are breaking the law."

The government wants to cut the number of child smokers, which has risen from 8% of 11- to 15-year-olds in 1988, to about 11% in 1998. Girls in this age group are most likely to smoke; nearly one in three were smoking regularly two years ago.The government has pledged, by 2010, to cut smoking among children from 13% to 9% or less.

The code has been agreed with the local authorities' co-ordinating body on food and trading standards, and the Local Government Association, and says retailers should be urged to adopt a "no proof, no sale" policy. There are a number of safeguards. The children used must not be given inducements, they must operate in an area where they are not known, and they must be followed the entire time.

Ted Forsyth, head of trading standards in Kingston, said: "We have to be sure that the child is happy and not doing it just because of a pushy parent. We ensure they are instructed always to tell the truth and they are not allowed to wear makeup or jewellery or dress to look older."

In Kingston, children are also used to check whether retailers are selling other goods to under-age children, such as butane lighter fuel, a solvent that can kill.

fields.headline: 'Robocop' faces disciplinary charges
fields.trailText: The suspended Detective Superintendent Ray "Robocop" Mallon is to face 14 disciplinary charges arising from the three-year-long corruption inquiry, Operation Lancet, which cleared him of criminal allegations this year.
fields.body:
The suspended Detective Superintendent Ray "Robocop" Mallon is to face 14 disciplinary charges arising from the three-year-long corruption inquiry, Operation Lancet, which cleared him of criminal allegations this year.

Mr Mallon, 45, is expected to be given details of conclusions reached by the police complaints authority before the end of the week, but he dismissed the issues involved yesterday as minor and a waste of public money.

Cleveland police confirmed that charges were expected to be put to the former head of crime prevention in Middlesbrough "within the next few days."

The allegations are understood to arise from Lancet's investigation into claims that Mr Mallon's zero tolerance policy on Teesside involved drugs-for-information deals and other malpractices. Although he was cleared of criminal charges, he was later accused of leaking information.

He said yesterday: "The charges have been magnified by my accusers to suit their own ends in an attempt to justify to the public this lengthy and costly investigation.

"People will ... see the charges for what they are - an attempt by my accusers to justify their decisions and the spending of £5m of public money."

Mr Mallon has been suspended on full pay from the Cleveland force since December 1997, not very long after his views on hardline policing were sought by the then opposition leader, Tony Blair, as well as the Conservative home secretary, Michael Howard.

A separate inquiry was launched last month into counter-claims that the Cleveland force's chief constable, Barry Shaw, had leaked material damaging to Mr Mallon.

Ashok Kumar, MP for Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland, said: "It has taken the PCA three months to make these charges. Obviously they have been scraping the barrel."

webTitle: Seven dead as record rainfall devastates central Japan

fields.headline: Seven dead as record rainfall devastates central Japan
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Seven people were killed and 360,000 advised to evacuate yesterday as central Japan was lashed with the heaviest downpour the country has seen in more than 100 years.
fields.body:
Seven people were killed and 360,000 advised to evacuate yesterday as central Japan was lashed with the heaviest downpour the country has seen in more than 100 years.

At its peak, the storm, which came in the vanguard of typhoon Saomai, dumped 97mm (3.8in) of rain on Nagoya, Japan's fourth biggest city, in the space of an hour.

A third of the city's average annual rainfall fell in just 24 hours.

The meteorological agency said it was the most torrential downpour since records began in Japan.

Streets were turned into rivers, houses were buried by landslides and factories and stations were forced to close.

The prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, set up an emergency headquarters in his official residence and ordered thousands of troops to help the 12,000 families whose homes were flooded.

"We must do everything in our power to help those affected," he told reporters.

News broadcasts showed stranded residents escaping from the floodwaters in boats.

"This is unbelievable. I never dreamed I would ever be leaving my home in a dinghy," a woman said on television.

To some the help came too late. An elderly couple were killed in Komaki, just outside of Nagoya, when a mudslide engulfed their house.

A young girl died after falling into an open drain, and a firefighter trying to help rescue her was swept to his death by flood water. Dozens were injured and at least one person is missing.

Japan's famously punctual transport systems were severely disrupted. About 50,000 commuters spent an uncomfortable night shut into railway carriages when power was cut on the bullet train line from Tokyo to Osaka, stopping the service for a record 18 hours. More than 100 flights were cancelled, inconveniencing 85,000 passengers.

The economic cost is still to be counted, but is likely to run into many millions of pounds, since the area around Nagoya is one of Japan's industrial heartlands.

Toyota, which has its headquarters in the region, had to shut down 11 factories, delaying the production of 10,000 vehicles. Mitsubishi Motors also closed one of its plants.

The centre of typhoon Saomai battered Okinawa, the southernmost main island in the Japanese archipelago, yesterday with winds of 55mph.

It is forecast to dump more rain on large swaths of the country today.

webTitle: Hotel owner charged with murder of backpacker

fields.headline: Hotel owner charged with murder of backpacker
fields.trailText: Thai police yesterday charged a British man for raping and conspiring to murder Kirsty Jones, the Welsh backpacker found strangled last month at a guesthouse in Chiang Mai.
fields.body:
Thai police yesterday charged a British man for raping and conspiring to murder Kirsty Jones, the Welsh backpacker found strangled last month at a guesthouse in Chiang Mai.

Aram Chanphen, a police commander of the northern Thailand region, said that Andrew Gill, 32, co-owner of the Aree guesthouse, was arrested on the basis of scientific tests and witness accounts. "We are confident we are on the right track," he said. "There is no mystery any more."

Ms Jones, 23, from Brecon in Powys, was killed at the guesthouse after a violent struggle on the evening of August 9.

For overstaying his visa, Mr Gill was already in police custody in the city, 400 miles north of Bangkok. Friends who saw him yesterday, said Mr Gill vehemently denied the charges, which carry the death penalty. One man said he shouted: "Not guilty!" as he was led from the cell he shares with more than half-a-dozen other detainees.

General Chanphen said the police were still looking for an accomplice but did not name the suspect. Local media have reported that the other person involved is Surin Channetr, 47, the guesthouse manager.

The arrest comes as a surprise since Mr Gill was cleared of involvement in the murder along with eight other foreigners and four locals when their DNA and hair samples did not match those found at the crime scene, Ms Jones' room in the £1-a-night hotel.

Ms Jones was found face down with a T-shirt knotted around her neck. Guests in neighbouring rooms said they heard shouting and a struggle the previous evening but dismissed the commotion as a lovers' tiff. Staff became suspicious the next morning when they found the room locked with a padlock on the outside.

Mr Gill, who comes from south London, first attracted police attention when he disappeared the day the body was found. Witnesses said he was the last person seen with Ms Jones before she died. However, he later insisted he only ran away because he panicked about his visa. He was later fined 2,000 baht (£36) for the offence and has been in custody since then.

A British embassy spokesman said consular officials would visit Mr Gill today to ensure he had legal representation. The first court appearance may be within 48 hours.

Mr Gill's friend added: "This is unbelievable. There is no way Andy did this. This whole investigation has been a joke... I know Andy well, and he is just not capable [of doing it]."

The Thai police have been criticised for being disorganised. The senior investigating detective was sacked after a fortnight for failing to solve the case.

fields.headline: US death penalty bias
fields.standfirst: Of federal calls for execution, 75% are against minorities
fields.trailText: The US justice department has confirmed what critics of capital punishment have claimed for years - that the chance of the death penalty being imposed depends largely on the defendant's skin colour and on where the trial is held.
fields.body:
The US justice department has confirmed what critics of capital punishment have claimed for years - that the chance of the death penalty being imposed depends largely on the defendant's skin colour and on where the trial is held.

According to leaks published in the New York Times yesterday, a survey ordered by the attorney general, Janet Reno, found that in 75% of the cases in which a federal prosecutor had sought the death penalty in the past five years, the defendant was from a minority. Black defendants accounted for more than half the death penalty cases.

About 40% of the death penalty submissions came from federal prosecutors in only five places - Puerto Rico, eastern Virginia, Maryland, and eastern and southern districts of New York. By contrast, Alaska submitted no death penalty cases in the five-year period, despite the fact that it has a relatively high homicide rate.

The justice department review was launched over a month ago, when the first federal prisoner to face the death penalty in 37 years, Juan Raul Garza, was due to be executed. Mr Garza's execution date was put back to December 12, but his lawyers are seeking clemency in a court case this week.

Most executions in the US are carried out by the fiercely independent state judicial systems, but the federal courts also have the theoretical right to impose the death penalty for a certain list of crimes, including large-scale drug trafficking, drive-by murders, carjacking and the destruction of a plane, train or motor vehicle resulting in death.

David Brock, a member of the Federal Death Penalty Counsel Project, a pressure group opposed to capital punishment, said the justice department report came as no surprise.

"This is what we've been observing for a long time," he said. "There's enough reason to believe the system is biased that no one should be executed under it."

Ms Reno was expected to order further studies on the administration of the death penalty this week, and the gathering uncertainty within the justice department is likely to add momentum to calls for a moratorium on the federal death penalty.

Illinois announced its own moratorium earlier this year, but other states, like Texas, Virginia and Florida, are fiercely attached to capital punishment and have fought off attempts to review their judicial systems.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Bookseller Amazon.co.uk says it has broken through the 2m customer mark, with 125,000 new customers using the service each month. Research company MMXI says that Amazon is significantly ahead of its nearest rivals with 1.3m unique visitors per month. The closest competitor is BOL.com with 238,000.
fields.body:
Bookseller Amazon.co.uk says it has broken through the 2m customer mark, with 125,000 new customers using the service each month. Research company MMXI says that Amazon is significantly ahead of its nearest rivals with 1.3m unique visitors per month. The closest competitor is BOL.com with 238,000.

Operating profit at Retail Decisions, the card fraud prevention company, fell to £300,000 in the six months to June 30 from £1.3m in the same period the year before, but turnover climbed 23% to £7.2m. Retail Decisions split from Card Clear - now Universe Group- in January to develop its online strategy. Its software helps detect payment card fraud by monitoring spending patterns and checking the velocity and value of transactions.

 Billion biller Media buying and market research group Aegis said that new billings for the first half of the year topped $1bn for the first time. The group, which owns the Carat media planning and buying business, reported a 19% increase in pre-tax profits to £34.7m on a 64% rise in revenues to £212.4m.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Plot to kill Putin
fields.body:
Plot to kill Putin

The Ukrainian and Russian security services claimed yesterday that Chechen assassins planned to kill President Vladimir Putin during the Kursk submarine crisis last month.

Leonid Derkach, the head of Ukraine's security service, said four Chechens were detained in the run-up to a summit of leaders of former Soviet countries (CIS) in the Crimea in mid-August. They were "suspected of preparing an attempt on the life of Vladimir Putin and deported from Ukraine," he said.
Ian Traynor, Moscow

Harare bombs

A hand grenade attack on the headquarters of Zimbabwe's opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, damaged the building and two vehicles in central Harare.

Police arrived late at the scene of the blast on Monday night, and left soon after, prompting MDC secretary-general Welshman Ncube to criticise them for not launching a serious investigation. "This is obviously part of the terror campaign being waged by the state against any opposition to the ruling party, Zanu-PF," he said.
Andrew Meldrum, Harare


Mauritius poll

The prime minister of Mauritius, Navin Ramgoolam, yesterday conceded defeat in the Indian Ocean island's general election.

"I recognise my party's defeat," Mr Ramgoolam said as tallies showed a virtual landslide defeat of his alliance by a coalition of the Socialist Militant Party and the Militant Party.
Reuters, Port Louis


Holy waters

A Spanish priest yesterday led a bible reading in an underwater cave off Benitachell in south-eastern Spain, as part of the Catholic Church in Valencia's attempt at non-stop bible readings throughout 2000.
Reuters, Benitachell

webTitle: Pakistan's clerics balk at school reforms

fields.headline: Pakistan's clerics balk at school reforms
fields.standfirst: Religious right says US is behind moves to modernise suspected academies of holy war
fields.trailText: In the oppressive heat of Pakistan's North West Frontier hundreds of young boys huddle together on the floor around a handful of electric fans, rocking backwards and forwards as they memorise verses from the Koran.
fields.body:
In the oppressive heat of Pakistan's North West Frontier hundreds of young boys huddle together on the floor around a handful of electric fans, rocking backwards and forwards as they memorise verses from the Koran.

This is a normal school day for these children just as it was for their fathers and their fathers' fathers for centuries before. Many of those former pupils went on to fight with the mojahedin against the Soviet forces in Afghanistan and are now fighting against Indian rule in Kashmir. Others are among the top leaders of Afghanistan's repressive Taliban militia.

Pakistan's military regime, under pressure from the west to curb terror groups, wants to modernise teaching in these Islamic schools. But the military is risking a confrontation with the increasingly influential religious right.

"The government can do nothing," said Sami-ul Haq, the hardline cleric who runs this madrassah, the Darul Uloom Haqqani, one of the leading Islamic seminaries in Asia.

"The United States wants to be the supreme power in the world and it knows that these madrassahs are the hurdles in its way so they put pressure on the government," said Mr Haq.

"But the madrassah is not just the building. If a teacher stands under the shade of a tree with his students that is a madrassah . If the United States closes down one madrassah we will build thousands more under every tree."

Mr Haq stroked his long, hennaed beard and reflected proudly on some of his star students now leading the Afghan Taliban. They include the interior minister, Khairula Khairkhwa, and the head of the feared religious police, Qalam Uddin.

After 53 years of military rule and corrupt democracy Pakistan was now ready to become an Islamic state like neighbouring Afghanistan, he said.

Few Pakistanis, however, voted for the religious parties when they had the chance. The clerics' power has always lain in the fear that they might bring students from the thousands of madrassahs out on to the streets.

It was the religious leaders' opposition that forced Pakistan's leader, General Pervez Musharraf, to back down this year on his proposal to make a slight procedural change to the country's blasphemy law. The law is often misused to target religious minorities, particularly Christians.

Then the religious parties backed shopkeepers in their opposition to a new income survey and the introduction of a new sales tax. Clerics want the weekly holiday switched back from Sunday to Friday.

Now the government has provoked their anger again by trying to survey the madrassahs and introduce new classes, like science and computing.

"Our main objective is that the ulema (clerics) should join the mainstream and make some positive contribution to society," said Mehmood Amed Ghazi, the member of Gen Musharraf's national security council who is in charge of the madrassah issue.

Gen Musharraf has met several religious leaders in the past month, including Mr Haq. He is reportedly planning to bring some of them, along with some former politicians, into his government as advisers.

Mr Haq is at pains to point out that his madrassah is no threat. It has no weapons and no military training. "You see, there is no terrorism in the madrassahs ," he said. But the thoughts of war in Kashmir and Afghanistan are not far from the minds of his young students.

"There is a vast difference between an Islamic war, which is a jihad, and terrorism," said Arshad Yusuf, a 24-year-old in his sixth year at the Haqqani school.

"Jihad is to fight for a very great cause, like Kashmir. If there are people who restrict the Muslims, then the Muslims are allowed to fight them. People in the west should understand the spirit of Islam."

Few Pakistanis, however, voted for the religious parties when they had the chance. The clerics' power has always lain in the fear that they might bring students from the thousands of madrassahs out on to the streets. It was the religious leaders' opposition that forced Pakistan's leader, General Pervez Musharraf, to back down this year on his proposal to make a slight procedural change to the country's blasphemy law. The law is often misused to target religious minorities, particularly Christians. Then the religious parties backed shopkeepers in their opposition to a new income survey and the introduction of a new sales tax. Clerics want the weekly holiday switched back from Sunday to Friday. Now the government has provoked their anger again by trying to survey the madrassahs and introduce new classes, like science and computing. "Our main objective is that the ulema (clerics) should join the mainstream and make some positive contribution to society," said Mehmood Amed Ghazi, the member of Gen Musharraf's national security council who is in charge of the madrassah issue. Gen Musharraf has met several religious leaders in the past month, including Mr Haq. He is reportedly planning to bring some of them, along with some former politicians, into his government as advisers. Mr Haq is at pains to point out that his madrassah is no threat. It has no weapons and no military training. "You see, there is no terrorism in the madrassahs ," he said. But the thoughts of war in Kashmir and Afghanistan are not far from the minds of his young students. "There is a vast difference between an Islamic war, which is a jihad, and terrorism," said Arshad Yusuf, a 24-year-old in his sixth year at the Haqqani school. "Jihad is to fight for a very great cause, like Kashmir. If there are people who restrict the Muslims, then the Muslims are allowed to fight them. People in the west should understand the spirit of Islam."

webTitle: The Tigers' young recruit tells of being forced into war

fields.headline: The Tigers' young recruit tells of being forced into war
fields.standfirst: Sri Lankan army puts 13-year-old captive on show to the press
fields.trailText: Renuka hobbles with the aid of a walking stick, accompanied by two women soldiers. An army intelligence officer says the girl was injured by a hand grenade while firing a rifle at a patrol. She looks drugged and ill, and answers questions only when her captors nod their approval.
fields.body:
Renuka hobbles with the aid of a walking stick, accompanied by two women soldiers. An army intelligence officer says the girl was injured by a hand grenade while firing a rifle at a patrol. She looks drugged and ill, and answers questions only when her captors nod their approval.

She is 13. The Tamil Tigers have pressganged children as young as eight for their latest offensive in the northern peninsula of Sri Lanka. The government in turn is parading her before the few foreign journalists to visit the area.

Renuka says that she and scores of other girls joined the Tigers because they were warned of dire consequences if they refused.

"I personally met [the Tigers' leader] Velupillai Prabakaran," she says. "He told us that the only way we could obtain true freedom was by joining the struggle for an independent state for Sri Lankan Tamils called Eelam."

She says she was given a few weeks' military training in which she was taught to throw grenades and fire a rifle. Almost immediately afterwards she was caught up in heavy fighting.

Hundreds on both sides have died this month as the army has tried to push the Tigers away from Jaffna town, which is in government hands.

Renuka's evidence against the Tigers will make it imposs ible for her to return home without fear of retribution.

"She is considered to have betrayed the cause," the intelligence officer says, "especially because she did not take the cyanide capsule, which is mandatory for all rebels after they are captured."

Renuka is being held in solitary confinement in a dark and dirty cell in an army camp. The military authorities have the power to hold her for several months without trial. Then she is likely to be sent to a rehabilitation centre to join other orphaned or neglected Tamil children.

In recent days the armed forces have has been shelling and bombing Tiger positions for up to 48 hours at a time. MiG fighters and helicopter gunships flying low over Jaffna town fire missiles in deafening salvoes at all times of day and night.

Daya Somaundaram, one of the few child psychiatrists on the peninsula, says this has traumatised the children of the town, who are showing severe psychological scars.

"It's not at all uncommon for children here to wake up screaming, become more reclusive or start bedwetting," she says.

"It's an understandable reaction to the ceaseless sound of bombs, and we have to remember that it's likely to be even worse for children in areas controlled by the Tigers, who are on the receiving end of most of the bombardments."

The army realises that its offensive is damaging young lives, but remains unrepentant. General Anton Wijendra, commanding officer of government forces on the peninsula, says: "It's a price we have to pay to rid this island of the scourge of terrorism."

Children suffer in other respects, too. Aid agencies say that about 110,000 people in the peninsula are displaced because of the war.

About 10,000 of them live in camps, where insanitary conditions and malnutrition are becoming more and more commonplace.

Médecins sans Frontières concluded recently that about 20% of the displaced people on the peninsula were suffering from acute malnutrition.

About 80% of Jaffna's predominantly Tamil population is on rations, and only the most basic food items are available in the shops.

Evidence of the general election campaign, currently gripping the capital Colombo, is hard to find.

"People on the streets," says the Bishop of Jaffna, Thomas Savundaranayagam, "say that they're worried about more important things, such as ensuring their families survive the war.

"They want to secure enough food for their families and ensure that the education of their children is interrupted as little as possible."

Only about 20% of the people in Jaffna have a stable income, and often it is insufficient to cover the rising cost of living.

"The Jaffna peninsula is the largest open prison in the world," an aid worker says, "because it's only accessible from government-controlled areas by air and sea, and it can take months for local people to get permission to leave."

fields.headline: Sir John Beith
fields.trailText: Few postwar British diplomats had a greater gift for making friends in the countries to which they were accredited, or for solving knotty problems over a drink or meal, than Sir John Beith, who has died aged 86.
fields.body:
Few postwar British diplomats had a greater gift for making friends in the countries to which they were accredited, or for solving knotty problems over a drink or meal, than Sir John Beith, who has died aged 86. Foreigners rightly considered him a man of utmost probity, who saw both sides of a question and with whom it was a pleasure to do business.

The son of Australian parents, Beith was brought up in England and, after Eton and King's College, Cambridge, joined the Foreign Office in 1937. Posted to Athens in 1940, he and the rest of the embassy staff were evacuated a year later under German air attack, not without loss. At the end of the second world war, he returned to Whitehall from a posting in Argentina, and, in 1949, married Diana, the daughter of Sir John Gilmour.

There followed three posts in Europe, as head of the British delegation to the United Nations in Geneva, and head of chancery in Prague and Paris. Back in London, Beith served as headed the Levant department, and then of African and Near East department. After this, his appointment as ambassador to Tel Aviv, from 1963-65, was perhaps inevitable, though it was not the cleverest of postings.

He then did a spell as assistant secretary-general at Nato, before being promoted to assistant under-secretary at the Foreign Office in London. His failure to achieve a break-through as leader of the British delegation in the Anglo-Spanish talks on Gibraltar was not held against him.

In 1969, Beith - by then Sir John - became ambassador to the King of the Belgians. Here, he and Diana were in their element. Backed by the splendid 18th-century embassy in Rue Ducale, they set out to make it the best address in town. Diana, who had spent some of her youth at Blenheim, knew how to manage large parties, and their dinners were legendary. The Beiths were soon on terms of real friendship with influential Belgians of all political shades. The significance of this for successful diplomacy does not need to be underlined; bilateral relations with Belgium were never in better hands.

In 1974, Sir John and Lady Beith retired to a Queen Anne farmhouse near Winchester, where Diana could garden and John play the piano and follow the racing he had always loved. He was a first-class shot.

She survived him, as do a son and daughter (one daughter died in infancy) and Diana's two children from her first marriage. Beith's marriage provided him with the family circle he had previously lacked, and with a wife who was as interested in the career as he was.

 John Greville Stanley Beith, diplomat, born April 4 1914; died September 4 2000

fields.headline: Tony Hollaway
fields.trailText: In 1963 the stained glass designer and craftsman Tony Holloway, who has died aged 72, was introduced to the Manchester architect, Harry Fairhurst. Eight years later, after they had worked together on commissions in Cheshire and Liverpool, Fairhurst sought Tony's advice about a plan for five large stained-glass windows in Manchester Cathedral.
fields.body:
In 1963 the stained glass designer and craftsman Tony Holloway, who has died aged 72, was introduced to the Manchester architect, Harry Fairhurst. Eight years later, after they had worked together on commissions in Cheshire and Liverpool, Fairhurst sought Tony's advice about a plan for five large stained-glass windows in Manchester Cathedral.

Thus was Tony asked to design and make the first window, the St George in the inner south-west aisle. It was completed in 1973. Further windows followed in 1976 and 1980 and the final window, Revelation was installed in 1995.

This series is a remarkable, sustained achievement. Their world of colour and form goes beyond abstraction to describe, in some purely ineffable way, the spiritual life.

But alongside his stained glass work Tony practised as a painter, a muralist and an inspirational art teacher. We first met as students at the Royal College of Art in 1954, and remained good friends for more than 40 years. He arrived in the stained glass department at a time when it attracted enterprising spirits who saw an opportunity to re-invigorate and do something contemporary with the neglected and under-exploited medium of glass.

The climate of the times was with us, and on leaving the RCA in 1957, Tony began work as a stained glass and mural designer and jumped, with astonishing confidence, into working as a consultant designer with the architects' division of the London County Council. He learned how to deal with architects and builders, and became adept at getting as much out of the money available - never enough - for his projects. He remained linked with what became the Greater London Council's architects department until its closure in 1968.

Offers of teaching eventually tempted him into art education. He taught both part time and full time, starting with one day a week at the Central School and finally, full time, as head of the three-dimensional design department at Trent Polytechnic. His lectures on architectural decoration to students and fellow professionals were famous. Only Tony could be evangelistically serious one minute, and then outrageously funny - about "getting a bit of art into public buildings" - the next.

Dorset was where he was born and grew up and the Dorset landscape was always there deep within him. He was educated at Poole grammar school between 1939 and 1945. After national service in the Royal Air Force in Dorset and Germany from 1948 to 1953 he studied at Bournemouth College of Art. Then came the RCA.

Tony was two kinds of artist - determinedly "modern" in his murals and stained glass, and much more conventional as a landscape painter. This aspect of his work he never pushed. I suspected that he needed to do something completely personal - and without having to please anybody else but himself. His painting allowed his natural good draughtsmanship its head. And this, allied to a strong compositional sense and a tonal attachment to colour, produced perhaps some of his most individual work. A reappraisal is due - and even during his last illness, he was planning another bout of painting.

Tony was awarded an honorary doctorate by De Montfort University, Leicester, in 1999 - and he had made stained glass for the university's Trinity Building.

He leaves behind his partner, Cilla Chapman, his daughter Amy, and his two sons, Nick and Bruce.

 Antony Holloway, artist, born March 8 1928; died August 9 2000

fields.headline: Sir John Astor
fields.trailText: Sir John "Jakie" Astor, who has died aged 82 after a long battle against Parkinson's disease, won distinction in his second and third careers after being vilified in his first. He won his 1978 knighthood for contributions to agriculture, partly from the success of his 1,900-acre farm at Hatley Park, Bedfordshire, but especially as chairman of the Agricultural Research Council.
fields.body:
Sir John "Jakie" Astor, who has died aged 82 after a long battle against Parkinson's disease, won distinction in his second and third careers after being vilified in his first. He won his 1978 knighthood for contributions to agriculture, partly from the success of his 1,900-acre farm at Hatley Park, Bedfordshire, but especially as chairman of the Agricultural Research Council.

He won even wider plaudits for his key roles in the racing world, as a successful breeder with three establishments at Newmarket and many winners. He was a steward of the Jockey Club, and a member of the Tote and the Horserace Betting Levy Board, widely recognised for his outspoken good sense.

Both these careers followed his rejection by the Conservative party for having been one of six Tory MPs who refused to support Sir Anthony Eden's 1956 invasion of Suez; like his older brother David, then editor of the Observer, he found it "unnecessary and wrong".

Astor immediately found himself ostracised by his party and vilified by the Tory press. He discovered that the Conservatives were "not a party but a regiment", and announced he would not stand for the "family seat" of Plymouth-Sutton, which had been first occupied in 1910 by his father, William Astor, and then by his mother, Nancy Astor, the first woman to sit in the Commons.

To be ostracised from any part of the establishment was a rare experience for an Astor. Although the first John Jacob Astor had been an 18th-century German migrant to the United States, he had made a fortune in the fur trade and invested it in Manhattan property - the basis of the Astor millions, even after his descendants transferred their affections to Britain, where they secured a barony and a viscountcy.

Jakie himself was born at Cliveden, the youngest of the four sons of the 2nd Viscount Astor. He followed his father to Eton and New College, Oxford, where he first displayed his enthusiasm for racing. When he came of age, he received his first £1m from his grandfather's will.

He joined the Life Guards, but soon transferred to the Phantom Regiment, and later to the SAS. Although the excitement of frontline service appealed, his skills with signals equipment gave him key supporting roles in the 1942 commando raid on Dieppe, as a signals officer on a supporting destroyer. He ended the war as a major, with a military MBE, a Legion d'Honneur and a Croix de Guerre.

On demobilisation, partly to please his mother, he agreed to fight her old Plymouth-Sutton seat. He failed by 924 votes in 1950 but succeeded by 710 in 1951, when the Conservatives returned to office. In the Commons, Jakie showed himself to be a liberal Tory, aligned with Peter Thorneycroft and RA Butler, and was one of the first MPs from his party to oppose capital punishment. He also sought to legalise gambling, and was an early pro-European.

He married three times, first in 1944 to the late "Chiquital" Carcano, daughter of the Argentine ambassador; they parted in 1972. In 1976 he married Susan Sheppard; they parted in 1995. Then, in 1988, he married Marcia de Savary, who survives him, together with a son and daughter from his first marriage.

 John Jacob Astor, farmer and horserace breeder, born August 29 1919; died September 10 2000
